1-5-1: REGULAR MEETINGS:
The regular meeting of the village board shall be held on the second and fourth
Wednesday of each month at the hour of seven thirty o'clock (7:30) P.M. in the
council room of the village hall. Any regular meeting falling upon a legal
holiday shall be held on the next following business day at the same hour and
place. No notice shall be required for regular meetings. (Ord. 1770, 11-9-2011,
eff. 12-1-2011)
1-5-2: SPECIAL MEETINGS:
Special meetings may be held at any time on call for the same by the president
or any three (3) or more trustees which call shall be in writing, duly signed
and presented to the clerk who shall proceed immediately to prepare notices of
the same and cause them to be served on the president and members of the board
of trustees in the usual manner at least twenty four (24) hours before the time
of the meeting. Such notices shall describe in brief the nature or objects of
the call.
At every special meeting the call therefor shall be read and then filed by the
clerk. No business other than that proposed by the call shall be in order at
such meeting. (Ord. 1, 5-10-1927)
1-5-3: ORDER OF BUSINESS:
The following order of business will be adhered to in all meetings of the board
unless suspended by the unanimous consent of members present.
At the hour selected for the meeting, the clerk or someone appointed to fill
his place, shall proceed to call the roll of members and mark the absentees.
Upon the appearance of a quorum, the board shall be called to order, the
president taking the chair, if present, but the board appointing a temporary
chairman if absent. If a quorum does not appear, the board shall not thereby
stand adjourned unless by a vote of the members present. When a quorum is
present, the board shall proceed to the business before it which shall be
conducted in the following order:
   (A)   Municipal commission and local organization attendance.
   (B)   Public comments.
   (C)   Consent agenda (pursuant to section 1-5-8 of this chapter).
   (D)   Trustee's business, which may include reports from standing
committees.
   (E)   President's business.
   (F)   Clerk's business and correspondence.
   (G)   Other business.
   (H)   Village administrator's business.
   (I)   Legal business.
   (J)   Village engineer's business.
   (K)   Department head's comments and/or business.
   (L)   Adjournment.
All questions relating to the priority of business shall be decided by the
chair without debate. (Ord. 1770, 11-9-2011, eff. 12-1-2011)
1-5-4: PRESIDENT; DUTIES:
The president shall sign all commissions and permits granted by the authority
of the board of trustees and grant or revoke all licenses, except as otherwise
provided by law, and perform such other acts as may be required by the
provisions of this code or other laws of the village.
He shall supervise the conduct of all officers of the village, examine the
grounds of all reasonable complaints made against any of them, and cause all
their violations of duty and other neglects to be properly punished or reported
to the proper tribunal for correction.
He shall appoint, by and with the consent of the board of trustees, all
officers whose appointment is not, by the laws of this state or the provisions
of this code, otherwise provided for. Whenever any vacancy shall occur in any
office, which by law he is empowered to fill, he shall, within thirty (30) days
after the occurrence of such vacancy, communicate to the board the name of his
appointee to such office. Pending the concurrence of the board of trustees in
such appointment the president may appoint some suitable person to discharge
the duties of such office. (Ord. 1, 5-10-1927)
1-5-5: PRESIDENT; VETO POWER:
The president shall have the right to veto all ordinances, resolutions and
orders passed by the board of trustees, but the trustees, by two-thirds (2/3)
vote of all the members elected, may pass the ordinances, resolutions or orders
over the veto of the president, with the exception of an ordinance repealing
subsection 1-5-20(A) of this chapter, which shall require a vote of five-sixths
(5/6) of all the members elected in order to override the veto of the
president. (Ord. 1832, 5-8-2013)
1-5-6: PRESERVATION OF ORDER:
The presiding officer shall preserve order and decorum and may speak to points
of order in preference to other members and shall decide all questions of
order.
While the presiding officer is putting the question, or while business is being
transacted, no member shall walk across or out of the village boardroom except
by consent of the board.
Every member, previous to his speaking, making a motion or seconding the same,
shall address himself to the presiding officer, but shall not proceed with his
remarks until recognized and named by the chair.
When two (2) or more members speak at approximately the same time, the
presiding officer shall name the member who is first to speak.
In case of any disturbance or disorderly conduct, the presiding officer shall
have the power to require the room to be cleared if necessary. (Ord. 1770, 11-
9-2011, eff. 12-1-2011)
1-5-7: BOARD OF TRUSTEES; DUTIES:
When a member wishes to present a communication, petition, order, resolution or
other original matter he shall rise in his place and briefly state its nature
before presenting the same.
No member without sanction of the board shall speak more than once upon the
same subject until every member desirous of speaking shall have spoken; and no
member shall speak longer than five (5) minutes at one time except by consent
of the board.
A member called to order by the chair shall immediately sit down, unless
permitted to explain. If there be no appeal, the decision of the chair shall be
conclusive, but if the member appeals from the decision of the chair, the board
shall decide on the case.
While a member is speaking, no member shall hold any private discourse.
Every member who shall be present when a question is stated from the chair
shall vote thereon unless excused by the board, or unless he is directly
interested in the question, in which case he shall not vote.
No member shall be allowed to leave the board while in session unless excused
by the presiding officer. (Ord. 1, 5-10-1927)
1-5-8: MOTIONS, ORDINANCES, ORDERS AND RESOLUTIONS:
   (A)   Consent Agenda: The corporate authorities may by unanimous consent
take a single vote by yeas and nays on the several questions of the passage of
any two (2) or more of the designated ordinances, orders, resolutions, or
motions placed together for voting purposes in a single group.
If one or more member(s) of the corporate authorities does not consent to take
a single vote on all of the several questions of the passage of any two (2) or
more of the designated ordinances, orders, resolutions, or motions placed
together for voting purposes in a single group, such item or items for which
placement on the consent agenda is not unanimous shall be voted upon as set
forth in subsection (B) of this section.
The single vote shall be entered separately in the minutes of the board under
the designation "consent agenda", and in that event the clerk may enter the
words "consent agenda" in the minutes of the board in each case instead of
entering the names of the members of the board voting yea and those voting nay
on the passage of each of the designated ordinances, orders, resolutions, and
motions included in the consent agenda.
The taking of a single or omnibus vote and the entries of the words "consent
agenda" in the minutes of the board shall have the same effect as if the vote
in each case had been taken separately by yeas and nays on the question of the
passage of each ordinance, order, resolution, and motion included in the
consent agenda and separately recorded in the minutes of the board.
   (B)   All Other Motions, Ordinances And/Or Resolutions: No motion shall be
put or debated unless it be seconded. When a motion is seconded, it shall be
stated by the presiding officer before debate and the proposer of the motion
shall be entitled to the floor.
After a motion regarding an ordinance, other motion or resolution is stated by
the presiding officer, it shall be deemed to be in possession of the board, but
may be withdrawn at any time before decision or amendment by unanimous consent
of the board.
In all cases where a resolution, ordinance or motion is entered on the minutes
of the board, the names of the trustees moving and seconding the same shall be
entered also.
The yeas and nays shall be taken upon the question of the passage of the
designated ordinances, resolutions, or motions and recorded on the minutes of
the board.
All ordinances, resolutions and amendments of rules or ordinances before being
presented shall be reduced to writing and delivered to the clerk. (Ord. 1770,
11-9-2011, eff. 12-1-2011)
1-5-9: TAKING OF VOTE:
If any member require it the yeas and nays shall be taken and entered on the
minutes, but the yeas and nays shall not be taken unless called for previous to
any vote on the question. (Ord. 1, 5-10-1927)
1-5-10: PRESENCE OF QUESTION:
When a blank is to be filled and different sums or times are proposed, the
question shall be taken first on the lesser sum or the longest time.
When a question is under debate the only motion or order shall be:
   (A)   To adjourn to a day certain.
   (B)   To adjourn.
   (C)   To lay on the table.
   (D)   The previous question.
   (E)   To refer.
   (F)   To amend.
   (G)   To substitute.
   (H)   To postpone indefinitely or to a day certain.
Subsections (B), (C) and (D) of this section are to be decided without debate.
(Ord. 1, 5-10-1927)
1-5-11: ADJOURNMENT:
A motion to adjourn the board shall always be in order, except:
   (A)   When a member is in possession of the floor.
   (B)   While the yeas and nays are being called.
   (C)   When the members are voting.
   (D)   When adjournment was the last preceding motion.
   (E)   When it has been decided that the previous question shall be taken.
A motion simply to adjourn cannot be amended, but a motion to adjourn to a time
named may be and is open to debate. (Ord. 1, 5-10-1927)
1-5-12: PREVIOUS QUESTION:
When the previous question is moved and seconded it shall be put in this form:
"Shall the main question now be put?". If this is carried, all further
amendments and all further motions and debates shall be excluded, and the
question put without delay, upon the pending amendments in proper order, and
then upon the main question. (Ord. 1, 5-10-1927)
1-5-13: LAY ON THE TABLE:
A motion to simply lay a question on the table is not debatable; but a motion
to lay on the table and publish, or any other condition, is subject to
amendment and debate.
A motion to take subject matter from the table may be proposed at the same
meeting; provided, two-thirds (2/3) of the trustees present vote therefor.
(Ord. 1, 5-10-1927)
1-5-14: INDEFINITE POSTPONEMENT; REFERENCE:
When a motion is postponed indefinitely it shall not be again taken up at the
same meeting. A motion to refer to a standing committee shall take precedence
of a similar motion for a special committee. (Ord. 1, 5-10-1927)
1-5-15: AMENDMENTS; SUBSTITUTIONS:
A motion to amend an amendment shall be in order, but one to amend an amendment
to an amendment shall not be entertained.
An amendment modifying the intention of a motion shall be in order, but an
amendment relating to a different subject shall not be in order.
On an amendment to "strike out and insert" the paragraph to be amended shall
first be read as it stands, then the words proposed to be stricken out and
those to be inserted and, finally, the paragraph as it will stand if so amended
shall be read.
A substitute for any original proposition in debate may be entertained when
further amendment is not admissible; but if accepted by the mover of such
original proposition, or by the board by vote, it shall entirely supersede the
original proposition and cut off all amendments appertaining thereto. (Ord. 1,
5-10-1927)
1-5-16: RECONSIDERATION:
A vote or question may be reconsidered at any time during the same meeting, or
at the first regular meeting held thereafter. A motion for reconsideration
being once made and decided in the negative, shall not be renewed, nor shall a
vote to reconsider be reconsidered.
No vote of the board of trustees shall be reconsidered or rescinded at a
special meeting unless at such special meeting there be present as large a
number of trustees as were present when such vote was taken.
A motion to reconsider must be made and seconded by members who voted in the
majority; provided, however, that where a motion is lost by reason of not
receiving a two-thirds (2/3) vote required for its passage, a motion to
reconsider may be made and seconded by those voting in the minority. (Ord. 1,
5-10-1927)
1-5-17: STANDING COMMITTEES:
All standing committees shall be appointed by the president at or before the
second regular meeting in each municipal year, or as soon thereafter as may be
practical, and whenever any vacancy shall occur. Special committees shall also
be appointed by the president, unless otherwise ordered by the board. (Ord. 1,
5-10-1927)
There shall be six (6) standing committees. Each committee shall consist of the
six (6) trustees and the president shall be ex officio a member of each
committee. The president shall appoint a chairman of each committee. The
committee shall be designated and cover the general area as hereinafter set
out:
   (A)   Administration And Finance: General office, treasurer, collector,
accounting budget, appropriation ordinance, tax levy, licenses, vehicle tags,
billing, internal audit, garbage and refuse, the chairman shall serve as
president pro tempore. (Ord. 552, 4-24-1963)
   (B)   Water, Sewer, Street Department: Shall have supervision, management
and control of the maintenance, enlargement and operation of the waterworks and
sewer system, the securing and selling of water, and all matters and things
connected with the operation, maintenance and extension of the waterworks
system and the selling of water therefrom and preserving the property belonging
thereto, and all matters connected with the operation of the sewer system and
maintenance and extension thereof. It shall have charge of the maintenance of
streets, sidewalks and public ways of the village and of the improvements and
repair thereof, also of the cleaning of streets and removal of dirt, garbage,
refuse and water therefrom. (Ord. 1332, 7-27-1994)
   (C)   Public Health And Welfare: Health services, sanitation inspections,
sanitation enforcement, nuisance complaints, liaison with mosquito abatement,
recreation, library.
   (D)   Public Safety: Police department, fire department, fire prevention
code enforcement, safety council, Cook County inspection bureau, civil defense.
(Ord. 552, 4-24-1963)
   (E)   Community Relations: Work with local agencies, including, but not
limited to, chamber of commerce, Midlothian park district, school districts and
library on community development and renewal issues. To act as municipal
liaison for federal and state economic and community development agencies. Work
with the organizations of and overseeing of all municipal satellites,
including, but not limited to, Harry Raday Lodge, Fine Art Society, and
Midlothian Historical Society. (Ord. 1332, 7-27-1994)
   (F)   Building And Zoning: Building permits, building code enforcement,
zoning enforcement, architectural harmony, housing code, sidewalks, street
lighting, liaison with planning commission and zoning board. (Ord. 552, 4-24-
1963)
1-5-18: JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES:
Unless in case of emergency, committee meetings shall be called at least twenty
four (24) hours prior to the time of meeting. Each member shall attend promptly
at the hour stated in the notice, or, if unable to do so, shall notify the
chairman of the committee to that effect.
All ordinances, petitions, resolutions, orders and communications to the board
shall be referred to appropriate committees to be announced by the chair. (Ord.
493, 4-14-1961)
1-5-19: REPORTS OF COMMITTEES:
Standing and special committees to whom references are made shall in all cases
report in writing at least once in each month, unless further time be granted
by a vote of the board, the state of facts with their opinion thereon, signed
by the members concurring therein. Minority reports may be received at the same
time with majority reports.
All reports of committees shall be addressed "to the president and board of
trustees". They shall briefly describe the matter referred, and the conclusion
shall be summed up in the form of an ordinance, order, resolution,
recommendation or some other distinct proposition. (Ord. 493, 4-14-1961)
1-5-20: ORDINANCES; EXPENDITURES:
   (A)   Property Tax Cap:
      1.   The village board shall limit any annual increase in its total tax
levy, rather than its tax rate, to the amount levied for the previous year plus
the lesser of five percent (5%) or the increase in the consumer price index
(urban) for the previous calendar year and shall otherwise abide by the
property tax limitations as set forth in the property tax extension limitation
law 1 , commonly referred to as the property tax cap, as it applies to the
total tax levy only (not the tax rate).
      2.   Repeal of this subsection (A) shall require a vote of five- sixths
(5/6) of all of the elected members of the village board and that vote shall be
conducted only after two (2) public hearings are held following all legal
notification requirements set forth in subsection 11-2-9(A) of this code. Both
public hearings required by this section shall occur forty five (45) days prior
to the vote to repeal this subsection (A). (Ord. 1832, 5-8-2013)
   (B)   Concurrence Of Majority: The ayes and nays shall be taken upon the
passage of all ordinances, and on all propositions to create any liability
against the village, or for the expenditure or appropriation of any money. A
concurrence of a majority of all the members elected shall be necessary to the
passage of any such ordinance or proposition, except as set forth in said
subsection (A) of this section and except that it shall require a two-thirds
(2/3) vote of all the members elected to sell any village property.
   (C)   Bills Referred To Committee: All bills against the village shall be
referred to the proper trustee, who shall examine such bills, and approve the
same in writing, and the same shall then be ready for payment upon approving
the same and the requisite vote of the board, but not otherwise. This rule
shall apply to all bills and expenses incurred by the village. Any bill
adversely reported by a trustee shall be, on the request of any two (2)
trustees, referred to a special committee before the same is disallowed. (Ord.
1832, 5-8-2013; amd. Ord. 1860, 2-12-2014)
 
Notes
1 1. 35 ILCS 200/18-185 - 18-245.
1-5-21: SUSPENSION OF RULES:
These rules may be temporarily suspended by a vote of two- thirds (2/3) of the
trustees present, but shall not be repealed, altered or amended unless notice
thereof shall have been given in writing, and the alteration or amendment
submitted at least one meeting prior thereto, and two-thirds (2/3) of all the
trustees entitled by law to be elected, shall concur therein. (Ord. 493, 4-14-
1961)
1-5-22: CENSURE:
Any member acting or appearing in a disgraceful manner, or who uses opprobrious
or insulting language to or about any member of the board of trustees, or who
does not obey the order of the chair, shall be on motion censured by a majority
vote of the members present.
No person not a member of the village board shall address the board without the
unanimous consent of the members present. (Ord. 493, 4-14-1961)
1-5-23: RULES OF PARLIAMENTARY PRACTICE:
The rules of the parliamentary practice comprised in "Robert's Rules Of Order"
shall govern the board in all cases to which they are applicable, and in which
they are not inconsistent with the standing rules of the board 1 . (Ord. 493,
4-14-1961)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3-1-11.
1-5-24: COMPENSATION:
   (A)   The salary of the village president shall be the sum of twenty three
thousand two hundred fifty dollars ($23,250.00) annually. This compensation
shall cover all meetings, regular or special or committee, and preparation for
all meetings and all work done for the village. (Ord. 1720, 4-14-2010)
   (B)   The compensation of the trustees of the village shall be the sum of
six thousand dollars ($6,000.00) annually. This compensation shall cover all
meetings, regular or special or committee, and preparation for all meetings and
all work done for the village. (Ord. 1741, 12-22-2010)
1-5-25: DATE ELECTED MUNICIPAL OFFICIALS TAKE OFFICE:
The terms of the newly elected officials shall commence at the first regular or
special meeting during the month of May following the proclamation of the
results of the regular municipal elections. (Ord. 997, 3-25-1981)
1-5-26: REMOTE ATTENDANCE:
If a quorum of the members of the village board is physically present at a
public meeting as defined under the open meetings act, a member of the body may
attend and participate in the meeting remotely by telephone or video conference
when said member is prevented from physically attending the meeting because of:
a) personal illness or disability, b) employment purposes, c) the member's
conducting of business on behalf of the public body, or d) a family or other
emergency. Any member wishing to attend remotely should notify the village
clerk before the meeting unless advance notice is impractical. Any member who
is attending a meeting remotely shall be entitled to vote, speak and
participate in both open and executive sessions of the village board in the
same fashion as if he or she was physically present at the meeting. (Ord. 1881,
10-8-2014)
1-5-27: VILLAGE NEWSLETTER, OTHER PUBLICATIONS:
No member of the corporate authorities of the village of Midlothian may publish
a village newsletter or use the village seal on a publication without the
specific prior direction and approval of the village board of trustees. (Ord.
1954, 1-18-2017)
CHAPTER 6
CLERK
SECTION:
1-6-1: Custodian Of Seal
1-6-2: Record Of Ordinances
1-6-3: Issuance Of Notices
1-6-4: Attesting Licenses
1-6-5: Delivery Of Documents To President
1-6-6: Notification Of Election Or Appointment
1-6-7: Filing Tax Levy With County Clerk
1-6-8: Records To Be Kept
1-6-9: Copies Of Records; Fees
1-6-10: Registrar Of Vital Statistics
1-6-11: Compensation
1-6-12: Deputy Clerk
1-6-1: CUSTODIAN OF SEAL:
The clerk shall keep the corporate seal to be provided under the direction of
the president and board of trustees, and all papers belonging to the village,
and he shall attend to all meetings of the president and board of trustees and
keep a full record of its proceedings in the journal. (Ord. 34, 6-19-1928)
1-6-2: RECORD OF ORDINANCES:
The clerk shall record in a book to be kept for that purpose, all ordinances
passed by the board of trustees, and at the foot of the record, at each
ordinance so recorded, shall make a memorandum of the date of passage and of
the publication or posting of the ordinance, which record and memorandum or
certified copy thereof shall be prima facie evidence of the passage and legal
publication or posting of such ordinance for all purposes. (Ord. 34, 6-19-1928)
1-6-3: ISSUANCE OF NOTICES:
The clerk shall issue all notices to the members of the board of trustees,
officers of the village, and other persons when required to do so, as herein
provided for, or as may be further directed by the board. (Ord. 34, 6-19-1928)
1-6-4: ATTESTING LICENSES:
The clerk shall attest all the licenses granted by the board, under the
provisions of this code. (Ord. 34, 6-19-1928)
1-6-5: DELIVERY OF DOCUMENTS TO PRESIDENT:
The clerk shall, without delay, deliver to the president, all ordinances or
resolutions under his charge, or vouchers which may require the approval or
signature of the president. (Ord. 34, 6-19-1928)
1-6-6: NOTIFICATION OF ELECTION OR APPOINTMENT:
The clerk shall, within five (5) days after the result of any election is
declared, or appointment made, notify such person so elected or appointed to
any village office, of his election or appointment, and unless such person
shall qualify respectively in ten (10) days, the office shall be considered
vacant and the clerk shall notify the president thereof. (Ord. 34, 6-19-1928)
1-6-7: FILING TAX LEVY WITH COUNTY CLERK:
It shall be the duty of the clerk on or before the second Tuesday of September
in each year, to file with the county clerk of Cook County, a certified copy of
the tax levy ordinance. (Ord. 34, 6-19-1928)
1-6-8: RECORDS TO BE KEPT:
The clerk shall file and preserve in a convenient form, for reference and use,
and index according to date of filing any subject matter, all official bonds,
oaths of office, written reports of officers and committees, vouchers and all
papers and documents filed within or deposited in his care, and promptly turn
the same over to his successor in office at the expiration of his term; except
the bond of the clerk which shall be filed with the treasurer. (Ord. 34, 6-19-
1928)
1-6-9: COPIES OF RECORDS; FEES:
The clerk shall be entitled to demand and receive in addition to his regular
salary, the following fees:
For certified copies of any record, each one hundred (100) words or fraction
thereof, twenty five cents ($0.25). (Ord. 109, 12-27-1932)
1-6-10: REGISTRAR OF VITAL STATISTICS:
The clerk shall be registrar of vital statistics for the village.
A report of all births, stillbirths and deaths shall be made to the local
registrar of vital statistics, which report shall contain all information
required by the "act to provide for the registration of all births,
stillbirths, and deaths in the state of Illinois, and to repeal an act herein
named", approved June 22, 1915, as amended.
The local registrar shall keep a record showing all births, stillbirths and
deaths occurring within the village, which record shall include all information
required to be kept by the act hereinbefore described. (Ord. 219, 9-22-1943)
1-6-11: COMPENSATION:
The salary of the village clerk shall be the sum of fifteen thousand seven
hundred fifty dollars ($15,750.00) annually. This compensation shall cover all
meetings, regular or special or committee, and preparation for all meetings and
all work done for the village. (Ord. 1720, 4-14-2010)
1-6-12: DEPUTY CLERK:
There is hereby created the position of deputy clerk. The president is
authorized to appoint the deputy clerk for a term of one year by and with the
advice and consent of the board of trustees. The compensation shall be as set
forth by the village board.
The duties of the deputy clerk shall be to act in place and stead of the clerk
in the event of his absence or inability to act. He shall assist the clerk in
the exercise of all his duties and help perform such other duties as may be
assigned to him by the clerk. (Ord. 1069, 6-27-1984)
CHAPTER 7
TREASURER
SECTION:
1-7-1: Appointment
1-7-2: Duties
1-7-3: Oath And Bond
1-7-4: Salary
1-7-1: APPOINTMENT:
The president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees shall
appoint a treasurer for a one year term. (Ord. 643, 5-10-1967)
1-7-2: DUTIES:
The duties of the treasurer shall be:
   (A)   To receive, collect and receipt for all monies and funds due or
payable to the village, including taxes, license fees, special assessments,
fines, penalties, refunds, credits and any and all other fees or monies payable
to the village. To ensure that all valid financial obligations and accounts
payable of the village are timely monitored and paid to avoid losses,
penalties, late charges and/or interest costs to the village.
   (B)   To keep a complete and accurate record and account of all monies
received; and to keep such records, accounts, warrants, books, vouchers and
other payments in the manner that the president and board of trustees may
prescribe. All such records may be examined from time to time by the president,
clerk or any member of the board of trustees.
   (C)   To perform such other duties as are required by 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes, and as may be prescribed by the village board from time to time.
(Ord. 643, 5-10-1967; amd. Ord. 2105, 8-10-2022)
1-7-3: OATH AND BOND:
Before entering upon the duties of the office the treasurer shall take and
subscribe to the oath required of other village officials and shall execute a
bond with security to be approved by the president and board of trustees. The
bond shall be payable to the village in whatever penal sum may be directed by
motion or resolution of the board, conditioned upon the faithful performance of
the duties of the office and the payment of all monies received by the
treasurer. (Ord. 643, 5-10-1967)
1-7-4: SALARY:
The salary of the treasurer shall be fixed from time to time by the village
board. (Ord. 643, 5-10-1967)
CHAPTER 8
ATTORNEY
SECTION:
1-8-1: Appointment
1-8-2: Duties
1-8-3: Compensation
1-8-1: APPOINTMENT:
The office of attorney is hereby created; said office shall be filled by
appointment made by the president and board of trustees, and shall be
transcribed upon the records or proceedings of the village, as soon as same is
made, or as conveniently thereafter as may be. The attorney shall take the oath
required by law, which oath shall be filed at any time after the appointment
with the clerk. (Ord. 24, 12-6-1928)
1-8-2: DUTIES:
The attorney shall be authorized and directed to prepare all of the necessary
papers, resolutions, ordinances, estimates, petitions, notices, orders, appear
in court, attend board of local improvements meetings, write up the minutes of
the board of local improvements meetings, and to do all other work necessary or
which may be necessary, including the spreading of the assessment and writing
up the assessment roll for the purpose of originating and pursuing to
completion, including confirmation of all special assessments that may be
levied in the village. (Ord. 24, 12-6-1928)
1-8-3: COMPENSATION:
The village attorney shall receive as his or her compensation for the services
set forth in section 1-8-2 of this chapter an amount determined from time to
time by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees.
(Ord. 1720, 4-14-2010)
CHAPTER 9
SUPERINTENDENT OF STREETS
(Rep. by Ord. 596, 1-13-1965)
CHAPTER 10
HEALTH OFFICER
(Rep. by Ord. 744, 6-14-1972)
CHAPTER 11
VILLAGE COURT
(Rep. by Ord. 738, 4-26-1972)
CHAPTER 12
FINANCE
SECTION:
1-12-1: Fiscal Year
1-12-2: Finance Director Office Created
1-12-3: Retirement Fund Participation
1-12-4: Maximum Tax Rates
1-12-5: Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax
1-12-6: Municipal Service Occupation Tax
1-12-7: Municipal Use Tax
1-12-8: Fraudulent Payment, Personal Check
1-12-9: Delinquent Special Assessments
1-12-10: Municipal Automobile Renting Use Tax
1-12-11: Municipal Automobile Renting Occupation Tax
1-12-12: Transaction Fees On Payments
1-12-13: Street Enhancement Fund
1-12-1: FISCAL YEAR:
The fiscal year for the village shall begin on May 1 of each year and end on
April 30 of the following year. (Ord. 226, 9-13-1944)
1-12-2: FINANCE DIRECTOR OFFICE CREATED:
There is created the office of Finance Director. The Finance Director shall be
appointed by the Village President with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees.
   (A)   Duties: The duties of the Finance Director shall include:
      1.   Overseeing day to day duties and operations of the Village's
Finances.
      2.   Managing, overseeing and being responsible for accounts payable,
payroll, bank reconciliations, and auditing insurance premiums.
      3.   Responsibility for the Village's independent annual audit, Tax
Increment Financing and Motor Fuel Tax reporting and management.
      4.   Preparing final audits, financial statements and ensuring conformity
with Government Finance Officers Association certificate program.
      5.   Ensuring that all financial institutions receiving public funds are
in compliance with the Public Funds Deposit Act (30 ILCS 225) and the Public
Funds investment Act (30 ILCS 225) as now or herein after amended.
      6.   Preparing the Village's annual budget and five-year financial
forecast; assuring the quality, accuracy, timeliness, completeness, and
compliance with local, state, and national standards.
      7.   Implementing and managing technology within the department.
      8.   Implementing and managing Village finance information on the Village
website.
      9.   Implementing and maintaining a grant and vendor contract database.
      10.   Responsibility for implementing and revising all financial policies
and procedures.
      11.   Managing the capital projects budget, coordinating with departments
to determine needs, prioritize projects and obtaining financing for capital
projects as needed.
      12.   Responsibility for ongoing monitoring and notifying the Village
Board of financial conditions and performance measurements throughout the
fiscal year, including quarterly reporting, cash flow analysis, forecasting,
rate studies, financial trend reviews and budget amendments, if necessary;
monitoring and directing the investment of surplus funds pursuant to investment
policies.
      13.   Responsibility for determining and recommending to the Village
Board appropriate rates for the Village's water and sewer services, and other
services as requested by the President and Board of Trustees.
      14.   Reviewing, developing, and implementing internal controls as well
as new processes and procedures to ensure accuracy, efficiency, and
transparency in all areas of Village operations related to Village finances.
      15.   Investigating and/ or responding to citizens' questions, concerns
and/ or complaints relating to the Finance Department.
      16.   Monitoring and coordinating with human resource personnel and
consultants.
      17.   Prepare documents for and attend monthly Village finance committee
meetings and Village Board meetings.
      18.   Coordinate and collaborate with the Village Treasurer to perform
all duties of the Village Treasure as required by the Illinois Municipal Code
and as provided in this section.
      19.   Perform other duties as assigned by the Village President and Board
of Trustees.
   (B)   Compensation: The Finance Director shall receive such compensation as
is established by the President with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees. (Ord. 2106, 10-12-2022)
1-12-3: RETIREMENT FUND PARTICIPATION:
The board of trustees, does hereby elect that the village participate in the
Illinois municipal retirement fund, effective January 1, 1961. (Ord. 483, 10-
19-1960)
1-12-4: MAXIMUM TAX RATES:
   (A)   The maximum tax rate for fire protection for the village shall be
0.0690 of the assessed value of all taxable property in the village as
ascertained and set by law. (Ord. 327, 12-12-1951)
   (B)   The maximum tax rate for general corporate purposes for the village
shall be 0.2499 of the assessed value of all taxable property in the village as
ascertained and set by law. (Ord. 328, 12-12-1951)
   (C)   The maximum tax rate for maintaining a public library for the village
shall be 0.0690 of the assessed value of all taxable property in the village as
ascertained and set by law. (Ord. 329, 12-12-1951)
   (D)   Pursuant to the provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-19-4,
as amended, the tax levy for the collection and disposal or solely for the
collection or solely for the disposal of garbage, refuse and ashes is herewith
increased to one-tenth percent (0.1%) of the full fair cash value, as equalized
or assessed by the department of revenue, on all of the taxable property in the
village. (Ord. 618, 12-18-1965)
1-12-5: MUNICIPAL RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX 1 :
   (A)   A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of
selling tangible personal property at retail in this village at the rate of
three-fourths of one percent (0.75%) of the gross receipts from such sales made
in the course of such business while this section is in effect, in accordance
with the provisions of section 8-11-1 of the Illinois municipal code.
   (B)   Every such person engaged in such business in the village shall file
on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the state
department of revenue required by section 3 of "an act in relation to a tax
upon persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property to
purchasers for use or consumption" approved June 28, 1933, as amended.
   (C)   At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state
department of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the
receipts from sales of tangible personal property during the preceding month.
   (D)   The village clerk is hereby directed to transmit to the state
department of revenue a certified copy of the ordinance codified herein not
later than five (5) days after the effective date hereof. (Ord. 645, 7-12-1967)

1-12-6: MUNICIPAL SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX 1 :
   (A)   A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in this municipality
in the business of making sales of service at the rate of three-fourths of one
percent (0.75%) of the gross receipts received from such business, in
accordance with the provisions of section 8-11-5 of the Illinois municipal
code.
   (B)   Every serviceman required to account for municipal service occupation
tax for the benefit of this municipality shall file, on or before the last day
of each calendar month, the report to the state department of revenue required
by section 9 of the service occupation tax act.
   (C)   At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state
department of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed.
   (D)   The village clerk is hereby directed to transmit to the state
department of revenue a certified copy of the ordinance codified herein not
later than five (5) days after the effective date hereof. (Ord. 647, 7-19-1967)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 5-5-1 of this code.
1-12-7: MUNICIPAL USE TAX:
   (A)   A tax is hereby imposed in accordance with the provisions of section
8-11-6 of the Illinois municipal code upon the privilege of using in the
village any item of tangible personal property which is purchased outside
Illinois at retail from a retailer, and which is titled or registered with an
agency of Illinois government. The tax shall be at a rate of one percent (1%)
of the selling price of such tangible property with selling price to have the
meaning as defined in the use tax act, approved July 14, 1955, as amended.
   (B)   Consent and authority are given to the Illinois department of revenue
to collect and enforce the tax imposed by subsection (A) of this section and
all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident thereof for or in
behalf of the village pursuant to the municipal use tax act. (Ord. 852, 6-23-
1976)
1-12-8: FRAUDULENT PAYMENT, PERSONAL CHECK:
   (A)   If any check received by the village in payment of a bill, fee,
charge, license, etc., is deposited by the village and thereafter returned to
the village because of nonsufficient funds, insufficient funds, uncollected
funds, stop payment, refer to maker, account closed or any similar reason, the
person, persons or company who gave the check to the village must make said
check good and pay an additional fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) for the work
done in processing said check. (Ord. 1305, 7-28-1993)
   (B)   If any person, persons or company causes two (2) checks to be returned
to the village as stated above within a twelve (12) month period, the village
shall not accept any further personal checks from said person, persons or
company and all further payments must be made by cashier's check, certified
check, money order or treasurer's check or cash. (Ord. 878, 5-25-1977)
1-12-9: DELINQUENT SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS:
In cases where any installments of a village special assessment levied on real
estate has been delinquent for a period of thirty (30) years, such installment
shall be presumed to be uncollectible and the village collector/treasurer and
the county collector and the county clerk shall enter upon the tax records in
their respective offices where such assessments appear the word "uncollectible"
and shall adjust the books and records of the respective offices therefor. When
such taxes shall have been designated "uncollectible" under this section, the
village may use any money it holds for payment of such special assessment for
improvements similar to the projects for which such monies were collected, for
the purchase of real estate or personal property in connection therewith. (Ord.
987, 9-24-1980)
1-12-10: MUNICIPAL AUTOMOBILE RENTING USE TAX:
   (A)   A tax is hereby imposed upon the privilege of using in this village an
automobile which is rented from a renter outside Illinois and which is titled
or registered with an agency of this state's government in this village at the
rate of one percent (1%) of the rental price of such automobile while this
section is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of section 8-11-8 of
the Illinois municipal code.
   (B)   The tax provided for in this section shall be collected from the
persons whose Illinois address for titling or registration purposes is given as
being in this village.
   (C)   The tax imposed by this section shall be paid to the Illinois
department of revenue. (Ord. 1022, 1-13-1982)
1-12-11: MUNICIPAL AUTOMOBILE RENTING OCCUPATION TAX:
   (A)   A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of
renting automobiles in this village at the rate of one percent (1%) of the
gross receipts from such rentals made in the course of such business while this
section is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of section 8-11-7 of
the Illinois municipal code.
   (B)   Every such person engaged in such business in the village shall file
on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the state
department of revenue required by section 2 and 3 of "an act in relation to a
tax upon persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property
to purchasers for use or consumption" approved June 29, 1933, as amended.
   (C)   At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state
department of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the
renting of automobiles during the preceding month. (Ord. 1021, 1-13-1982)
1-12-12: TRANSACTION FEES ON PAYMENTS:
(A)   The Village of Midlothian hereby authorizes that the transaction fees
associated with accepting credit cards, debit cards, and e-checks be passed on
to the users of credit cards, debit cards, and e-checks when paying for Village
fees and services.
(B)   In addition to the amount charged for the fees and services, there shall
be a transaction fee of two and one-quarter percent (2.25%) of the total amount
charged per transaction for credit cards and debit cards. In addition to the
amount charged for the fees and services, there shall be a fifty cents ($0.50)
per e-check charge. These transaction fees are intended to cover the merchant
fees paid by the Village to the merchant services provider. No credit card,
debit card, or e-check will be accepted without the transaction fees stated in
this section being charged. (Ord. 2156, 11-13-2024)
1-12-13: STREET ENHANCEMENT FUND:
(A)   A fund is hereby created to prioritize and provide for the paving,
repairing, rebuilding and maintaining of streets within the Village.
(B)   The fund established in this section shall be monetized by a fee applied
to all real property within the Village that has a structure upon it as defined
by the International Building Code and the International Residential Code as
adopted herein.
(C)   The fee shall be billed per property at a rate of eight dollars and
twenty-five cents ($8.25) quarterly except that water and garbage account
holders billed monthly may be billed monthly at a rate of two dollars and
seventy-five cents ($2.75) and except as provided for in paragraphs (D), (E),
and (F) of this section. All revenue generated by the fee shall be deposited
into the Village general fund.
(D)   For apartment buildings of four (4) or more units the fee shall apply to
each occupied unit and may be billed separately to each lessee. Only one (1)
fee shall be charged per unit regardless of the number of lessees or occupants
residing in the unit and the fee shall be jointly and severally collectable
against lessors and lessees of the subject property.
(E)   For condominiums and townhomes, the fee shall apply to each unit and may
be billed separately to each unit owner. Only one (1) fee shall be charged per
unit regardless of the number of owners, lessees or occupants residing in the
unit. Vacant home owner association (HOA) owned units shall be exempt from the
fee requirement in this section.
(F)   Senior Citizens' Rate: Any person subject to paying the fee in this
section who has reached the age of sixty-five (65) years by July 1 of the year,
shall therein after pay a reduced fee of one dollar and twenty-five cents
($1.25) per quarter, provided he or she supplies proof of age and proof of
ownership of the property and/or a valid lease if the lessee is obligated to
pay the fee, to the village clerk.
(G)   Failure to pay or default in the full payment of the fee required under
this section shall be a debt due and owing the municipality and, as such, may
be collected in accordance with the applicable law. (Ord. 2167, 4-9-2025)
CHAPTER 13
DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC RELATIONS
SECTION:

1-13-2: Duties
1-13-1: OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT; TERM; SALARY:
There is hereby created the office of director of public relations. The
director of public relations shall be appointed by the president with the
advice and consent of the village board. His term shall commence on May 1 of
each year and expire April 30 of the succeeding year. He may be removed from
office at the will of the village president. The director of public relations
shall receive a salary as set by the village board as compensation for
performing his duties. (Ord. 879, 6-8-1977)
1-13-2: DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the director of public relations to attend all the
village board meetings, to compile and edit the monthly newsletter and compile
and edit all press releases from the village so as to fully inform the
residents of the village of the operations and programs of their village
government. (Ord. 553, 6-12-1963)

CHAPTER 15
OFFICIAL PLAN
SECTION:
1-15-1: Datum Plane
1-15-2: Bench Marks
1-15-3: Official Plan; Establishment
1-15-4: Compliance With Plan
1-15-5: Official Map
1-15-6: Requirements Of Village
1-15-1: DATUM PLANE:
The datum plane of the city of Chicago as established by ordinance as a plane
579.896 feet above mean low water level at Biloxi, Mississippi, as determined
by the United States geological survey be and the same is hereby established as
the base or datum of all village levels.
All grades or elevations that may hereafter be established by the board of
trustees shall be measured in feet and decimals of a foot above or below the
plane as the base or datum of all levels in the village. (Ord. 20, 11-14-1927;
amd. Ord., 1971)
1-15-2: BENCH MARKS:
The engineer is hereby authorized and empowered to establish bench marks within
the village and shall properly record such bench marks and file with the clerk
a true copy of such record. (Ord. 20, 11-14-1927; amd. Ord., 1971)
1-15-3: OFFICIAL PLAN; ESTABLISHMENT:
The official plan of the village shall consist of the following:
   (A)   The "official map" approved by the board on June 13, 1962, consisting
of a map of the village and contiguous unincorporated territory, charts and
diagrams showing proposed additions to and improvements of the village streets,
parks, public buildings, sewage disposal system, water system and street
lighting system.
   (B)   The specifications for street construction and paving hitherto
established by the board.
   (C)   The zoning title.
   (D)   The subdivision control chapter. (Ord. 522, 6-13-1962; amd. Ord.,
1971)
1-15-4: COMPLIANCE WITH PLAN:
No plat of subdivision, plan for the construction or layout of streets, or work
involving laying sewer or water mains shall be approved unless the same
complies fully with the requirements of the official plan. (Ord. 522, 6-13-
1962; amd. Ord., 1971)
1-15-5: OFFICIAL MAP:
The map drawn by George J. Chlebicki & Associates, Consulting Engineers, and
approved by the plan commission on April 4, 1962, entitled "official plan of
the village of Midlothian", is hereby incorporated as a part of this chapter
and is hereby adopted as the official map of the village. (Ord. 521, 6-13-1962;
amd. Ord., 1971)
1-15-6: REQUIREMENTS OF VILLAGE:
   (A)   Rights Of Way Widths: The minimum rights of way widths for street,
alley and crosswalkways shall be:
Major street (except in cases where a greater or lesser width is shown 100 feet
on the major street plan)
Secondary street                                                       66 feet
Minor street, for row houses and apartments                            60 feet
Minor street, for other residences                                     50 feet
Cul-de-sac                                                             50 feet
Marginal access street (with intersecting streets)                     50 feet
Marginal access street (without intersecting streets)                  40 feet
Alley                                                                  20 feet
Crosswalkway                                                           10 feet
 
   (B)   Roadway Widths (Outside To Outside Of Curbs):
Major street (as shown on major street plan)           
Secondary street                                      36 feet
Minor street                                          31 feet
Cul-de-sac                                            31 feet
Marginal access street (with intersecting streets)    31 feet
Marginal access street (without intersecting streets) 20 feet
Alley                                                 20 feet
Crosswalkway                                          5 feet
Sidewalk                                              5 feet
 
   (C)   Parks And Playgrounds: Not less than seven percent (7%) of the area of
every subdivision, exclusive of streets, alleys and unusable land, shall be set
aside for public recreational, school or other public purposes, other than of
streets and alleys, unless the village shall find that the proposed subdivision
is adequately served by such facilities. In small subdivisions, such
reservation of land shall be so located as to permit combining it with similar
reservations in adjoining tracts. Reservations of land for park and
recreational use shall be located to conform, as nearly as possible, with the
parks section of the official plan. In the event that the village shall
determine that the required seven percent (7%) of the subdivider's property for
use as a public site is not feasible in the particular location, the subdivider
shall, in lieu of dedicating a public site, pay into such fund as may be
directed by the village a sum equal in value to the seven percent (7%) of the
land value as mutually agreed upon between the subdivider and the village.
   (D)   Easements: All aboveground utilities shall be placed on rear or side
property lines. When a subdivision is transversed by a watercourse, an
appropriate easement shall be provided for the watercourse in either an open
cut or in an underground conduit, depending upon the density of development.
Where water mains, sanitary sewers, storm sewers, gas mains, telephone lines,
power lines or other utilities are located on or adjacent to property lines,
adequate easements together with right of ingress or egress thereto and
therefrom shall be provided and platted. Easements shall not be less than ten
feet (10') in width and shall be centered upon the centerline of the utility.
Where more than one utility is to occupy the easement, the easement shall be of
such width as to extend five feet (5') at each side beyond the centerlines of
the outermost utilities. Additional width shall be provided where necessary to
accommodate utility pole bracing. The village may require evidence of approval
by the public utility company of easement width. Where side lot easements occur
adjacent to a driveway, there shall not be less than ten feet (10') clearance
between the easement line and the extreme projection of the building structure.
   (E)   Street Construction: The kind and quality of materials which shall be
used in the construction of streets and alleys shall conform to the standard
and quantity of materials required by the state for macadam type streets.
   (F)   Drainage And Sanitary Sewers: All plats submitted should indicate the
surface water drainage plan. The plan is subject to the approval of the board
of trustees. Sanitary sewers are required for all construction. The plan for
the installation and connection of sanitary sewers shall be shown on the plat
and is subject to the approval of the board of trustees and the metropolitan
sanitary district of greater Chicago 1 . (Ord. 521, 6-13-1962; amd. Ord., 1971)
