CHAPTER 1
PLAN COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-1-1: Commission Created
2-1-2: Members Of Commission
2-1-3: Term Of Members
2-1-4: Officers Of Commission; Compensation
2-1-5: Powers Of Commission
2-1-6: Records To Be Kept
2-1-1: COMMISSION CREATED:
A plan commission for the village is hereby created under the authority of 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-12. (Ord. 413, 4-10-1957)
2-1-2: MEMBERS OF COMMISSION:
The plan commission shall consist of a chairman and eight (8) members, one of
whom shall be a member of the zoning board of appeals, to be appointed by the
president with the approval of the board of trustees and in addition thereto
the village president and the president of the board of local improvements
shall be members ex officio of the commission. (Ord. 413, 4-10-1957)
2-1-3: TERM OF MEMBERS:
The chairman and two (2) members shall be appointed for a term of one year;
three (3) members shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years and three (3)
members for a term of three (3) years. Terms of all members of the commission
thereafter appointed shall be three (3) years. All vacancies occurring in the
plan commission shall be filled by appointment for the remainder of the
unexpired term in the same manner as original appointments. (Ord. 413, 4-10-
1957)
2-1-4: OFFICERS OF COMMISSION; COMPENSATION:
The plan commission shall complete its organization by the election of a vice
chairman, secretary and such other officers as in their judgment may be
necessary. All members and officers of the plan commission shall serve without
compensation. If the plan commission shall deem it advisable to secure
technical advice or service, it may do so upon authority from the board of
trustees and appropriation therefor by the board of trustees. (Ord. 413, 4-10-
1957)
2-1-5: POWERS OF COMMISSION:
The plan commission shall have power:
   (A)   To prepare and recommend to the president and board of trustees a plan
for the development and redevelopment of the village and contiguous
unincorporated territory not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles beyond the
corporate limits of the village and not included in any other municipality. The
plan when adopted by the president and board of trustees shall be designated as
the official plan, or part thereof, of the village. The plan may be adopted in
whole or in separate geographical or functional parts, each of which, when
adopted shall be the official plan, or part thereof, of the village. Thereafter
from time to time, the plan commission may recommend changes in the official
plan or in any part thereof. To provide for the health, safety, comfort and
convenience of the inhabitants of the village and contiguous territory, the
plan may establish reasonable standards of design for subdivisions and for
resubdivisions of unimproved land and of areas subject to redevelopment,
including reasonable requirements for public streets, alleys, ways for public
service facilities, parks, playgrounds, school grounds, and other public
grounds.
   (B)   To prepare and recommend to the president and board of trustees, from
time to time, plans for specific improvements in pursuance of the official
plan.
   (C)   To give aid to the village officials charged with the direction of
projects for improvements embraced within the official plan, to further the
making of these projects, and generally to promote the realization of the
official plan.
   (D)   To exercise such other powers, germane to the powers granted herein,
as may be conferred by the president and board of trustees. (Ord. 413, 4-10-
1957)
2-1-6: RECORDS TO BE KEPT:
The plan commission shall keep written records of its proceedings and they
shall be open to inspection by the president and board of trustees at all times
1 . (Ord. 413, 4-10-1957)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-12-4.
CHAPTER 2
ZONING COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-2-1: Commission Created
2-2-2: Members
2-2-3: Powers Of Commission
2-2-4: Records To Be Kept
2-2-1: COMMISSION CREATED:
A zoning commission for the village is hereby created under the authority of 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-13. (Ord. 233, 8-29-1945)
2-2-2: MEMBERS:
The zoning commission shall consist of seven (7) members appointed by the
president and confirmed by the board of trustees. (Ord. 233, 8-29-1945)
2-2-3: POWERS OF COMMISSION:
The zoning commission shall:
   (A)   Recommend the boundaries of the zoning districts and appropriate
regulations to be enforced therein.
   (B)   Prepare a tentative report and proposed zoning ordinance for the
entire village.
   (C)   Hold a hearing thereon and shall afford persons interested an
opportunity to be heard, by publishing notices of such hearing at least fifteen
(15) days in advance thereof in a newspaper of general circulation in the
village, which notice shall state the time and place of hearing and the place
where copies of the proposed ordinance shall be accessible for examination by
interested parties. The hearing may be adjourned from time to time.
   (D)   Make a final report within thirty (30) days after the final
adjournment of such hearing, and submit the proposed ordinance for the entire
village to the board of trustees, to be enacted with or without change, or to
be referred back to the commission for further consideration. (Ord. 233, 8-29-
1945)
2-2-4: RECORDS TO BE KEPT:
The zoning commission shall keep written records of its proceedings which shall
be open to inspection by the board of trustees at all times 1 . (Ord. 233, 8-
29-1945)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-13-2.
CHAPTER 3
COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT LIAISON COMMITTEES
SECTION:
2-3-1: Community Involvement Liaison Committee Established
2-3-2: Appointment
2-3-3: Terms Of Office
2-3-4: Meetings
2-3-5: Compensation
2-3-6: Duties
2-3-7: Ethics And Conflict Of Interest
2-3-8: Penalties
2-3-1: COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT LIAISON COMMITTEES ESTABLISHED:
The Village of Midlothian hereby establishes Community Involvement Liaison
Committees for the purpose of providing increased participation of residents
and the community in enhancing the quality of life in the Village of
Midlothian. The committees shall provide input regarding community enhancing
activities and the manner and extent that services of the Village Departments
are provided. The committees in this Chapter shall be advisory in nature.
The committees shall consist of the Community Policing and Safety Committee,
Veterans Committee, the Beautification Committee, Keep Midlothian Beautiful
Committee, Community Service Committee, Historical Society, and Events
Committee. (Ord. 2087, 12-8-2021)
2-3-2: APPOINTMENT:
Membership of the committees designated in
2-3-1 of this chapter shall be composed of seven (7) members. The committees
shall consist of the trustee designated to oversee the subject and a Village
employee designated to facilitate the activities of the committees as ex
official members and up to five (5) residents of the village. The chairperson
and the resident members of the committees shall be appointed by the president
of the village with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. (Ord.
2087, 12-8-2021)
2-3-3: TERMS OF OFFICE:
All members of the committees shall serve for a term of one year commencing on
the second regular board meeting of May and serve until a successor has been
duly appointed and qualified, and any vacancies which shall occur shall be
filled in the same manner as the original appointment. (Ord. 2087, 12-8-2021)
2-3-4: MEETINGS:
Meetings of the committees shall be every other month or as necessary to
complete the business of the committees and shall be noticed in compliance with
the requirements of the Illinois Open Meetings Act, (5 ILCS 120/). (Ord. 2087,
12-8-2021)
2-3-5: COMPENSATION:
Upon application to and approval of the Village Clerk, qualified resident
members of the Community Involvement Liaison Committees that serve for the
entire one-year term shall be eligible to receive one complimentary Village of
Midlothian Vehicle License for each year of service as compensation. (Ord.
2087, 12-8-2021)
2-3-6: DUTIES:
The duties of the committees shall be as follows:
   (A)   To submit an initial mission statement, revise the mission statement
from time to time and establish yearly goals of the Committee to the Village
Board for review and approval by July 1, of each year.
   (B)   Provide input and recommendation to the Village Board on matters that
are relevant to the Committee. (Ord. 2087, 12-8-2021)
2-3-7: ETHICS AND CONFLICT OF INTEREST:
All members of any Community Involvement Liaison Committee, whether voting
members or nonvoting members, shall be governed by the following rules or
ordinances:
   (A)   Ethics: The ethics ordinance contained in title 1, chapter 19 of this
code shall apply to all members of any Community Involvement Liaison Committee,
whether the member is a voting or nonvoting member. The penalties for the
violation of the village ethics ordinance shall be those set forth in the
ethics ordinance in section
1-19-8 of this code.
   (B)   Conflict of Interest: No member of any Community Involvement Liaison
Committee shall engage in a conflict of interest with regard to his or her
duties as a member of the Community Involvement Liaison Committee. Matters that
will be considered to be a conflict of interest include, but are not limited
to, the following:
      1.   The use of documents, data or any information that has not been
communicated to the public for a member's personal advantage, benefit or use.
      2.   The use of documents, data or any information that has not been
communicated to the public for a member's relative's personal advantage,
benefit or use.
      3.   The use of documents, data or any information that has not been
communicated to the public for the benefit of any third party, even if the
member does not benefit from such use of documents, data or other information
that has not been communicated to the public.
      4.   The use of documents, data or any information that has not been
communicated to the public for the benefit of any third party's relative, even
if the member does not benefit from such use of documents, data or any other
information that has not been communicated to the public.
      5.   The representation of, acting as agent of, or in any other manner
assisting a client, customer or other individual with whom a member has a
business relationship and which is adverse to the interests of the village or
which utilizes documents, data or any information that has not been
communicated to the public.
      6.   The representation of, acting as agent of, or in any other manner
assisting a business in which a member has any type of an ownership or
financial interest and which is adverse to the interests of the village or
which utilizes documents, data or any information that has not been
communicated to the public.
      7.   A member shall not enter into a business transaction utilizing data
or information which has not been made available to the general public by
acquiring an ownership, possessory, security or other pecuniary interest in a
business entity, parcel of real estate, or otherwise.
      8.   A member shall not provide financial assistance with regard to any
matter that has come before any Community Involvement Liaison Committee and
which would benefit the member, a member's relative, a business entity in which
the member has an interest, or any other third party, including one whom the
member may represent or act as an agent.
      9.   Any act or omission in which the member behaves or acts
inconsistently with his or her duties as a member of the economic development
committee or in which the member could be said to be acting in a dual capacity.
(Ord. 2087, 12-8-2021)
2-3-8: PENALTIES:
The penalties for violation of section
2-3-7 of this chapter shall be one or more of the following:
   (A)   The member shall be removed by the president from the committee; and/
or
   (B)   The penalties provided under section
1-19-8 of this code. (Ord. 2087, 12-8-2021)

CHAPTER 5
PARK COMMISSION
(Rep. by Ord. 739, 4-26-1972)
CHAPTER 6
ZONING BOARD OF APPEALS
SECTION:
2-6-1: Board Established; Members
2-6-2: Powers And Duties
2-6-3: Vote By Board
2-6-4: Appeal; Cash Deposit Required
2-6-5: Fair Housing Duties
2-6-1: BOARD ESTABLISHED; MEMBERS:
A zoning board of appeals is hereby established. The members of the board of
appeals shall be appointed by the president and the board of trustees. The
board of appeals shall consist of seven (7) members, to serve respectively for
the following terms: one for one year, one for two (2) years, one for three (3)
years, one for four (4) years, one for five (5) years, one for six (6) years
and one for seven (7) years, the successor to each member so appointed to serve
for a term of five (5) years. The board of appeals shall adopt from time to
time such rules and regulations as it may deem necessary to interpret and to
carry into effect the provisions of the zoning title of this code. (Ord. 474,
3-10-1960)
2-6-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The board of appeals may hold hearings on zoning changes after giving proper
public notice and send their recommendations to the village board per
subsection 11-2-3(B)1 of this code.
The board of appeals may hold hearings on zoning variation requests which vary
the application of any of the provisions or regulations of the zoning title
relating to the use, construction or alteration of buildings or structures, or
the use of land whenever it is alleged that strict enforcement would cause
practical difficulties or particular hardship not intended or not common to
other property in the vicinity or in the same districts; provided, the board:
   (A)   Holds a public hearing of which there shall be an advance notice of
fifteen (15) days published in a newspaper of general circulation in the
village, stating the time and place of such hearing and the nature of the
variation requested.
   (B)   Finds at such hearing that the variation will not:
      1.   Impair an adequate supply of light and air to adjacent property.
      2.   Increase materially the hazard from fire and other dangers.
      3.   Diminish the taxable value of land and buildings throughout the
village.
      4.   Increase congestion in the public streets.
      5.   Otherwise impair the public health, safety, comfort, morals or
general welfare.
   (C)   Shall not reduce the required dimensions of open space by more than
twenty percent (20%), nor reduce the required total area of open spaces or the
required total lot area by more than ten percent (10%), whether such
requirements are applicable to new buildings, or to additions to or
alterations, or extensions of existing buildings.
   (D)   Shall not permit an increase in the height of structures more than ten
percent (10%) above the maximum height permitted by the zoning title of this
code.
   (E)   Shall not permit any extensions of a nonconforming use throughout a
building or lot contrary to the limitations imposed in subsections (C) and (D)
of this section.
   (F)   Shall make and record findings of fact specifying the reasons for
recommending a variation.
   (G)   Must submit the recommendation to the village board and must attach
copies of exhibits, plans and specifications for the proposed use or variation.
   (H)   The power to determine and authorize variation is reserved to the
village board and can be made only by passing an appropriate ordinance. Where a
variation is to be made by ordinance, upon the report of the board of appeals,
the corporate authorities, by ordinance, without further public hearing, may
adopt any proposed variation or may refer it back to the zoning board for
further consideration, and any proposed variation which fails to receive the
approval of the zoning board of appeals shall not be passed except by the
favorable vote of two-thirds (2/3) of all the trustees of the village. (Ord.
945, 12-13-1978)
2-6-3: VOTE BY BOARD:
When a quorum is present a majority of the votes cast is sufficient to adopt
any motion. (Ord. 946, 12-13-1978)
2-6-4: APPEAL; CASH DEPOSIT REQUIRED:
An appeal to the board of appeals for a variation as permitted in this chapter
shall be accompanied by cash or certified check in the amount determined by the
village board, which shall be delivered to the treasurer to the credit of the
general fund of the village to cover the approximate cost of the procedure in
this chapter, and under no circumstances shall the sum of money or any part
thereof be refunded for failure of the proposal or request to be enacted or if
the appeal is not granted. The village board shall set the amount of the fee by
resolution or ordinance in a fee schedule to be maintained by the village clerk
and which shall be made available to the public upon request. (Ord. 1651, 10-
10-2007)
2-6-5: FAIR HOUSING DUTIES:
The zoning board of appeals is hereby authorized to hold appropriate hearings
and to take any action required to implement their duties as set out in the
village fair housing ordinance, title 5, chapter 18 of this code. (Ord. 1696,
7-8-2009)
CHAPTER 7
FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-7-1: Appointment; Terms Of Office
2-7-2: First Appointments
2-7-3: Qualifications; Oath; Bond; Removal
2-7-4: Fire And Police Departments; Appointment Of Members; Certificates Of
Appointments
2-7-5: Rules; Publications
2-7-6: Examination Of Applicants; Disqualifications
2-7-7: Fingerprints To Be Furnished
2-7-8: Veterans And Educational Preference
2-7-9: Original Appointments; Preferences; Limitation
2-7-10: Preference; Time For Allowance
2-7-11: Notice Of Examination
2-7-12: Register Of Eligibles
2-7-13: Promotions; Merit; Seniority
2-7-14: Temporary Appointments
2-7-15: Removal Or Discharge; Investigation Of Charges; Retirement
2-7-16: Fire Or Police Departments; Reduction Of Force; Reinstatement
2-7-17: Annual Report; Budget Request
2-7-18: Secretary Of Board; Duties; Seal Of Board
2-7-19: Rooms And Funds For Operation Of Boards
2-7-20: Compensation Of Secretary And Members Of Board
2-7-21: Attorney For Board
2-7-22: Application Of This Chapter
2-7-1: APPOINTMENT; TERMS OF OFFICE:
The village president shall appoint a board of fire and police commissioners.
This board shall consist of three (3) members, whose terms of office shall be
three (3) years and until their respective successors are appointed and have
qualified, except as provided in section 2-7-2 of this chapter. No such
appointment, however, shall be made by the village president within thirty (30)
days before the expiration of his term of office. (Ord. 1723, 5-12-2010)
2-7-2: FIRST APPOINTMENTS:
   (A)   Within thirty (30) days after this chapter becomes effective, the
village president, shall appoint the members of the board. One of the members
shall be appointed to serve until the end of the then current fiscal year,
another to serve until the end of the fiscal year next ensuing, and the third
to serve until the end of the fiscal year second next ensuing. But every member
shall serve until his successor is appointed and has qualified.
   (B)   Vacancies on the board of fire and police commissioners shall be
filled in the same manner as the original appointment.
   (C)   The village president shall appoint a chairman to serve during each
fiscal year.
   (D)   A majority of the board constitutes a quorum for the conduct of all
business. (Ord. 1723, 5-12-2010)
2-7-3: QUALIFICATIONS; OATH; BOND; REMOVAL:
   (A)   No person holding an office under a village, shall be a member of the
board of fire and police commissioners or the secretary thereof. The acceptance
of any such office by a member of the board shall be treated as a resignation
of his office as a member of the board or the secretary thereof.
   (B)   No person shall be appointed a member of the board of fire and police
commissioners who has been convicted of a felony under the laws of this state
or comparable laws of any other state or the United States.
   (C)   Members shall not be subject to removal, except for cause, upon
written charges, and after an opportunity to be heard within thirty (30) days
in his or their own defense, before a regular meeting of the village board. A
majority vote by a quorum of the village board shall be required to remove any
such member from office. (Ord. 1723, 5-12-2010)
2-7-4: FIRE AND POLICE DEPARTMENTS; APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS; CERTIFICATES OF
APPOINTMENTS:
   (A)   The board of fire and police commissioners shall appoint all officers
and members of the fire and police departments of the village after
authorization from the village president and board of trustees, except the
chief of police, deputy chief of police and the chief of the fire department.
   (B)   The chief of the fire department shall be appointed in accordance with
subsection 3-2-1(A) of this code.
   (C)   The chief of the police department shall be appointed in accordance
with subsection 3-1-3(A) of this code. A deputy chief of police may, but is not
required to, be appointed. If a deputy police chief is appointed, he shall be
appointed in accordance with subsection 3-1-3(B) of this code.
   (D)   The chief of the fire department, chief of the police department and
deputy chief of police may be removed or discharged by the village president,
with the advice and consent of the board of trustees.
   (E)   If a member of the department is appointed chief of police or chief of
the fire department prior to being eligible to retire on pension, he shall be
considered as on furlough from the rank he held immediately prior to his
appointment as chief. If he resigns as chief or is discharged as chief prior to
attaining eligibility to retire on pension, he shall revert to and be
established in whatever rank he currently holds, except for previously
appointed positions, and thereafter be entitled to all the benefits and
emoluments of that rank, without regard as to whether a vacancy then exists in
that rank.
   (F)   All appointments to each department other than that of the lowest rank
shall be from the rank next below that to which the appointment is made except
as otherwise provided in this section, and except that the chief of police and
the chief of the fire department may be appointed from among members of the
police and fire departments, respectively, regardless of rank. A chief of
police or the chief of the fire department, having been appointed from among
members of the police or fire department, respectively, shall be permitted,
regardless of rank, to take promotional exams and be promoted to a higher
classified rank than he currently holds, without having to resign as chief of
police or chief of the fire department.
   (G)   The sole authority to issue certificates of appointment shall be
vested in the board of fire and police commissioners and all certificates of
appointments issued to any officer or member of the fire or police department
shall be signed by the chairman and secretary of the board of fire and police
commissioners. The village of Midlothian and the board of fire and police
commissioners shall comply with section 10-2.1-4 of the Illinois municipal code
1  regarding the hiring of temporary or substitute members of the fire
department.
   (H)   The term policemen or police officer as used in this chapter does not
include auxiliary police officers except as provided for in section 2-7-6 of
this chapter.
   (I)   Pursuant to section 10-2.1-4 of the Illinois municipal code, no
firefighter appointed to the lowest rank shall serve a probationary employment
period of longer than one year. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in
this section, the probationary employment period limitation may be extended for
a firefighter who is required, as a condition of employment, to be a certified
paramedic, during which time the sole reason that a firefighter may be
discharged without a hearing is for failing to meet the requirements for
paramedic certification. (Ord. 1723, 5-12-2010)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-4.
2-7-5: RULES; PUBLICATIONS:
   (A)   The board of fire and police commissioners shall make rules to carry
out the purpose of this chapter, and for appointments and removals in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter and Illinois law. The board,
from time to time, may make changes in these rules.
   (B)   All rules and changes thereto shall be printed immediately for
distribution. The board shall give notice of the places where the printed rules
may be obtained, and of the date, not less than five (5) days subsequent to the
time of publication, when the rules or changes thereto shall go into effect.
This notice shall be published in one or more newspapers published in the
village, or in one or more newspapers with a general circulation within the
village.
   (C)   These rules of the board shall apply only to the conduct of
examinations for original appointments, for promotions, and to the conduct of
hearings on charges brought against a member of the police or fire department.
No such rule shall be made by the board to govern the operation of the police
or fire department or the conduct of its members unless the village board
specifically authorizes the board of fire and police commissioners to make such
rules; however, the village board may also rescind such authorization. (Ord.
1723, 5-12-2010)
2-7-6: EXAMINATION OF APPLICANTS; DISQUALIFICATIONS:
   (A)   Age Limitation: All applicants for a position in either the fire or
police department of the village shall be under thirty five (35) years of age,
shall be subject to an examination that shall be public, competitive, and open
to all applicants and shall be subject to reasonable limitations as to
residence, health, habits, and moral character. The village may not charge or
collect any fee from an applicant who has met all prequalification standards
established by the village for any such position. With respect to a police
department, a veteran shall be allowed to exceed the maximum age provision of
this section by the number of years served on active military duty, but by no
more than ten (10) years of active military duty.
   (B)   Age Limitation Exceptions: The age limitation in subsection (A) of
this section does not apply:
      1.   To any person previously employed as a policeman or fireman in a
regularly constituted police or fire department of:
         (a)   Any village, regardless of whether the village is located in
Illinois or in another state, or
         (b)   A fire protection district whose obligations were assumed by a
village under section 21 of the fire protection district act,
      2.   To any person who has served a village as a regularly enrolled
volunteer fireman for five (5) years immediately preceding the time that
village begins to use full time firemen to provide all or part of its fire
protection service, or
      3.   To any person who has served as an auxiliary police officer under
section 3.1-30-20 of the Illinois municipal code for at least five (5) years
and is under forty (40) years of age,
      4.   To any person who has served as a deputy under section 3-6008 of the
counties code and otherwise meets necessary training requirements, or
      5.   To any person who has served as a sworn officer as a member of the
Illinois department of state police.
   (C)   Applicants Under Twenty One Years Of Age: Applicants who are twenty
(20) years of age and who have successfully completed two (2) years of law
enforcement studies at an accredited college or university may be considered
for appointment to active duty with the police department. An applicant
described in this subsection who is appointed to active duty shall not have
power of arrest, nor shall the applicant be permitted to carry firearms, until
he or she reaches twenty one (21) years of age.
   (D)   Examinations:
      1.   The examinations shall be practical in character and relate to those
matters that will fairly test the capacity of the persons examined to discharge
the duties of the positions to which they seek appointment. No person shall be
appointed to the police or fire department if he or she does not possess a high
school diploma or an equivalent high school education. The board of fire and
police commissioners may, by its rules, require police applicants to have
obtained an associate's degree or a bachelor's degree as a prerequisite for
employment.
      2.   The examinations shall include tests of physical qualifications and
health.
      3.   The board of fire and police commissioners may, by its rules, waive
portions of the required examination for police applicants who have previously
been full time sworn officers of a regular police department in any municipal,
county, university, or state law enforcement agency, provided they are
certified by the Illinois law enforcement training standards board and have
been with their respective law enforcement agency within the state for at least
two (2) years.
      4.   No applicant shall be examined concerning his or her political or
religious opinions or affiliations.
   (E)   Conscientious Objector: No person who is classified by his local
selective service draft board as a conscientious objector, or who has ever been
so classified, may be appointed to the police department.
   (F)   Character: No person shall be appointed to the police or fire
department unless he or she is a person of good character and not a habitual
drunkard, gambler, or a person who has been convicted of a felony or a crime
involving moral turpitude. (Ord. 1723, 5-12-2010)
2-7-7: FINGERPRINTS TO BE FURNISHED:
A classifiable set of the fingerprints of every person who is now employed, or
who hereafter becomes employed, as a full time member of the fire or police
department of the village, whether with or without compensation, shall be
furnished to the Illinois department of state police and to the federal bureau
of investigation by the board of fire and police commissioners. (Ord. 1723, 5-
12-2010)
2-7-8: VETERANS AND EDUCATIONAL PREFERENCE:
   (A)   Persons who have successfully obtained an associate's degree in the
field of law enforcement, criminal justice, fire service, or emergency medical
services, or a bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university;
persons who have been awarded a certificate attesting to the successful
completion of the minimum standards basic law enforcement training course as
provided in the Illinois police training act and are currently serving as a law
enforcement officer on a part time or full time basis within the state of
Illinois; and persons who were engaged in the active military or naval service
of the United States for a period of at least one year and who were honorably
discharged therefrom, or who are now or may hereafter be on inactive or reserve
duty in such military or naval service (not including, however, in the case of
offices, positions and places of employment in the police department, persons
who were convicted by court martial of disobedience of orders, where such
disobedience consisted in the refusal to perform military service on the ground
of religious or conscientious objections against war) shall be preferred for
appointments to offices, positions, and places of employment in the fire and
police departments of the village.
   (B)   For purposes of this section, if a person has been deployed, then
active duty military or naval service of the United States includes training
and service school attendance, as defined in 10 USC 101(d), which is ordered
pursuant to 10 USC 12301(d). The preference points awarded under this section
shall not be cumulative. (Ord. 1723, 5-12-2010)
2-7-9: ORIGINAL APPOINTMENTS; PREFERENCES; LIMITATION:
   (A)   The board of fire and police commissioners shall give preference for
original appointment to persons designated in section 2-7-8 of this chapter
whose names appear on any register of eligibles resulting from an examination
for original entrance in the classified service of the fire and police
departments of the village by adding to the final grade average which they
receive or will receive as the result of any examination held for original
entrance, five (5) points. The numerical result thus attained shall be applied
by the board of fire and police commissioners in determining the position of
such persons on any eligibility list which has been created as the result of
any examination for original entrance for purposes of preference in
certification and appointment from such eligibility list.
   (B)   The board shall strike off the names of candidates for original
appointment after such names have been on the list for more than two (2) years.
(Ord. 1723, 5-12-2010)
2-7-10: PREFERENCE; TIME FOR ALLOWANCE:
A person entitled to preference or credit for military or naval service shall
be required to claim military credit for service in the armed forces before any
examination is held under the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 1723, 5-12-
2010)
2-7-11: NOTICE OF EXAMINATION:
Notice of the time and place of every examination shall be given by the board
by a publication at least two (2) weeks preceding the examination, in one or
more newspapers published in the village, or, if no newspaper is published
therein, then in one or more newspapers with a general circulation within the
village, except on promotional examinations, notice may be waived in writing by
all members of the fire or police department, for which the promotional
examination is to be given. (Ord. 1723, 5-12-2010)
2-7-12: REGISTER OF ELIGIBLES:
   (A)   Register:
      1.   The board of fire and police commissioners shall prepare and keep a
register of persons whose general average standing, upon examination, is not
less than the minimum fixed by the rules of the board, and who are otherwise
eligible. These persons shall take rank upon the register as candidates in the
order of their relative excellence as determined by examination, without
reference to priority of time of examination.
      2.   The board of fire and police commissioners may prepare and keep a
second register of persons who have previously been full time sworn officers of
a regular police department in any municipal, county, university, or state law
enforcement agency, provided they are certified by the Illinois law enforcement
training standards board and have been with their respective law enforcement
agency within the state for at least two (2) years.
      3.   The persons on the list referenced in subsection (A)2 of this
section shall take rank upon the register as candidates in the order of their
relative excellence as determined by members of the board of fire and police
commissioners. Applicants who have been awarded a certificate attesting to
their successful completion of the minimum standards basic law enforcement
training course, as provided in the Illinois police training act, may be given
preference in appointment over noncertified applicants.
      4.   Applicants for appointment to fire departments who are licensed as
an EMT-B, EMT-I, or EMT-P under the emergency medical services (EMS) systems
act, may be given preference in appointment over nonlicensed applicants.
   (B)   Eligibility List: Within sixty (60) days after each examination, an
eligibility list shall be posted by the board, which shall show the final
grades of the candidates without reference to priority of time of examination.
Appointment shall be subject to a final physical examination.
   (C)   Age Requirements: If a person is placed on an eligibility list and
becomes over age before he or she is appointed to a police or fire department,
the person remains eligible for appointment until the list is abolished
pursuant to authorized procedures. Otherwise no person who has attained the age
of thirty six (36) years shall be inducted as a member of a police department
and no person who has attained the age of thirty five (35) years shall be
inducted as a member of a fire department, except as otherwise provided in this
chapter. With respect to a police department, a veteran shall be allowed to
exceed the maximum age provision of this section by the number of years served
on active military duty, but by no more than ten (10) years of active military
duty. (Ord. 1723, 5-12-2010)
2-7-13: PROMOTIONS; MERIT; SENIORITY:
   (A)   The board of fire and police commissioners, by its rules, shall
provide for promotion in the fire and police departments on the basis of
ascertained merit and seniority in service and examination, and shall provide
in all cases, where it is practicable, that vacancies shall be filled by
promotion.
   (B)   All examinations for promotion shall be competitive among such members
of the next lower rank as desire to submit themselves to examination.
   (C)   All promotions shall be made from the three (3) having the highest
rating, as set forth in subsection (D) of this section, and where there are
less than three (3) names on the promotional eligible register, as originally
posted, or remaining thereon after appointments have been made therefrom,
appointments to fill existing vacancies shall be made from those three names
having the highest ranking remaining on the promotional register.
   (D)   The chief of the police department or chief of the fire department
shall be allowed to choose for promotion from any one of the three (3) names on
the list having the highest rating ("promotional eligible register") and such
choice shall be made based on merit and at the sole discretion of the chief of
the police department or the chief of the fire department.
   (E)   The method of examination and the rules governing examinations for
promotion shall be the same as provided for applicants for original
appointment, except that original appointments only shall be on probation, as
provided by the rules. The board shall strike off the names of candidates for
promotional appointment after they have remained thereon for more than three
(3) years. (Ord. 1723, 5-12-2010)
2-7-14: TEMPORARY APPOINTMENTS:
In order to prevent a stoppage of public business, to meet extraordinary
exigencies, or to prevent material impairment of either the police or fire
department, the board of fire and police commissioners may make temporary
appointments, to remain in force until regular appointments may be made under
the provisions of this chapter, but never to exceed one hundred eighty (180)
days. (Ord. 1723, 5-12-2010)
2-7-15: REMOVAL OR DISCHARGE; INVESTIGATION OF CHARGES; RETIREMENT:
   (A)   Except as hereinafter provided, no officer or member of the fire or
police department of the village appointed pursuant to this chapter shall be
removed or discharged except for cause, upon written charges, and after an
opportunity to be heard in his own defense.
   (B)   The hearing shall be as hereinafter provided.
   (C)   The chief of the fire department, the chief of the police department
or the deputy chief of the police department, may be removed or discharged by
the village president. In such case the village president shall file with the
village board of trustees the reasons for such removal or discharge, which
removal or discharge shall not become effective unless confirmed by a majority
vote of the corporate authorities, after fourteen (14) days' notice to the fire
chief, police chief or deputy police chief and after an opportunity for the
fire chief, police chief or deputy fire chief to be heard by the village board.
   (D)   With regard to any member of the fire department or police department
appointed pursuant to this chapter (not including the chief of the fire
department, the chief of the police department or the deputy chief of the
police department), the board of fire and police commissioners shall conduct a
fair and impartial hearing of the charges, to be commenced within thirty (30)
days of the filing thereof, which hearing may be continued from time to time
upon mutual agreement of the parties, but in no event beyond one hundred twenty
(120) days from the filing of the charges or appeal pursuant to subsection (J)1
of this section.
   (E)   In case an officer or member is found guilty, the board may discharge
him, or may suspend him not exceeding thirty (30) days without pay. The board
may suspend any officer or member pending the hearing with or without pay, but
not to exceed thirty (30) days.
   (F)   If the board of fire and police commissioners determines that the
charges are not sustained and the officer or member has been suspended pursuant
to subsection (E) of this section, the officer or member shall be reimbursed
for all wages withheld, if any.
   (G)   In the conduct of this hearing, each member of the board shall have
power to administer oaths and affirmations, and the board shall have power to
secure by its subpoena both the attendance and testimony of witnesses and the
production of books and papers relevant to the hearing.
   (H)   The age for retirement of policemen or firemen in the service of the
village is sixty five (65) years.
   (I)   The provisions of the administrative review law, and all amendments
and modifications thereto, and the rules adopted pursuant thereto, shall apply
to and govern all proceedings for the judicial review of final administrative
decisions of the board of fire and police commissioners hereunder. The term
administrative decision is defined as in section 3-101 of the code of civil
procedure.
   (J)   Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent the chief of the
fire department or the chief of the police department from suspending without
pay a member of his department for a period of not more than five (5) calendar
days, but he shall notify the board in writing of such suspension.
      1.   Any policeman or fireman so suspended may appeal to the board of
fire and police commissioners for a review of the suspension within five (5)
calendar days after such suspension, and upon such appeal, the board may
sustain the action of the chief of the department, may reverse it with
instructions that the man receive his pay for the period involved, or may
suspend the officer for an additional period of not more than thirty (30) days
or discharge him, depending upon the facts presented. (Ord. 1723, 5-12-2010)
2-7-16: FIRE OR POLICE DEPARTMENTS; REDUCTION OF FORCE; REINSTATEMENT:
   (A)   When the force of the fire department or of the police department is
reduced, and positions displaced or abolished, seniority shall prevail and the
officers and members so reduced in rank, or removed from the service of the
fire department or of the police department shall be considered furloughed
without pay from the positions from which they were reduced or removed.
   (B)   Such reductions and removals shall be in strict compliance with
seniority and in no event shall any officer or member be reduced more than one
rank in a reduction of force. Officers and members with the least seniority in
the position to be reduced shall be reduced to the next lower rated position.
For purposes of determining which officers and members will be reduced in rank,
seniority shall be determined by adding the time spent at the rank or position
from which the officer or member is to be reduced and the time spent at any
higher rank or position in the department.
   (C)   For purposes of determining which officers or members in the lowest
rank or position shall be removed from the department in the event of a layoff,
length of service in the department shall be the basis for determining
seniority, with the least senior such officer or member being the first so
removed and laid off. Such officers or members laid off shall have their names
placed on an appropriate reemployment list in the reverse order of dates of
layoff.
   (D)   If any positions which have been vacated because of reduction in
forces or displacement and abolition of positions, are reinstated, such members
and officers of the fire department or of the police department as are
furloughed from the said positions shall be notified by the board by certified
mail of such reinstatement of positions and shall have prior right to such
positions if otherwise qualified, and in all cases seniority shall prevail.
Written application for such reinstated position must be made by the furloughed
person within thirty (30) days after notification as above provided and such
person may be required to submit to examination by physicians of both the board
of fire and police commissioners and the appropriate pension board to determine
his physical fitness. (Ord. 1723, 5-12-2010)
2-7-17: ANNUAL REPORT; BUDGET REQUEST:
At any time the village president or the village board request, the board of
fire and police commissioners shall submit to the village president a report of
its activities, and of the rules in force and the practical effect thereof. In
this report, the board of fire and police commissioners may make suggestions
which the board of fire and police commissioners believes would result in
greater efficiency in the fire or police department. The board of fire and
police commissioners shall also submit an annual budget request to the
municipal governing body prior to the end of each fiscal year. The village
president shall transmit the report to the board of trustees. (Ord. 1723, 5-12-
2010)
2-7-18: SECRETARY OF BOARD; DUTIES; SEAL OF BOARD:
The board of fire and police commissioners may employ a secretary, or may
designate one of its own members to act as secretary. The secretary shall keep
the minutes of the board's proceedings, shall be the custodian of all records
pertaining to the business of the board, shall keep a record of all
examinations held, shall perform all other duties the board of fire and police
commissioners prescribes, and shall be custodian of the seal of the board of
fire and police commissioners, if one has been adopted. (Ord. 1723, 5-12-2010)
2-7-19: ROOMS AND FUNDS FOR OPERATION OF BOARDS:
The corporate authorities shall provide suitable rooms for the board of fire
and police commissioners, and shall allow reasonable use of public buildings
for holding examinations by the board of fire and police commissioners and
shall further provide adequate funds in the annual appropriation ordinance for
the operation of the board of fire and police commissioners. (Ord. 1723, 5-12-
2010)
2-7-20: COMPENSATION OF SECRETARY AND MEMBERS OF BOARD:
The corporate authorities may fix compensation to be paid to the members of the
board of fire and police commissioners, but until the corporate authorities
make such provision, the members of the board shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 1723, 5-12-2010)
2-7-21: ATTORNEY FOR BOARD:
The village attorney shall serve to prosecute charges brought by the chief of
the fire department or the chief of the police department and shall also serve
to defend appeals brought pursuant to subsection 2-7-15(J)1 of this chapter.
The board of fire and police commissioners shall retain, hire and employ an
attorney of its own choosing to represent the board of fire and police
commissioners in disciplinary proceedings brought under this chapter. (Ord.
1723, 5-12-2010)
2-7-22: APPLICATION OF THIS CHAPTER:
The provisions of this chapter shall apply only to full time firemen and full
time policemen and not to any other personnel of any kind or description. (Ord.
1723, 5-12-2010)
CHAPTER 8
FLOOD CONTROL COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-8-1: Commission Created
2-8-2: Members Of Commission
2-8-3: Powers And Duties Of The Commission
2-8-1: COMMISSION CREATED:
A village flood control commission is hereby created. (Ord. 955, 7-25-1979)
2-8-2: MEMBERS OF COMMISSION:
The flood control commission shall consist of the following: the chairman shall
be the village trustee in charge of building; the other members shall be the
building commissioner, the chairman of the planning commission, the
superintendent of public works, the village engineer and any other persons or
consultants deemed necessary by the village president. (Ord. 955, 7-25-1979)
2-8-3: POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION:
The flood control commission shall have the following powers and duties:
   (A)   To review and hear requests for variations from the regulatory
standards of the flood control ordinance and make recommendations to the
village board and to comply with the requirements of the flood control
ordinance 1 .
   (B)   To review any building permit application for structures within the
regulatory flood area as shown on the flood hazard boundary map and to ensure
compliance with the terms of the ordinance.
   (C)   To review and make recommendations to the village board regarding
requests for channel straightening.
   (D)   To review and make recommendations to the village board on special use
permit applications.
   (E)   To interpret the flood hazard maps and critical elevations.
   (F)   To initiate or require investigations to verify or change, if
necessary, official maps and profiles and to make recommendations for necessary
changes.
   (G)   To review for completeness and accuracy submittal of required flood
data for subdivision as regards flood hazard protection.
   (H)   To review or investigate such other flood control matters as may from
time to time be requested by the village board.
   (I)   To keep all records and to review all documents as required by the
village flood control ordinance.
   (J)   The commission shall be responsible for the proper administration of
the flood control ordinance and shall keep appropriate minutes.
   (K)   The commission shall have authority to make inspections and to require
petitioners or applicants to provide any documentation deemed necessary by the
board or required by the flood control ordinance. (Ord. 955, 7-25-1979)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 12, chapter 2 of this code.
CHAPTER 9
MIDLOTHIAN LODGE BOARD
SECTION:
2-9-1: Board Established; Members
2-9-2: Manager; Leases
2-9-3: Powers And Duties
2-9-1: BOARD ESTABLISHED; MEMBERS:
A "Midlothian Lodge board" is hereby established. The board shall consist of
seven (7) members who shall be appointed by the village president and approved
by the village board of trustees. The village president shall appoint a
chairman to serve for three (3) years. Three (3) members shall be appointed to
serve two (2) year terms and three (3) members shall be appointed to serve a
one year term. There shall be no pay for the board members. The board shall
adopt its own rules of procedure and shall appoint one of its members as
secretary to keep records and minutes. (Ord. 1024, 2-10-1982)
2-9-2: MANAGER; LEASES:
The village president may appoint a full or part time manager to run the events
of the Midlothian Lodge and said manager may approve the standard leases for
the use of the premises. All leases must be on an approved village form. All
leases must be sponsored by a legal homeowner in the village. Any lease for
more than two (2) nights must be approved by the village president. Any
extraordinary or unusual lease shall require the review of the village board of
trustees and the approval of the village president. (Ord. 1024, 2-10-1982)
2-9-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The manager shall report to the Midlothian Lodge board and said manager shall
make recommendations on return of deposits to lessee. Said board shall review
procedures for the day to day operation and maintenance of the building,
property and parking lot. The Midlothian Lodge board shall make recommendations
to the village board on any unusual or extraordinary leases and shall provide
input to the village board on any remodeling or revisions to the building or
for any contracts which are to be signed. All expenditures of funds and all
contracts must be approved by the village board. All rental payments and
deposits must be made at the village hall. (Ord. 1024, 2-10-1982)
CHAPTER 10
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY
SECTION:
2-10-1: Establishment
2-10-2: Purpose
2-10-3: Functions
2-10-4: Coordinator
2-10-5: Location Of Office
2-10-6: Oath
2-10-7: Emergency
2-10-8: Ability To Negotiate Mutual Aid Agreements
2-10-9: Authority To Contract And Purchase In Event Of Disaster
2-10-10: Mobile Support Team
2-10-11: Reimbursement By State For Expenses Of EMA Members
2-10-12: Compensation Of Members Called For Training
2-10-13: Appropriation/Levy Of Taxes
2-10-14: Acceptance Of Gifts
2-10-15: Utilization Of Existing Agency, Facility And Personnel
2-10-1: ESTABLISHMENT:
Pursuant to the authority granted by the Illinois emergency management agency
act, there is hereby created an emergency management agency ("EMA") for the
village. The EMA shall subsume and perform all of the duties of the previously
designated emergency services and disaster agency ("ESDA") of the village.
(Ord. 1907, 11-11-2015)
2-10-2: PURPOSE:
The purpose of the EMA is to prevent, minimize, repair and alleviate injury or
damage resulting from disaster caused by enemy attack, sabotage, other hostile
action or natural causes or manmade disasters. (Ord. 1907, 11-11-2015)
2-10-3: FUNCTIONS:
The EMA shall perform such EMA functions within the village as shall be
prescribed in and by the Illinois emergency management agency (IEMA) plan and
program prepared by the IEMA and such orders, rules and regulations as may be
promulgated by the IEMA and village ordinances. In addition, the EMA shall
perform such duties outside the corporate limits of the village as may be
required pursuant to any mutual aid agreement with any other political
subdivision, municipality or taxing district entered into as provided by the
Illinois emergency management agency act. (Ord. 1907, 11-11-2015)
2-10-4: COORDINATOR:
A coordinator of EMA shall be appointed by the village president, and shall
serve for a period of one year, commencing May 1 of each year, or until a
successor shall be appointed or until he is relieved of his duties by the
village president. In the event of the absence, resignation, death or inability
of the coordinator to serve, the village president or any person designated by
him shall be and act as coordinator until a new appointment is made as provided
in this section. The coordinator of the EMA shall have the direct
responsibility for the organization, administration, training and operation of
the EMA, subject to the direction and control of the village president as
provided by statute. (Ord. 1907, 11-11-2015)
2-10-5: LOCATION OF OFFICE:
The office space to be occupied by the EMA shall be designated by the village
president in the village hall or elsewhere in facilities under the jurisdiction
of the village. (Ord. 1907, 11-11-2015)
2-10-6: OATH:
Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the EMA shall before
entering upon his/her duties, subscribe to an oath which shall be filed with
the coordinator of the EMA. Such oath shall be in substantially the following
form:
I                     , do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and
defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United
States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory,
institutions and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all
enemies, foreign and domestic; that I take this obligation freely, without any
mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully
discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter.
And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate nor am I, nor have I
ever been, a member of a political party or organization that advocates the
overthrow of the government of the United States or of this State by force or
violence, and that during such time as I am affiliated with the Village of
Midlothian EMA, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party
or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United
States or of this State by force or violence.
(Ord. 1907, 11-11-2015)
2-10-7: EMERGENCY:
If the governor declares that a disaster emergency exists in the event of
actual enemy attack upon the United States or in the event of a major disaster
within the state resulting from enemy sabotage, other hostile action or from
natural causes, it shall be the duty of the EMA to cooperate fully with
municipal officials, with the state IEMA as the governor in the exercise of
emergency powers, as provided by law. (Ord. 1907, 11-11-2015)
2-10-8: ABILITY TO NEGOTIATE MUTUAL AID AGREEMENTS:
The coordinator of the EMA may negotiate mutual aid agreements with other
municipal corporations, political subdivisions, and taxing districts, but no
such agreement shall be effective until it has been approved by the corporate
authorities of each of the participating municipalities, political subdivisions
or taxing districts. (Ord. 1907, 11-11-2015)
2-10-9: AUTHORITY TO CONTRACT AND PURCHASE IN EVENT OF DISASTER:
In the event of enemy caused or natural disaster, the coordinator is authorized
on behalf of the village, subject to the approval of the village president, to
procure such services, supplies, equipment or material as may be necessary for
the purposes stated in this section in view of the exigency, without regard to
the statutory procedures or formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining
to municipal contracts or to the statutory procedures or formalities normally
prescribed by law pertaining to municipal contracts or obligations, as
authorized by the Illinois emergency management agency act. However, if the
village board meets at the time of such disaster, the coordinator's action
shall be subject to the directions and restrictions imposed by the village
board.
The village president or, in his absence, the president pro tempore, may on
recommendation of the coordinator of the EMA, authorize any purchase or
contract necessary to place the village in a position to effectively combat any
disaster, to protect the public health and safety, to protect property and to
provide emergency assistance to victims, whether such disaster results from the
explosion of any nuclear or other bomb or missile or from any natural cause or
manmade disasters. (Ord. 1907, 11-11-2015)
2-10-10: MOBILE SUPPORT TEAM:
All members of the EMA may be designated as members of a mobile support team
created by the state director of IEMA. The leader of such mobile support team
shall be designated by the coordinator of the EMA. Any member of a mobile
support team is a municipal employee or officer while serving on call to duty
by the governor or the director of IEMA and shall receive the compensation and
have the powers, duties, rights and immunities incident to such employee or
office. Any such member who is not a paid officer or employee of the
municipality while so serving shall receive from the state such reasonable
compensation as is or may be provided by law. (Ord. 1907, 11-11-2015)
2-10-11: REIMBURSEMENT BY STATE FOR EXPENSES OF EMA MEMBERS:
The village treasurer, or any person fulfilling his duties, may receive and
allocate to the appropriate funds any reimbursement by the state to the village
for expenses incident to training members of the EMA or for compensation for
services and expenses of members of a mobile support team while serving outside
of the village in response to a call by the governor or director of IEMA, as
provided by law, and any reimbursement made by the state incident to EMA
activities, as provided by law. (Ord. 1907, 11-11-2015)
2-10-12: COMPENSATION OF MEMBERS CALLED FOR TRAINING:
The members of the EMA who are paid employees or officers of the village, if
called for training by the director of IEMA, shall receive for time spent in
such training the same rate of pay as is attached to the position held in the
village. Members of the EMA who are not such municipal employees or officers
shall receive for such training time such compensation as may be established by
the board of trustees. (Ord. 1907, 11-11-2015)
2-10-13: APPROPRIATION/LEVY OF TAXES:
The village board may make appropriations for emergency services and disaster
operations in the manner provided by law for making appropriations for the
ordinary expenses of EMA. The board of trustees may also levy for emergency
services and disaster operations a tax not to exceed 0.05 percent of the full,
fair cash value as equalized or assessed on all taxable property in the village
for the current year. However, the amount collectible under such a levy shall
in no event exceed twenty five cents ($0.25) per capita. The annual tax shall
be in addition to and in excess of the amount authorized to be levied for
general corporate purposes. (Ord. 1907, 11-11-2015)
2-10-14: ACCEPTANCE OF GIFTS:
Whenever the federal or state governments, or any agency or officer thereof, or
whenever any person, firm or corporation shall offer to the village services,
equipment, supplies, materials or funds by way of gift or grant for purposes of
emergency management, the village, acting through the village president or the
board of trustees, may accept such offer and upon such acceptance the village
president or the board of trustees may authorize any officer of the village to
receive such services, equipment, supplies, materials or funds on behalf of the
village. (Ord. 1907, 11-11-2015)
2-10-15: UTILIZATION OF EXISTING AGENCY, FACILITY AND PERSONNEL:
In carrying out the provisions of this chapter, the coordinator is directed to
utilize the services, equipment, supplies and facilities of existing village
departments, offices and agencies to the maximum extent practicable, and the
officers and personnel of all such departments, offices and agencies are
directed, upon request, to cooperate and extend such services and facilities to
the coordinator and the EMA. (Ord. 1907, 11-11-2015)
CHAPTER 11
RESERVED
(Ord. 1936, 7-20-2016)
CHAPTER 12
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMITTEE
SECTION:
2-12-1: Economic Development Committee Established
2-12-2: Appointment
2-12-3: Terms Of Office
2-12-4: Meetings
2-12-5: Compensation
2-12-6: Duties
2-12-7: Ethics And Conflict Of Interest
2-12-8: Penalties
2-12-1: ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMITTEE ESTABLISHED:
A Midlothian economic development committee is hereby established for the
purpose of promoting and encouraging quality economic development within the
village. (Ord. 1364, 9-13-1995)
2-12-2: APPOINTMENT:
Membership of the economic development committee shall be composed of seven (7)
members, two (2) of whom shall be Village Trustees and five (5) public members.
The public members shall be composed of three (3) residents of the village and
two (2) owners of businesses in the Village who need not be residents. The
Chairperson and the six (6) other members of the committee shall be appointed
by the President of the Village with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees. (Ord. 1703, 9-9-2009; amd. Ord. 2099, 5-11-2022)
2-12-3: TERMS OF OFFICE:
All members of the committee shall serve for a term of one year or until a
successor has been duly appointed and qualified, and any vacancies which shall
occur shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. (Ord.
1364, 9-13-1995)
2-12-4: MEETINGS:
Meetings of the economic development committee shall be every other month or as
necessary to complete the business of the committee and shall be noticed and
conducted in compliance with the requirements of the Illinois Open Meetings
Act. (Ord. 2099, 5-11-2022)
2-12-5: COMPENSATION:
Upon application to and approval of the Village Clerk, qualified resident
members of the economic development committee that serve for the entire one-
year term shall be eligible to receive one complimentary Village of Midlothian
Vehicle License for each year of service as compensation. (Ord. 1364, 9-13-
1995; amd. Ord. 2099, 5-11-2022)
2-12-6: DUTIES:
The duties of the committee shall include the following:
   (A)   Development of a villagewide marketing strategy for undeveloped
business properties, including the development of promotional material.
   (B)   Meet with owners of undeveloped business property to determine ways in
which the village can assist them in marketing of the property.
   (C)   Advise the board on whether or not the employment of a professional
marketing consultant is necessary to accomplish quality economic development.
   (D)   Assist property owners in finding tenants for vacant businesses.
   (E)   Meet with businesses that are considering leaving the community to
encourage them to remain in the village and to identify if there is any action
that can or should be taken to assist them.
   (F)   Study the conditions and trends of development, advise the village
board of its growth and potential.
   (G)   Work closely with the Midlothian area chamber of commerce to
accomplish the above items.
   (H)   The committee may also be given other duties by the president of the
board of trustees to help the committee coordinate their efforts with the
village board and other community groups. (Ord. 1364, 9-13-1995)
2-12-7: ETHICS AND CONFLICT OF INTEREST:
All members of the economic development committee, whether voting members or
nonvoting members, shall be governed by the following rules or ordinances:
   (A)   Ethics: The ethics ordinance contained in title 1, chapter 19 of this
code shall apply to all members of the economic development committee, whether
the member is a voting or nonvoting member. The penalties for the violation of
the village ethics ordinance shall be those set forth in the ethics ordinance
in section 1-19-8 of this code.
   (B)   Conflict Of Interest: No member of the economic development committee
shall engage in a conflict of interest with regard to his or her duties as a
member of the economic development committee. Matters that will be considered
to be a conflict of interest include, but are not limited to, the following:
      1.   The use of documents, data or any information that has not been
communicated to the public for a member's personal advantage, benefit or use.
      2.   The use of documents, data or any information that has not been
communicated to the public for a member's relative's personal advantage,
benefit or use.
      3.   The use of documents, data or any information that has not been
communicated to the public for the benefit of any third party, even if the
member does not benefit from such use of documents, data or other information
that has not been communicated to the public.
      4.   The use of documents, data or any information that has not been
communicated to the public for the benefit of any third party's relative, even
if the member does not benefit from such use of documents, data or any other
information that has not been communicated to the public.
      5.   The representation of, acting as agent of, or in any other manner
assisting a client, customer or other individual with whom a member has a
business relationship and which is adverse to the interests of the village or
which utilizes documents, data or any information that has not been
communicated to the public.
      6.   The representation of, acting as agent of, or in any other manner
assisting a business in which a member has any type of an ownership or
financial interest and which is adverse to the interests of the village or
which utilizes documents, data or any information that has not been
communicated to the public.
      7.   A member shall not enter into a business transaction utilizing data
or information which has not been made available to the general public by
acquiring an ownership, possessory, security or other pecuniary interest in a
business entity, parcel of real estate, or otherwise.
      8.   A member shall not provide financial assistance with regard to any
matter that has come before the economic development committee and which would
benefit the member, a member's relative, a business entity in which the member
has an interest, or any other third party, including one whom the member may
represent or act as an agent.
      9.   Any act or omission in which the member behaves or acts
inconsistently with his or her duties as a member of the economic development
committee or in which the member could be said to be acting in a dual capacity.
(Ord. 1703, 9-9-2009)
2-12-8: PENALTIES:
The penalties for violation of section 2-12-7 of this chapter shall be one or
more of the following:
   (A)   The member shall be removed by the president from the economic
development committee; and/or
   (B)   The penalties provided under section 1-19-8 of this code. (Ord. 1703,
9-9-2009)
TITLE 3
DEPARTMENTS
