CHAPTER 1
POLICE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
3-1-1: Department Established
3-1-2: Authorized Positions
3-1-3: Appointments To Sworn Positions
3-1-4: Duties Of Chief Of Police
3-1-5: Duties Of Deputy Chief Of Police
3-1-6: Custodian Of Seized Property; Record
3-1-7: Seized Property; Proceeds From Sale
3-1-8: Seized Weapons; Sale Forbidden
3-1-9: Duties Of Members
3-1-10: Arrests
3-1-11: Service Of Warrants
3-1-12: Assistance To The Fire Department
3-1-13: Part Time Police Officers
3-1-14: Auxiliary Police Officers
3-1-15: Police Pension Fund
3-1-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a Police Department of the Village for the
protection of lives and property within the limits of the Village, the
enforcement of Federal and State Statutes and Village ordinances, and related
police functions. (Ord. 1541, 6-12-2002)
3-1-2: AUTHORIZED POSITIONS:
   (A)   The Village President and the Board of Trustees shall, from time to
time, determine the number of police officers and civilian employees necessary
for the effective operation of the Police Department, and the Police Department
shall have the following authorized positions:
      1.   Chief of Police.
      2.   Administrative Aide to the Chief of Police (civilian position).
      3.   Deputy Chief of Police.
      4.   Lieutenant.
      5.   Sergeant.
      6.   Patrol officer.
      7.   Part time police officers.
      8.   Auxiliary police officers. (Ord. 1803, 9-12-2012)
3-1-3: APPOINTMENTS TO SWORN POSITIONS:
   (A)   The Chief of Police shall be appointed by the Village President, with
the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, for a term of one year unless
the Village Board authorizes the Village President to sign a contract with the
Chief for a longer period of time. The Chief may be removed by the Village
President upon the Village President filing with the Corporate Authorities the
reasons for such removal or discharge, which removal or discharge shall not
become effective unless confirmed by a majority vote of the Corporate
Authorities. If the Chief of Police holds a rank or position attained under the
Board of Police and Fire Commissioners, he shall revert to the rank or position
if he is not reappointed Chief of Police upon the expiration of his term or if
he resigns as Chief or is discharged as Chief prior to obtaining eligibility to
retire on pension. (Ord. 1803, 9-12-2012)
   (B)   The Deputy Chief of Police shall be appointed by the Chief of Police
from any rank of sworn, full time officer with at least five (5) years of full
time service as a police officer in the State of Illinois. The Deputy Chief of
Police's position shall be an exempt rank immediately below that of Chief. He
shall serve at the discretion of the Chief of Police and, if removed from the
position, shall revert to the rank held immediately prior to the appointment to
the Deputy Chief position. (Ord. 1964, 10-11-2017)
   (C)   The Administrative Aide to the Chief of Police shall be appointed by
the Chief of Police and the position shall be a civilian position. The
Administrative Aide to the Chief of Police's position shall be an exempt
position. He shall serve at the discretion of the Chief of Police. The
Administrative Aide shall have those duties assigned from time to time by the
Chief of Police.
   (D)   All original sworn appointments (except part time police officers and
auxiliary police officers) to the police department and promotions within the
department, other than the chief of police, deputy chief of police and
administrative aide to the chief of police shall be made and effected by the
board of fire and police commissioners as prescribed by village ordinance or
state statute. (Ord. 1803, 9-12-2012)
3-1-4: DUTIES OF CHIEF OF POLICE:
The police chief shall be responsible for the performance of the police
department, and all persons who are members of the police department shall
serve subject to the orders of the chief of police. He shall perform those
duties prescribed by the rules and regulations governing the police department,
as approved by the village president and board of trustees, and shall in
addition perform the following duties:
   (A)   Be the keeper of the village jail and have custody of all persons
incarcerated therein.
   (B)   Keep such books and records and make such reports concerning the
activities of his department as may be required by statute or by the village
president and board of trustees.
   (C)   Provide for the custody, care and control of the public property of
the police department, including all vehicles, firearms and other equipment.
   (D)   Preserve the peace, order and safety of the village.
   (E)   Execute and enforce the state and federal laws, all village
ordinances, police regulations and orders of the village president and board of
trustees.
   (F)   Protect the rights of persons and property within the village.
   (G)   Appoint the deputy police chief and provide for his duties.
   (H)   Promulgate rules and regulations for the conduct and guidance of the
members of the department. (Ord. 1541, 6-12-2002)
3-1-5: DUTIES OF DEPUTY CHIEF OF POLICE:
The deputy chief of police shall have those duties assigned from time to time
by the chief of police. (Ord. 1748, 4-13-2011)
3-1-6: CUSTODIAN OF SEIZED PROPERTY; RECORD:
The chief of police shall act as custodian of all property seized or taken by
the police.
All members of the department into whose possession may come any property
seized or taken shall deliver the same at once to the chief of police.
The chief of police shall keep a record of all property which may be seized or
otherwise taken possession of by the police department. If such property shall
not be claimed by the rightful owner thereof and possession surrendered to the
owners within sixty (60) days from the date of the final disposition of the
court proceedings in connection with which such property was seized or
otherwise taken possession of, or, in case there are no such court proceedings,
then if such property shall not be claimed by the rightful owner thereof and
possession surrendered to the owner within sixty (60) days of the date of such
seizure or taking by the police, the chief of police shall cause to be
published in a local newspaper a description thereof, together with the date of
seizure and shall give notice that if the property be not claimed by the
rightful owner thereof within ten (10) days of the date of publication such
property will be sold at public auction at such place as the chief of police
may direct and in such manner as to expose to the inspection of bidders all
property so offered for sale; provided, that the unclaimed property, if deemed
by the chief of police to be of use to the department may be retained for the
use of the department; and provided further, that no member of the department,
directly or indirectly, shall purchase such unclaimed property.
If any property so seized or taken shall be of perishable nature or so bulky or
of such a nature as to make it dangerous or inadvisable to retain possession
thereof for the length of time herein set forth, the chief of police, with the
approval of the chairman of the committee on public safety, may cause such
property to be advertised immediately and shall sell the property at public
auction at any time after three (3) days shall have elapsed from the seizure or
taking thereof, but no sooner than three (3) days after advertising the same.
(Ord. 1541, 6-12-2002)
3-1-7: SEIZED PROPERTY; PROCEEDS FROM SALE:
The proceeds of any such sale after deducting the costs and expenses incident
thereto shall be paid to the police association or as directed by the village
board. (Ord. 1541, 6-12-2002)
3-1-8: SEIZED WEAPONS; SALE FORBIDDEN:
None of the provisions of section 3-1-6 of this chapter shall apply to pistols,
revolvers, knives, metallic knuckles or other deadly weapons of like character.
These items shall be kept or disposed of or destroyed as directed by a court
order. (Ord. 1541, 6-12-2002)
3-1-9: DUTIES OF MEMBERS:
It shall be the duty of the members of the police department to see to the
enforcement of all the ordinances of the village, federal and state laws and
statutes applicable therein, to preserve order, and to prevent infractions of
the law and arrest violators thereof. Each member shall obey the orders and
directions of his or her superior officer and shall perform the duties as
prescribed by the rules and regulations governing the police department. (Ord.
1541, 6-12-2002)
3-1-10: ARRESTS:
Police officers are conservators of the peace and shall have power to arrest,
with or without process, all persons found violating any village ordinance or
any state or federal law or statute. (Ord. 1541, 6-12-2002)
3-1-11: SERVICE OF WARRANTS:
All warrants for the violation of village ordinances or the state criminal law,
directed to any person, may be served and executed within the limits of the
village by any police officer of the village. (Ord. 1541, 6-12-2002)
3-1-12: ASSISTANCE TO THE FIRE DEPARTMENT:
It shall be the duty of police officers of the village to aid the fire
department by giving alarm in case of fire and by clearing the streets or
grounds in the immediate vicinity of a fire, so that members of the fire
department shall not be hindered or obstructed in the performance of their
duties. (Ord. 1541, 6-12-2002)
3-1-13: PART TIME POLICE OFFICERS:
   (A)   The village of Midlothian may employ part time police officers from
time to time as it deems necessary.
   (B)   A part time police officer shall have all the responsibilities of a
full time police officer and such specific duties as delineated in the general
orders of the village of Midlothian police department, but the number of hours
a part time officer may work within a calendar year is restricted. Part time
police officers shall not be assigned to supervise or direct full time police
officers. Part time police officers shall be trained in accordance with the
Illinois police training act 1  and the rules and requirements of the ILETSB.
   (C)   All applicants for the position of part time police officer must
comply with all state laws requiring certification standards and must meet the
following hiring standards of the village:
      1.   Must be at least twenty one (21) years of age.
      2.   Must be a high school graduate or equivalent.
      3.   Must provide a certified physician's statement of good health.
      4.   Must possess a valid Illinois driver's license and have a good
driving record.
      5.   Must pass an oral interview with the chief of police or his
designee.
      6.   Need not be a resident of Midlothian but must live within the limits
of the boundaries set out in police union contract.
      7.   Must be in good physical shape and pass the state of Illinois POWER
test.
      8.   Must be able to qualify with a firearm and pass the required firearm
training course certified by the state.
      9.   Must be able to complete the mandatory police training required by
the state and pass the final test for certification by the state or receive a
waiver from the Illinois law enforcement training and standard board for prior
training or experience.
      10.   Must be of good character and pass a background investigation.
      11.   Must not have been convicted of any felony or other crime of moral
turpitude.
      12.   Must have fingerprints submitted to the state and FBI for purposes
of checking criminal history record.
      13.   Must pass any physical, written, lie detector or psychological
tests required by the village.
      14.   Any individual who has served in the U.S. military must have been
honorably discharged.
   (D)   All applicants must be approved by the village president with the
advice and consent of the village board.
   (E)   All salaries are to be set by the village board.
   (F)   Any part time police officer who is terminated or leaves the position
within three (3) years of passing all hiring standards for the position of part
time police officer for the village must reimburse the village for all training
costs and expenses incurred by the village during said time. If any funds are
due the officer they may be used by the village to pay a portion or all of the
training funds.
   (G)   Part time officers shall be under the disciplinary jurisdiction of the
chief of police. Part time police officers shall comply with all applicable
rules and general orders issued by the police department.
   (H)   A part time police officer has no vested interest in the position and
the village may discipline or discharge a part time officer at any time. A part
time officer shall be a member of the regular police department except for
pension purposes. They shall not be assigned to supervise or direct full time
police officers of the police department and they shall not be used as
permanent replacements for permanent full time police officers.
   (I)   Initial appointment as a part time police officer is to the position
of "probationary" part time police officer. This means a recruit, a part time
police officer, who is required to successfully complete the state mandated
certification standards as well as the minimum standards set forth in this
section. (Ord. 1787, 6-13-2012)
 
Notes
1 1. 50 ILCS 705/1 et seq.
3-1-14: AUXILIARY POLICE OFFICERS:
   (A)   The chief of police may appoint auxiliary police officers from time to
time as he or she deems necessary.
   (B)   Auxiliary police officers shall not be conservators of the peace and
shall only carry firearms while on duty, with the permission of the chief of
police, and only after completing the state certified forty (40) hour mandatory
firearms training as provided under 50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 710/2, as
amended.
   (C)   Auxiliary police officers shall only be assigned to perform the
following duties in the village of Midlothian:
      1.   To aid or direct traffic within the municipality;
      2.   To aid in control of natural or manmade disasters; and
      3.   To aid in case of civil disorder as directed by the chief of police.
   (D)   Auxiliary police officers shall, at all times during the performance
of their duties, be subject to the direction and control of the chief of
police.
   (E)   Auxiliary officers shall be under the disciplinary jurisdiction of the
chief of police. Auxiliary police officers shall serve at the discretion of the
mayor and the board of trustees, shall not have any property rights in said
employment, and may be removed by the chief of police, mayor and/or the board
of trustees at any time.
   (F)   Identification symbols and collar brass, worn by the auxiliary police
officers shall be different and distinct from those used by the regular police
department. (Ord. 1803, 9-12-2012)
3-1-15: POLICE PENSION FUND:
The provisions of "an act to provide for the setting apart, formation and
disbursement of a police pension fund in cities, villages and incorporated
towns having a population of not more than 200,000 inhabitants approved June
14, 1909, as amended by an act approved July 17, 1959", is hereby adopted by
the village, and the village shall take such steps as may be necessary to
comply with the provisions thereof. (Ord. 1803, 9-12-2012)
CHAPTER 2
FIRE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:

3-2-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a fire department for the village, the equipment of
which shall be used and managed by full time and by volunteer fire companies,
and which may consist of a chief of the fire department, chief emeritus and the
following volunteer officers: four (4) deputy chiefs, two (2) captains, four
(4) lieutenants, a chief of the fire prevention bureau and such other
assistants and firefighters as may, from time to time, be appointed by the
village board.
   (A)   1. A chief of the fire department, who within seven (7) months of his
official retirement, takes his vacation/due time until his actual retirement
date, may be appointed chief emeritus by the village president with the advice
and consent of the board of trustees. The duties of the chief emeritus shall be
to provide counsel and guidance to the new chief of the fire department. The
chief emeritus will be entitled to his normal pay until his actual retirement
date, and nothing in this section affects his pensions or retirement benefits.
Upon retirement the position of said chief emeritus shall end. If a chief
emeritus is appointed, the president of the village board with the advice and
consent of the board of trustees shall appoint a new chief of the fire
department, and he shall have all the duties and powers as set forth in the
state statutes and village ordinances.
      2.   The chief of the fire department shall be appointed by the
president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, for a term of
one year. If the fire chief holds a rank or position attained under the board
of fire and police commissioners, he shall revert to that rank or position if
he is not reappointed chief of the fire department upon the expiration of his
term.
      3.   Upon recommendation of the fire chief, the deputy chiefs of the fire
department shall be appointed by the president upon the advice and consent of
the board of trustees for a term of one year. If a deputy chief holds a
volunteer rank of captain or lieutenant, he shall revert to that rank or
position if he is not reappointed deputy chief of the fire department upon the
expiration of his term. (Ord. 1339, 11-9-1994)
   (B)   Volunteer officer appointments of captain and lieutenant shall be made
as follows: With the consent of the president and board of trustees competitive
written examinations shall be given to the rank below. To the examination score
the board of officers shall add the individual's annual "proficiency" rating.
The criteria for the annual proficiency rating shall include, but not be
limited to, their most recent annual percentage of: 1) responses to alarms, 2)
attendance at drills and training, and 3) completion of duty assignments.
   The examination score plus the annual proficiency rating shall produce a
"gains" score. To this gains score the board of officers shall add an
"efficiency" rating. The efficiency rating shall be on a scale of one to ten
(10). Criteria to be used in determining the efficiency rating shall include,
but not be limited to, character, work performance, ability to learn, job
knowledge, loyalty, displays initiative and leadership, oral and written
communication skills, uses good judgment and ability to make sound decisions.
   The proficiency rating and the efficiency ratings shall be determined by the
board of officers before the written examination is taken. After the efficiency
rating has been added to the gains score it shall produce a final grade which
shall be used for the ranking on the promotion list. Once the list is
established the complete list and the proposed names for promotion shall be
submitted by the fire chief to the president and board of trustees for their
approval of those to be promoted. The promotion list shall be valid for two (2)
years.
   The volunteer officers may be made up of both volunteers and/or full time
members of the department. If full time officers are required by the president
and board of trustees, they shall advise the board of fire and police
commissioners to conduct the necessary tests required by state statute. This
chapter shall not affect the existing rank of the current volunteer officers.
   (C)   Regular full time firemen and officers may be appointed by the board
of fire and police commissioners after authorization has been received from the
village president and board of trustees to conduct the necessary tests. (Ord.
1153, 5-25-1988)
   (D)   The chief of the fire department with the approval of the village
board, may set up a program for cadet firefighters of the Midlothian fire
department. A group of young adults will consist of applicants fifteen (15)
years of age and not more than eighteen (18) years of age, who would be
eligible for membership. The objectives of the organization will be to prepare
its members to become regular members of the Midlothian fire department by: 1)
participating in all training sessions, meetings, and other fire department
activities; 2) performing all duties and responsibilities that may be required;
3) abiding by all rules and regulations of the Midlothian fire department and
cadet program; and 4) creating good fellowship towards all men. The chief of
the department, with the approval of the village board, shall establish a
constitution and bylaws of the Midlothian fire department cadet program, which
constitution and bylaws may be amended from time to time by the chief with the
approval and consent of the Midlothian village board. (Ord. 1382, 1-24-1996)
3-2-2: DUTIES OF CHIEF:
The chief of the fire department (subject to the authority of the president and
board of trustees) shall have complete command and control of the department
and all members thereof. He has the right to delegate to others duties as he
deems appropriate. He shall have the general care and custody of all apparatus,
equipment and all other property of the department, and shall personally attend
to any and all repairs required to be made upon same. (Ord. 1153, 5-25-1988)
3-2-3: COMMAND AT FIRES:
The fire chief shall respond to all fires occurring within the village and take
command of the organization and see that the members of the fire department
faithfully perform their respective duties. (Ord. 1153, 5-25-1988)
3-2-4: DEPUTY FIRE CHIEF; DUTIES:
The duties of the deputy chief of the fire department shall be to act in place
and stead of the chief of the fire department. In the event of his absence or
inability to act, he shall assist the chief of the fire department in the
exercise of all of his duties and shall also perform such duties as may be
assigned to him by the fire chief. There may be four (4) deputy chiefs. (Ord.
1153, 5-25-1988)
3-2-5: ENFORCEMENT OF DEPARTMENT REGULATIONS:
It shall be the special duty of the fire chief to see that all the provisions
of this code and the department regulations having any relation to the
protection of life or property in the village from fire or relating to the fire
department are strictly enforced and that all the members of the fire
department are faithful in the discharge of their duties. (Ord. 1153, 5-25-
1988)
3-2-6: PROTECTION AGAINST FIRES:
It shall be the duty of the fire chief to visit and examine all places reported
or known to him as being liable to cause or occasion the breaking out or spread
of fire, and to make such orders in relation thereto as the protection of life
and the property in the village may require. (Ord. 1153, 5-25-1988)
3-2-7: BOARD OF OFFICERS AND RULES AND REGULATIONS:
There is hereby established a "board of officers". This board of officers may
consist of three (3) officers with the rank of captain or deputy chief. The
board shall be appointed by the fire chief after approval of the president and
board of trustees. The fire chief shall have authority to appoint an alternate
to the board of officers if anyone on the existing board is not available to
attend a particular meeting. In addition to the annual efficiency and
proficiency ratings referred to in subsection 3-2-1(B) of this chapter, the
duty of the board shall be to work with the fire chief in establishing a set of
rules and regulations for the conduct of the fire department and any proposed
revisions in this chapter. The chief shall work with the board of officers on
the rules and regulations and any revisions. They shall review the rules and
regulations periodically to ensure they remain current. No change shall be made
in said rules and regulations unless the change is approved by a majority of
the board of officers and has been submitted and approved by the village board.
The board of officers may also hear appeals of suspended volunteer officers or
volunteer members per section 3-2-17 of this chapter. (Ord. 1153, 5-25-1988)
3-2-8: FIRE RECORD TO BE KEPT:
The fire chief shall keep a full, true and complete record of all the property
and equipment of the fire department, together with a record of all
transactions in the fire department and of all property placed in his charge
and custody; and he shall annually, at the close of each calendar year, make a
written report to the president and board of trustees showing the condition of
the department under his management, together with a complete list of all fires
occurring in the village during the preceding year, the loss incurred thereby,
and such other information as he may deem important to the village. The fire
chief shall provide an incident report for every alarm to which the fire
department responds. (Ord. 1153, 5-25-1988)
3-2-9: PRESCRIBE LIMITS AT FIRES:
The fire chief or other officer in command may prescribe limits in the vicinity
of any fire, within which no persons except those who reside therein, firemen,
policemen, and those admitted by order of any officer of the fire department be
permitted to go. He shall have power to cause a removal of any property
whenever it shall become necessary for the preservation of such property from
fire, to prevent the spreading of fire, or to protect adjoining property. (Ord.
1153, 5-25-1988)
3-2-10: SPECTATORS AT FIRES; DISOBEDIENCE:
Every person who shall be present at a fire shall be subject and obedient to
the orders of the fire chief and other officers of the fire department engaged
in extinguishing the fire and in the removal and protection of property; and in
case any person shall refuse to obey such orders, he shall be deemed guilty of
a misdemeanor. (Ord. 1153, 5-25-1988)
3-2-11: DAMAGING EQUIPMENT:
Any person who shall offer any hindrance to any officer or firemen in the
performance of his duty at a fire, or shall in any manner destroy, damage or
deface any hose cart, hose or other fire apparatus belonging to the village,
shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. 1153, 5-25-1988)
3-2-12: DRIVING OVER FIRE HOSE:
No car, truck, wagon, railroad car, or other vehicle shall be driven over any
unprotected hose of the fire department when laid down on any street or alley
by order of the fire chief or other proper officer, without the consent of the
fire chief or officers or members in charge of such hose; and any person
violating this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. 1153, 5-
25-1988)
3-2-13: TAMPERING WITH ALARM BOXES:
No person, except those connected with the management of the fire department,
shall open any signal box unless it be to communicate an alarm of fire; or
break, cut, deface, derange, or in any manner meddle or interfere with any
signal box or fire alarm, telegraph or telephone wires. (Ord. 1153, 5-25-1988)
3-2-14: REMOVAL FROM OFFICE:
If charges are filed against anyone on the fire department requesting removal
of that person from the department, the matter will be referred either to the
president and board of trustees or to the board of fire and police
commissioners.
The fire chief (as chief) and any volunteer firemen or volunteer officers may
be removed by the president and board of trustees for any violation of the
provisions of this code, bylaws, rules and regulations pertaining to the fire
department. The village board may hold a hearing if it feels a hearing is
necessary. All full time men who were appointed by the board of fire and police
commissioners can only be removed from any position attained under the board of
fire and police commissioners after full compliance with state statutes and
after appropriate hearings before the board of fire and police commissioners.
(Ord. 1153, 5-25-1988)
3-2-15: DELIVERY OF BOOKS AND EQUIPMENT TO SUCCESSOR:
On the expiration of his term of office or his resignation thereof or removal
therefrom, the fire chief shall, on demand, deliver to his successor in office
all books, records, equipment, and property of every description in his
possession belonging to the village or appertaining to his office. (Ord. 1153,
5-25-1988)
3-2-16: COMPENSATION OF FIREMEN:
The fire chief and members of the department shall receive for their services
such compensation and shall be granted such privileges and immunities as the
president and board of trustees may lawfully allow and prescribe. (Ord. 1153,
5-25-1988)
3-2-17: SUSPENSION OF MEMBERS:
The chief may suspend for up to thirty (30) days any volunteer officer or
volunteer member. When any such suspension shall be ordered by the chief, he
shall at once file with the chairman of the committee on public safety a
written report of such suspension and of the reasons therefor. An appeal of
said suspension may be made by the suspended person within five (5) calendar
days of such action to the board of officers who, after proper hearing, may
sustain the suspension, or reinstate the member or may modify the suspension as
they feel appropriate.
If a volunteer officer is a full time fireman, his suspension by the chief
shall only apply to his officer's rank, unless the suspension is in accordance
with state statutes as to full time men. Any suspension of a full time man must
be in accordance with the state statutes and any appeals must be to the board
of fire and police commissioners. All hearings on full time men shall be by the
board of fire and police commissioners. (Ord. 1153, 5-25-1988)
3-2-18: MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR MEMBERS OF THE MIDLOTHIAN FIRE DEPARTMENT:
   (A)   All members of the Midlothian fire department shall maintain the
following level of performance to remain in good standing in the department:
      1.   Volunteer members must respond to thirty three percent (33%) of the
total number of alarms received. Full time paid members must respond to twenty
five percent (25%) of all off duty calls.
      2.   Volunteer members must acquire one hundred twenty (120) hours of
creditable training in a fiscal year. Full time members must acquire three
hundred twelve (312) hours of creditable training in a fiscal year.
      3.   Members must be certified by the Illinois fire protection personnel
standards and education commission as having successfully completed an approved
training course, and such basic training must be completed by the trainee
within his probationary period of twelve (12) months.
   (B)   The fire chief shall review or cause to be reviewed the performance of
all members of the fire department at three (3), six (6), nine (9) and twelve
(12) month intervals. Upon completion of each review, written notice shall be
given to any member who has not met the minimum standard requirements. Said
notice shall advise the member that he has thirty (30) days in which to bring
his performance up to minimum standards. Failure of the member to bring his
performance up to standard within the allotted time will result in disciplinary
action. Said disciplinary action may include, but is not limited to, a request
for dismissal of the member.
   (C)   Any member of the Midlothian fire department who resigns or is
expelled shall return all fire department equipment, badges, uniforms, and all
other department property in his possession within ten (10) days of his
resignation or expulsion. (Ord. 1153, 5-25-1988)
3-2-19: FILING CHARGES AGAINST FIRE CHIEF:
Charges may be filed against the fire chief. If said charges reflect on his
position as chief of the fire department, they are to be filed with the
president and board of trustees. If the charges are of such a nature that they
require discipline against the chief in his position attained under the board
of fire and police commissioners, charges must be filed with the board of fire
and police commissioners. (Ord. 1153, 5-25-1988)
3-2-20: FIRE DEPARTMENT; PAYMENT BY VILLAGE:
The village shall pay to the fire department such amount biannually as shall be
fixed from time to time by the village board, which sum shall be payment for
all calls answered by the volunteer members and volunteer officers. (Ord. 1153,
5-25-1988)
3-2-21: FIREMEN'S PENSION FUND:
The provisions of "an act to create a firemen's pension fund in cities,
incorporated towns, villages, townships and fire protection districts having a
population of not less than 5,000 nor more than 200,000 inhabitants, filed July
11, 1919 as amended by act approved July 24, 1959" is hereby adopted by the
village and the village shall take such steps as may be necessary to comply
with the provisions thereof. (Ord. 1153, 5-25-1988)
3-2-22: FIRE CALLS OUTSIDE LIMITS; CHARGES:
The fire department is hereby authorized to furnish fire protection service
outside the limits of the village under written mutual aid agreements with
political subdivisions desiring said protection.
The fire department is authorized to answer calls outside the village limits
where no mutual aid agreement exists and they shall make the following charges
for the service: one hundred seventy five dollars ($175.00) for the first hour
plus one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for every additional hour or fraction
thereof. This charge shall apply for every piece of apparatus that responds to
the call. The time shall be figured from the receipt of the alarm to the time
each individual piece of apparatus is back in service. (Ord. 1153, 5-25-1988)
3-2-23: FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE BOARD:
   (A)   Foreign Fire Insurance Board: There is hereby created for the village
fire department a foreign fire insurance board (insurance board). (Ord. 1203,
10-10-1990)
   (B)   Members; Officers: There shall be an election by all the members of
the Midlothian fire department to elect seven (7) members to the foreign fire
insurance board.
   (C)   Election:
      1.   The first election shall take place before December 1, 1990. Any
member elected at the first election shall serve up to and including April 30,
1992. The term of each member elected in April of 1992 shall be for one year.
Starting with the election in April 1993, the term of each member elected shall
be for two (2) years.
      2.   All members of the fire department shall be eligible to be elected
as officers of the foreign fire insurance board.
      3.   After the election of the seven (7) members to the insurance board,
those members shall then elect the following officers: president, vice
president, secretary and treasurer, whose duties and powers are set forth
below. (Ord. 1796, 7-11-2012)
   (D)   Duties And Powers:
      1.   President: The president shall preside at all meetings of the
officers. The president shall have such other powers as he may be given from
time to time by action of the village board of trustees, consistent with the
Illinois municipal code.
      2.   Vice President: The vice president shall carry out the duties of the
president during the absence or inability of the president to perform such
duties and shall carry out such other functions as are assigned from time to
time by the insurance board president or the village board of trustees.
      3.   Secretary: The secretary shall take minutes at any and all meetings
of the officers. The secretary shall keep these minutes in a manner identical
to the manner in which village board minutes are kept. The secretary shall also
perform any other duties and functions as are assigned from time to time by the
insurance board president or the village board of trustees. (Ord. 1203, 10-10-
1990)
      4.   Treasurer:
         (a)   The officers of the fire department foreign fire insurance board
shall develop and maintain a list of those items that the board feels are
appropriate expenditures under this section. All the monies paid to the
municipal treasury as provided in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-10-1 shall
be set apart and shall be appropriated annually by the corporate authorities to
the department foreign fire insurance board, and the treasurer of the
department foreign fire insurance board shall receive the appropriated money
and shall pay out the money upon the order of the department of foreign fire
insurance board for the maintenance, use and benefit of the fire department;
         (b)   The treasurer shall maintain, on the same fiscal year as the
village, the financial books and records of the foreign fire insurance board;
         (c)   The treasurer shall provide, on or before April 30 of each
calendar year, a written statement indicating the amounts to be appropriated by
the village board pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-10-2, which
shall be based upon expected revenues to be generated in the upcoming fiscal
year which starts on May 1 of each calendar year;
         (d)   The treasurer shall perform all duties incident to the office of
treasurer and such other duties as from time to time may be assigned to him/her
by the insurance board president or the village board of trustees;
         (e)   The treasurer of the foreign fire insurance board shall give a
sufficient bond to the village. This bond shall be approved by the village
president, conditioned upon the faithful performance by the treasurer of his or
her duties under this section, the rules and regulations provided herein and
the Illinois municipal code. The cost of said bond shall be paid from the funds
collected from the foreign fire insurance company fees. (Ord. 1705, 9-23-2009)
   (E)   Rules And Regulations: The officers shall make all needful rules and
regulations with respect to the management of the foreign fire insurance board.
All such rules and regulations promulgated by the foreign fire insurance board
officers must be passed by the affirmative vote of at least a majority of the
then presiding officers. All rules and regulations promulgated by the foreign
fire insurance board officers must be approved by the village board of trustees
in the same manner as a village ordinance must be passed. (Ord. 1796, 7-11-
2012)
   (F)   Budget:
      1.   Preliminary Budget: By March of each year the foreign fire insurance
board officers shall approve a preliminary budget for the expenditure of the
foreign fire insurance company fees.
      2.   Final Budget: The foreign fire insurance board officers shall, by
May 1 of each year, adopt a final budget for the collection and payment of the
foreign fire insurance company fees. The final budget shall be approved by the
village board of trustees in the same fashion as any other regular village
ordinance. The village board shall appropriate annually to the department
foreign fire insurance board all the funds paid to the village treasurer per 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-10-1.
      3.   Budget Amendments: The foreign fire insurance board budget referred
to in subsection (F)2 of this section may be amended at any time by the
unanimous vote of the foreign fire insurance board officers and a majority vote
of the village board of trustees.
   (G)   Annual Audit: The foreign fire insurance board officers shall provide
to the village board an annual audit of the financial affairs of the foreign
fire insurance board to be made by a certified public accountant at the end of
each fiscal year in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards. As
part of the annual municipal audit, these funds shall be audited to verify that
the foreign fire insurance board purchases are for maintenance, use, and
benefit of the department. The annual report shall be delivered to the village
president and each village trustee. Said audit shall be paid for from the funds
collected from the foreign fire insurance company fees. (Ord. 1366, 9-27-1995)
3-2-24: SPILLER PAY:
   (A)   Definitions: As used in this section, the following terms shall have
the following meanings:
   COSTS: All expenses incurred by the village of Midlothian or its fire
department or any other public agency assisting the village of Midlothian or
its fire department as a result of any removal or remedial action.
   FACILITY: Any building, structure, installation, equipment, pipe or
pipeline, including, but not limited to, any pipe into a sewer or publicly
owned treatment works, well, pond, lagoon, impoundment, ditch, landfill,
storage container, tank, motor vehicle, truck trailer, rolling stock or
aircraft. Also, any site or area where a hazardous material has been deposited,
stored, disposed of, abandoned, placed or otherwise come to be located.
   HAZARDOUS MATERIALS: Any material, substance or mixture of materials or
substances which are toxic, flammable, corrosive, explosive, carcinogenic or
radioactive including, but not limited to, any substance or material which is
designated a hazardous material pursuant to the "hazardous materials
transportation act" (49 USCA, section 1801 et seq.) in a quantity and form
which may pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health,
property or the environment when improperly released, treated, stored,
transported, disposed of or otherwise managed.
   MUTUAL AID: Any action taken by Midlothian fire department or any other
public agency pursuant to an intergovernmental agreement, including, but not
limited to, the district II mutual aid agreement.
   PERSON: Any individual, business, firm, partnership, corporation,
association, trust, estate, joint venture or other legal entity, or their legal
representative, agent or assign.
   RELEASE: Any spilling, leaking, pumping, pouring, emitting, escaping,
emptying, discharging, injecting, leaching, dumping or disposing of a hazardous
material into or on any land, air, water, well, stream, sewer or pipe so that
such hazardous material or any constituent thereof may enter the environment.
   REMEDIAL ACTION: Any action consistent with permanent remedy taken instead
of, or in addition to, removal actions in the event of a release or threatened
release of a hazardous material into the environment, to prevent or minimize
the release of hazardous materials so that they do not migrate to cause a
substantial present or potential hazard to human health, property or the
environment. The term includes, but is not limited to, such actions at the
location of the release as storage, confinement, perimeter protection using
dikes, trenches or ditches, clay cover, neutralization, cleanup of released
hazardous materials or contaminated materials, recycling or reuse, diversion,
destruction, segregation of reactive wastes, repair or replacement of leaking
containers, collection of leachate and runoff, on site treatment or
incineration, provision of alternate water supplies, and any monitoring
reasonably required to assure that such actions protect the public health and
welfare and the environment.
   REMOVAL: The cleanup or removal of released hazardous materials from the
environment, such actions as may be necessary or appropriate to monitor,
assess, and evaluate the release or threat of release of hazardous materials,
the disposal of removed material, or the taking of such action as may be
necessary to prevent, minimize, or mitigate damage to the public health or
welfare of the environment. The term includes, but is not limited to, security
fencing, provision of alternative water supplies, and temporary evacuation of
threatened individuals.
RESPONSE: Any removal or remedial action.
   (B)   Prohibited Acts: No person shall cause, threaten or allow the release
of hazardous materials into the environment unless such release is in
accordance with an appropriate permit granted by the Illinois environmental
protection agency or other state or federal agency having primary jurisdiction
over the release, and such release is in such place and manner as will not
create a substantial present or potential hazard to human health, property or
the environment.
   (C)   Response Authority:
      1.   The fire chief or his authorized representative shall have authority
to respond to any release or threatened release of hazardous materials within
the territory of the village or affecting the public water supply, wells or
sewage treatment works located within the village or pursuant to any lawful
intergovernmental agreement of which the village or its fire department is a
party. This authority includes, but is not limited to, remedial action and
removal.
      2.   The fire chief shall have primary authority to respond to any
release or threatened release of hazardous materials as described above. The
fire chief shall report any release or threatened release of hazardous
materials to all appropriate federal, state and local public health, safety and
emergency agencies within twenty four (24) hours of any substantial release of
hazardous materials. The fire chief shall relinquish his response authority at
such time, if any, as the federal, state or local public health, safety or
emergency agency having primary jurisdiction over the release or threatened
release has assumed responsibility for response to the release or threatened
release.
      3.   The fire chief, during such time as response authority is vested in
him, shall be authorized to utilize all district personnel and equipment, and
he may, in his sole discretion, take such remedial or removal action as he may
deem necessary or appropriate to respond to the release or threatened release
of hazardous material.
      4.   All responding personnel shall cooperate with and operate under the
direction of the fire chief or other person then exercising response authority
under this section until such time as the person exercising such response
authority has determined that the response is complete or responsibility for
response is assumed by the federal, state or local public health, safety or
emergency agency having primary jurisdiction over the release or threatened
release.
      5.   The person exercising response authority under this section shall
coordinate and/or cooperate with other federal, state or local public health,
safety or emergency agencies involved in response to the release or threatened
release of hazardous materials.
   (D)   Liability For Costs: Notwithstanding any other provision or rule of
law, and subject only to the defenses set forth in subsection (E) of this
section, the following persons shall be jointly and severally liable for all
costs of removal and remedial action incurred by the village or its fire
department as a result of a release or threatened release of a hazardous
material:
      1.   The owner and operator of a facility or vessel from which there is a
release or substantial threat of release of a hazardous material.
      2.   Any person who, at the time of disposal, transport, storage or
treatment of a hazardous material, owned or operated the facility or vessel
used for such disposal, transport, treatment or storage from which there was a
release or substantial threat of a release of any such hazardous material.
      3.   Any person who by contract, agreement or otherwise has arranged with
another party or entity for transport, storage, disposal or treatment of
hazardous materials owned, controlled or possessed by such person at a facility
owned or operated by another party or entity from which facility there is a
release or substantial threat of a release of such hazardous materials.
      4.   Any person who accepts or accepted any hazardous materials for
transport to disposal, storage or treatment facilities from which there is a
release or a substantial threat of release of such hazardous substances.
   (E)   Defenses: There shall be no liability under subsection (D) of this
section for a person otherwise liable who can establish by a preponderance of
the evidence that the release or substantial threat of release of a hazardous
material and the damages resulting therefrom were caused solely by:
      1.   An act of nature over which he or she had no control;
      2.   An act of war; or
      3.   Any combination of the foregoing.
   (F)   Costs And Penalties:
      1.   Any person who is liable for the release or threatened release of a
hazardous material who fails without sufficient cause to pay for or provide
removal or remedial action upon or in accordance with a notice and request of
the village or its fire department, or in accordance with any order of any
court having jurisdiction on the matter, shall be liable to the village for any
costs incurred by the village or its fire department as a result of such
failure to provide or take such removal or remedial action, together with the
cost of any removal or remedial action taken by the village or its fire
department in accordance with this section, and all attorney fees and related
legal costs incurred in connection therewith.
      2.   In addition, any such person shall be guilty of a violation of this
section and shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. A separate offense
shall be deemed committed for each day on which a violation occurs or
continues. Where such violation is found to be the result of wilful and/or
wanton conduct or gross negligence, or the person committing such violation
attempts to evade responsibility hereunder by leaving the scene of the
occurrence or by other means, that person shall be subject to a fine as
provided for above or a fine in an amount equal to three (3) times the costs,
including attorney fees and legal costs, for which it is liable under
subsection (F)1 of this section, whichever is greater.
      3.   Charges for removal or remedial action when rendered by the village
or its fire department or any other agency rendering mutual aid shall be as
follows:
         (a)   The reasonable cost of each vehicle responding as determined by
the responding agency, but in no case less than seventy five dollars ($75.00)
per hour per vehicle, and
         (b)   The cost of all personnel including any overtime cost to the
village or to any responding agency, incurred as a result of the removal or
remedial action, and
         (c)   The cost of all materials and equipment used, expended,
depleted, destroyed or removed from service in accordance with federal, state
or local ordinance as a result of the mitigation or containment operations if
or at the request of the village or its fire department or any responding
agency.
         (d)   The cost of services and/or goods provided by a private or
public entity which are used, expired, depleted, or destroyed as a result of
the response at the request of the village or its fire department or any
responding agency. (Ord. 1421, 8-13-1997)
3-2-25: ADOPTION OF OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY PROGRAM FOR THE MIDLOTHIAN
FIRE DEPARTMENT:
The village, for the purpose of prescribing minimum requirements for the
occupational health and safety program as it relates to the fire department,
states that a certain program known as "village of Midlothian, Midlothian fire
department, occupational health and safety program, December 1994" including
all national fire protection association (NFPA) standards referred to in
appendix C and as modified by said appendix, and any subsequent amendments
thereto, be and the same are hereby adopted as the occupational health and
safety program for the fire department. For thirty (30) days previous to the
passage of this section, three (3) copies of said program and appendices have
been filed with and are currently on file with the village clerk. The program
and appendices and the NFPA standards referred to in the appendices are hereby
adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the
date on which this amendment shall take effect, the program and any subsequent
amendments thereto shall be in full force and effect within the fire
department. (Ord. 1347, 1-11-1995)
3-2-26: KNOX BOX REQUIREMENTS:
   (A)   Knox Boxes Required: All properties, businesses or multi- family
building of five (5) units or more or two (2) floors or more, where common ways
(hallways) are encountered or as prescribed by the fire prevention bureau,
shall be required to have knox boxes.
   (B)   Specifications: All knox boxes shall be UL listing and shall be
compatible with existing fire department equipment and current master keys to
keep current uniformity, as approved by the fire department.
   (C)   Contents: All knox boxes shall contain keys for the following:
      1.   All entrance/exit doors, whether on the exterior or the interior of
the building;
      2.   Mechanical and electrical rooms;
      3.   Closet storage rooms;
      4.   Fire alarm control panels;
      5.   Elevator controls (where applicable); and
      6.   Any other keys required by the fire prevention bureau.
   (D)   Compliance Of Existing And New Buildings: Existing properties and
buildings must comply with the provisions of this section within twelve (12)
months from the date of enactment of this section. All newly constructed
buildings or buildings under construction must comply with the provisions of
this section immediately.
   (E)   Current Key Required: The owner, tenant or organization in control of
a building shall have current keys placed in the knox box by the fire
department upon any change of locks in the building or ownership of the
premises.
   (F)   Violation; Penalty:
      1.   Whoever violates any of the provisions or if they do not comply with
this section, they shall be fined one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for the
first offense and three hundred dollars ($300.00) for the second offense. The
second offense effective after reasonable time given to comply. For all
subsequent offenses the fine shall be seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
      2.   Whoever fails to place the required keys inside his or her knox box
or changes locks without notification to the department shall be fined one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense and three hundred dollars
($300.00) for all subsequent offenses. (Ord. 1586, 2-25-2004)
3-2-27: AMBULANCE SERVICE AND FEES:
   (A)   General: The Village of Midlothian Fire Department is hereby
authorized to operate an emergency service providing Basic Life Support
Services ("BLS") and Advanced Life Support Services ("ALS") and to impose and
collect fees for certain services provided to those persons receiving said BLS
and/or ALS services from the Village of Midlothian Fire Department.
   (B)   Fees: The Village of Midlothian shall charge the fees for BLS Services
as provided from time to time by the Village Board which shall be published by
the Village Clerk and made readily available to the public for the following
categories of service:
      1.   BLS Services:
         Resident Flat Rate
         Non-Resident Flat Rate
         Mileage at per mile rate
      2.   ALS I Services:
         Resident Flat Rate
         Non-Resident Flat Rate
         Mileage at per mile rate
      3.   ALS II Services:
         Resident Flat Rate
         Non-Resident Flat Rate
         Mileage at per mile rate
   (C)   Discretion: It shall be in the sole discretion and best judgement of
the persons providing BLS and/or ALS services to determine the medical facility
to transport the patient(s) receiving aid services.
   (D)   Charges: Each resident or non-resident refusing transport but
requiring on scene BLS or ALS services shall be charged the applicable BLS and
ALS fee as set forth from time to time by the Village Board in the following
circumstances without any charge for mileage:
   (E)   Definitions: For purposes of this section, the following definitions
shall be applicable:
   ADVANCED LIFE SUPPORT (ALS) SERVICES: An advanced level of pre-hospital and
inter-hospital emergency care and non-emergency medical care that includes
basic life support care, cardiac monitoring, cardiac defibrillation,
electrocardiography, intravenous therapy, administration of medications, drugs
and solutions, use of adjunctive medical devices, trauma care, and other
authorized techniques and procedures, as provided in rules adopted by the
Illinois Department of Public Health pursuant to the Emergency Medical Systems
Act 1 .
   ADVANCED LIFE SUPPORT SERVICE, LEVEL I (ALS I): The provision of ALS
services and/or assessment at a level below that specified for ALS II services
described below.
   ADVANCED LIFE SUPPORT SERVICE, LEVEL II (ALS II): The provision of ALS
service and/or assessment with treatment including the administration of three
(3) or more different medications or the provision of at least one of the
following ALS procedures:
         Cardiac pacing
         Central venous line insertion
         Chest decompression
         Endotracheal intubation
         Intraosseous line insertion
         Manual defibrillation/cardioversion
         Surgical airway
   BASIC LIFE SUPPORT (BLS) SERVICES: A basic level of pre- hospital and inter-
hospital, emergency care and non-emergency medical care that includes airway
management, cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), control of shock and bleeding
and splinting of fractures, as provided in rules adopted by the Illinois
Department of Public Health pursuant to the Emergency Medical Systems Act 2 .
   MILEAGE: A fee for each mile, or portion thereof, that an ambulance travels
when transporting a patient in need of medical care to a hospital or other care
providing facility.
   RESIDENT: A person whose primary, regular and fixed nighttime place of abode
is within the corporate limits of the Village of Midlothian. (Ord. 1960, 7-26-
2017; amd. Ord. 2125, 7-26-2023)
 
Notes
1 1. 210 ILCS 50/1 et seq.
2 2. 210 ILCS 50/1 et seq.
3-2-28: FIRE SERVICE AND FEE MITIGATION RATES:
   (A)   General: The Village hereby establishes cost mitigation rates for the
deployment of certain emergency services by the Fire Department of the Village
for services provided and/or rendered, including the provision of personnel,
supplies and equipment to the scene of motor vehicle incidents and other
emergency incidents as provided below, which are based on the actual costs of
the services and those costs that are usual, customary and reasonable ("UCR")
and set by the Village Board.
   (B)   The Village of Midlothian shall charge the rates as set and amended
from time to time by the Village Board which shall be published by the Village
Clerk and made readily available to the public for the following categories of
service:
      1.   Motor Vehicle Incidents: Shall apply for the provision of technical
services to residents and nonresidents at the levels indicated for response to
motor vehicle incidents:
         Level 1: This service includes hazardous materials assessment, scene
stabilization and basic response services.
         Level 2: Includes level 1 services, cleanup and material use
(sorbents) for hazardous fluid cleanup and disposal. Billing at this level will
occur if the Fire Department must clean up any gasoline or other automotive
fluids that are spilled as a result of the accident/incident.
         Level 3: Relating to a car fire, provision of scene safety, fire
suppression, breathing air, rescue tools, hose, tip use, foam, exposure
protection and cleanup of gasoline or other automotive fluids that are spilled
as a result of the accident/incident.
         Level 4: Includes level 1 and 2 services as well as extrication of
occupant (heavy rescue tools, ropes, airbags, cribbing, etc.). Billing at this
level will occur if the Fire Department is required to free/remove anyone from
the vehicle(s) using any powered equipment. Billing at this level will not
occur if the person to be extricated is unconscious or unable to move and the
Fire Department is able to open a door to the vehicle to access and safely
remove the person.
      2.   Hazardous Materials: The following rate categories shall apply for
the provision of technical services to residents and nonresidents at the levels
indicated for responses involving hazardous materials:
         Level 1: Basic response includes engine response, first responder
assignment, perimeter establishment, evacuations, setup and command.
         Level 2: Intermediate response includes level 1 services, HAZMAT
certified team and appropriate equipment, level A or B suit donning, breathing
air and detection equipment, and setup and removal of decon center as
necessary.
      Level 3: Advanced response includes provisions of level 1 and level 2
services as well as robot deployment, recovery and identification of material,
disposal and environmental cleanup. Also includes any disposal rates for
contaminated equipment and material used at scene. This level includes three
(3) hours of on scene time. Any hour in excess of three (3) hours shall be
billed at the published rate per hour for each HAZMAT team present. This
additional amount shall be charged in fifteen (15) minute increments.
      3.   Pipeline Incidents/Power Line Incidents: The published hourly rate
shall apply for technical services provided to residents and nonresidents for
responding to incidents involving all of the following: gas, sewer, septic to
sewer, water pipelines and power lines:
         Level 1: Provision of basic response services including engine
response, first responder assignment, perimeter establishment, evacuations,
first responder setup and command. This charge also includes inspection without
damage or breakage.
         Level 2: Includes provision of level 1 services as well as HAZMAT
certified team and appropriate equipment, level A or B suit donning, breathing
air, detection equipment and the supervision and/or assisting of pipeline
repair.
         Level 3: Itemized claim charge: Advanced response includes provisions
of levels 1 and 2 as well as supervision and/or assisting of intermediate to
major pipeline damage, setup and removal of decon center, detection, recovery
and identification of material, disposal and environmental cleanup.
      4.   Fire Investigation Team: Fire investigation services will be charged
at the published hourly rate. These services include scene safety,
investigation, source identification, K-9/arson dog unit, identification
equipment, mobile detection equipment and fire report. For purposes of this
charge, the claim shall begin when the fire investigator or investigation team
responds to the incident. This charge is limited to logged time only. This fee
will only be levied if it is determined that fire investigation is necessary
based upon the facts and circumstances of the fire in question.
      5.   Fires: Fire suppression services will be charged at the published
hourly rates, per incident, per engine and per truck. This service shall
include scene safety, investigation and fire/hazard control. For purposes of
this charge, the claim shall begin when the Village Fire Department responds to
the incident and this charge is only for logged time. This charge is only
assessed against property owner's properties in an unincorporated area without
a fire contract.
      6.   Water Incidents: The following rates shall apply for the provision
of technical services to residents and nonresidents at the levels indicated for
response to water incidents:
         Level 1: Will be charged a flat fee plus the published hourly rates
per rescue person. Provision of basic response services including engine
response, first responder assignment, perimeter establishment, evacuations,
first responder setup and command, scene safety and investigation (including
possible patient contact and hazard control).
         Level 2: Will be charged a flat fee plus the published hourly rates,
per rescue person. Intermediate response includes provision of level 1 services
as well as cleanup and material used (sorbents), minor hazardous cleanup and
disposal. Billing will occur at this level if the Fire Department of the
Village must clean up small amounts of gasoline or other fluids that are
spilled as a result of the incident.
         Level 3: Will be charged a flat fee plus the published hourly rates,
per rescue person and per HAZMAT team member. Advanced response includes
provisions of level 1 and 2 services as well as DART activation, donning
breathing apparatus, detection equipment, setup and removal of decon center,
recovery and identification of material, and disposal and environmental
cleanup. Also includes any disposal rates of contaminated equipment and
material used at scene.
         Level 4: Itemized response. In the case of an unusual incident, the
Fire Department may bill each incident as an independent incident with actual
costs and/or customary mitigation rates using itemized rates deemed usual,
customary and reasonable (UCR). Such incidents will be billed using itemized
amounts for each trained rescue person plus rescue products and equipment used.
      7.   Special Rescue: Will be charged a minimum flat fee plus the
published hourly rates per rescue person. Each incident will be billed in
accordance with actual costs and/or customary mitigation rates using itemized
rates deemed usual, customary and reasonable ("UCR"), subject to the minimum
amounts described above. Such incidents will be billed using itemized amounts
for each apparatus and each trained rescue person per hour, plus rescue
products and equipment used.
      8.   Fire Chief Response To Incident: For any incident for which a
response attended to by the fire chief, will be charged the published hourly
rate. This will be charged when the fire chief directly responds to an
incident, including the setup of command and providing direction of the
operations, safety and administration of the incident.
      9.   Equipment Charges: The charges for equipment used for the services
identified in this section, including specialized rescue services to the extent
the same is not limited by law, may include the published hourly rates for:
         (a)   Engine.
         (b)   Truck/squad.
         (c)   Boat rescue.
         (d)   Other/miscellaneous equipment.
   (C)   Implementation, Procedures, Waiver and Remedies:
      1.   The mitigation rates above are flat fees, except as otherwise
identified, and have been determined to be usual, customary and reasonable for
the incident responses listed. The mitigation rates were determined by
itemizing costs for a typical incident (from the time a fire apparatus leaves
the station until it returns to the station) and are based on the actual costs,
using amortized schedules for apparatus (including useful life, equipment,
repairs and maintenance) and labor rates (based upon an average department's
"actual personnel expense", and not simply a firefighter's basic wage). The
actual personnel expense includes costs such as wages, retirement, benefits,
workers' compensation, insurance, etc. When a claim is submitted, it will be
itemized and based on the actual services provided in accordance with the above
rates.
      2.   The mitigation rates shall represent an additional cost of the claim
for damages of the vehicles, property and/or injuries, and shall be filed with
the insurance carrier of the owner of the vehicle, owner of the property or the
responsible party/parties as set forth above. In some circumstances, the
responsible party will be billed directly. In all cases, however, the fire
department will endeavor to obtain insurance coverage as a primary mitigation
source. The fire department will exhaust all avenues related to insurance
coverage, and will only charge individuals as a last line of defense when all
insurance companies involved deny the claim(s).
      3.   The fees imposed by this section may be reduced or waived upon
recommendation by the fire chief and approval by the village president in cases
where in their discretion it is deemed to be in the best interests of the
village or when payment of the fee would be an undue hardship or the person
receiving said services is incapable of paying said fees. Under no
circumstances, however, shall any party have the ability to require the fire
chief or village president to make such a discretionary determination.
      4.   The village board may make rules or regulations and from time to
time may amend, revoke or add rules and regulations as they may deem necessary
or expedient in respect to billing for services under this section and the
collection of rates as established herein.
      5.   Any person or entity that refuses to pay or fails to pay charges
billed will be deemed to have violated this section. The village may pursue all
remedies at law and equity to recover service charges due and owing, including
the use of the services of a collection agency. (Ord. 1862, 2-12-2014; amd.
Ord. 2125, 7-26-2023)
3-2-29: FIRE ALARM RESPONSE AND FEES:
   (A)   Purpose:
      1.   The purpose of this section is to encourage owners and fire alarm
businesses to properly use and maintain the operational effectiveness of fire
alarm systems in order to improve the reliability of fire alarm systems and
reduce or eliminate false fire alarms and nuisance fire alarms.
      2.   This section governs fire alarm systems intended to summon fire
department personnel, and requires registration, assessment of fees for
excessive false fire alarms and nuisance fire alarms, and provides procedures
for repeat offenders.
   (B)   Definitions: As used in this section, the following words and terms
shall have the following meanings:
   ADOPTED CODE(S): Code adopted by the jurisdiction and in the absence of
adopted code, the National Fire Protection Association national fire alarm code
72 (NFPA 72) and the National Fire Protection Association life safety code 101
(NFPA 101).
   ALARM INITIATING DEVICE: A device that is designed to respond either
manually or automatically to smoke, fire, or activation of a fire suppression
system.
   ENFORCEMENT OFFICIAL: The fire chief or his designated representative.
   FALSE FIRE ALARM: The activation of any fire alarm system which results in a
response by the fire department and which is caused by the negligence or
intentional misuse of the fire alarm system by the owner, its employees, agents
or any other activation of a fire alarm system not caused by heat, smoke or
fire, exclusive of a nuisance fire alarm.
   FEE: The assessment of a monetary charge payable to the village in order to
defray the expenses of responding to a false fire alarm or nuisance fire alarm.
   FIRE ALARM ACTIVATION REPORT: A document issued by the enforcement official
indicating that the activation was deemed to be the result of a fire alarm
activation due to fire, a nuisance fire alarm, or a false fire alarm.
   FIRE ALARM BUSINESS: Any individual, partnership, corporation or other
entity that is appropriately licensed in the state/jurisdiction and installs,
causes to be installed, permits to be installed, alters, maintains, repairs,
replaces or services (including runner services) any fire alarm system.
   FIRE ALARM SYSTEM: A system or portion of a combination system consisting of
components and circuits arranged to monitor and/or exterior annunciate the
status of a fire alarm or supervisory signal initiating devices and to initiate
the appropriate response to those signals.
   FIRE WATCH: An enforcement official approved person or persons assigned to
the premises for the purpose of protecting the occupants from fire or similar
emergencies. A fire watch may involve at least some special action beyond
normal staffing, such as assigning an additional security guard(s) to walk the
premises, who has been specially trained in fire prevention and in the use of
fire extinguishers, in notifying the fire department, in sounding the fire
alarm system located on the premises, and in understanding the particular fire
safety situation.
   MONITORED SYSTEM: The process by which a fire alarm business receives
signals from a fire alarm system and notifies emergency forces.
   NUISANCE FIRE ALARM: The activation of any fire alarm system, which results
in a response by the fire department, caused by mechanical failure,
malfunction, improper installation, lack of proper maintenance or any other
response for which the fire department personnel are unable to determine the
apparent cause of the alarm activation.
   OWNER: Any person who owns the premises in which a fire alarm system is
installed or the person or persons who lease, operate, occupy or manage the
premises.
   PREMISES: Any building, structure or combination of buildings and structures
which serve as dwelling units such as single-family, multi-family or any other
area within a building, structure or combination thereof which is used for any
purpose, wherein a fire alarm system is installed.
   QUALIFIED FIRE ALARM TECHNICIAN: Any person who inspects, installs, repairs
or performs maintenance on fire alarm systems. This person shall be: 1) factory
trained and certified; 2) National Institute Of Certification In Engineering
Technologies (NICET) fire alarm level II certified; or 3) licensed or certified
by state or local authority.
   (C)   Inspection, Testing And Maintenance:
      1.   The owner shall ensure that all fire alarm systems are inspected and
tested at least once per year in accordance with adopted codes.
      2.   The owner shall ensure that all fire alarm systems are periodically
maintained per manufacturer specifications and adopted codes.
   (D)   Fire Alarm Activation; Response:
      1.   The owner shall be responsible for the activation of a fire alarm
system.
      2.   A response to the activation of a fire alarm system shall result
when any officer or member of the fire department is dispatched to the premises
where the fire alarm system has been activated.
         (a)   At the time of response, the enforcement official shall notify
any person identified in the registration required pursuant to title 4, chapter
15 of this code of the activation of the fire alarm system and shall require
such person to respond to the premises.
         (b)   In the event the fire alarm system is a monitored system, it is
the responsibility of the company monitoring the fire alarm system to notify
any person identified in the registration at the request of the enforcement
official.
         (c)   In the event the household fire alarm system is a monitored
system, it is the responsibility of the fire alarm business to offer the owner
the option to verify the fire alarm signal before dispatch, as allowed by
adopted code.
         (d)   In the event the household fire alarm system is a monitored
system, it is the responsibility of the fire alarm business to forward
cancellation of a fire alarm signal to the fire department.
      3.   The officer or member of the fire department who responded to said
premises shall serve the owner or authorized representative with a fire alarm
activation report.
   (E)   Nuisance Fire Alarms:
      1.   In the event the activation of a fire alarm system is deemed by the
enforcement official to be a nuisance fire alarm, the owner shall be served
with a fire alarm activation report by an officer or member of the fire
department, indicating that the activation was deemed to be the result of a
nuisance fire alarm.
      2.   This shall require the owner to return a completed report of
service/repair within fifteen (15) days of receipt of the fire alarm activation
report to verify, to the reasonable satisfaction of the enforcement official,
that:
         (a)   The fire alarm system has actually been examined by a qualified
fire alarm technician; and
         (b)   A bona fide attempt has been made to identify and correct any
defect of design, installation or operation of the fire alarm system which was
identifiable as the cause of the nuisance fire alarm.
      3.   Failure to return a report of service/repair within said fifteen
(15) day period, which is reasonably satisfactory to the enforcement official,
shall result in assessment against the owner of a fee of one hundred dollars
($100.00) in addition to any fees for the false fire alarm.
   (F)   Grace Period:
      1.   The fee provisions of this section shall not apply to any newly
installed fire alarm system for a period of forty five (45) days from the date
of installation, but shall apply from and after the expiration of said forty
five (45) day period.
   (G)   Fee Schedule:
      1.   One false alarm within twelve (12) months in a calendar year tracked
by the fire department or billing company is free of charge.
      2.   The second false alarm in a twelve (12) month calendar year will be
billed at one hundred dollars ($100.00).
      3.   The third false alarm in a twelve (12) month calendar year will be
billed at two hundred dollars ($200.00).
      4.   Any subsequent false alarms to the third false alarm within a twelve
(12) month calendar year will be billed at three hundred dollars ($300.00) per
event not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) per calendar day.
   (H)   Collection:
      1.   The owner and lessee of any alarmed premises shall be jointly and
severally responsible to pay the fees for each occasion on which the fire
department responds to a false alarm from an alarmed premises.
      2.   The fire department shall report, monthly, a list of false alarms
identifying the alarmed premises and the responsible owners and lessees. The
treasurer or billing services contracted by the village shall bill each
responsible owner and lessee for the amounts due in accordance with the
established schedule of fees. All amounts billed by the village treasurer/
billing service under this section shall be due within thirty (30) days after
each billing. The village is authorized to prosecute collection procedures for
any overdue amounts. (Ord. 1868, 5-14-2014)
3-2-30: FIRE DEPARTMENT VEHICLE REPLACEMENT FUND:
   (A)   Creation: A fund, hereinafter called the "fire department vehicle
replacement fund", is hereby created. The fire department vehicle replacement
fund shall be separately maintained by the village for the purposes set forth
herein.
   (B)   Funding: The fire department vehicle replacement fund shall be funded
solely by the collection of fees by the village for the provision of fire and
ambulance services as set forth in sections 3-2-27 and 3-2-28 of this chapter.
The village shall cause the fees collected pursuant to sections 3-2-27 and 3-2-
28 of this chapter each month to be placed into the fire department vehicle
replacement fund up to a maximum contribution of ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00) monthly. Any fees collected pursuant to sections 3-2-27 and 3-2-28
of this chapter in excess of the ten thousand dollar ($10,000.00) monthly
maximum contribution shall be placed into the village corporate fund.
   (C)   Use: The funds contained in the fire department vehicle replacement
fund shall be used to pay for the purchase or lease costs incurred for the
replacement of fire department vehicles which have reached or exceeded their
level of economic usefulness or to pay for the purchase or lease costs incurred
for the acquisition of additional vehicles deemed necessary for the operation
of and use by the village fire department.
   (D)   Accumulations: Monies in the fire department vehicle replacement fund
may be accumulated from year to year beyond that which may be expended in any
particular fiscal year. All interest earned on the investment of monies in the
fire department vehicle replacement fund shall become part of the fire
department vehicle replacement fund.
   (E)   No Restriction: The creation of the fire department village
replacement fund shall not limit or restrict the village's authority to
otherwise purchase vehicles for the fire department as deemed necessary and in
conformity with state and local law. (Ord. 1896, 7-8-2015)

3-3-1: DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS:
There is hereby established an executive department of the village to be known
as the department of public works. Said department shall be under the general
supervision of the superintendent of public works, and said department shall
