consist of the superintendent and such other officers, employees and workers as
may from time to time be provided. The president is hereby authorized to
appoint the superintendent of public works for a term of one year by and with
the advice and consent of the board of trustees. There is hereby created the
office of assistant superintendent of public works. The duties of the assistant
superintendent shall be to act in place and instead of the superintendent of
public works in the event of his absence or inability to act. He shall assist
the superintendent in the exercise of all his duties and shall perform such
other duties as may be assigned to him by the superintendent. The duties and
salary of said director and assistant of public works shall be as set forth
from time to time by the president and board of trustees. (Ord. 2169, 4-23-
2025)
3-3-2: JJURISDICTION OF DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS:
The department of public works shall have two (2) sections. Number 1, the water
department which shall have supervision, management and control of the
maintenance, enlargement and operation of the combined waterworks and sewer
system, the securing and provision of water, and all matters and things
connected with the operation, maintenance and extension of the waterworks
system and the selling of water therefrom, and preserving the property
belonging thereto, and all matters connected with the operation of the sewer
system and maintenance and extension thereof. Number 2, the street department
which shall have special charge of the maintenance of streets, sidewalks and
public ways of the village and of the improvements and repair thereof, except
where such repair or improvement of streets, sidewalks and public ways is to be
wholly or in part, paid for by special assessment, also of the cleaning of
streets and removal of dirt, garbage, refuse and water therefrom. (Ord. 2169,
4-23-2025)
3-3-3: DUTIES OF SUPERINTENDENT:
The superintendent of the water department, subject to the general direction of
the president and board of trustees shall have the general direction and
control of the water department and shall see that the object and purposes
thereof are carried out, and that the waterworks system and sewer system are
conducted on an economical, businesslike basis and for this purpose it shall be
the duty of the superintendent and all of the officers, employees and workers
of the department to enforce all the provisions of this chapter and to observe
and obey and carry out the orders and directions of the president and board of
trustees, and it shall be the further duty of the superintendent to see that
such orders and directions are faithfully observed, carried out and obeyed. The
superintendent shall, when requested by the president and board of trustees,
report upon the condition of the department and the affairs thereof, and the
matters and things relating thereto. (Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-4: MONTHLY REPORT OF SUPERINTENDENT:
The superintendent shall prepare, or cause to be prepared, each month a full
and complete report of all activities, claims, salaries and expenses incurred
by the department in the discharge of its duties, which report shall be signed
by the superintendent and submitted to the president and board of trustees, and
the claims, salaries and expenses of the water department shall be paid upon
warrants drawn against the "water, sewer and street funds" in accordance with
the order of the president and board of trustees. (Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-5: ANNUAL REPORT OF SUPERINTENDENT:
The superintendent shall present to the president and board of trustees an
annual report each year including a detailed report of all transactions,
revenues, cost of repairs, maintenance, condition and management of the water
department for the preceding fiscal year, including a complete statement of the
financial condition and property interests of the department and any required
water quality reports. (Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-6: EMPLOYEES OF DEPARTMENT:
The superintendent shall submit to the president and board of trustees his
recommendation as to the employees necessary to be employed in and about the
department of public works and the compensation to be paid to non-bargaining
unit employees, the same shall be fixed by the president and board of trustees.
The president and board of trustees shall fix the compensation and terms of
employment for bargaining unit members by approval of lawfully negotiated
collective bargaining agreements. (Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-7: OFFICE HOURS:
The office of the department shall be open to the public as determined, from
time to time, by the president and/or village board. (Ord. 1821, 1-23-2013;
amd. Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-8: RECORDS OF ACCOUNT:
The superintendent or his designee shall keep, or cause to be kept, full and
complete books and or electronic records of account showing the exact condition
of the financial affairs of the department and for that purpose shall establish
a complete and comprehensive system of recordkeeping regarding the same. The
system shall show how much sewer service and water each piece of property
consumes and the amount charged therefor. The superintendent shall also cause
to be made a complete and correct map or profile of all water and sewer mains
now or hereafter laid, showing their location, connections, valves, hydrants
and shutoffs, and all such records of account, maps and profiles shall be open
at all times for the inspection of the president and members of the village
board. It shall be the duty of the superintendent at the time each permit, as
herein required, is granted, to enter into a book and or electronic record
documentation of such permit showing the size of the connection, the size of
the meter and the amount of all charges and fees collected. (Ord. 2169, 4-23-
2025)
3-3-9: BILLS:
(A)   Bills; Preparation And Collection: Regular bills for water service and
other charges under this code shall be rendered to the person designated on
village records as soon as practicable, but in no event later than the tenth
day of the month following the most recent meter reading subject to each
billing cycle. Upon request, in connection with a sale or other transfer of the
premises or other change of person responsible for charges hereunder, the
village may make a special meter reading and render a special billing for water
services and other charges incurred up to the date of such meter reading.
Except as hereinafter provided, a bill for water usage shall be rendered for
each primary meter in accordance with the consumption registered thereon and in
accordance with section 3-3-16 of this chapter. Bills for buildings used for
multiple-family residence purposes or mixed business and residential uses which
have more than one primary meter (but not having separate meters for each
dwelling unit or use therein) shall be based upon the combined consumption
registered on the several meters except that separate bills shall be rendered
for each meter for which the number of dwelling units or uses served by such
meter can be determined from inspection of the plans for such building. All
billed accounts shall include a water infrastructure fee, which shall be set
from time to time by the president and board of trustees.
(B)   Billing Cycle: Residential water users up to a maximum of two (2) units
in a single building and commercial establishments, in the discretion of the
village board, may be billed monthly, every two (2) months, or quarterly.
(C)   Commercial Establishments And Apartments: Commercial establishments and
apartments other than as provided in subsection (C) of this section shall be
billed monthly.
(D)   Gross And Net Bills: The gross bills shall be computed by adding ten
percent (10%) to the total water, sewer, and garbage net charges. The bills
shall be mailed as soon as practicable, but in no event later than the fifth
day of the month following the end of a billing period. If the bill is paid
within twenty-one (21) days of the mailing, the net bill shall be paid. If the
bill is not paid within twenty-one (21) days of the mailing, then the gross
amount will be due. If the gross amount is not paid within thirty-five (35)
days of the mailing, a final disconnection notice may be mailed notifying the
consumer that water service will be turned off in accordance with subsection
(F) of this section. (Ord. 1901, 8-26-2015; amd. Ord. 2024, 4-24-2019)
(E)   Garbage Collection Charges: The village shall add to the water and sewer
bill a monthly charge as determined by section
8-2-12 of this code for garbage collection for each residential unit up to a
maximum of two (2) units. Commercial, industrial or business establishments and
multiple dwellings over two (2) units shall contract individually for garbage
collection. (Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-10: DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE:
(A)   Actions Causing Discontinuance: The village may discontinue service when
any customer pays a shutoff notice with an NSF check or fails to do any of the
following:
   1.   Correct the condition of waste, tampering or unauthorized use by a
notice issued under this code;
   2.   Make a deposit or increase a deposit as required by this Code;
   3.   Pay a past due bill owed to the village for the water service furnished
at the same or at another location;
   4.   Make payment in accordance with the terms of a deferred payment
agreement as described in this code;
   5.   Provide village representatives with access to the metering devices as
required by this code;
   6.   Provide village representatives with access or easements for the
purposes of inspecting, repairing, replacing or upgrading the potable water
pipes and fixtures as required by this code; or
   7.   Refrain from engaging in theft of services. (Ord. 1901, 8-26-2015)
(B)   Procedure:
   1.   Notice shall be mailed via first-class mail to the customer whose water
service may be discontinued. The notice shall inform the customer of the
payment or other action required to prevent discontinuance of service, the date
by which such payment or other action must be made (which date shall not be
less than ten (10) days from the date such notice is mailed; unless a shutoff
noticed bill balance was paid with a non-sufficient funds (NSF) check, then no
additional notice shall be required). The notice shall also include the charges
for disconnection and reconnection of the service and the person or department
with the authority to resolve disputes. (Ord. 2024, 4-24-2019)
   2.   Except as provided in subsection (F)2(c) of this section, water service
may be discontinued at the sole discretion of the village, without further
notice to the owner or occupants of the premises, in the event that the
customer has failed to correct the conditions specified in the written notice.
   3.   Water service shall not be discontinued to any building in which
multiple residential or commercial units are served through a common metering
device until the village has mailed, delivered or posted on the premises a
notice to all lessees or tenants, which notice shall comply with the
requirements of subsection (F)2(a) of this section.
   4.   Except for matters of safety, emergency maintenance and cooperation
with civil authorities, the village shall not:
      (a)   Disconnect water service within one hour before or during any time
during which the Village does not have customer service personnel available to
handle customer contact;
      (b)   Disconnect water service after four o'clock (4:00) P.M. on Monday
through Thursday unless village staff is able to take customer payment and
reconnect the customer the same day if the customer remedies the reason for
disconnection;
      (c)   Disconnect residential water service after twelve o'clock (12:00)
noon on Friday or a nonresidential customer after four o'clock (4:00) P.M. on
Friday unless village staff is able to take customer payment and reconnect the
customer the same day if the customer remedies the reason for disconnection;
      (d)   Disconnect water service on a Saturday or Sunday unless village
staff is able to take customer payment and reconnect the customer the same day
if the customer remedies the reason for disconnection;
      (e)   Disconnect water service on a State of Illinois or utility holiday
or after twelve o'clock (12:00) noon on any day preceding a State of Illinois
or utility holiday unless village staff is able to take customer payment and
reconnect the customer the same day if the customer remedies the reason for
disconnection. (Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-11: DEFERRED PAYMENT AGREEMENTS:
(A)   Customers who are indebted to the village for past due water service
shall have the opportunity to make arrangements to retire the debt by periodic
payments referred to hereinafter as a deferred payment agreement; except that
customers who have failed to make payment under such a plan during the past
twelve (12) months shall not be afforded such an opportunity.
(B)   The terms and conditions of a deferred payment agreement, shall be
determined by the clerk or his/her designee, after consideration of the
following:
   1.   Size of the past due account;
   2.   Customer's payment history;
(C)   A deferred payment agreement shall be in writing, with a copy provided to
the customer, and shall conform to the following requirements:
   1.   The customer shall be required to pay all future bills for utility
service by the due date;
   2.   The customer shall retire the debt according to the terms of the
deferred payment agreement, which shall allow a minimum of two (2) months and a
maximum of twelve (12) months to retire the debt.
   3.   If a customer defaults on any payment due under the deferred payment
agreement, the village shall have the right to discontinue service in
accordance with this code.
   4.   Any customer account receiving water as a tenant in a leasehold, shall
obtain approval from the landlord in writing before entering into a deferred
payment agreement.
(D)   Renewal Of Service:
   1.   If water service is shut off for any reason permitted under this code,
the water service shall not be turned on except upon the payment of the
reconnection fees set forth in subsection (D)(3) of this section, payment of
the unpaid bills and payment of the current service charge, plus all late fees
and any and all unpaid fines or fees owed to the village or the entry of a
deferred payment agreement as provided herein.
   2.   Resumption of service may not be immediately available upon payment of
the bill. If a payment is made by the customer no later than three o'clock (3:
00) P.M. Monday through Friday, every reasonable effort will be made to
reconnect water service within twenty-four (24) hours. The renewal of water
service will take place within a reasonable period of time after the water
department is advised by the clerk or his designee that the reasons for
disconnection have been remedied and it is instructed to reconnect service. The
reasonableness of the time will consider the time of day the payment is made,
the availability of manpower to do the work, the day of the week payment is
made, and other services being performed by the water department employees.
Reconnection shall be made within three (3) calendar days of receipt of all
outstanding amounts due and fees required under subsection (G)3 of this
section.
   3.   A reconnection fee shall be charged when the water supply is
reconnected after having been shut off for any reason permitted under this
code. The reconnection fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each
reconnection for any particular owner or occupant of a particular property.
(Ord. 2024, 4-24-2019; amd. Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-12: LIABILITY OF OWNER OR OCCUPANT:
The owner of the real estate, and the occupant thereof and user of either the
water or sewer service, or both the water and sewer service, shall be jointly
and severally liable to pay for the service furnished to or upon the real
estate, and the water and sewer services are furnished by the village only upon
the condition that the owner of the real estate, and the occupant thereof and
user of the services are jointly and severally liable for the service charge to
the village, and each tenancy shall be deemed to have been entered into in
consideration of this provision. (Ord. 169, 11-22-1938; amd. Ord. 2169, 4-23-
2025)
3-3-13: DELINQUENT BILLS; LIENS AGAINST REAL ESTATE:
Delinquent water bills shall be liens against the real estate pursuant to the
provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-139-8 (1961). (Ord. 2169, 4-
23-2025)
3-3-14: CONNECTIONS WITH WATER SYSTEM:
(A)   Any person desiring to make any connection with the water division of the
combined waterworks and sewerage system shall first make application to the
superintendent or his/her designee for that purpose upon a blank form to be
furnished by the department. Every applicant shall pay all charges, state
specifically and in detail the place, location and kind of connection and
appendages sought, the purpose for which the water is to be used, and all the
plumbing or plumbing work in any manner or way connected therewith. Every
person so making the connection with the system, or using water therefrom,
shall make such connection and use such water and maintain the same subject at
all times to the provisions and conditions of this chapter.
(B)   When the applicant has complied with all the provisions of this chapter,
a permit shall then be issued by the superintendent of buildings or his/her
designee authorizing the connection to be made and specify the size thereof.
All plumbing and plumbing work, also all excavating, filling and replacement of
pavement, shall be done by a plumber authorized by this code to do such
plumbing. The permit shall authorize any plumber who may be selected by the
applicant to do the plumbing work, in the permit described. A permit must be
obtained for each connection and such connection shall serve only a single
building, residence, premises or place.
(C)   The village board shall set the amount of the fee from time to time by
resolution or ordinance. (Ord. 1728, 6-22-2010; amd. Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-15: CONNECTIONS WITH SEWER SYSTEM:
(A)   Each owner or builder of a business interest desiring to connect with the
sewer system shall comply with chapter 5 of this title.
(B)   Upon receipt of a proper application, and when the applicant has complied
with the provisions of this chapter and chapter 5 of this title, a permit shall
be issued by the Superintendent authorizing the making of the connection to the
sewerage system. A permit shall be obtained for each connection made. The
connection to the sewerage system shall be made within thirty (30) days after
the date of the permit, or if the sewerage system has not been constructed at
the expiration of thirty (30) days to such an extent that such connection can
be made, then within thirty (30) days after such construction has been
completed, otherwise the permit shall become null and void.
(C)   It shall be the duty of every person connecting or causing to be
connected any pipe with the sewerage system, to cause such connecting pipe to
be at all times adequate for its purpose, and of such size and dimensions as to
convey and allow freely to pass whatever may properly enter same. All plumbing
and plumbing work, and also all excavating, filling and replacement of pavement
shall be done by a licensed plumber and in such manner as the superintendent
shall direct.
(D)   All connections shall be made by circular saw cut of sewer mains by
proper tools (sewer tap machine or similar) and installation of wye saddle or
tee saddle in accordance to manufacturer's recommendations. (Ord. 1728, 6-22-
2010)
3-3-16: TURNING WATER ON; CHARGE; DEPOSIT:
Before any water is turned on in residential, business or multiple dwelling
property, an application shall be made to the village, and the applicant shall
deposit the following amounts with the application:
(A)   On residential property, the sum of seventy-five dollars ($75.00).
(B)   On business property, the applicant shall deposit the sum of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) for each business unit involved.
(C)   On multiple dwellings, the applicant shall deposit the sum of seventy-
five dollars ($75.00) for each living unit.
The deposits made under the provisions of this chapter shall be held by the
village as security for the payment of water used by the applicant upon the
premises to which its application pertains, and may be so applied when any
default is made in the payment of the water bill. (Ord. 903, 12-14-1977; amd.
Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-17: TAPPING MAINS:
Whenever any permit is issued for a connection to the water system, the
superintendent shall tap the main where such a connection is to be made and
shall insert the corporation valve. For tapping the main, charges shall be made
as determined by the village board. The village board shall set the amount of
the fee by resolution or ordinance in a fee schedule to be maintained by the
village clerk and which shall be made available to the public upon request.
(Ord. 1651, 10-10-2007; amd. Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-18: RATES; COMBINED WATERWORKS AND SEWERAGE SYSTEM:
For the use and service of the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the
village, there are hereby established the following rates and charges:
(A)   Sewer Rates: Sewer rates are set forth in chapter 5 of this title. (Ord.
1728, 6-22-2010)
(B)   Water Meter Rates: The charge for water supplied through meters shall be
as follows: There shall be a basic water usage rate which shall be calculated
from actual gallon usage and billed on a monthly basis. In addition to said
basic water usage rate, there may be a capital improvement surcharge and a debt
service surcharge. The basic water usage rate, the capital improvement
surcharge and debt service surcharge shall be set from time to time by the
village board by ordinance or resolution. The basic water usage rate will be
based upon a cost per one thousand (1,000) gallons. Bills may be issued every
month or every two (2) months or every three (3) months as determined by the
village board.
(C)   Unmetered Water Users: If there are any unmetered water users, their rate
shall be set by the village board by ordinance or resolution. (Ord. 2110, 12-
14-2022; amd. Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-19: OBSTRUCTING HYDRANT; OTHER OFFENSES:
No person shall in any manner obstruct the access to any stop valve, hydrant or
valve or any public faucet or opening for taking water in any street, alley,
public ground or place connected with or part of the water system or plant, nor
pile or place any lumber, brick or building material or other article, thing or
hindrance whatsoever within twelve feet (12') of the same or so as to in any
manner hinder, delay or obstruct the members of the fire department in reaching
the same. It shall be unlawful for any person in any manner to interfere with
or obstruct the flow, retention, storage or authorized use of water in the
water system or plant or any part thereof, or to injure, deface, remove or
displace any water main, hydrant, service pipe, water meter, shutoff box,
public fountain, valve, engine or building connected with the combined
waterworks and sewer system, or to cause, suffer or permit any of said things
to be done. Any person not duly authorized who turns the water on at any fire
hydrant or service cock, or uses water therefrom when so turned on shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor, and the person so using or wasting water in such
unlawful manner shall be liable to pay therefor at the regular water rates
without discount. (Ord. 148, 12-10-1935; amd.Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-20: CARE OF METERS:
All water consumers supplied by the village shall be supplied through meters
only, and shall pay for the water at the rates and in the manner hereinafter
specified.
No water meter shall be used by any consumer unless and until such meter is
sealed by the superintendent, or by someone acting under his direction and
authority.
Every consumer of water shall afford to the superintendent and any and all
persons acting under his direction and authority, free access to any water
meter used by such consumer for the purpose of enabling the same to be sealed
as herein provided. (Ord. 156, 6-22-1937)
All meters shall be placed in a frostproof meter box of approved pattern in the
parkway in front of the building where such parkway exists, and in such manner
as to afford easy access for examining and reading. After the meter is placed,
only members or employees of the water department shall be allowed to repair,
remove or in any manner interfere with the same. A stop valve shall be placed
on each side of the meter. Only the cost of the meter shall be paid by the
village. All repairs and renewals of such meters shall be at the expense of the
village but the owner of, or the applicant for, such meter shall at all times
be responsible for any damage done to the meter, including that done by
freezing or breakage, and also the theft thereof. It shall be unlawful for any
person to injure, deface, mar, destroy or in any manner interfere with any
meter. It shall be the duty of the owner of or applicant for such meter
promptly to notify the department of all defects in any meter or of its failure
properly to register the quantity of water. (Ord. 280, 3-10-1948; amd. Ord.
2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-21: METER FAILURE:
Whenever any meter, by reason of its being out of repair, or for any cause
fails promptly to register the water passing through the same, the consumer
shall be charged at the rate shown for the corresponding time of the previous
year under like conditions.
If no record of the previous year exists, then it shall be the duty of the
superintendent to estimate or determine so far as he can the amount of water
consumed during the time such meter failed to operate, and the consumer shall
pay the amount so estimated by the superintendent. The superintendent shall
make every effort to cause the immediate repair of any malfunctioning meter
upon having notice of the same. (Ord. 148, 12-10-1935; amd. Ord. 2169, 4-23-
2025)
3-3-22: INTERRUPTION OF SERVICE; VILLAGE NOT LIABLE:
All connections and water applied for hereunder, and all the water used
hereunder shall be upon the express condition that the village shall not be
liable, nor shall any claim be made against it for damages or injury caused by
reason of the breaking of any main, branches, service pipes, apparatus or
appurtenances connected with the system or plant, or any part or portion of the
plant, or for any interruption of the supply by reason of the breakage of
machinery or by reason of stoppage, alterations, extensions or renewals or the
refusal of a property owner to provide access to the property to service or
upgrade water lines. (Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-23:  ACCESS TO PREMISES:
The superintendent and every person authorized by him or the department, shall
have ready access to the premises where meters and waterlines are located for
the purpose of installing, inspecting, repairing and testing village meters and
water supply lines and water quality. The superintendent and every person
authorized by him or the department, and all meter inspectors, shall have ready
access to the premises where meters are located for the purpose of reading,
examining, testing and repairing the same, and examining and testing the
consumption, use and flow of water, and it shall be unlawful for any person to
interfere with, prevent or obstruct the superintendent or such other person or
inspector in his work hereunder. Every consumer of village water shall take the
same upon the conditions prescribed in this section. (Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-24: OPENING STREETS:
No street, alley, or public place shall be disturbed or opened for the purpose
of laying water or sewer pipes or making connections with water or sewer pipes
unless a permit so to do is first obtained from the superintendent. The
provisions of this section are not intended to apply to the water department.
(Ord. 143, 12-10-1935)
No person shall make any excavation in any street or highway, within four and
one-half feet (4 ½') of any laid water pipe while the ground is frozen, except
by special order of the Superintendent. (Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-25: PIPES BETWEEN MAIN AND METER; REGULATIONS:
The connection from the main to the meter shall be placed at least four feet
(4') below the surface of the ground and shall be made of copper type "K".
Minimum diameter size is one inch (1"). (Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-26: VALVES AND CONNECTIONS:
A stop valve, to be known as the "service valve", shall be inserted in each
connection at a convenient point in the public ground or place through which
the connection passes and whenever there are curb lines established, the
service valve shall be placed one foot (1') inside of such curb line with a
buffalo box to grade. (Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-27: APPROVAL OF SERVICE PIPES AND METERS:
All service pipes and meters shall be inspected and approved by the
superintendent or some other person under his direction, and no such service
pipes shall be covered until they have been so inspected. The village shall
have the right to test any meter at any time; however, if the test is made at
the request of the consumer, the consumer shall pay the cost for such test,
which will be set, from time to time, by the public works superintendent. (Ord.
1728, 6-22-2010; amd. Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-28: EXTRAORDINARY USE; RATES:
For purposes not hereinbefore specified, and for peculiar and extraordinary
purposes, the rates and conditions for the use of water shall be subject to
special permit and contract with the Village as approved by the president and
board of trustees. (Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-29: RULES AND REGULATIONS FOR TAKERS, PLUMBERS:
The following rules and regulations for the government of water takers and
plumbers are hereby adopted and established and authority is hereby conferred
upon the superintendent to make and establish such additional rules and
regulations as he may deem advisable from time to time and with the consent and
approval of the president and board of trustees:
Rule 1. The president subject to the ratification of the village board shall
appoint all the necessary officers and agents for furnishing water and sewer
service, collecting water and sewer rates, and assessments, and the board shall
determine the term of office, duties and salaries or compensation of such
officers and agents.
Rule 2. All work on the streets and alleys contemplated by this chapter must be
done under the supervision of the superintendent and subject to his direction
and approval.
Rule 3. The corporation valve inserted in the distributing pipes and the
service pipe laid shall be of the size specified in the permit and order. The
superintendent shall keep a complete record and profile of the exact location
and number and sizes of all taps inserted and length of service pipe laid, the
tapper being hereby required to make immediate returns to the superintendent of
such details.
Rule 4. Notice must be left at the office of the superintendent by the plumber
about to lay down a service pipe fixing the day on which he wishes the ferrule
inserted.
Rule 5. No tap shall be any closer than six inches (6") from the bell of the
pipe. The size of the corporation valve to be inserted shall be that specified
in the permit.
Rule 6. It shall be the duty of the superintendent to superintend and direct
all work connected with the combined water and sewer system which may be done
upon the streets of the village, and from time to time to report to the
president and board of trustees as to the manner in which the plumbers perform
their work and the condition in which they find the streets repaired.
Rule 7. Hydrants, taps, hoses, water closets, urinals, baths, and other
fixtures will not be permitted to be kept running when not in actual use; all
faucets connected with the service pipes must be of such pattern as may be
approved by the superintendent.
Rule 8. No private hydrant shall be located on the sidewalk or elsewhere beyond
the limits of the lot of the party to whom the permit is issued.
Rule 9. Every residence or building must have its own separate service line
from the main to the building/residence.
Rule 10. No owner or occupant of any building, premises or enclosure into which
water shall be introduced, will be allowed to supply water to other persons or
families; if so supplied, the water will be cut off.
Rule 11. Applications for water must state fully and truly the purposes for
which it is required, and when paying the charges for it, parties must frankly
and without concealment, answer all questions put to them, relative to the
consumption. The applicant shall, in such application, agree that in
consideration of the insertion of the corporation valve he will pay the
assessments levied or rates charged on the premises for the water pipe that is
proposed to be tapped, and that he will faithfully comply with the rules
established by this chapter, and as changed from time to time. In case of
fraudulent misrepresentation on the part of the applicant or of uses of water
not embraced in the applicant's bill, or of willful or unreasonable use of
water, the supply of water will be cut off and all payments shall be forfeited
to the village.
Rule 12. The superintendent and his authorized agents shall have free access at
all hours of the day between seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00)
P.M. to all parts of every building in which the water is delivered and
consumed, in order to examine the pipes and fixtures and ascertain whether
there is any unnecessary waste, and, if such access be refused, the supply of
water may be cut off without further notice.
Rule 13. The right is reserved to suspend the use of lawn fountains and hose
for sprinkling lawns and gardens, whenever in the opinion of the president and
board of trustees the public exigencies require it.
Rule 14. Every water consumer shall have a water meter, to be approved by the
water department, attached to his water supply pipes; provided, no water meter
shall be so connected until it has been tested by the proper officer and a
permit granted by the superintendent as hereinbefore provided.
Rule 15. All meters must be placed by a licensed plumber or the water
department. The plumber doing the work must flush the pipe thoroughly before
connecting the meter.
Rule 16. The conducting pipes of meters shall be joined with unions or flanges,
ball valves or gate valves inserted to conveniently provide for draining pipes
and meter repairs. The shutoff must be as low as the meter connection. The
meter must not be set in a place where the ground and surface water can rise
and cover it.
Rule 17. No meter shall be removed or disturbed without first having obtained
permission from the superintendent.
Rule 18. The water will not be turned on into any house or private service pipe
except upon the order of the superintendent nor until the applicant shall have
paid his rent for the current term; and the plumbers are strictly prohibited
from turning the water into any service pipe except upon the order and
permission of the superintendent. This rule shall not be construed to prevent
any plumber admitting water to test pipes and for that purpose only.
Rule 19. No hydrants, except public drinking fountains, shall be placed within
the limits of any street, and no drinking fountain shall be erected for public
use which has openings by which it can be used as a source of domestic supply.
Rule 20. All water supplied by the village shall be measured by meter except as
hereinafter provided. Any tap heretofore made in any private water service
pipe, which is located between the public water supply pipe and the meter,
shall be plugged at the main supply pipe and the use of any such tap
discontinued. Consumers of water supplied through any meter shall make all
necessary repairs for the proper operations of the meter, and in case the
superintendent shall deem it necessary or expedient to repair a defective
meter, the expense of such repair shall be charged to the consumer and paid for
when the repair is made.
Rule 21. All bills must be paid to the water department billing staff promptly
when due, and extension of payment in full date shall only be allowed pursuant
to 3-3-9(b) of this chapter.
Rule 22. In all cases where one service pipe supplies two (2) or more separate
consumers in a building occupied by several families, one meter may be placed
at the service connection for either or all of the consumers and the water
rent, as registered by the meter, shall be charged to and be payable by the
owner of the premises or building.
Rule 23. The setting, taking off or repairing of meters shall be done under the
supervision of the superintendent or any other person authorized by the
president.
Rule 24. Whenever two (2) or more persons shall be supplied with one service
pipe connecting with the distribution main, the failure on the part of any one
of the parties to comply with the rules and restrictions provided for the use
of water shall authorize the superintendent to withhold the supply of water
from the main without any liability whatever, and all payments shall be
forfeited. (Ord. 148, 12-10-1935)
Rule 25. For the violation of any of these rules and regulations and such
others as the president and board of trustees may hereafter adopt, the village
reserves the right to stop the supply of water without any preliminary notice,
nor will it be restored until all back water rent, cost and damages shall be
paid, together with the expense of turning off the water and turning it on
again, and upon the satisfactory understanding with the party that no further
cause for complaint shall arise, and the village hereby reserves to itself the
full right, power and authority, to cut off the supply of water at any time,
without incurring any liability or cause of action for damages of any kind; any
permit granted or regulation to the contrary notwithstanding. The expense for
turning off the water and turning it on again shall be established, from time
to time, by the public works superintendent. (Ord 1728, 6-22-2010; amd. Ord.
2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-30: OWNER TO NOTIFY OF PROPERTY LEASE:
Every owner of property in the village shall, within five (5) days, after
making any lease or contract of sale thereof or any portion thereof to any
person, whether the lease or contract be written or oral, notify the
superintendent of public works in writing of the making of the lease or
contract giving the name of the tenant or purchaser, the duration of the lease
or period of contract, and the street number of the property. The owner and
tenant or occupant of such property shall be jointly and severally liable for
all water and sewer service provided by the village and shall be jointly and
severally liable for all such charges and bills as set forth in section
3-3-10 of this chapter. (Ord. 1728, 6-22-2010; amd. Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-31: GREASE TRAPS; CATCH BASINS:
(A)   Business Property: On property used for business purposes, kitchen or
other greasy wastes shall not be emptied directly into the sewerage system, but
the same shall be intercepted by a catch basin or grease trap and thence
conducted to the sanitary sewer.
(B)   Residential Property: The use of catch basins and/or grease traps shall
be optional on property used for residential purposes. (Ord. 633, 12-14-1966;
amd. Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-32: RESTRICTIONS ON LAWN SPRINKLING AND OTHER WATER USES:
(A)   So as to comply with the Illinois department of transportation's "rules
and regulations for the allocation of water from Lake Michigan", it shall be
unlawful for any person to use water for the sprinkling or irrigation of lawns,
gardens or shrubbery on any day of the week between the dates of May 15 and
September 15 of any year, except between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.
to eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. to eleven o'clock
(11:00) P.M. Provided, however, that in the event of a drought, as to be
determined and declared by the village board, it shall be unlawful for any
person with an even numbered address to use water for the sprinkling or
irrigation of lawns or gardens on any day of the week, except on even numbered
calendar days between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to eleven o'clock
(11:00) A.M. or eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. to eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M., and
it shall be unlawful for any person with an odd numbered address to use water
for the sprinkling or irrigation of lawns or gardens on any day of the week,
except on odd numbered calendar days between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00)
A.M. to eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. or eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. to eleven
o'clock (11:00) P.M.
(B)   The village reserves the right to further limit or suspend entirely the
use of water for the sprinkling or irrigation of lawns and gardens or shrubbery
or for any other special purpose(s) whenever the president and board of
trustees shall determine that the public exigencies require such action. If
public exigencies so require, the president may unilaterally take such action
prior to the earliest opportunity available for consultation with the board of
trustees.
(C)   Whenever the president/president and board of trustees limit or suspend
the use of water for the sprinkling or irrigation of lawns and gardens or for
any other special purpose(s), it shall be unlawful for any person to use water
for the sprinkling or irrigation of lawns and gardens or for any other special
purpose(s) designated, other than during the times allowed for such use(s) of
water, provided that said person has been given notice of said limitation on,
or the suspension of, the use of water, from the village, by telephone, United
States mail or personal service or other notification. (Ord. 1196, 8-8-1990)
(D)   Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be fined not
less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than the penalty as provided in
section 1-4-1 of this code or the maximum allowed by state statutes for each
offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or
on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-33: WATER MAIN CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL:
(A)   All plumbing installed within the village shall be installed in
accordance with the Illinois plumbing code, 77 Illinois administrative code
890. If in accordance with the Illinois plumbing code or in the judgment of the
village superintendent of public works, an approved backflow prevention device
is necessary for the safety of the public water supply system, the
superintendent of public works will give notice to the water customer to
install such an approved device immediately. The water customer shall, at his
own expense, install such an approved device at a location, and in a manner,
which is in accordance with the Illinois plumbing code, Illinois environmental
protection agency requirements and all applicable local regulations, and shall
have inspections and tests made of such approved devices upon installation and
as required by the Illinois plumbing code, Illinois environmental protection
agency and local regulations.
(B)   No person shall establish or permit to be established or maintain or
permit to be maintained any connection whereby a private, auxiliary or
emergency water supply other than the regular public water supply of the
village may enter the supply or distribution system of said municipality,
unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and the method of
connection and use of such supply has been approved by the village and the
Illinois environmental protection agency.
(C)   It shall be the duty of the superintendent of public works to cause
inspections, surveys and investigations to be made of industrial and other
properties served by the public water supply to determine whether actual or
potential hazards to the public water supply exist. Such inspections, surveys
and investigations shall be made a matter of public record and shall be
repeated at least every two (2) years, or as often as the superintendent of
public works shall deem necessary. Records of such surveys shall be maintained
and available for review for a period of at least five (5) years.
(D)   Duly authorized cross connection control device inspector(s) as
designated by the superintendent of public works or Illinois environmental
protection agency shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any
property served by a connection to the public water distribution system of the
village for the purpose of verifying the presence or absence of cross
connections, and the superintendent of public works or his duly authorized and
designated agent shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any
property served by a connection to the public water distribution system of the
village for the purpose of verifying information submitted by the customer
regarding the required cross connection control inspection. On demand, the
owner(s), lessee(s) or occupant(s) of any property so served shall furnish to
the superintendent of public works any information which he may request
regarding the piping system(s) or water use on such property. The refusal to
provide such information within a reasonable time, subject to the discretion of
the superintendent of public works, may be deemed evidence of the presence of
improper connections as provided for in this chapter. (Ord. 1234, 11-13-1991)
(E)   The superintendent of public works of the village is hereby authorized
and directed, after reasonable notice to the occupant thereof, to discontinue
the water service to any property wherein any connection in violation of the
provisions of this chapter is known to exist, and to take such other
precautionary measures as he may deem necessary to eliminate any danger of
contamination of the public water distribution mains. Water service to such
property shall not be restored until such conditions have been eliminated or
corrected in compliance with the provisions of this chapter, and until a
reconnection fee as established by the village board is paid to the village.
Immediate disconnection with verbal notice can be effected when the
superintendent of public works is assured that imminent danger of harmful
contamination of the public water supply system exists. Such action shall be
followed by written notification of the cause of disconnection. Immediate
disconnection without notice to any party can be effected to prevent actual or
anticipated contamination or pollution of the water supply; provided, that in
the reasonable opinion of the superintendent of public works or the Illinois
environmental protection agency, such action is required to prevent actual or
potential contamination or pollution of the public water supply. Neither the
village, nor the superintendent of public works or his agents or assigns shall
be liable to any customer for injury, damages, or lost revenues which may
result from termination of said customer's water supply in accordance with the
terms of this chapter, whether or not said termination was with or without
notice. The village board shall set the amount of the fee by resolution or
ordinance in a fee schedule to be maintained by the village clerk, and which
shall be made available to the public upon request. (Ord. 1651, 10- 10-2007)
(F)   The consumer responsible for back siphoned or back pressured material or
contamination through backflow, if contamination of the potable water supply
system occurs through an illegal cross connection or an improperly installed,
maintained or repaired device, or a device which has been bypassed, must bear
the cost of cleanup of the potable water supply system. (Ord. 1234, 11-13-1991;
amd. Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-34: WATER CERTIFICATION OF PAYMENT FEE:
(A)   Unless otherwise provided by law or rule, a full payment certificate
shall be required in all transfers of real property, whether such transfers are
subject to or exempt from the real property transfer stamp requirements of this
code. In order to obtain a full payment certificate, an application with an
application fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be made to the finance
director or their designee. Provided, however, if the property is exempt from
the real property transfer tax under section 4-21-4 of this code, the full
payment certificate application fee shall not be charged. If a full payment
certificate was required and such certificate was not obtained when the real
property was transferred, both the transferor and the transferee will be
jointly and severally liable for any outstanding water fees, sewer charges, and
penalties that have accrued to the water account.
(B)   Where a townhome or condominium property has a single meter and the
respective association's assessments include the individual owner's share of
the water bill, the finance director or their designee may issue a certificate
of condo or townhome owner payment or notice of account arrears as applicable,
upon application and payment of an application fee of twenty-five dollars
($25.00). (Ord. 2124, 6-14-2023; amd. Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
3-3-35: USE OF GROUNDWATER AS A POTABLE WATER SUPPLY PROHIBITED:
(A)   Groundwater As Potable Water Supply: The use or attempt to use as a
potable water supply groundwater from within the corporate limits of the
Village of Midlothian, by the installation or drilling of wells or by any other
method, is hereby prohibited. The prohibitions stated in this section shall be
applicable to units of local government, including the Village of Midlothian.
(Ord. 2001, 9-12-2018)
(B)   Definitions:
 
               Any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company,
PERSON:        limited liability company, corporation, association, joint stock
               company, trust estate, political subdivision, or any other legal
               entity, or their legal representatives, agents, or assigns.
               Any water used for human or domestic consumption, including, but
POTABLE WATER: not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming,
               washing dishes, preparing foods, or watering outside vegetation.
 
(C)   Penalty: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be
subject to a minimum fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation.
Each day a violation exists is a separate offense. (Ord. 1790, 6-27-2012; amd.
Ord. 2169, 4-23-2025)
CHAPTER 4
BUILDING DEPARTMENT
(Rep. by Ord. 1242, 2-12-1992)
CHAPTER 5
PUBLIC SEWERS AND CHARGES
SECTION:
3-5-1: Use Of Public Sewers Required
3-5-2: Private Sewage Disposal
3-5-3: Building Sewers And Connections
3-5-4: Prohibited Discharges; Tests And Analyses
3-5-5: Protection Of Sewage Works From Damage
3-5-6: Powers And Authority Of Inspectors
3-5-7: Penalties
3-5-8: Wastewater Service Charges
3-5-9: General Provisions
3-5-10: Setting Of Rates
3-5-11: Validity
3-5-12: Rate Information
3-5-13: Definitions
3-5-1: USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS REQUIRED:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be
deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the
village in any area under the jurisdiction of said village, any human or animal
excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the
village, or in any area under the jurisdiction of said village, any sewage or
other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in
accordance with subsequent provisions of this chapter.
   (C)   Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or
maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility
intended or used for the disposal of sewage.
   (D)   The owner of all houses, buildings or properties used for human
occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes situated within the
village and abutting on any street, alley, or right of way in which there is
now located or may in the future be located any public sanitary (or combined)
sewer of the village, is hereby required at his expense to install suitable
toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the
proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, within
ninety (90) days after date of official notice to do so, provided that said
public sewer is within three hundred feet (300') of the property line. (Ord.
1191, 6-27-1990)
3-5-2: PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL:
Private sewage disposal is not allowed. (Ord. 1191, 6-27-1990)
3-5-3: BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS:
   (A)   No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or
opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof
without first obtaining a written permit from the village.
   (B)   All disposal by any person into the sewer system is unlawful except
those discharges in compliance with federal standards promulgated pursuant to
the federal act and more stringent state and local standards. (Ord. 1191, 6-27-
1990)
   (C)   1. There shall be two (2) classes of building sewer permits:
         (a)   For residential wastewater service; and
         (b)   For commercial, institutional/governmental or industrial
wastewater service.
      2.   In either case, the owner or his agent shall make application on a
special form furnished by the village. The permit application shall be
supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information considered
pertinent in the judgment of the village. A sewer tap fee shall be set by the
village board from time to time by ordinance or resolution. The owner or agent,
as a condition of permit authorization, must provide information describing its
wastewater constituents, characteristics, and type of activity.
      3.   The village board shall set the amount of the fees and/or bonds from
time to time by resolution or ordinance. (Ord. 1728, 6-22-2010)
   (D)   A building sewer permit will only be issued and a sewer connection
shall only be allowed if it can be demonstrated that the downstream sewerage
facilities, including sewers, pump stations and wastewater treatment
facilities, have sufficient reserve capacity to adequately and efficiently
handle the additional anticipated waste load.
   (E)   All costs and expenses incident to the installation and connection of
the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the
village from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned
by the installation of the building sewer.
   (F)   A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every
building, except that where one building stands at the rear of another on an
interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the
rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the
building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and
the whole considered as one building sewer.
   (G)   No old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings.
   (H)   The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building
sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing,
testing, and backfilling the trench, shall all conform to the requirements of
the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the
village. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the
materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the
American Society Of Testing Materials, "Water Pollution Control Federation
Manual Of Practice No. 9" and "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer Main
Construction In Illinois" shall apply.
   (I)   Only overhead sewers will be allowed in the village for new
construction.
   (J)   No person(s) shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior
foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or
groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected
directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer.
   (K)   The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall
conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code, or other
applicable rules and regulations of the village, or the procedures set forth in
appropriate specifications of the American Society Of Testing Materials, "Water
Pollution Control Federation Manual Of Practice No. 9", and "Standard
Specifications For Water And Sewer Main Construction In Illinois". All such
connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any deviation from the
prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the village before
installation.
   (L)   The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the village
when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public
sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the village
superintendent of public works or his representative.
   (M)   All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately
guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard.
Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course
of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the village. (Ord.
1191, 6-27-1990)
3-5-4: PROHIBITED DISCHARGES; TESTS AND ANALYSES:
   (A)   No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, any stormwater,
surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated
cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer.
   (B)   Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to
such sewers as are specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers,
or to a natural outlet approved by the village. Industrial cooling water or
unpolluted process waters may be discharged on approval of the village, to a
storm sewer, combined sewer, or natural outlet.
   (C)   No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the
following described waters or wastes to any public sewers:
      1.   Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or
explosive liquid, solid, or gas.
      2.   Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids,
or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other
wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a
hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or create any hazard in
the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant.
      3.   Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or having any other
corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures,
equipment, and personnel of the sewage works.
      4.   Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of
causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the
proper operation of the sewage works such as, but not limited to, ashes,
cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar,
plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and
fleshings, entrails and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole
or ground by garbage grinders.
   (D)   No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following
described substances, materials, waters, or wastes if it appears likely in the
opinion of the village that such wastes can harm either the sewers, sewage
treatment process or equipment; have an adverse effect on the receiving stream;
or can otherwise endanger life, limb, public property, or constitute a
nuisance. In forming its opinion as to the acceptability of these wastes, the
village will give consideration to such factors as the quantities of subject
wastes in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of
construction of the sewers, nature of the sewage treatment process, capacity of
the sewage treatment plant, degree of treatability of wastes in the sewage
treatment plant, and maximum limits established by regulatory agencies. The
substances prohibited are:
      1.   Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred
fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°F) or sixty five degrees Celsius (65°C).
      2.   Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous materials; or
oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred milligrams per liter
(100 mg/l) or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at
temperatures between thirty two degrees (32°) (0°C) and one hundred fifty
degrees Fahrenheit (150°F) (65°C).
      3.   Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation
and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths (3/
4) horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater shall be subject to the review and
approval of the village.
      4.   Any waters or wastes containing strong acid, iron pickling wastes,
or concentrated plating solution whether neutralized or not.
      5.   Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc, or
similar objectionable or toxic substances; or wastes exerting an excessive
chlorine requirement, to such degree that any such material received in the
composite sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds the limits established
by the village for such materials.
      6.   Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste or odor
producing substances, in such concentrations exceeding limits which may be
established by the village as necessary after treatment of the composite
sewage, to meet the requirements of the state, federal, or other public
agencies of jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving waters.
      7.   Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or
concentration as may exceed limits established by the village in compliance
with applicable state or federal regulations.
      8.   Any wastes or waters having a pH in excess of 9.5.
      9.   Any mercury or any of its compounds in excess of 0.0005 mg/l as Hg
at any time except as permitted by the village in compliance with applicable
state and federal regulations.
      10.   No cyanide at any time.
      11.   Materials which exert or cause:
         (a)   Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but
not limited to, fuller's earth, lime slurries, and lime residues) or of
dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium
sulfate);
         (b)   Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes
and vegetable tanning solutions);
         (c)   Unusual BOD, chemical oxygen demand, or chlorine requirements in
such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the sewage treatment
works;
         (d)   Unusual volume of flow or concentrations of wastes constituting
slugs as defined herein.
      12.   Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to
treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment processes employed, or are
amenable to treatment only to such degree that the sewage treatment plant
effluent cannot meet the requirements of agencies having jurisdiction over
discharge to the receiving waters.
   (E)   If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be
discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess
the characteristics enumerated in subsection (D) of this section and/or which
are in violation of the standards for pretreatment provided in 40 CFR 403, June
26, 1978, and any amendments thereto, and which in the judgment of the village
and/or the metropolitan water reclamation district of greater Chicago (MWRDGC)
may have a deleterious effect upon the sewage works, processes, equipment or
receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a
public nuisance, the village may:
      1.   Reject the wastes;
      2.   Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge into
the public sewers;
      3.   Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or
      4.   Require payment to cover the added costs of handling and treating
the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges, under the provisions
of subsection (K) of this section.
If the village and/or MWRDGC permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste
flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject
to the review and approval of the village and/or MWRDGC and subject to the
requirement of all applicable codes, ordinances, and laws.
   (F)   Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the
opinion of the village and/or MWRDGC, they are necessary for the proper
handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any
flammable wastes, sand, or other harmful ingredients; except that such
interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling
units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the village
and/or MWRDGC and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for
cleaning and inspection.
   (G)   Where preliminary treatment or flow equalizing facilities are
provided, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective
operation by the owner at his expense.
   (H)   Each industry shall be required to install a control manhole and, when
required by the village and/or MWRDGC, the owner of any property serviced by a
building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control
manhole together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the
building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of the
wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located,
and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the village. The
manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense, and shall be maintained
by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times.
   (I)   The owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying
industrial wastes shall provide laboratory measurements, tests, and analyses of
waters and wastes to illustrate compliance with this chapter and any special
conditions for discharge established by the village or regulatory agencies
having jurisdiction over the discharge.
The number, type, and frequency of laboratory analyses to be performed by the
owner shall be as stipulated by the village, and/or MWRDGC, but no less than
once per year. The owner must supply a complete analysis of the constituents of
the wastewater discharge to assure that compliance with the federal, state, and
local standards are being met. The owner shall report the results of
measurements and laboratory analyses to the village at such times and in such a
manner as prescribed by the village. The owner shall bear the expense of all
measurements, analyses, and reporting required by the village. At such times as
deemed necessary the village reserves the right to take measurements and
samples for analysis by an outside laboratory service.
   (J)   All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters
and wastes to which reference is made in this chapter shall be determined in
accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods For The Examination Of
Water And Wastewater" published by the American Public Health Association and
shall be determined at the control or inspection manhole provided or upon
suitable samples taken at said control or inspection manhole. In the event that
no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered
to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which
the building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily
accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works
and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb, and property. (The
particular analyses involved will determine whether a 24 hour composite of all
outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples
should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids analyses
are obtained from 24 hour composites of all outfalls, whereas pHs are
determined from periodic grab samples.)
   (K)   No statement contained in this section shall be construed as
preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the village and any
industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character
may be accepted by the village for treatment, subject to payment therefor, in
accordance with section 3-5-8 of this chapter, by the industrial concern;
provided, such payments are in accordance with federal and state guidelines for
user charge system and industrial cost recovery system. (Ord. 1191, 6-27-1990)
3-5-5: PROTECTION OF SEWAGE WORKS FROM DAMAGE:
No unauthorized person shall maliciously, wilfully, or negligently break,
damage, destroy, or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or equipment which
is a part of the sewage works. Any person violating this provision shall be
subject to immediate arrest under charge of disorderly conduct. (Ord. 1191, 6-
27-1990)
3-5-6: POWERS AND AUTHORITY OF INSPECTORS:
   (A)   The duly authorized employees of the village, the MWRDGC, the Illinois
environmental protection agency, and the United States environmental protection
agency, bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to
enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement,
sampling, and testing in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The
village representative shall have no authority to inquire into any processes,
including metallurgical, chemical oil, refining, ceramic, paper, or other
industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of
discharge to the sewers or waterway or facilities for waste treatment.
   (B)   While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to
in subsection (A) of this section, the duly authorized employees of the
village, the MWRDGC, the Illinois environmental protection agency, and the
United States environmental protection agency shall observe all safety rules
applicable to the premises established by the company.
   (C)   The duly authorized employees of the village bearing proper
credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private
properties through which the village holds a duly negotiated easement for the
purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement,
sampling, repair, and maintenance of any portion of the sewage collection
system lying within said easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on
said easement, shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly
negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. (Ord. 1191, 6-
27-1990)
3-5-7: PENALTIES:
   (A)   Any person found to be violating any provision of section 3-5-1 to 3-
5-6 of this chapter (except section 3-5-5 of this chapter) shall be served by
the village with written notice stating the nature of the violation and
providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The
offender shall, within the period of the time stated in such notice,
permanently cease all violations. The village may revoke any permit for sewage
disposal as a result of any violation of any provision of this chapter. (Ord.
1191, 6-27-1990)
   (B)   Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit
provided for in subsection (A) of this section shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof shall be fined in an amount not
exceeding seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation. Each day in
which any such violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense.
(Ord. 1728, 6-22-2010)
   (C)   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall
become liable to the village by reasons of such violation. (Ord. 1191, 6-27-
1990)
3-5-8: WASTEWATER SERVICE CHARGES:
   (A)   Basis For Wastewater Service Charges: The wastewater service charge
for the use of and for service supplied by the wastewater collection system of
the village shall consist of a basic user charge, a debt service charge, a
capital improvement charge and any applicable surcharges.
   (B)   Basic User Charge:
      1.   The basic user charge is levied on all users to recover the
operation, maintenance plus replacement (OM&R) costs and shall be based on
water usage as recorded by water meters or sewage meters for wastes having the
following normal domestic concentrations:
         (a)   A five (5) day, twenty degree centigrade (20°C) biochemical
oxygen demand (BOD) of two hundred fifty milligrams per liter (250 mg/l).
         (b)   A suspended solids content of three hundred fifty milligrams per
liter (350 mg/l).
      2.   The basic user charge shall be computed as follows:
         (a)   Estimate the annual wastewater volume.
         (b)   Estimate the projected annual revenue required to operate and
maintain the wastewater collection system including a replacement fund for the
year, for all works categories.
         (c)   Proportion the estimated OM&R costs to wastewater collection
system categories by volume.
         (d)   Compute costs per one thousand (1,000) gallons for normal
domestic strength sewage.
         (e)   Compute surcharge costs per pound for BOD and SS concentrations
in excess of normal domestic strengths.
   (C)   Debt Service Charge: The debt service charge is computed by
apportioning the annual debt service as a fixed charge per billing period.
(Ord. 1191, 6-27-1990)
   (D)   Capital Improvement Charge: The capital improvement charge is levied
upon users to provide capital improvements, extensions or reconstruction of the
sewerage collection system. The capital improvement charge shall be a fixed
amount plus a charge per one thousand (1,000) gallons as set forth in
subsection (K) of this section. (Ord. 1728, 6-22-2010)
   (E)   Surcharge: A surcharge will be levied to all users whose waters exceed
the normal domestic concentrations of BOD two hundred fifty milligrams per
liter (250 mg/l) and SS three hundred fifty milligrams per liter (350 mg/l) if
the board of trustees of the village determines that a surcharge is necessary
to pay any additional cost incurred by the village due to the discharge of
sewage described in this section. A surcharge will be based on water usage as
recorded by water meters or sewage meters for all wastes which exceed the two
hundred fifty milligrams per liter (250 mg/l) and three hundred fifty
milligrams per liter (350 mg/l) concentrations for BOD and SS respectively.
The concentration of sewage used for computing surcharges shall be established
by sewage sampling. Such sewage sampling shall be performed as often as may be
deemed necessary by the village and shall be binding as a basis for surcharges.
   (F)   Annual Review: The adequacy of the wastewater service charge shall be
reviewed, not less often than annually, by certified public accountants for the
village in their annual audit report. The wastewater service charge shall be
revised periodically to reflect a change in local capital costs or OM&R costs.
   (G)   Notification Of Rate: The users of the wastewater services will be
notified annually, in conjunction with a regular bill, of the rate and that
portion of the user charges which are attributable to the wastewater operation,
maintenance and replacement.
   (H)   Measurement Of Flow: The volume of flow used for computing basic user
charges and surcharges shall be metered water consumption read to the lowest
even increments of one hundred (100) gallons.
      1.   If the person discharging wastes into the public sewers procures any
part, or all, of his water from sources other than the public waterworks
system, all or part of which is discharged into the public sewers, the person
shall install and maintain, at his expense, water meters of a type approved by
the village for the purpose of determining the volume of water obtained from
these other sources.
      2.   Devices for measuring the volume of waste discharged may be required
by the village if these volumes cannot otherwise be determined from the metered
water consumption records.
      3.   Metering devices for determining the volume of waste shall be
installed, owned, and maintained by the person. Following approval and
installation, such meters may not be removed, unless service is canceled,
without the consent of the village. (Ord. 1191, 6-27-1990)
   (I)   Basic User Charge: The village board shall establish a basic user
charge based upon one thousand (1,000) gallons of metered water use and a fixed
charge to cover operating, maintenance plus replacement costs to be applied to
all users. These rates shall be set by the village board from time to time as
deemed necessary by ordinance or resolution. (Ord. 1866, 5-14-2014)
   (J)   Debt Service Charge: There shall be and there is hereby established a
debt service charge to be issued on a monthly basis to each user of the village
sewerage collection system. The debt service charge shall be set by the village
board from time to time by ordinance or resolution.
   (K)   Capital Improvement Charge: There shall be and there is hereby
established a capital improvement charge as stated in subsection (D) of this
section to be issued on a monthly basis to each user of the village sewage
collection system. The capital improvement charge shall be set by the village
board from time to time by ordinance or resolution.
   (L)   Rates: A minimum charge per month shall be applied to all users whose
water consumption does not exceed two thousand (2,000) gallons per month. This
minimum charge shall consist of a charge for OM&R costs (including a fixed OM&R
cost), a debt service charge and a capital improvement charge. Such minimum
charge, consisting of OM&R costs, as well as the debt service charge and
capital improvement charge shall be set by the village board from time to time
by ordinance or resolution.
Usage in excess of two thousand (2,000) gallons per month will be charged at a
rate as set by the village board from time to time by ordinance or resolution.
Bills may be issued every month or every two (2) months or every three (3)
months as determined by the village board. (Ord. 1728, 6-22-2010)
   (M)   Metered Services: At this time all water services are metered and all
new water services are required to be metered.
   (N)   Surcharge Rates: The rates of surcharges for BOD and SS shall be as
follows:
      Per pound of BOD: None at this time.
      Per pound of SS: None at this time.
   (O)   Computation Of Wastewater Service Charge: The wastewater service
charge shall be computed by the following formula:
         CW = CC + CD + CM + (Vu-X)CU + CS
Where:  
CW =   Amount of wastewater service charge ($) per billing period
CC =   Capital improvement charge
CD =   Debt service charge
CM =   Minimum charge for operation, maintenance and replacement
Vu =   Wastewater volume for the billing period
X  =   Allowable consumption in gallons for the minimum charge
CU =   Basic user charge for operation, maintenance and replacement
CS =   Surcharges, if applicable
 
   (Ord. 1191, 6-27-1990)
3-5-9: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   (A)   Bills: Said rates or charges for service may be payable monthly, every
two (2) months or quarterly depending on the determination of the village
board. The village board may authorize a different billing cycle for
residential use other than for apartments and commercial. The owner of the
premises, the occupant thereof and the user of the service shall be jointly and
