   (G)   Heater Room Interior Finish:
      1.   Material: One hour fire resistive construction; see chapter 22,
"Appendix A", of this title.
      2.   Installation: Apply over all combustible materials, including
ceiling area, within four feet (4') of heating unit and flue pipe. (Ord., 12-

4-10-14: FINISH FLOORS:
   (A)   Cement Floors:
      1.   Mix: See subsections 4-10-5(B) and (K)2 of this chapter.
      2.   Heater room floors on wood construction where heating equipment
raises temperatures of floor to above one hundred sixty degrees (160°), comply
with the following:
         (a)   Minimum thickness, four inches (4").
         (b)   Use sheet metal over tops of joists for concrete forms or out of
one inch (1") boards flush with top of joists. If wood boards are used, remove
after slab has set.
         (c)   Reinforce slab with wire mesh weighing not less than thirty (30)
pounds per one hundred (100) square feet, or with one-fourth inch (1/4") bars
spaced one foot (1') on center each way.
   (B)   Wood Floors: See subsection 4-10-8(C)5 of this chapter.
      1.   Materials:
         (a)   Flooring. Kiln dried material.
         (b)   Strip flooring, hardwood or softwood minimum thickness twenty
five thirty seconds inch (25/32"), maximum width two and one- fourth inches
(21/4") for hardwood, three and one-fourth inches (31/4") for softwood. Three-
eighths inch (3/8") thickness may be used when laid directly on a subfloor.
Wider widths (plank flooring) and parquet flooring may be used when precautions
are taken to prevent warping or cupping.
         (c)   Nails. Maximum spacing, sixteen inches (16") on center.
         (d)   Building paper or deadening felt. Apply under all finish
flooring unless floor is insulated.
      2.   Installation:
         (a)   Finish flooring over subflooring: Apply at right angles to
subflooring except when subflooring is laid diagonally.
         (b)   Finish flooring on strips: Wood strips, minimum size, three-
eighths inch by one and one-half inch (3/8" x 11/2"). Maximum spacing, sixteen
inches (16") on center. Apply strips over building paper or deadening felt on
top of subflooring.
         (c)   Strip flooring on concrete: Apply on not less than two inch by
two inch (2" x 2") sleepers embedded in concrete.
         (d)   Wood block floorings on concrete: Set blocks in mastic and
install in accordance with flooring manufacturer's directions.
   (C)   Ceramic Tile:
      1.   Materials: See chapter 22, "Appendix A", of this title.
      2.   Grade: Not less than standard grade.
      3.   Setting bed:
         (a)   Mix one part Portland cement, four (4) parts sand; one part
Portland cement, two (2) parts sand and four (4) parts pea size aggregate.
         (b)   Minimum thickness: One and one-fourth inches (11/4"), if
reinforced with wire mesh; three inches (3") when installed below top of
chamfered joists, with finish tile surface at least one and one-half inches
(11/2") above tops of joists.
      4.   When applied over wood subfloor: Install asphalt saturated felt over
subfloor underneath the wire mesh.
   (D)   Resilient Floor Covering: Install according to manufacturer's
instructions. (Ord., 12-12-1962)
4-10-15: GARAGES:
   (A)   Attached And Built In Garages:
      1.   Construction same as required for dwelling.
      2.   If door opening occurs between garage and dwelling, provide six inch
(6") curb at the door or construct garage floor six inches (6") lower than
adjoining floor.
      3.   Installation of house heating unit or other fuel burning appliance
in garage space not permitted. Install one hour fire resistant partition
between space containing house heating unit and garage space.
      4.   Wood frame walls and doors common to dwelling and garage: Finish on
garage side to be one hour fire resistive construction. Where rooms occur over
garage ceiling and all walls shall be one hour fire resistive construction.
Sheet metal on door acceptable. See chapter 22, "Appendix A", of this title.
   (B)   One-Story Detached Garages:
      1.   Comply with construction requirement for one-story dwellings with
the following exceptions:
         (a)   Bottom of concrete footings of frame garages, unless supported
on not less than four inch (4") slab, not less than eighteen inches (18") below
natural grade.
         (b)   Studs, maximum spacing twenty four inches (24") on center.
Doubling of studs not required on jambs of openings less than three feet five
inches (3'5") wide.
         (c)   Sheathing and building paper may be omitted.
         (d)   Corner post may be two (2) two inch by four inch (2" x 4") or a
four inch by four inch (4" x 4").
         (e)   Rafter ties at eaves not less than two inches by four inches (2"
x 4"), maximum spacing, six feet (6') on center.
         (f)   Corner bracing is required, except where sheathing is used, and
may be applied on the outside surface of studs.
         (g)   Flooring may be gravel. If concrete, see subsection 4-10-5(K)5
of this chapter.
      2.   Garages with masonry wall shall have a concrete footing at least
three feet six inches (3'6") below grade. (Ord., 12-12-1962)
4-10-16: SIDEWALKS:
Sidewalks will be required to be installed on all new construction of homes,
apartments, businesses, industrial or recreational use. Sidewalks shall also be
required where they do not exist on any remodeling projects where, in the
determination of the Building Superintendent, the interest of the Village would
require installation of the sidewalk. The construction of the cement sidewalk
would be on the full street frontage of the lot or lots to be improved and on
the side lot frontage on corner lots. Sidewalks shall be built and located in
accordance with the regulations and ordinances of title 9, chapter 1 of this
Code. (Ord. 874, 2-23-1977)
4-10-17: FIRE RESISTANCE:
The provisions of this section shall apply to all multi-family structures
containing three (3) or more living units; or one or more living units in a
structure containing any other type of use such as business or industrial. The
fire resistance rating of structural elements (including walls, floors and
roof) and tenant separation or party walls shall be a minimum of two (2) hours
and be constructed of noncombustible materials.
Exterior and load bearing wall construction shall be of masonry. All floors
shall be of the precast concrete type, poured concrete type or other type
having at least a two (2) hour fire resistance rating. (Ord. 1132, 5-27-1987)
4-10-18: ENERGY CODE ADOPTED:
   (A)   Code Adopted: The 2018 International Energy Conservation Code as
published and triennially amended by the State of Illinois, is hereby adopted
and incorporated in full as if set forth at length herein, and shall apply and
control within the Village of Midlothian, save and except such portions as
hereinafter deleted, modified or amended.
   (B)   Other Code References: References to other International Codes herein
shall mean and apply as follows:
      1.   International Building Code (IBC) as adopted and amended by the
Village of Midlothian.
      2.   References to the International Existing Building Code are hereby
deleted.
      3.   International Fire Code (IFC) references shall be deleted and
replaced with the National Fire Code, 2009 edition published by the National
Fire Protection Association, the National Fire Protection Association Code #1,
2009 edition, the National Fire Protection Association Code 101, Life Safety
Code, 2009 edition and their subsequent revisions and the whole thereof, except
such portions pertaining to the organization, administration, operation, and
equipment of the Fire Department and such portions as are otherwise
inapplicable to the Village, or as are hereinafter deleted, modified or amended
by the Village of Midlothian.
      4.   International Plumbing Code (IPC) references shall be deleted and
replaced with the Illinois Plumbing Code as adopted and amended by the Village
of Midlothian.
      5.   International Residential Code (IRC) as adopted and amended by the
Village of Midlothian.
      6.   International Mechanical Code (IMC) and the International Fuel Gas
Code (IFGC) as adopted and amended by the Village of Midlothian.
      7.   References to the International Private Sewage Disposal Code are
hereby deleted and replaced with the provisions of title 3, chapter 5 of the
Village Code.
      8.   International Property Maintenance Code as adopted and amended by
the Village of Midlothian.
   (C)   Amendments: The following amendments to the 2018 edition of the
International Energy Conservation Code (hereinafter IECC), shall apply:
      1.   Section C101.1 shall name the Village of Midlothian as the
jurisdiction and shall state the following: These regulations shall be known as
the Energy Conservation Code of the Village of Midlothian, hereinafter referred
as the "Energy Code."
      2.   Section C109.1 referencing Board of Appeals is hereby amended to
designate the Village Board of the Village of Midlothian as the Board of
Appeals and to provide that the Village board shall adopt rules of procedure
for conducting its appeal functions and issue all decisions and findings in
writing.
      3.   Section C109.3 referencing Qualifications is hereby deleted.
      4.   Section R101.1 shall name the Village of Midlothian as the
jurisdiction and shall state the following: These regulations shall be known as
the Energy Conservation Code of the Village of Midlothian, hereinafter referred
as the "Energy Code."
      5.   Section R109.1 referencing Board of Appeals is hereby amended to
designate the Village Board of the Village of Midlothian as the Board of
Appeals and to provide that the Village board shall adopt rules of procedure
for conducting its appeal functions and issue all decisions and findings in
writing.
      6.   Section R109.3 referencing Qualifications is hereby deleted.
(Ord. 2032, 7-10-2019)

REGULATIONS
SECTION:
4-11-1: Other Buildings

4-11-1: OTHER BUILDINGS:
Whenever this Code does not specifically cover the construction of any building
or structure or part of building for which plans have been submitted or
application is made, the provisions of the National Building Code of 1967, as
amended, will apply. The National Building Code of 1967, as amended, referred
to herein and made a part of this Code, as recommended and distributed by the
American Insurance Association, Midwestern Department, 120 South La Salle
Street, Chicago, Illinois. (Ord. 701, 5-13-1970)
4-11-2: ILLINOIS PLUMBING CODE ADOPTED:
   (A)   Code Adopted: There is hereby adopted by the Village of Midlothian for
the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the construction,
alteration, removal, demolition, use of equipment, use, occupancy, location,
and maintenance of building structures, including permits and penalties, a
Plumbing Code known as the Illinois Plumbing Code (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890) as
required by the State of Illinois, Department of Public Health. The Illinois
Plumbing Code (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890) is adopted with local amendments and
incorporated by this reference as though fully set forth herein. From the date
on which this section shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall control
the construction of buildings and other structures therein contained within the
corporate limits of the Village.
   (B)   Amendments: The Illinois Plumbing Code (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890) is
amended with the following local amendments:
      1.   Pursuant to 17 Ill. Admin. Code 3730.307(c)(4) and subject to the
Illinois Plumbing Code (77 Ill. Admin. Code 890) and the Lawn Irrigation
Contractor and Sprinkler Registration Code (77 Ill. Admin. Code 892), all new
plumbing fixtures and irrigation controllers installed after November 15, 2015
shall bear the WaterSense label (as designated by the U.S. environmental
Protection Agency WaterSense Program), when such labeled fixtures are
available.
      2.   The first sentence of Section 890.1190-b) shall be deleted in its
entirety and replaced with the following: "The utility meter (water meter)
shall be located within the building. Meter vaults are prohibited unless
approved by the Superintendent of Public Works or Building Superintendent"
(Amends Section 890.1190-b).
      3.   Water Service Pipe Sizing. For all new construction, water service
piping from the street main into the building shall be a minimum size of one
and a half inches in diameter, type K copper. Existing residential water
service piping from the street into the building shall be a minimum size of one
inch in diameter. (Amends Section 890.1200-a)
      4.   Building drainage/vent pipes shall consist of the following approved
materials:
         (a)   Brass pipe. (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890, Appendix A, #2)
         (b)   Cast iron pipe. (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890, Appendix A, #3)
         (c)   Chlorinated polyvinyl chloride (CPVC) only for chemical waste
drainage systems (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890, Appendix A, #4)
         (d)   Copper/copper alloy. (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890, Appendix A, #5)
         (e)   Copper/copper alloy tubing - Type K, L or M. (77 Ill. Adm. Code
890, Appendix A, #6)
         (f)   Galvanized steel pipe. (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890, Appendix A, #7)
         (g)   Glass fiber borosilicate. (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890, Appendix A,
#8)
         (h)   High silicone content cast iron pipe. (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890,
Appendix A, #9)
         (i)   Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) pipe and fittings. (77 Ill. Adm. Code
890, Appendix A, #11)
         (j)   Solder. (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890, Appendix A, #14)
         (k)   Stainless steel - types 304 and 316L. (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890,
Appendix A, #15)
         (l)   Stainless steel buttweld fittings. (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890,
Appendix A, #16)
         (m)   Stainless steel flanges. (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890, Appendix A,
#17)
         (n)   Identification of piping systems per ASME A13.1-2007. (77 Ill.
Adm. Code 890, Appendix A, #18)
(Amends Section 890 by deleting items 1, 10, 12 and 13 of Appendix A)
      5.   Building sewer pipes shall consist of the following approved
materials:
         (a)   Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) pipe-white and
         (b)   SDR - 26 green (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890, Appendix A)
         (c)   Piping systems as provided by ASME A13.1-2007. (77 Ill. Adm.
Code 890, Appendix A, #12);
(Amends Section 890 by deleting items 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 9, 10, and 11 of
Appendix)
      6.   Water service piping shall consist of the following approved
materials:
         (a)   Cast iron (ductile iron) water pipe 2 inches and larger for
commercial use. (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890, Appendix A, #3)
         (b)   Copper/copper alloy pipe. (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890, Appendix A,
#5)
         (c)   Copper/copper alloy tubing. (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890, Appendix A,
#6)
(Amends Section 890 by deleting items 1, 2, 4, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, and
15 of Appendix A)
      7.   Water distribution pipes shall consist of the following approved
materials:
         (a)   Brass pipe. (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890, Appendix A, #1)
         (b)   Copper/copper alloy pipe. (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890, Appendix A,
#3)
         (c)   Copper/copper alloy tubing - Type K, L or M (77 Ill. Adm. Code
890, Appendix A, #4)
         (d)   Galvanized steel pipe. (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890, Appendix A, #7)
         (e)   Stainless Steel pipe. (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890, Appendix A, #10)
         (f)   Welded copper water tube. (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890, Appendix A,
#11)
         (g)   Lead free solder. (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890, Appendix A, #12)
(Amends Section 890, by deleting items 2, 5, 6, 8, and 9 of Appendix A)
      8.   Gravity Sewer: Only overhead sewers shall be allowed for new
construction in the Village as required by 3-5-3(I) of the Village Code.
   (C)   Penalty: Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be
fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than the penalty as
provided in section 1-4-1 of the Village Code or the maximum allowed by State
Statutes for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on
each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 2034, 7-24-
2019)

4-11-4: ELECTRICAL CODE ADOPTED:
   (A)   The last amended Electrical Code of the City of Chicago with the
following changes and additions thereto is hereby adopted by the Village of
Midlothian:
      1.   The Building Superintendent of the Village of Midlothian shall have
primary authority to enforce this code.
      2.   Article 210.8(A)(5) regarding Branch Circuits is amended to allow a
single receptacle to be installed for sump pumps and ejector pumps.
      3.   Article 210.8(A)(2) regarding Garages, and 210.8(A)(5) regarding
Unfinished Basements is amended to allow a single receptacle that is not
readily accessible for appliances located within a dedicated space for each
appliance that, in normal use, is not easily moved from one place to another
and that is cord and plug connected in accordance with Section 400.10(A)(6),
(A)(7) or (A)(8).
      4.   Article 210.12(A) is amended to allow the omission of AFCI
protection for a single receptacle located in hallways.
      5.   Article 230.42(B)(1) regarding service size is amended to add
minimum electrical service size for a single-family residence shall be a 100-
amp service for a single-family home of up to 1500 square feet of habitable
space and minimum electrical service size for a single-family residence over
1500 square feet of habitable space is a 200-amp service.
      6.   Electrical Contractor Defined: The term "electrical contractor"
means any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of installing or
altering by contract, electrical equipment for the utilization of electricity
supplied for light, heat or power not including radio apparatus or equipment
for wireless reception of sounds and signals, and not including apparatus,
conductors and other equipment installed for or by public utilities (including
common carriers) which are under the jurisdiction of the Illinois commerce
commission for use in their operation as public utilities, but the term
"electrical contractor" does not include employees of such contractor to do or
supervise such work.
(Ord. 2011, 1-9-2019)
CHAPTER 11A
FENCES
SECTION:
4-11A-1: Permits And Fees
4-11A-2: Definition
4-11A-3: Height Of Fences
4-11A-4: Location Of Fence
4-11A-5: Visional Clearance
4-11A-1: PERMITS AND FEES:
It shall be unlawful to construct or cause to be constructed a fence or fences
unless a permit is obtained from the department of buildings. The fee for the
permit shall be established by the village board. The village board shall set
the amount of the fee by resolution or ordinance in a fee schedule to be
maintained by the village clerk and which shall be made available to the public
upon request. (Ord. 1651, 10-10-2007)
4-11A-2: DEFINITION:
For the purpose of this code, a "fence" shall be defined as any manmade
structure which is constructed for the purpose of or has the effect of
enclosing or screening the area it is constructed upon. The provisions of this
code shall not apply to shrubbery or trees except in relation to the provisions
relating to corner visional clearance. (Ord. 606, 6-9-1965)
4-11A-3: HEIGHT OF FENCES:
Fences shall be constructed so as not to exceed the following heights:
   (A)   On the side or front of a lot which is adjacent to a street and on
other side lot lines on the street side of the building line, the height of the
fence shall not exceed three and one-half feet (31/2') except where the fence
is on or behind the building setback line, in that area the fence may be up to
six feet (6'). These provisions shall not apply to fences built on property
zoned E, F and G if the property is used for commercial or industrial purposes.
(Ord. 737, 4-26-1972)
   (B)   On all other lot lines or portions of lot lines the height of the
fence shall not exceed six feet (6'). (Ord. 606, 6-9-1965)
4-11A-4: LOCATION OF FENCE:
The fence may be constructed on the lot line or inside the lot line. (Ord. 606,
6-9-1965)
4-11A-5: VISIONAL CLEARANCE:
Notwithstanding any provisions relating to height hereinbefore stated, the
"visional clearance area" which shall be defined as a triangular area measured
twenty five feet (25') on the front lot line and fifty feet (50') on the side
lot line of a corner lot shall not be obstructed by any wall, fence, hedge or
shrubbery which exceeds three and one-half feet (31/2') in height. In the event
that the grade of a lot is higher than the street grade, the height of the
wall, fence, hedge or shrubbery shall be reduced so that the visional clearance
is not obstructed three and one-half feet (31/2') over the grade of the street.
(Ord. 606, 6-9-1965)
These provisions do not apply to fences built on property zoned E, F and G if
the property is used for commercial or industrial purposes. (Ord. 737, 4-26-
1972)
CHAPTER 11B
SIGNS
SECTION:
4-11B-1: Requirements; Fees And Bonds
4-11B-1: REQUIREMENTS; FEES AND BONDS:
The requirements, standards, landscape requirements, maintenance and all other
regulations concerning signs are contained in title 11, chapter 14 of this
code. All permit fees, bonds and other fees with regard to signs shall be
established by the village board. The village board shall set the amount of the
fee by resolution or ordinance in a fee schedule to be maintained by the
village clerk and which shall be made available to the public upon request.
(Ord. 1651, 10-10-2007)
CHAPTER 11C
DECKS AND PORCHES
SECTION:
4-11C-1: Permits And Fees
4-11C-2: Definitions
4-11C-3: Adoption Of Guidelines
4-11C-1: PERMITS AND FEES:
It shall be unlawful to construct or cause to be constructed a deck or porch
unless a permit is obtained from the Department of Buildings. The fee for the
permit shall be established by the Village Board. The Village Board shall set
the amount of the fee by resolution or ordinance in a fee schedule to be
maintained by the Village Clerk and which shall be made available to the public
upon request. (Ord. 2021, 3-19-2019)
4-11C-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, a deck shall be defined as a one or multi-
level platform constructed near grade, the highest floor of which is not in
excess of six feet (6') in height from the ground. A porch shall be an open-air
structure typically attached to the exterior of a building, the floor of which
is in excess of six feet (6') in height from the ground. (Ord. 2021, 3-19-2019)
4-11C-3: ADOPTION OF GUIDELINES:
The most current American Wood Council's DCA #6 "Prescriptive Residential Wood
Deck Construction Guide" is hereby adopted and incorporated in full as if set
forth at length herein, and shall apply and control for decks under six feet
(6') in height from the ground and the provisions of City of Chicago Building
Department's most current "Porch Design and Construction Guidelines" shall
apply and control for decks or porches in excess of six feet (6') in height
from the ground in the Village of Midlothian. (Ord. 2021, 3-19-2019)
CHAPTER 11D
TENTS
SECTION:
4-11D-1: Permits And Fees
4-11D-2: Definitions
4-11D-3: Regulations, Permit Requirements
4-11D-1: PERMITS AND FEES:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to erect, construct, or cause to be erected or
constructed, a tent within the Village, unless a permit is obtained from the
Building Department, as follows:
      1.   Any tent that is larger than two hundred (200) square feet (i.e.:
10x20 measurement) and is located in any zone.
   (B)   Smaller temporary tents or other structures located in a residential
zone do not require a building permit if they meet the following:
      1.   Residential-use pop-up canopies that measure two hundred (200)
square feet or less.
      2.   Camping tents in a residential zone.
   (C)   Camping tents shall not be permitted in any business or office/
industrial zone.
   (D)   The fee for the permit shall be established by the Village Board. The
Village Board shall set the amount of the fee by resolution or ordinance in a
fee schedule to be maintained by the Village Clerk and which shall be made
available to the public upon request. (Ord. 2101, 7-13-2022)
4-11D-2: DEFINITIONS:
Except as otherwise provided herein, for the purposes of this chapter, the term
"tent" shall be defined as any tent, canopy, or portable structure, including
sunscreens, with or without walls of canvas or other like material, covered
with similar materials and supported by poles, stakes, and/or ropes. (Ord.
2101, 7-13-2022)
4-11D-3: REGULATIONS, PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   (A)   No tent requiring a permit in any zoning district shall be erected for
more than seven (7) consecutive days, and no tent shall be erected on any given
property more than three (3) times per year.
   (B)   All tents in office/industrial or business districts shall be
regulated through an event permit.
   (C)   No tents in office/industrial or business districts shall be erected
on any property between November 1 and March 30 of any year.
   (D)   All erected tents must be located behind the building lot line or
located in such an area that is approved by the Building Department and Fire
Department and at a minimum, at least fifteen feet (15') behind the front lot
line of the property where the tent is erected.
   (E)   All tents requiring a permit shall be subject to inspection by the
Building Department, Fire Department, and/or Police Department prior to their
intended use.
   (F)   All tents intended to be part of an outdoor café and/or accessory to a
restaurant or bar, shall be a permitted for special use, pursuant to Title 11-
9 of the Village Code.
   (G)   Permit requirements include, but may not be limited to, the following:
      1.   Permission letter from property owner is required if installing a
tent on property owned by others.
      2.   If the tent is to be installed by a commercial tent installer,
regardless of size, a contractor license and a twenty thousand dollar
($20,000.00) surety bond made out to the Village of Midlothian are required,
      3.   If the tent occupancy is forty (40) or more, a detailed site/floor
plan is required, detailing exits, seating arrangements, lighting requirements,
fire extinguisher location, and electrical equipment.
      4.   All tents must be made of Fire-Resistant Material, with certificate.
   (H)   All tents or other temporary structures must otherwise comply with all
requirements of the Village of Midlothian. (Ord. 2101, 7-13-2022)
CHAPTER 12
SPECIAL PROVISIONS AND STRUCTURES
SECTION:
4-12-1: Fallout Shelters
4-12-2: Permits; Fees
4-12-3: Location
4-12-1: FALLOUT SHELTERS:
Family shelters shall be constructed in accordance with instructions issued by
the department of defense, office of civil defense, Washington, D.C., in a
pamphlet known as PSD F-61-1.
Shelters constructed for use of more than one family or for use of the general
public shall be constructed in accordance with the recommendations of the civil
defense director of the village who shall obtain the necessary plans and
specifications from the department of defense. (Ord., 12-12-1962)
4-12-2: PERMITS; FEES:
No fallout shelter shall be constructed unless a permit for same has been
obtained from the chairman of the building committee.
No permit fee shall be charged for such permit. (Ord., 12-12-1962)
4-12-3: LOCATION:
Prior to the issuance of any permit for a fallout shelter to be constructed
aboveground, the building committee shall inspect the proposed site of the
shelter and shall ascertain the effect said construction may have on
surrounding buildings and structures. The building committee shall deny such
permit if said construction will violate the rights of surrounding property
owners and/or residents. (Ord., 12-12-1962)
CHAPTER 13
VIOLATIONS; PENALTY
SECTION:
4-13-1: Enforcement
4-13-2: Liability
4-13-3: Violations; Penalty
4-13-1: ENFORCEMENT:
It shall be the duty of all officers of the village to enforce the provisions
of this code.
For the purpose of enforcement of this code, the superintendent of buildings
and inspectors shall be considered officers of the village and shall have the
power to arrest or cause to be arrested any firm or person who shall violate
the provisions of this code. (Ord., 12-12-1962)
4-13-2: LIABILITY:
The superintendent of buildings, the building committee, or any assistant or
deputy carrying out the instructions of the superintendent of buildings or
building committee is not personally liable for actions taken by him or them
for carrying out their duties in good faith and without malice. (Ord., 12-12-
1962)
4-13-3: VIOLATIONS; PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this code shall be fined not less
than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than the penalty as provided in section 1-4-
1 of this code or the maximum allowed by state statutes for each offense. Each
day that said violation shall continue shall be a separate offense. Any person
who shall construct any building or structure, or who shall alter any building
or structure in violation of the provisions of this code, or any architect
having supervision over such building or construction, who shall wilfully
permit such violations, and/or the owner of any building or structure who shall
wilfully permit such violation, shall also be subject to such penalties as are
provided herein. Whoever shall perform any construction in violation of this
code shall be required to remove such construction at his or their expense.
(Ord. 823, 10-9-1974; amd. Ord. 1362, 9-13-1995)
CHAPTER 14
DANGEROUS BUILDINGS
SECTION:
4-14-1: Definition
4-14-2: Prohibition
4-14-3: Abatement
4-14-4: Fire Limits
4-14-5: Lien
4-14-6: Repeal Of Ordinances
4-14-7: Penalty
4-14-1: DEFINITION:
The term "dangerous building", as used in this chapter, is hereby defined to
mean and include:
   (A)   Any building, shed, fence or other manmade structure which is
dangerous to the public health because of its condition, and which may cause or
aid in the spread of disease, or injury to the health of the occupants of it or
neighboring structures.
   (B)   Any building, shed, fence or other manmade structure which, because of
faulty construction, age, lack of proper repair or any other cause, is
especially liable to fire and constitutes or creates a fire hazard.
   (C)   Any building, shed, fence or other manmade structure, which, by reason
of faulty construction or any other cause, is liable to cause injury or damage
by collapsing or by a collapse or fall of any part of such structure.
   (D)   Any building, shed, fence or other manmade structure, which, because
of its condition or because of lack of doors or windows is available to and
frequented by malefactors or disorderly persons or children who are not lawful
occupants of such structure.
Any such dangerous building in the village is hereby declared to be a nuisance.
(Ord. 568, 3-11-1964)
4-14-2: PROHIBITION:
It shall be unlawful to maintain or permit the existence of any dangerous
building in the village, and it shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant or
person in custody of any dangerous building to permit the same to remain in a
dangerous condition, or to occupy such building or permit it to be occupied
while it is or remains in a dangerous condition. (Ord. 568, 3-11-1964)
4-14-3: ABATEMENT:
Whenever the building inspector, the fire chief or the health officer shall be
of the opinion that any building or structure in the village is a dangerous
building, he shall file a written statement to this effect with the chairman of
the building committee. The village board may then instruct the village clerk
to thereof cause written notice to be served upon the owner of record thereof,
and upon the occupant thereof, if any, by registered or certified mail or by
personal service. Such notice shall state that the building has been declared
to be in a dangerous condition, and that such dangerous condition must be
removed or remedied by repairing or altering the building or by demolishing it,
and that the condition must be remedied at once. Such notice may be in the
following terms:
To                           (owner-occupant of premises) of the premises known
and described as                          .
You are hereby notified that (describe building) on the premises above
mentioned has been condemned as a nuisance and a dangerous building after
inspection by                          .
The causes of this decision are (here insert the facts as to the dangerous
condition).
You must remedy this condition or demolish the building immediately, or the
Village will proceed to do so, or contract to have same done pursuant to the
provision of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-31-1 and 5/11-31-2.
If the person receiving the notice has not complied therefor or taken an appeal
from the determination of the officer or employee finding that a dangerous
building exists, within twenty (20) days from the time when this notice is
mailed or served upon such person by personal service or mail, the building
inspector may, upon orders of the village, proceed to remedy the condition or
demolish the dangerous building, or cause said building to be demolished and a
lien filed as provided in aforementioned statute. (Ord. 568, 3-11-1964)
4-14-4: FIRE LIMITS 1 :
Any frame building or structure within the fire limits of the city as
prescribed by ordinance, which has or may be damaged by fire, decay or other
causes to the extent of fifty percent (50%) of its value, shall be torn down
and removed, or rebuilt with nonflammable walls. (Ord. 568, 3-11-1964)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 7-1-1 of this code.
4-14-5: LIEN:
If the said building is demolished by the village, the village board shall
instruct the village attorney to file a lien against said property pursuant to
the provision of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-31-1. (Ord. 568, 3-11-1964)
4-14-6: REPEAL OF ORDINANCES:
All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with the provisions of this
and specifically ordinance 294, inserted as chapter 2, "Dangerous Buildings",
sections 4-2-1 to 4-2-4 of this code, are hereby repealed. (Ord. 568, 3-11-
1964)
4-14-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter, or permitting any dangerous
building, or any building or structure to remain in a dangerous condition, or
to remain in the fire limits, without remodeling, as above provided for, after
it has been damaged to the extent of fifty percent (50%) of its value shall be
fined not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than the penalty as provided
in section 1-4-1 of this code or the maximum allowed by state statutes for each
offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or
on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 568, 3-11-1964; amd. Ord. 1362,
9-13-1995)
CHAPTER 15
AUTOMATIC FIRE SUPPRESSANT SPRINKLER SYSTEMS; HEAT AND SMOKE DETECTION AND
INTERIOR FIRE ALARM SYSTEMS
SECTION:
4-15-1: Conflict With Fire Code
4-15-2: Definitions
4-15-3: Enforcement Of Provisions Of This Chapter
4-15-4: Automatic Fire Suppressant System
4-15-5: Heat And Smoke Detection And Interior Fire Alarm Systems
4-15-6: Request For Waiver
4-15-7: Application
4-15-8: Penalty
4-15-1: CONFLICT WITH FIRE CODE:
Should any provision of this chapter conflict with the provisions of the
Midlothian fire prevention code, the provisions of this chapter shall prevail.
(Ord. 1286, 2-24-1993)
4-15-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
APPROVED:
   (A)   As applied to automatic fire suppressant sprinkler installations,
means approved by the official or other authority charged with the enforcement
of this chapter.
   (B)   As applied to automatic fire suppressant sprinklers and devices, means
approved by a nationally recognized testing laboratory.
AREA: As applied to a building or structure, shall mean the maximum horizontal
projected area of the building or structure at or above grade, including all
enclosed extensions; within the exterior walls and/or approved firewalls.
AUTOMATIC FIRE SUPPRESSANT SPRINKLER SYSTEM: An arrangement of piping,
sprinklers and devices designated to operate automatically, by the heat of
fire, to discharge water upon the fire.
BASEMENT: Any story of a building or structure, the ceiling of which is located
less than six feet (6') above the finish grade.
CHIEF OF THE FIRE DEPARTMENT: The chief of the Midlothian fire department or
his duly authorized representative.
COMBUSTIBLE: Any material which will ignite when subjected to any temperature
up to one thousand three hundred eighty two degrees Fahrenheit (1,382°F) for
five (5) minutes.
DWELLING UNIT: One or more rooms which are arranged, designed or used as living
quarters for a family or an individual.
FIREWALL: A wall having adequate fire resistance and structural stability under
fire conditions to accomplish the purpose of completely separating adjoining
buildings or structures to resist the passage of fire. Refer to Midlothian
building code, fire resistance ratings 1 .
GARAGE: A building or structure, or a portion thereof, arranged, designed or
used for the storage, sale, repair, rental, greasing, washing, servicing,
adjusting or equipping of automobiles or other motor vehicles.
INSTITUTIONAL BUILDINGS: Buildings used for educational, medical, charitable or
other similar purposes.
MEZZANINE: An intermediate floor between the floor and the ceiling of any
story, and covering less than thirty three and one-third percent (331/3%) of
the floor area immediately below.
MULTIPLE-FAMILY DWELLING: A building or structure containing three (3) or more
dwelling units.
NONCOMBUSTIBLE: Any material, no part of which will ignite when subjected to
any temperature up to one thousand three hundred eighty two degrees Fahrenheit
(1,382°F) for five (5) minutes.
PARKING AREA: Any area designed, arranged or used for the storage or parking of
automobiles or other motor vehicles.
STORY: That part of a building or structure comprised between a floor and the
floor or roof next above (not including a mezzanine). (Ord. 1286, 2-24-1993)
 
Notes
1 1. See section 4-7-1 of this title.
4-15-3: ENFORCEMENT OF PROVISIONS OF THIS CHAPTER:
It shall be the duty and responsibility of the chief of the Midlothian fire
department or his duly authorized representative to enforce the provisions of
this chapter. Approval of devices shall be based on reports of a nationally
recognized testing laboratory. (Ord. 1286, 2-24-1993)
4-15-4: AUTOMATIC FIRE SUPPRESSANT SYSTEM:
   (A)   Where Installation Is Required: Approved automatic fire suppressant
sprinkler systems shall be installed and maintained as follows (not required in
single-family homes):
      1.   Manufacture, Storage, Sale Of Combustibles: In all buildings or
structures for the manufacture, storage or sale of combustible goods or
merchandise.
      2.   Certain Buildings, Garages:
         (a)   Buildings or structures over five thousand (5,000) square feet.
         (b)   Garages and parking areas below other occupancies for more than
six (6) motor vehicles or exceeding two thousand (2,000) square feet in area.
      3.   Basements: All basements when used for the manufacture, sale or
storage of combustible goods or merchandise. Basement structures having an area
of two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet or more.
      4.   Hotels And Motels: Throughout all buildings and structures. (Ord.
1286, 2-24-1993)
      5.   Theaters, Recreation Buildings And Assembly Halls: Throughout all
buildings or structures. (Ord. 1873, 6-25-2014)
      6.   Nursing, Convalescent And Other Institutional Buildings: Throughout
all buildings or structures. (Ord. 1286, 2-24-1993)
      7.   Multi-Family Dwellings: All multi-family dwellings, including
condominiums, townhomes and apartment complexes. All areas used as storage
rooms, boiler, furnace and laundry rooms, basements, all areas where
combustible materials are handled or stored and in hallways and landings on
each floor. (Ord. 1873, 6-25-2014)
      8.   Restaurants: Throughout all buildings or structures with a seating
capacity of more than forty (40) people.
      9.   Atriums: Sprinkler protection required for all atriums as determined
and approved by the Midlothian fire department fire prevention bureau.
   (B)   Installation And Maintenance:
      1.   Approved automatic fire suppressant sprinkler systems and equipment
shall be installed in accordance with the current edition of the National Fire
Protection Association pamphlet no. 13, "Standards For The Installation Of
Sprinkler Systems", and the provisions of this chapter.
      2.   All equipment and automatic fire suppressant sprinkler installations
shall be properly maintained by the owner and/or the occupant of the building.
Maintenance shall be in accordance with the current edition of the National
Fire Protection Association pamphlet no. 13A. Where the term, "the local
authority having jurisdiction", is used, it shall mean the chief of Midlothian
fire department or his duly authorized representative.
      3.   The owner, occupant or contractor shall notify the Midlothian fire
department before any valves are closed and before any work is to be done on
any sprinkler system or equipment. The owner and/or occupant shall maintain a
record of all inspections, tests and work done on all sprinkler systems and
equipment. Such records shall be maintained on the premises of the sprinkler
installation and they should be available and ready for inspection and review
upon request of the Midlothian fire department.
   (C)   Prohibited Connections: No auxiliary connection shall be made to
sprinkler systems for sill cock, house service or other house outlet purpose.
   (D)   Approved Plans: Before any fire suppressant sprinkler system is
installed, remodeled or altered, one set of the plans, setting forth all
essential details of the installation, including approved backflow preventor,
shall be submitted to each department (fire department/bureau of fire
prevention and building department) for their review and approval. Upon
approval of the plans by both departments and receipt of permits, work on the
installation may commence.
   (E)   Exemption And Substitution Of Other Fire Protection Equipment: Nothing
herein shall be construed to require the installation of sprinklers in rooms or
buildings devoted to the manufacture of material where the application of water
may cause or increase the fire, nor in any other location where the
installation of sprinklers may increase the hazard; nor shall it be construed
in any way to interfere with the substitution of other approved automatic
extinguishing equipment or systems. (Ord. 1286, 2-24-1993)
4-15-5: HEAT AND SMOKE DETECTION AND INTERIOR FIRE ALARM SYSTEMS:
   (A)   Where Both Systems Are Required: An approved heat and smoke detection
and interior fire alarm system shall be installed in the following buildings
and establishments:
      1.   Residential Buildings: All multi-family dwellings including
townhouses, condominiums, apartment complexes, hotels and motels.
      2.   Institutional Buildings: Institutional buildings.
      3.   Churches And Public Buildings: All churches and public buildings.
(Ord. 1286, 2-24-1993)
      4.   Restaurants: All restaurant buildings.
      5.   Assembly Halls: All assembly halls. (Ord. 1873, 6-25-2014)
      6.   Office, Business And Professional Buildings: All buildings of this
class.
      7.   Air Plenum Areas: All buildings and areas of buildings which are
permitted to use hollow spaces as an air plenum will require submittal of plans
to the bureau of fire prevention for approval.
      8.   Doors: Doors opening into corridors or exits shall be equipped with
an approved automatic door closure and shall be tightfitting. Fire doors shall
be provided with a magnetic door holder and shall close upon fire alarm.
   (B)   Single Station Smoke Detection: All residential type buildings shall
have single station smoke detection installed on all levels and wired in
series.
   (C)   Maintenance Of Heat And Smoke Detection And Interior Fire Alarm
Systems:
      1.   All heat and smoke detection and interior fire alarm systems shall
be installed and maintained in accordance with the NFPA pamphlet no. 72A
"Standard For The Installation, Maintenance And Use Of Local Protective
Signaling Systems For Watchman, Fire Alarms And Supervisory Service" (current
edition). It shall be the responsibility of the owners of all buildings having
interior fire alarm systems, both existing and those which are to be
constructed, to provide for the continuous maintenance of such systems through
no less than an annual inspection and testing of the system, and through a
maintenance agreement with a reliable firm actively engaged in the servicing of
fire alarm systems. Proof of such a maintenance agreement, and each subsequent
agreement for continuous service will be provided to the Midlothian fire
department/bureau of fire prevention.
         (a)   For new construction, such proof will initially be provided at
the time the fire alarm system plans are submitted for approval to the fire
department/bureau of fire prevention and then on an annual basis.
         (b)   For existing construction, proof of such a maintenance agreement
will be provided within ninety (90) days of the effective date hereof.
         (c)   Proof of each annual inspection and testing of the fire alarm
system will be provided to the Midlothian fire department/bureau of fire
prevention upon completion of the test. A valid maintenance agreement and
report of the most recent inspection and testing of the fire alarm system will
be provided by the owners of the system to any fire inspection officer upon
request. (Ord. 1286, 2-24-1993)
         (d)   All occupancies required to have a fire alarm system under this
section shall notify the authority having jurisdiction of any interruption in
service of the fire alarm, including, but not limited to, interruption due to
malfunction, cancellation of service by either the business owner or the alarm
company, or other reasons. The authority having jurisdiction may require the
business to have the fire alarm repaired, reactivated or in proper working
condition before permitting the building or structure to be reoccupied. (Ord.
1873, 6-25-2014)
      2.   The heat and smoke detection and interior fire alarm system shall be
zoned as required by floor and/or area. (Ord. 1286, 2-24-1993)
      3.   The indicating systems of any alarm system installed in or for any
building or structure shall be located in such a fashion to permit access to
the indicating system by fire personnel without the need for said fire
personnel to pass through or enter into the building or structure any farther
than the main entrance in order to view or operate the alarm panel. (Ord. 1873,
6-25-2014)
      4.   All heat and smoke detection devices shall be of the combination
type unless otherwise authorized by the Midlothian fire department/bureau of
fire prevention.
      5.   All heat and smoke detection and interior fire alarm systems shall
have a direct connection to the Midlothian fire department communications
center. This connection shall be made and be in working order before occupancy
of the building can be approved by the Midlothian fire department/bureau of
fire prevention.
   (D)   Approval Of Plans For Heat And Smoke Detection And Interior Fire Alarm
Systems: One set of plans showing the location of the heat and smoke detection
and interior fire alarm system must be submitted to each organization (fire
department/bureau of fire prevention and building department) for their
approval. Such approval shall be granted if the plans meet the requirements of
this chapter and otherwise conform with applicable ordinances and regulations
of the village and sound fire prevention standards. One set of plans will be
retained by the building department and one set of plans will be retained by
the fire department/bureau of fire prevention. (Ord. 1286, 2-24-1993)
4-15-6: REQUEST FOR WAIVER:
When buildings are constructed and require both a heat and smoke detection and
interior fire alarm system and a sprinkler system, the contractor may forward a
letter to the fire department/bureau of fire prevention requesting a waiver of
one or the other. The fire department/bureau of fire prevention shall review
such waiver request and recommend which system shall be required. Said waiver
shall be granted only upon the recommendation by the chief of the Midlothian
fire department and approval by the board of trustees. (Ord. 1286, 2-24-1993)
4-15-7: APPLICATION:
This chapter shall be in full force and effect for all new construction, major
remodeling, repairs or alterations and projects where, in the determination of
the superintendent of buildings, the interest of the village would require
installation of the system. (Ord. 1286, 2-24-1993)
4-15-8: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not more
than the penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code or the maximum
allowed by state statutes for each offense. Each day's continued violation of
any provision of this chapter shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. 1286,
2-24-1993; amd. Ord. 1362, 9-13-1995)
CHAPTER 16
CABLE TV
SECTION:
4-16-1: Permit Required
4-16-2: Contractors
4-16-3: Occupation Of Streets
4-16-4: Fees
4-16-5: Applicability
4-16-6: Penalty
4-16-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to construct or erect any portion of a cable TV system
prior to obtaining a permit from the village. An application shall be filed
with the village clerk upon such forms as he shall deem necessary. Said
application shall be accompanied by a complete set of plans showing the
location of all work to be performed and certified to as required by law. (Ord.
994, 1-28-1981)
4-16-2: CONTRACTORS:
Any and all persons constructing or erecting any portion of a cable TV system
shall obtain a license and be bonded as all other contractors in the village.
Any person who installs wire or cable through which an electric charge is
carried shall be licensed as an electrical contractor. All other contractors
shall be licensed as general contractors. (Ord. 994, 1-28-1981)
4-16-3: OCCUPATION OF STREETS:
No street shall be blocked or occupied by any person constructing or erecting
any portion of a cable TV system without obtaining prior village approval. For
the purposes of cable TV, the locations to be blocked or occupied shall be
given to the public works department and the director of public works at least
two (2) business days prior to their blockage or occupation. Adequate warning
devices, including barricades, shall be supplied to direct traffic to other
areas by the contractor. (Ord. 994, 1-28-1981)
4-16-4: FEES:
The permit fee for the construction and erection of a cable TV system shall be
one hundred dollars ($100.00) per mile of cable installed or mile of strand
installed. The distance of cable to and from any residence or building from the
main line shall not be calculated for the per mile cost. In addition, an
inspection fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per building to which a connection is
made from the main line shall be paid, except in the case of buildings wherein
more than one dwelling unit or more than one commercial unit is being serviced,
in which case the inspection fee shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per building
plus five dollars ($5.00) for each additional unit serviced therein.
The one hundred dollars ($100.00) per mile fee shall be paid in advance of work
performed, but may be paid in installments if work is to be performed in
installments or by sections. The ten dollar ($10.00) inspection fee shall be
paid in advance of any connection to a building. (Ord. 994, 1-28-1981)
4-16-5: APPLICABILITY:
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the construction of any and all
cable TV systems from and after the date of its passage, regardless of whether
or not a portion of that cable TV system may have already been erected. (Ord.
994, 1-28-1981)
4-16-6: PENALTY:
Any person guilty of violating any of the provisions of this chapter or the
village building code shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00)
nor more than the penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code or the
maximum allowed by state statutes for each offense and each separate day upon
which a violation exists shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 994, 1-28-
1981; amd. Ord. 1362, 9-13-1995)
CHAPTER 17
SATELLITE DISH ANTENNAS
SECTION:
4-17-1: Definition
4-17-2: Building Permits Required
4-17-3: Construction Of Structure
4-17-4: Existing Satellite Antennas
4-17-5: Variation
4-17-6: Severability
4-17-7: Penalty
4-17-1: DEFINITION:
"Satellite dish type signal receiving antennas (also referred to as earth
stations or ground stations)" shall be defined as a device commonly parabolic
in shape, mounted at a fixed point for the purpose of capturing television
signals transmitted via satellite communications facilities and serving the
same or similar function as the common television antenna. Said devices are
hereinafter defined as accessory structures and may be referred to as
"structures". (Ord. 1106, 1985)
4-17-2: BUILDING PERMITS REQUIRED:
No satellite dish antenna shall be erected on any parcel of land or building
unless a building permit for such antenna has been approved and issued by the
village using the following guidelines:
   (A)   Applicant submits a written application upon forms provided and
approved by the village building department. The applicant shall specify, among
other things, the name and address of the owner of the real estate, the
engineer or contractor who prepared the construction plans and specifications
and the person to be permitted to construct the proposed structure. Attached to
the application must be plans and specifications showing proper mounting
instructions, structural analysis and showing elevations, wiring layout from
receiver to earth station. Also, structure shall be built and secured for wind
resistance and shall be properly grounded.
   (B)   Applicant demonstrates that the intended use is private and for use of
that property only, and is in compliance with all federal codes and permits and
presents proof of possession of any federal permits which may be needed.
   (C)   Applicant must submit three (3) sets of plot plans of the lot showing:
      1.   Exact location and dimensions of the proposed structure;
      2.   Exact location and dimensions of all existing buildings or
structures;
      3.   Exact location and description of existing screening foliage and
additional landscaping foliage needed to reasonably conceal the structure from
view.
   (D)   Applicant shall submit with the application the sum of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) which represents the permit fee. The permit fee shall cover
the costs of processing the application, reviewing the construction plans and
specifications and inspecting the final construction. (Ord. 1106, 1985)
4-17-3: CONSTRUCTION OF STRUCTURE:
Construction shall be governed as follows:
   (A)   Order Of Construction: Construction will not be allowed on any lot
prior to construction of the principal structure to which it is an accessory.
   (B)   Mounting Of Satellite:
      1.   In residential areas, construction shall be ground mounted, in all
cases, with a maximum allowable height of fifteen feet (15'), including base
from grade. Dish portion of antenna shall be no greater than twelve feet (12')
in its maximum dimension.
      2.   In nonresidential areas, construction of satellite may be roof
mounted. Installation shall be located on the rear portion of the structure,
and such installation shall not be mounted upon such roof appurtenances as
chimneys, towers, poles or spires. No installation shall exceed the height of
any existing structure on the building, provided further that in no event the
overall height of the satellite antenna does not exceed thirty five feet (35')
from the ground to the top of the antenna. All roof mounted installations shall
have a certification from a licensed structural engineer regarding the
location, stating that the structure is capable of handling the antenna and
said antenna does not provide any additional stress which the structure cannot
bear. All installations shall be screened if possible.
   (C)   Placement: The structure shall be constructed to the rear of the
residence or main structure. It shall not be constructed in any front or side
yard. Rear lot status of corner lots shall be determined by the village
building inspector.
   (D)   Property Line; Easement: No structure, including its concrete base
slab or other substructure, shall be constructed less than eight feet (8') from
any property line or easement.
   (E)   Screening Foliage: No ground mounted structure shall be constructed
without appropriate landscaping foliage to reasonably conceal said structure
from view. Planting of screening foliage must be completed within thirty (30)
days from date permit was issued. Replacement foliage will be required where
foliage has died. It shall be a violation of this chapter if appropriate
screening foliage is not properly maintained.
   (F)   Other Receivers: No structure shall be linked physically or
electronically to a receiver which is not located on the same lot, premises or
parcel of land as said structure.
   (G)   Construction By Licensed Contractor: Construction shall be performed
by a licensed contractor registered with the village, or in appropriate
circumstances may be performed by the individual homeowner. Licensed electrical
contractors are required to install all line voltage electrical work.
   (H)   Materials; Color: The structure shall be constructed with galvanized
structural supports and shall be nonreflective. Coloration shall blend with
surroundings.
   (I)   Advertising; Signage: Structure shall have no advertising or signage
of any type displayed on it other than name of manufacturer in letters not to
exceed two inches (2"). (Ord. 1106, 1985)
4-17-4: EXISTING SATELLITE ANTENNAS:
Satellite antennas legally in existence at the time of the passage of this
chapter shall be considered "grandfathered" for a period of two (2) years from
the effective date of this chapter. At the end of the two (2) year period the
antennas must be in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 1106,
1985)
4-17-5: VARIATION:
   (A)   The satellite antenna board, consisting of the building
superintendent, building inspector and one member of the electrical commission,
may hold public hearings on any requested variation of this chapter, after
giving proper public notice. Notice shall be published at least fifteen (15)
days before said hearing. Anyone requesting a variation from these regulations
must request said variation in writing and detail the reasons for the request.
Said request for variation shall be accompanied by a payment of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) to cover the cost of the variation hearing. At said public
hearing the petitioner and any interested parties may be given the opportunity
to be heard.
   (B)   After said public hearing, the satellite antenna board shall send
their recommendations to the village board, who shall make the final decision
on granting any variation of these regulations. (Ord. 1106, 1985)
4-17-6: SEVERABILITY:
The provisions of this chapter shall be deemed severable, and the invalidity of
any provision or provisions thereof shall not affect the validity of the
remaining provisions. (Ord. 1106, 1985)
4-17-7: PENALTY:
Whosoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be liable for a
fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than the penalty
as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code or the maximum allowed by state
statutes for each offense. A separate violation shall be deemed to have been
committed each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues to occur.
(Ord. 1106, 1985; amd. Ord. 1362, 9-13-1995)
CHAPTER 18
PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE
SECTION:
4-18-1: Property Maintenance Code Adopted
4-18-2: Applicability
4-18-3: Building Department Code Official
4-18-4: Duties And Powers Of The Building Superintendent
4-18-5: Modifications And Approval
4-18-6: Violations
4-18-7: Notices And Orders
4-18-8: Unsafe Structures And Equipment
4-18-9: Emergency Measures
4-18-10: Demolition
4-18-11: Means Of Appeal
4-18-12: Definitions
4-18-13: General Requirements
4-18-14: Exterior Structure
4-18-15: Interior Structure
4-18-16: Rubbish And Garbage
4-18-17: Extermination
4-18-18: Light, Ventilation And Occupancy Limitations
4-18-19: Plumbing Facilities And Fixture Requirements
4-18-20: Mechanical And Electrical Requirements
4-18-21: Fire Safety Requirements
4-18-22: Outdoor Parking And/Or Storage Containers
4-18-1: PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE ADOPTED:
   (A)   The 2018 Property Maintenance Code as published by the International
Code Council and as from time to time amended, is hereby adopted and
incorporated in full as if set forth at length herein and shall apply and
control within the Village of Midlothian, save and except such portions as
hereinafter deleted, modified or amended.
   (B)   Other Code References. References to International Codes and other
codes herein shall mean and apply as follows:
      1.   International Building Code (IBC) as adopted and amended by the
Village of Midlothian.
      2.   References to the International Existing Building Code are hereby
deleted.
      3.   International Fire Code (IFC) references shall be deleted and
replaced with the National Fire Code, 2009 Edition published by the National
Fire Protection Association, the National Fire Protection Association Code
(NFPAC) #1, 2009 Edition, the National Fire Protection Association Code 101,
Life Safety Code, 2009 Edition and their subsequent revisions and the whole
thereof, except such portions pertaining to the organization, administration,
operation, and equipment of the fire department and such portions as are
otherwise inapplicable to the Village, or as are hereinafter deleted, modified
or amended by the Village of Midlothian.
      4.   International Plumbing Code (IPC) references shall be deleted and
replaced with the Illinois Plumbing Code as adopted and amended by the Village
of Midlothian.
      5.   International Residential Code (IRC) as adopted and amended by the
Village of Midlothian.
      6.   International Mechanical Code (IMC) and the International Fuel Gas
Code (IFGC) as adopted and amended by the Village of Midlothian.
      7.   References to the International Private Sewage Disposal Code is
hereby deleted and replaced with the provisions of Title III, Chapter 5 of the
Village Code.
      8.   International Property Maintenance Code (IPMC) as adopted and
amended by the Village of Midlothian.
      9.   References to NFPA 70-the National Electrical Code is hereby deleted
and replaced with the provisions of the 2017 Chicago Electrical Code as adopted
and amended by the Village of Midlothian.
      10.   References to Accessible and Usable Buildings and Facilities is
hereby deleted and replaced with the Illinois Accessibility Code as adopted by
the Village of Midlothian.
   (C)   Amendments. The following amendments to the 2018 edition of the
International Property Maintenance Code, shall apply in the Village of
Midlothian:
      1.   Section 101.1 shall name the Village of Midlothian as the
jurisdiction and shall state the following: These regulations shall be known as
the "Property Maintenance code of the Village of Midlothian," hereinafter
referred as "this code."
      2.   Section 103.5 referencing "Fees" shall be amended to provide the
fees for activities and services performed by the department in carrying out
its responsibilities under this code and shall be determined by Village Board
Resolution and published by the Village Clerk or Building Superintendent.
      3.   Section 109.4 referencing "Emergency Repairs" shall be amended to
provide the following: Application for a permit must be made for all repair
work requiring permits under this Code however, where equipment replacement and
repairs must be performed in an emergency situation making prior application
impracticable, the permit application shall be submitted within the next
business day to the building official.
      Maintenance items such as painting, sealing, decorating and repair
related home improvements are not considered to be repairs and do not require
that a fee be paid. Such repairs shall not include the cutting away of any
wall, partition or portion thereof, the removal or cutting of any structural
beam or load-bearing support, or the removal or change of any required means of
egress, or rearrangement of parts of a structure affecting the egress
requirements; nor shall ordinary repairs include addition to, alteration of,
replacement or relocation of any standpipe, water supply, sewer, drainage,
drain leader, gas, soil, waste, vent or similar piping, electric wiring or
mechanical or other work affecting public health or general safety.
      4.   Section 111 referencing "Means of Appeals" is hereby amended to
delete all its provisions except for Section [A] 111.1 which is amended to
provide as follows: Any person directly affected by a decision of the code
official or a notice or order issued under this code shall have the right to
appeal under the provisions of
4-20-4 of the Village Code.
      5.   Section 302.4 referencing "Weeds" is hereby amended to delete its
provisions and replace with the following provisions: All premises and exterior
property shall be maintained free from weeds or plant growth in excess of eight
inches (8") except as provided in this section. All noxious weeds shall be
prohibited. Weeds shall be defined as all grasses, annual plants and
vegetation, other than trees or shrubs provided; however, this term shall not
include common turf grasses under eight inches (8") in height, cultivated
flowers and gardens.
      Action to Cut or Destroy Weeds: Upon failure of the owner or agent having
charge of a property to cut and destroy weeds after service of a notice of
violation, they shall be subject to prosecution in accordance with section
4-20-4 of the Village Code. Upon failure to comply with the notice of
violation, any duly authorized employee of the village or contractor hired by
the village shall be authorized to enter upon the property in violation and cut
and destroy the weeds growing thereon, and the costs of such removal shall be
paid by the owner or agent responsible for the property.
      6.   Section 303 referencing "SWIMMING POOLS, SPAS AND HOT TUBS" is
hereby deleted and the provisions of
4-5-1 of the Village Code shall apply.
      7.   Section 304.14 referencing "Insect screens" is hereby amended to add
the requirement dates of April 1, to November 1, of each year.
      8.   Section 308 referencing "RUBBISH AND GARBAGE" is hereby amended to
add the following provisions after Section 308.3.2 as follows:
         (a)   Violations: With regard to residential or commercial properties,
the following shall be a violation of this chapter:
            (1)   Open Garbage or Refuse For Scavenger Pick Up: To allow, cause
or permit garbage or refuse to be set out upon the parkways, at the rear of
store buildings, or other places, for the purpose of being picked up by a
garbage or scavenger collector, in containers which are not suitable or which
permit or allow the garbage/refuse contents to be scattered or blown around,
causing an unclean and unhealthy condition.
            (2)   Scavenger Pick up Timing: To place, cause or permit any
tangible thing to be placed upon or permitted to remain upon any parkway within
the village, except for the purpose of being picked up by a regularly scheduled
scavenger service; to allow or permit the placement of items for pick up by a
scavenger service upon any parkway sooner than four o'clock (4:00) P.M. the day
before the regularly scheduled day for pick up; to allow or permit containers
or other tangible things to remain upon any parkway after ten o'clock (10:00)
P.M. of the regularly scheduled day for scavenger service pick up.
            (3)   Garbage Or Refuse On Premises: To cause or permit to remain
on any premises garbage, refuse, ashes, miscellaneous waste or any animal or
vegetable matter which is likely to become offensive or injurious to health or
to be blown about by the wind at any time, except in approved containers with
tightfitting covers thereon from which regular garbage collection is made at
least once a week or as otherwise provided in this code.
            (4)   Storage of Junk: To permit or maintain an unsightly yard, lot
or premises where there is an accumulation or deposit of junk or debris
including but not limited to, metal, glass or plastic containers, broken glass,
metal or plastic materials, refuse, yard waste, straw, tree stumps, tree
clippings, brush, discarded or broken building materials, discarded sod,
lumber, brick or concrete blocks not in use as landscaping, machinery or parts
thereof, or other like matter or things. It shall be unlawful for any person
owning, leasing, occupying or controlling any plot of real estate to permit the
accumulation or deposit of the aforesaid junk and debris.
            (5)   Garbage, Debris, Yard Waste and Snow in Street/Public Way: It
shall be unlawful to blow, rake, place or cause the accumulation of yard waste,
manure, grass clippings, leaves, twigs, branches, trees, ashes, stone, sand,
snow, ice, dirt, building materials or debris or other refuse of any kind on
the public way or street.
            (6)   Discarded, broken or unused building materials incident to
construction on the site where the debris is located shall not remain on the
plot for more than seven (7) days. Failure to remove said building materials
within seven (7) days or permitting the deposit or accumulation of any of the
other garbage or debris described in this chapter for any period of time shall
constitute a violation of this chapter.
            Action to Remove: In the event any person notified as provided in
this chapter shall fail or refuse to comply with said notices or citations, the
village may cause such garbage, debris or junk to be removed in any manner
provided by law, and to charge the cost of such removal to any person owning,
leasing, occupying or controlling such real estate. The cost for so doing shall
be calculated on the basis of an administration fee of two hundred and fifty
dollars ($250.00), plus the actual cost of garbage and debris removal. The
administrative fee and costs shall be in addition to any fine imposed under
4-20-6 of the Village Code.
            (7)   An authorized village official or representative thereof
shall serve or cause to be served a notice or citation upon any person owning,
leasing, occupying or controlling any real estate within the village upon which
the prohibited conditions described in this chapter are found to exist. The
notice requiring them to remove the garbage debris and waste constituting a
violation of this chapter within twenty-four (24) hours shall be made in
accordance with the provisions of
4-20-4 of the Village Code.
            (8)   Lien Upon Property: The cost and expense incurred by the
village, and/or by the person or firm performing the service by authority of
the village, in the abatement of the nuisance following the refusal or failure
of the responsible party to abate the nuisance, including reasonable attorney
fees, shall constitute a lien upon the real estate affected, which lien shall
be enforced as provided by statute. The village shall provide notice of the
lien either by personally serving or sending notice by certified mail to the
person to whom was sent the tax bill for the general taxes on the property for
the last preceding year.
            (9)   Repeat Offender: Any commercial or residential property
within the village that has been previously issued a notice or citation under
this section within the same calendar year will be considered a repeat offender
and the village shall have the authority to abate the violation without
additional prior notice, and the real estate property owner will have a lien
placed upon this property as provided for in
4-20-10(B) of the Village Code and applicable law.
            (10)   Burning Garbage Or Leaves: It shall be illegal to burn
materials in any fashion not permitted by section
6-8-15 of the Village Code. (Ord. 1872, 6-11-2014)
            (11)   Open Building Materials: To create or allow to be created or
to remain upon any premises in a residential district for a period of more than
seven (7) days, unless incident to construction on the premises and then not to
exceed thirty (30) days, the storing, piling, accumulating, heaping, amassing
or collecting bricks, concrete blocks, lumber, iron, pipe or any building
materials in such quantities that the same is, or may become a threat to the
health of individuals or the public; or that the same is unsightly, unhealthy
and a detriment to those living in the neighborhood or to the public; or that
the same may or does become dangerous to children present in the neighborhood;
or that the same may become an attraction to rats or other vermin and thereby
become a danger to the health of any individual or the public.
            (12)   Business Use of Public Property: To use or occupy any part
of a street, parkway, alley or sidewalk of the village for the purpose of
carrying on, soliciting or promoting any trade, business or other enterprise;
also, to cause or permit the storage of any product, supplies for or equipment
incidental to the operations of such business or enterprises, upon any street,
parkway, alley or sidewalk within the village.
            (13)   Obstructing Public Ways: To obstruct or encroach upon public
streets and highways, private ways, streets, alleys, sidewalks, parking lots or
public places of the village so as to interfere with the passage of vehicles or
persons thereon. (Ord. 1764, 9-14-2011)
      9.   Section 506.1 referencing "General" is hereby amended to delete the
words "either" and "or to an approved private sewer disposal system" so as to
require and allow only a connection to a public sewer system.
      10.   Section 602.3 referencing "Heat supply" is hereby amended to add
the following dates in the first paragraph to read "from October 1 to May 15."
      11.   Section 602.4 referencing "Occupation work spaces" is hereby
amended to add the following dates in the first paragraph to read “from October
1 to May 15." (Ord. 1721, 5-12-2010; amd. Ord. 2045, 1-8-2020)
4-18-2: APPLICABILITY:
   (A)   Residential Districts: In residential zoning districts:
      1.   No commercial vehicles shall be parked and/or stored for any length
of time in excess of one hour.
      2.   The parking and/or storage of recreational vehicles in excess of two
(2) consecutive days shall be permitted, but only if the following conditions
are met:
         (a)   The parking of such vehicles is behind the front building line,
no closer to the rear lot line than five feet (5') and no closer than three
feet (3') from the side lot line; and
         (b)   No recreational vehicle shall be used for living, sleeping or
housekeeping purposes at any time; and
         (c)   Such vehicle is properly covered.
      3.   No commercial vehicles or recreational vehicles shall be parked in
the public right of way at any time in a residential district.
      4.   Business vehicles are allowed to be parked in residential zoning
districts; however, business vehicles shall not be allowed to be parked in the
front yard, rear yard or side yard unless in a driveway.
      5.   Any recreational vehicle or business vehicle that is parked or
stored in any residential zoning district must be owned or legally controlled
by residents or occupants of the premises on which it is parked.
      6.   Pickup trucks and/or vans principally used as passenger cars are
excluded from the regulations contained herein.
      7.   Inoperable motor vehicles shall not be parked and/or stored in
residential zoning districts for a time period in excess of two (2) days unless
such inoperable motor vehicle is parked and/or stored in a garage or fully
enclosed structure. No inoperable motor vehicle shall be parked or stored for
any time period on side yards, rear yards or front yards.
   (B)   Storage Containers: Containers made of plastic, fiberglass, metal,
wood or any composite material of any size shall not be stored outside in any
zoning district except as provided below. This includes commercial storage
containers, commercial steel containers and/or steel intermodal containers, POD
containers and other similar containers. Such containers shall include any
container placed or stored on a front yard, side yard, back yard or driveway.
This subsection shall not apply to the following:
      1.   Any containers which are stored in a garage or fully enclosed
structure; or
      2.   Any containers used by a residential homeowner prior to moving into
a new home or moving out of a home, as long as the storage of such container is
on the driveway, is not stored for more than ten (10) consecutive days, and the
homeowner has obtained a permit from the village; or
      3.   Any containers used for garbage, recycling or lawn/yard waste in
compliance with the provisions of
8-2-8 of the Village Code or
      4.   Temporary construction trailers and/or storage bins, for which a
permit has been issued by the village, as long as such construction trailers
and/or construction storage bins are removed within seventy-two (72) hours of
the completion of the project for which such temporary construction trailers or
temporary construction storage bins are placed on the property. (Ord. 1721, 5-
12-2010; amd. Ord. 2045, 1-8-2020)
4-18-3: BUILDING DEPARTMENT CODE OFFICIAL:
   (A)   General: The official in charge of this code shall be the building
superintendent.
   (B)   Deputies: In accordance with the prescribed procedures of the village
of Midlothian and with the concurrence of the village president, the building
superintendent shall have the authority to appoint a deputy building
superintendent, other related technical officers, inspectors and other
employees.
   (C)   Liability: The building superintendent, officer or employee charged
with the enforcement of this code, while acting for the jurisdiction, shall not
thereby be rendered liable personally, and is hereby relieved from all personal
liability for any damage accruing to persons or property as a result of an act
required or permitted in the discharge of official duties.
Any suit instituted against any officer or employee because of an act performed
by that officer or employee in the lawful discharge of duties and under the
provisions of this code shall be defended by the legal representative of the
jurisdiction until the final termination of the proceedings. The building
superintendent or any subordinate shall not be liable for costs in an action,
suit or proceeding that is instituted in pursuance of the provisions of this
code; and any officer of the department of property maintenance inspection,
acting in good faith and without malice, shall be free from liability for acts
performed under any of its provisions or by reason of any act or omission in
the performance of official duties in connection therewith.
   (D)   Fees: The fees for activities and services performed by the department
in carrying out its responsibilities under this code shall be set by the
village board by resolution or ordinance from time to time and shall be made
available to the general public. (Ord. 1721, 5-12-2010)
