5-2-1: BILLIARD AND POOL HALLS:
   (A)   Fee: The annual license fee shall be computed on a square footage
basis.
   (B)   Minors: Minors under the age of eighteen (18) years shall under no
circumstances frequent, loiter, go to or remain in any hall licensed hereunder
at any time, unless it be upon some lawful errand sent by the direction or with
the consent and knowledge of the parent, guardian or other person having the
lawful custody of said minor; and it shall be unlawful for the proprietor of
any hall so licensed to allow or permit any such minor to frequent, loiter or
remain within the hall in violation of this section. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
   (C)   Hours: The business establishments shall not be open from eleven
o'clock (11:00) P.M. to twelve o'clock (12:00) noon.
   (D)   Alcoholic Beverages: No alcoholic beverages shall be allowed on the
premises.
   (E)   Open View: No person conducting or opening a billiard or pool hall
shall be allowed or permit any screens, curtains, partitions or other
obstructions to be placed between the front window and the back or rear wall of
such room. An unobstructed view of the entire interior must be maintained at
all times. This provision, however, shall not be construed to preclude the
maintenance of washrooms or toilet rooms or the maintenance of closets for
storing purposes exclusively.
   (F)   Enforcement: It is the responsibility of the owner and/or manager and/
or supervisor to see that all terms of this section are followed.
   (G)   Revocation Of License:
      1.   The village president may revoke any license for any violation of
any provisions of this section or for the violation of any state laws or for
violations of ordinances of the village.
      2.   The village president may hold hearings regarding any violations. At
said hearings the owner must appear as well as all employees of the licensed
establishment which were working the day of the violations.
      3.   After the hearings and within five (5) days the president may enter
an order which he feels is appropriate under local ordinances and/or under
state statutes and shall serve a copy of said order within five (5) days upon
said licensee. He may revoke the license or suspend same for a period up to
sixty (60) days. (Ord. 831, 5-14-1975)
   (H)   Penalty: Any persons convicted of violating any of the provisions of
this section shall be subject to a fine not exceeding the penalty as provided
in section 1-4-1 of this code or the maximum allowed by state statutes for such
offense. (Ord. 831, 5-14-1975; amd. Ord. 1362, 9-13-1995)
5-2-2: BOWLING ALLEYS:
   (A)   Fee: The annual license fee shall be computed on a square footage
basis.
   (B)   Minors: Minors under the age of eighteen (18) years shall under no
circumstances frequent, loiter about, go to or remain in any hall licensed
hereunder at any time, unless it be upon some errand or sent by the direction
and with the consent and knowledge of or accompanied by the parent, guardian or
other person having the lawful custody of said minor; and it shall be unlawful
for the proprietor of any hall so licensed to allow or permit any such minor to
frequent, loiter about, or remain within the hall in violation of this section;
provided, however, that boys over the age of fourteen (14) years may be
employed in such halls if the person operating or conducting the same shall
have first procured the written consent of the parent or guardian or other
person having lawful custody of the minor so employed. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-2-3: CARNIVALS, PARKS, MENAGERIES, EXHIBITIONS:
   (A)   Fees: The annual license fee shall be:
      1.   Parks where amusement rides are operated during summer season:
Thirty dollars ($30.00) per season for first ride and ten dollars ($10.00) for
each additional ride.
      2.   Carnivals: Thirty dollars ($30.00) per day together with ten dollars
($10.00) per day for each side show and concession connected therewith.
      3.   Menageries: Thirty dollars ($30.00) per day.
      4.   Exhibitions: Thirty dollars ($30.00) per day.
      5.   Other amusement not specifically licensed: Thirty dollars ($30.00)
per day. (Ord. 910, 4-12-1978)
5-2-4: CIRCUSES:
   (A)   Fees: The fee for circus licenses shall be four hundred dollars
($400.00) for each day during which the circuses are conducted or open to the
public. There shall be an additional license fee for each side show and
concession operated in connection with a circus in the amount of thirty dollars
($30.00) per day. (Ord. 910, 4-12-1978)
   (B)   Inspection: It shall be the duty of the chief of police and the fire
chief to see that inspections shall be made of all circus performances and of
the premises used.
   (C)   Bond: It shall be unlawful to conduct or exhibit any parade connected
with a circus in or on any public street, alley or other public way or place in
the municipality unless a permit therefor is first obtained from the chief of
police. Such permit shall specify the route to be followed, and shall be
accompanied by a bond in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00)
conditioned to indemnify the municipality for any loss, damage or liability
incurred or caused by the conduct or exhibition of such parade. (Ord. 633B, 12-
14-1966)
5-2-5: AMUSEMENT DEVICES:
   (A)   Definition: An "amusement device" (hereafter referred to as "amusement
device") is any device which, upon the insertion of a coin, paper bill, credit
card, debit card, slug, token or disk, may be operated by the public as a game,
entertainment or amusement. It includes, but is not limited to, such devices as
pinball machines, computer games, CD-ROM driven devices, skill ball machines,
bagatelle, pigeon hole, pool or any other table or implement kept for a similar
purpose and electronic games using a video screen and electrical impulses that
are not video gaming devices as defined in this chapter. It includes any other
type of mechanical game the object of which is to secure a particular score or
high score by the use of balls, spheres, springs, trigger devices, electrical
impulses, or throwing objects at targets. Billiard and pool halls are also
covered by section
5-2-1 of this chapter. Electronic card game devices, as defined in this
chapter, are not covered under this section, and are not "amusement devices" as
used in this section. Such electronic card game devices are covered under
section
5-2-9 of this chapter. Video gaming devices, as defined in this chapter, are
not covered under this section, and are not "amusement devices" as used in this
section. Such video gaming devices are covered under section
5-2-9 of this chapter.
   (B)   Regulations:
      1.   Each license issued shall be for a period of one calendar year and
is the responsibility of the business license holder.
      2.   A renewal application must be filed prior to the expiration of the
current license and pursuant to the provisions of renewing the owner's business
license where the device is located.
      3.   The annual license fee for each device shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00).
      4.   Each device shall have posted in a prominent place on its front side
a current village decal with an assigned number.
      5.   A license shall not be transferable from person to person nor place
to place and shall be usable only at the place and by the person designated on
the license. License for devices as defined in subsection (A) of this section
may be transferred to another similar device upon application to and receiving
approval from the village clerk. The transfer fee shall be five dollars ($5.00)
per device.
   (C)   Restrictions:
      1.   Except as specified below, it shall be unlawful for any person or
business to keep or use in any place of business or any club, clubhouse,
clubroom or hall within the village an "amusement device" as defined in
subsection (A) of this section.
      2.   The exceptions to the above are as follows:
         (a)   All licensees who have a class A, C, D or E liquor license shall
be allowed twenty (20) amusement devices on their premises as long as they are
properly licensed and are not gambling devices (video gaming devices or other
devices used for gambling).
         (b)   For the purpose of this section, a jukebox shall be considered a
device. However, it shall not be included as one of the twenty (20) devices
allowed.
         (c)   Such devices must be placed in a location which does not block
or slow the use of any entrance or exit doors.
         (d)   Additional amusement devices may be obtained as follows:
            (1)   Application filed with the village clerk requesting
additional devices.
            (2)   Tentative approval by the police, fire and building
department heads. Unanimous approval required to validate request.
            (3)   Final approval determined by village board of trustees.
         (e)   No person holding a license under this section shall permit
persons under eighteen (18) years of age to play or operate any "amusement
devices" as defined under subsection (A) of this section.
   (D)   Penalty:
      1.   Tickets may be issued to the owner of the business license and the
owner of any devices kept or used in violation of this section.
      2.   Any person who shall violate the provisions of this section, shall
be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than the penalty
as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code or the maximum allowed by state
statutes for each offense, and each day that the violation continues shall be
regarded as constituting a distinct and separate offense.
      3.   Gambling violations may cause the business owner's business and/or
liquor license to be suspended and/or revoked.
      4.   Illegal devices or devices not properly licensed must be removed
within five (5) days of notification to the owner of the business or the
village may remove them and charge the owner of the business and/or the owner
of the device rent and cost of removal. (Ord. 1801, 8-22-2012)
5-2-6: MOTION PICTURES AND THEATRICALS:
The annual license fee shall be computed on a square footage basis. (Ord. 633B,
12-14-1966)
5-2-7: SHOOTING GALLERIES:
   (A)   Fees: The annual license fee shall be computed on a square footage
basis.
   (B)   Safety: Targets shall be placed before a backstop of steel,
sufficiently thick to prevent any bullet from piercing it, and so arranged that
there will be no danger from ricochetting bullets or deflected pieces of
bullet. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-2-8: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
   (A)   Order; Crowding: The audience of any amusement, show or theatrical
must be orderly and quiet at all times, and it shall be unlawful for any person
attending such amusement, show or theatrical to create a disturbance in the
audience.
      It shall be unlawful to permit or gather such a crowd to witness any
amusement or show as to create a dangerous condition because of fire or other
risks.
   (B)   Inspection: It shall be the duty of the chief of police and fire
marshal to see that every exhibition, amusement, theatrical or other public
show or amusement is inspected by a member of the police and fire department,
and to ensure conformity with the provisions concerning such amusements.
   (C)   Exhibitions Of Criminals: It shall be unlawful for any person to
exhibit any criminal or the body of any criminal or any person who shall have
become notorious because of the commission of a crime, in any theatrical,
exhibition, carnival or other public place.
   (D)   Riots: It shall be unlawful to present any public amusement or show of
any kind which tends to or is calculated to cause or promote any riot or
disturbance.
   (E)   Smoking: It shall be unlawful to smoke or carry a lighted cigar,
cigarette or pipe on or beneath the stage or in a dressing room of any building
used as an assembly hall with seating accommodations for more than one hundred
(100) persons or in which theatricals, shows, amusements, lectures or other
entertainments are offered, presented, operated or exhibited.
      It shall be the duty of the owner of such premises or of the occupant in
charge, to provide and place printed signs on which the words "No Smoking"
shall appear in letters at least four inches (4") high, in conspicuous places,
at least two (2) signs being upon the stage or in the wings thereof and one in
each dressing room.
   (F)   Exit Lights: It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant in charge
of any building or hall used as an assembly hall with accommodations for one
hundred (100) persons or more in which theatricals, shows, amusements,
lectures, and other entertainment is offered, operated or presented to provide
and place a sign on which the word "Exit" shall appear in letters at least six
inches (6") high, over every door or other opening from such hall to every
means of egress therefrom, and a light shall be provided with a red globe and
placed at or over such sign, which lights shall be kept burning during the
entire period that the hall is open to the public and until the audience has
left the hall. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-2-9: VIDEO GAMING:
   (A)   Definitions:
 
                          Any Illinois Gaming Board licensed retail
                          establishment where alcoholic liquor is drawn,
LICENSED ESTABLISHMENT:   poured, mixed, or otherwise served for consumption on
                          the premises, whether the establishment operates on a
                          nonprofit or for-profit basis.
                          Means an individual, partnership, corporation, or
                          limited liability company that is licensed under 230
                          ILCS 40/5 of the Illinois Video Gaming Act and that
TERMINAL OPERATOR:        owns, services, and maintains video gaming terminals
                          for placement in licensed establishments, licensed
                          truck stop establishments, licensed large truck stop
                          establishments, licensed fraternal establishments, or
                          licensed veterans' establishments.
                          A licensed establishment whose primary business
                          enterprise is providing video gaming terminals for
VIDEO GAMING CAFÉ/PARLOR:video gaming on the premises, and the sale of
                          alcohol, food and other goods or services is
                          incidental to the operation of the video gaming
                          enterprise.
                          Any electronic video gaming machine, or device that,
                          upon insertion of cash, credit card, debit card,
                          electronic cards or vouchers is available to play or
                          simulate the play of a video game, including, but not
VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL:    limited to, video poker, line up, and blackjack, as
                          defined in the video gaming act, 230 Illinois
                          Compiled Statutes 40/1 et seq., as amended and which
                          fully complies with the provisions of the video
                          gaming act, 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 40/1 et
                          seq., as amended.
 
   (B)   Video gaming is allowed in licensed establishments within the village.
No establishment licensed by the Illinois Gaming Board shall be permitted to
operate any video gaming terminal pursuant to the Illinois Video Gaming Act
unless the establishment has also obtained a license and paid a yearly fee to
the village. No license may be issued where the license applicant owes a debt,
fine, fee or penalty to the village.
      1.   The annual licensing fees for licensed establishments beginning
November 1, 2021 and thereafter shall be:
         (a)   Five hundred dollars ($500) per year for each video gaming
terminal as defined in the Illinois Video Gaming Act (ILCS Ch. 230, Act 40); or
         (b)   One hundred dollars ($100) per year for each video gaming
terminal for fraternal or veterans' establishments.
   (C)   Application to the village for a video gaming license shall be made in
conformity with Title V of this code except as otherwise provided herein. The
applicant shall meet and provide for the following criteria as part of said
application:
      1.   A copy of the applicant's active state video gaming license;
      2.   The location of the premises where the video gaming terminal is to
be located, maintained and/or operated;
      3.   The charge to be made to the player for operating the device;
      4.   That the applicant is over the age of twenty one (21);
      5.   That the applicant or any principal officer therein has not held a
license under this section or had an interest therein that was revoked for
cause;
      6.   That the applicant or any principal officer therein has not
furnished false or misleading information on the application;
      7.   That the applicant has a liquor license in good standing in the
Village of Midlothian and has provided the Liquor Commissioner with a report or
reports showing its gross annual sales totals and categories, including food
and beverage sales and if a new applicant the establishments projected sales;
      8.   That the video gaming area shall be bounded by a minimum four-foot
(4') barrier wall. If said barrier walls prohibit applicant from complying with
ILCS Ch. 230, Act 40, § 58, applicant shall maintain video surveillance of the
gaming area at all times. If applicant provides sufficient evidence that the
gaming area is fully contained in an area of the establishment that can only be
accessed by persons twenty one (21) or older, the requirement of a four-foot
(4') barrier wall is not applicable;
      9.   Such other information as the village may determine is necessary.
   (D)   No more than six (6) video gaming terminals may be located, maintained
or operated in any one establishment except that large truck stop
establishments may have as many as ten (10) gaming terminals as provided in 230
ILCS 4/5. No license issued hereunder shall permit the operation of a video
gaming terminal in a manner which will disturb the peace of persons otherwise
properly within or without the premises where the terminal is located or
otherwise constitute a nuisance.
   (E)   The Village Clerk shall issue a license to each licensed establishment
that obtains a license to locate, maintain and/or operate any video gaming
terminal on its premises. The license must be displayed by the applicant in a
conspicuous place and must indicate the number of video gaming terminals
allowed.
   (F)   All current annual licenses shall terminate no later than December 31
in each year where no provision to the contrary is made. If at the time of
application for a license six (6) months or more of the calendar year have
expired, the applicant shall be required to pay one-half (1/2) of the license
fee set forth above. No license shall be issued for less than one-half (1/2) of
the annual fee.
   (G)   All existing licenses as of November 1, 2021 shall be valid until
their expiration date with no additional fees.
   (H)   The Village Clerk shall mail to all licensees a statement three (3)
weeks prior to the date of expiration informing the licensees of the upcoming
expiration date. Failure to send out the notice, or failure of any licensee to
receive it, shall not excuse the licensee from failure to secure a new license,
or a renewal thereof, nor shall it be a defense in any action for operation
without a license.
   (I)   Any licensee who fails to pay the fees and charges for the renewal of
a license by January 31 of the year following expiration of the license shall
be charged a penalty of fifty dollars ($50) per unlicensed video gaming
terminal. The penalty shall be paid at the time of renewal of the license.
   (J)   Issuance: In addition to all other general licensing requirements set
forth in this code. Issuance will occur after all application requirements as
outlined above in paragraph (B) above of this section are met.
   (K)   Terminal Operators: The regulations and provisions contained in this
section shall apply to terminal operators as such term is defined in the
Illinois Video Gaming Act and govern applications and qualifications for the
issuance of terminal operators' licenses issued by the village.
      1.   No terminal operator shall own, maintain, operate or place a video
gaming terminal in the village unless:
         (a)   He or she has a valid terminal operator's state license issued
under the Video Gaming Act; and
         (b)   He or she has a valid village video gaming terminal operators
license for each video gaming terminal placed and maintained in the village.
      2.   Each terminal operator shall pay to the village a yearly fee of
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750) per each video gaming terminal it owns,
maintains, operates or places within the village. A terminal operator may only
place video gaming terminals in the village for use in licensed video gaming
locations. It is unlawful to operate a video gaming terminal in the village
without a valid video gaming sticker affixed thereon.
      3.   Application to the village for a terminal operator's license shall
be made in conformity with Title V of this Code except as otherwise provided
herein. The applicant shall provide the following as part of said application:
         (a)   A copy of the applicant's active state video gaming license;
         (b)   The location of the premises where the video gaming terminal is
to be located, maintained and/or operated;
         (c)   The charge to be made to the player for operating the device;
and
         (d)   Such other information as the village may determine is
necessary.
      4.   No license issued hereunder shall permit the operation of a video
gaming terminal in a manner which will disturb the peace of persons otherwise
properly within or without the premises where the terminal is located or
otherwise constitute a nuisance.
      5.   The Village Clerk shall issue a license to each terminal operator
for each licensed establishment that obtains a license to locate, maintain and/
or operate any video gaming terminal in the village. The license must be
displayed by each licensed establishment in a conspicuous place and must
indicate the number of video gaming terminals allowed. A copy of the terminal
operator license will be provided by the village to the establishment upon
successful issuance to the terminal operator.
      6.   All annual licenses shall terminate on December 31 in each year
where no provision to the contrary is made. If at the time of application for a
license six months or more of the calendar year have expired, the applicant
shall be required to pay one-half (1/2) of the license fee set forth above. No
license shall be issued for less than one-half (1/2) of the annual fee.
      7.   The Village Clerk shall mail to all licensees a statement three
weeks prior to the date of expiration informing the licensees of the upcoming
expiration date. Failure to send out the notice, or failure of any licensee to
receive it, shall not excuse the licensee from failure to secure a new license,
or a renewal thereof, nor shall it be a defense in any action for operation
without a license.
   (L)   Gaming Cafés/Parlors shall offer for sale prepared food and non-
alcoholic beverages for patron consumption on the premises. The failure to
provide the food and beverages as stated in this paragraph shall be grounds for
the suspension and or revocation of the business owner's business license. At
no time shall more than seven (7) gaming café/parlor licensees be issued in the
Village concurrently.
   (M)   Penalty:
      1.   Tickets may be issued to the owner of the business license and the
owner of any devices kept or used in violation of this section.
      2.   Any person who shall violate the provisions of this Section, shall
be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than the penalty
as provided in Section
1-4-1 of this code or the maximum allowed by state statutes for each offense,
and each day that the violation continues shall be regarded as constituting a
distinct and separate offense.
      3.   Gambling violations may cause the business owner's business and/or
liquor license to be suspended and/or revoked.
      4.   Illegal devices or devices not properly licensed must be immediately
made inoperable or inaccessible for use and removed within five (5) days of
notification to the owner of the business or the village may remove them and
charge the owner of the business and/or the owner of the device rent and cost
of removal. (Ord. 1801, 8-22-2012; amd. Ord. 1836, 5-30-2013; Ord. 1948, 12-14-
2016; Ord. 2076, 3-17-2021; Ord. 2084, 10-27-2021)
5-2-10: STREAMING SERVICES:
   (A)   Applicability Of Provisions: The provisions of this Section except as
otherwise provided, shall apply to all streaming services as hereinafter
defined, whether specifically licensed or regulated under other provisions of
this Code or other ordinances, or not.
   (B)   Definitions: For the purpose of this Section the following definitions
shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different
meaning. The masculine, feminine, singular or plural is included in any
circumstances.
 
            The gross amount of consideration paid for the privilege to enter, to witness, to
            view or to participate in a streaming service, including amounts paid for the
            right to access a streaming service, valued in money, whether received in money
            or otherwise, including cash, credits, property, and services, determined without
            any deduction for costs or expenses whatsoever. The term Charges Paid includes
CHARGES     any and all charges that the patron pays incidental to obtaining the privilege to
PAID:       enter, to witness, to view or to participate in a streaming service, including
            but not limited to any and all related markups, service fees, convenience fees,
            facilitation fees, cancellation fees and other such charges, regardless of
            terminology. The term Charges Paid does not include charges that are added on
            account of the tax imposed by this Section or on account of any other tax or
            surcharge imposed on the charge.
            (a)   Any person who sells or resells a ticket or other license to a streaming
            service for consideration or who, directly or indirectly, receives or collects
            the charges paid for the sale or resale of a ticket or other license to the
            streaming service. The term includes, but is not limited to, persons engaged in
            the business of selling or reselling tickets or other licenses to streaming
            services, whether online, in person or otherwise;
            (b)   With respect to the owner of a streaming service, any person which has an
            ownership or leasehold interest in such streaming service or any person who has a
OWNER OR    proprietary interest in the streaming service so as to entitle such person to all
OPERATOR:   or a portion of the proceeds, after payment of reasonable expenses, from the
            operation, conduct or presentation of such streaming service, excluding proceeds
            from non-amusement services and from sales of tangible personal property;
            (c)   Any person or entity operating a community antenna television system or
            wireless cable television system, or any person or entity receiving consideration
            from the patron for furnishing, transmitting, or otherwise providing access to
            paid television programming; or
            (d)   A person or entity operating a system, or any person or entity receiving
            consideration from the patron, for providing access to or electronically
            delivering video streaming, audio streaming or online games to patrons.
PAID        Programming that can be viewed on a television or other screen, and is
TELEVISION: transmitted by cable, fiber optics, laser, microwave, radio, satellite, or
            similar means to members of the public for consideration.
            Any person who acquires the privilege to enter, to witness, to view or to
PATRON:     participate in a streaming service in the Village; or any person who has a
            primary place of use within the Village who purchases the right to access a
            streaming service.
            Any individual, firm, organization, society, foundation, institution,
            partnership, limited liability company, association, joint stock company, joint
PERSON:     venture, public or private corporation, receiver, executor, trustee, or other
            representative appointed by the order of any court, or any other entity
            recognized by law.
            Any paid television programming, whether transmitted by wire, cable, fiber
STREAMING   optics, laser, microwave, radio, satellite, or similar means. Any video
SERVICE:    streaming, audio streaming or remotely accessed online games made available or
            delivered electronically to patrons on a rental or subscription basis, including,
            but not limited to, shows, movies, videos or music.
 
   (C)   Tax Imposed:
      1.   A streaming service tax of five percent (5%) of the charges paid for
such streaming service is imposed upon every patron for the privilege of access
to and witnessing, viewing, or participating in any streaming service in the
Village or that is delivered to a patron with a primary place of use with the
jurisdictional boundaries of the Village.
      2.   The tax imposed by paragraph (1) of this Section shall not be
imposed on transactions where the patron pays for the rights of the permanent
use of an electronic amusement.
      3.   In the case of streaming services that are delivered electronically
to mobile devices, as in the case of video streaming, audio streaming and
online games, the rules set forth in the Illinois Mobile Telecommunications
Sourcing Conformity Act, 638 ILCS 35, as amended, may be utilized for the
purpose of determining which customers and charges are presumed to be subject
to the streaming service tax. If those rules indicate that the tax applies, it
shall be presumed that the tax does apply unless the contrary is established by
books, records, or other documentary evidence.
   (D)   Payment And Collection:
      1.   The ultimate incidence of and liability for payment of the streaming
service tax shall be borne by the patron and shall never be shifted to the
owner or operator.
      2.   The owner or operator of each streaming service shall bear, jointly
and severally, the duty to collect the streaming service tax from each patron.
The owner or operator shall secure the streaming service tax from the patron at
the time that the charges paid for the streaming service are collected. For
purposes of this Section, it shall be presumed that the amount of the streaming
service tax imposed on each person, unless the person or owner or operator
provides otherwise with books, records, or other documentary evidence, has been
collected from the person by the owner or operator.
      3.   Every owner or operator who is required to collect the streaming
service tax shall be considered a tax collector for the Village. All streaming
service taxes collected shall be held by such tax collector as trustee for and
on behalf of the Village. The failure of the tax collector to collect the tax
shall not excuse or release the patron from the obligation to pay the tax.
      4.   The streaming service tax shall be paid in addition to any and all
other taxes and charges.
   (E)   Registration:
      1.   Every owner or operator providing services to customers subject to
the streaming service tax within the Village shall apply for registration as a
tax collector with the Village no later than thirty (30) days after commencing
such business or thirty (30) days after the effective date of this Section
imposing the streaming service tax, whichever occurs later.
      2.   The application shall be submitted to the Village Finance Director
on forms prepared by the Village and shall contain such information as
reasonably required by the Village to impose, collect, and audit all amounts
related to the streaming service tax.
   (F)   Administration And Enforcement:
      1.   The Village Finance Director, or such designee, shall administer and
enforce the streaming service tax. It shall be the responsibility and duty of
the Village Finance Director or such designee, to collect all amounts due the
Village from every person required to collect the streaming service tax.
      2.   A sworn monthly streaming service tax return, prepared on a calendar
month basis, shall be filed by each person required to collect the streaming
service tax with the Village Finance Director on forms prepared by the Village,
showing the gross receipts from the streaming service and the amount of
streaming service tax collected. Said tax returns and payment of the streaming
service tax collected during the reporting period shall be received by the
Village on or before the last day of the calendar month succeeding the end of
the monthly filing period. Acceptance by the Village of any amount tendered in
payment of the tax shall be without prejudice to any claim, demand or right on
account of any deficiency.
      3.   Any officer or employee of any entity who is an owner or operator
subject to the provisions of this Section who has the control supervision or
responsibility of collecting the streaming service tax, filing returns and
transmitting the collected tax and who willfully fails to file such return or
to transmit any tax so collected to the Village shall be personally liable for
any such amounts collected, including interest and penalties thereon, if after
proper proceedings for the collection of such amount, such entity is unable to
pay such amounts to the Village, and the personal liability of such officer or
employee shall survive dissolution of the entity. For purposes of this Section,
an officer or employee willfully fails to act if the officer or employee takes
any conscious and voluntary action intending not to perform any of the
officer's or employee's obligations hereunder, including but not limited to the
utilizing of tax proceeds collected for the Village to pay any other entity
obligations.
      4.   The Village Finance Director or such designee, may upon reasonable
notice inspect and examine the books and records of an owner or operator for
the proper administration of this tax, and for the enforcement of the
collection of the tax. It is unlawful for any person to prevent, hinder, or
interfere with the Village Finance Director or such designee, in the discharge
of the Village or such designee's duties hereunder. It shall be the duty of
every person required to collect the tax to keep accurate and complete books
and records, containing all information necessary for the collection of the
tax, to which the Finance Director or such designee, shall have full access.
      5.   In the event that the inspection and examination by the Village
Finance Director or such designee, discloses a discrepancy in excess of five
percent (5%) from the information furnished by the person required to collect
the tax, the cost of said inspection and examination shall be borne by said
person.
      6.   The Village is authorized to adopt, promulgate, and enforce any
additional rules and regulations pertaining to the interpretation, collection,
administration, and enforcement of this Section.
   (G)   Penalties: In the event of any failure by any person required to
collect the streaming service tax to file the required streaming service tax
return or collect and pay the streaming service tax on or before the due date,
penalty provisions of Section
1-4-1 shall apply with respect to late filing, late payment and failure to file
penalties. The total of such late filing, late payment, or failure to file
penalties shall be paid along with the tax imposed.
   (H)   Proceeds Of Tax: All proceeds resulting from the imposition of the
streaming service tax, including penalties, shall be paid into the treasury of
the Village.
   (I)   Suit For Collection: Whenever any person fails to pay any streaming
service tax, or when any person required to collect the streaming service tax
fails to collect the tax from the patron, the Village Attorney shall, upon
request of the Village, bring an action to enforce the payment of said tax on
behalf of the Village in any court of competent jurisdiction, with costs of
such enforcement to be borne by the defendant.
   (J)   Application Of Village Code: Any citation under this Section shall be
in addition to any other citations issued by the Village under any and all
applicable Sections of this Code.
   (K)   Fines:
      1.   Any owner or operator of a business with activity subject to the
streaming service tax failing or omitting to pay said tax when due; failing or
omitting to collect, to account for, or to pay over said tax and any penalty,
failing to maintain or allow examination of the required records; falsely
reporting or failing to report the amount of tax due as required by this
Section; or knowingly furnishing false or inaccurate information to the Village
shall in addition to any other payment or penalty provided herein or elsewhere
by law or ordinance, be imposed a fine of not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) and also be
ordered to pay all of the costs and fees incurred by the Village in prosecuting
the violation, which may include, but shall not be limited to the costs of an
administrative adjudicative proceeding or court proceeding and reasonable
attorney's fees and costs.
      A separate and distinct offense shall be regarded as committed on each
day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. All fines shall be in
addition to the unpaid streaming service tax plus penalties. The payment of a
fine shall not relieve the person so fined from liability for the streaming
service tax. The purpose of imposing penalties for the violation of this
Section is to ensure the integrity of the collection process established
pursuant to this Section. (Ord. 2141, 4-10-2024, eff. 7-1-2024)
CHAPTER 3
FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:
5-3-1: Bakeries
5-3-2: Beverage Dealers; Wholesale
5-3-3: Food Delivery Vehicles
5-3-4: Food Refrigeration Locker Plants
5-3-5: Retail Food Dealers
5-3-6: Milk Dealers
5-3-7: Restaurants
5-3-8: Wholesale Provision Dealer
5-3-9: General Conditions
5-3-1: BAKERIES:
   (A)   Definition: Any place or establishment used for any process of mixing,
compounding or baking for sale, any bread, biscuits, pretzels, crackers, buns,
rolls, macaroni, cake, pies or any food product of which flour or meal is the
principal ingredient, shall be deemed a bakery for the purpose of this section,
provided that restaurants in which any of the foregoing food products are mixed
and baked, on or in an ordinary kitchen stove or range shall not be considered
to be a bakery.
   (B)   Fee: The annual license fee shall be computed on a square footage
basis.
   (C)   Specific Regulations: Every place used as a bakery shall be adequately
lighted at all times and shall be ventilated by means of windows or skylights
or airshafts or ducts, or mechanical apparatus, if necessary, to ensure a free
circulation of fresh air at all times. Such ventilation construction and
equipment shall be of such character that a complete change of air in all parts
of the bakery may be made at least four (4) times each hour; provided, however,
that it shall not be necessary to ventilate at such times or in such a manner
that the process of mixing or raising dough shall of necessity be interfered
with or prevented. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-3-2: BEVERAGE DEALERS; WHOLESALE:
   (A)   Definition: A "wholesale beverage dealer" is a person, firm or
corporation who or which engages in the business of the manufacture or sale for
wholesale distribution of nonalcoholic carbonated beverages.
   (B)   Fee: The annual license fee shall be computed on a square footage
basis. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-3-3: FOOD DELIVERY VEHICLES:
   (A)   Definition: "Food delivery vehicles" are any vehicles, including
wagons and motor vehicles and vehicles propelled by manpower, for the storage
or carrying of any meat, poultry, fish, butter, cheese, lard, vegetables, bread
or bakery goods, or any other provisions intended for human consumption,
including beverages, but excluding milk, for the purpose of delivering any such
foodstuffs as a retail sale to any place in the municipality. (Ord. 633B, 12-
14-1966)
   (B)   Fee: The annual license fee for such license shall be fifty dollars
($50.00) for each vehicle delivering at retail. (Ord. 911, 4-12-1978)
   (C)   Exemption: No license fee shall be required for any vehicle used to
deliver foodstuffs from any establishment which is licensed and inspected as a
food dealing establishment in the municipality.
   (D)   Specific Regulations: If unwrapped foodstuffs are transported in any
such vehicle such foods shall be carried in a portion or compartment of the
vehicle which is screened and protected against dust and insects. (Ord. 633B,
12-14-1966)
5-3-4: FOOD REFRIGERATION LOCKER PLANTS:
   (A)   Definitions:
   FOOD: Shall mean and include any edibles or beverages used or intended for
human consumption.
   FOOD REFRIGERATION LOCKER PLANT: Shall mean and include any establishment
wherein compartments are rented, leased or made available to other than the
owner of the establishment for the refrigeration of food.
   (B)   Application For License: In addition to all other information
contained in such application, it shall state the number of units maintained on
the premises, and the size of each unit; and each application shall also state
whether a unit is maintained in which food will be stored belonging to several
individuals in addition to the separate units rented to other than the owner of
the premises.
   (C)   Fee: The annual license fee shall be computed on a square footage
basis.
   (D)   Temperature Requirements: No food shall be stored in any such plant
unless such food has been frozen to a temperature of zero degrees Fahrenheit
(0°F) or below being so stored; and the lockers or compartments used for the
refrigerated storage of food must be kept at all times at a temperature of
below fifteen degrees Fahrenheit (15°F). (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-3-5: RETAIL FOOD DEALERS:
   (A)   Definition: A retail food dealer is a person, firm or corporation who
or which engages in the retail sale at a permanent location of meat, produce,
fruit, groceries, soft drink beverages and other food products not intended to
be consumed on seller's premises.
   (B)   Fee: The annual license fee shall be computed on a square footage
basis.
   (C)   Milk Dealers: Retail food dealers engaging in the sale of dairy
products are not subject to subsections 5-3-6(A), (B) and (C) of this chapter;
however, such licensees are subject to all other provisions of said section 5-
3-6 of this chapter. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-3-6: MILK DEALERS:
   (A)   Definition: A "milk dealer" is a person, firm or corporation who or
which engages in the sale or distribution of milk, cream or other dairy
products from a vehicle operating on the public streets. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-
1966)
   (B)   Fee: The annual license fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for each
vehicle used for delivery. (Ord. 911, 4-12-1978)
   (C)   Standards: "Milk", as the term is used herein, shall mean the whole,
fresh clean lacteal secretion obtained by the complete milking of one or more
healthy cows, properly fed and kept clean, excluding that obtained within
fifteen (15) days before and five (5) days after calving, or such longer period
as may be required to render the milk practically colostrum free, and shall
contain not less than three percent (3%) of milk fat; and not less than eight
and one-half percent (81/2%) of milk solids not fat. No milk not conforming to
this section shall be sold or offered for sale in the municipality.
   (D)   State Dairy Statute: All skim milk, buttermilk and cream shall conform
to the standards fixed in the state dairy statute, and the sale or offering for
sale of any milk or milk products not in conformity with this law is
prohibited.
   (E)   Percentage Of Butterfat In Cream; Regulations For Selling Cream: No
cream shall be sold, offered for sale, exchanged or delivered or kept for the
purpose of sale that contains less than eighteen percent (18%) of milk fat, or
that is obtained from any impure, diseased, adulterated or unwholesome milk, or
from milk to which any foreign substance has been added, or from milk
containing less than three percent (3%) of butterfat or from cows fed on refuse
or slop, mash or food which has been subject to fermentation, or any food other
than good, wholesome food.
   (F)   Artificial Preservative: It shall be unlawful to sell any milk or
cream containing any artificial preservative.
   (G)   Milk Animals; Bacterial Rating: All milk offered for sale or sold must
come from animals under state and federal supervision and proven free from all
contagious and infectious diseases, and shall contain not more than fifty
thousand (50,000) bacteria per cubic centimeter and no pathogenic bacteria, and
shall be produced under the following conditions:
      1.   All persons living upon farms, employed thereon or coming in contact
with milk in dairies or other places shall be free from contagious or
infectious diseases and shall not have been exposed to anyone having such
diseases within a period of one week prior to the exercise of such duties.
      2.   No person who is a paratyphoid, typhoid, diphtheria or septic sore
throat carrier shall be employed in the production or handling of such milk.
      3.   It shall be the duty of every person, firm or corporation with a
knowledge of the facts to notify the health officer or other legally
constituted authority at once of the occurrence of any of the above afflictions
in persons living or employed in or about a place where milk is produced,
handled or sold. Milk and milk derivatives that have been exposed shall not be
shipped into or sold or offered for sale in the municipality.
   (H)   Grade A Milk: It shall be unlawful to offer for sale any milk labeled
"Grade A Milk" unless the same has been produced and transported in compliance
with the statutes of the state of Illinois relating thereto.
   (I)   Pasteurization Required: It shall be unlawful to sell, or offer for
sale for human consumption any milk or milk products which have not been
produced and pasteurized in the manner required by statute.
   (J)   Deliveries To Quarantined Premises: Milk may be delivered to
quarantined premises, provided that there is no contact of any kind between the
inmates and contents of the quarantined premises and the delivery agent.
No milk receptacles shall be taken from such premises during the period of
quarantine; and before taken away for use, such receptacles shall be thoroughly
sealed and sterilized.
   (K)   Containers: No milk except skimmed milk, buttermilk or sour milk,
shall be peddled or sold at retail in quantities of less than one gallon except
in containers bearing the true name of the article, the name and address of the
producer, dealer or distributor and the net volume of the contents in
accordance with the Illinois dairy statute, and no person shall sell milk or
cream in any bottle or container other than those bearing the seller's name or
to which he has acquired title as required by law.
   (L)   Inspection: The health officer shall conduct periodic inspections of
all milk distribution plants, dairies, vehicles and equipment used in the sale
or distribution of milk as well as of the milk itself. Such inspections shall
be made every quarter and as often as the said health officer deems necessary.
The inspector may in his discretion in lieu of inspection, accept the
certificate of inspection of any other municipality having equal or more rigid
requirements than provided by this section. The licensee shall pay the cost of
all bacteriological inspections and tests necessary. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-3-7: RESTAURANTS:
   (A)   Annual License Fee: The annual license fee for such licenses shall be
computed on a square footage basis. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
   (B)   Definitions; Purpose: The purpose of these regulations is to ensure
that all foods served in the village are served in a safe and healthful manner.
   CRITICAL VIOLATION: A violation requiring immediate correction.
   EMPLOYEE: Any individual having supervisory or management duties, and any
other person working in a food service establishment.
   FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENT: Any place where food or drink is prepared or
served to the public either for consumption on the premises or to be carried
off the premises.
   HEALTH INSPECTOR: Any individual employed by the village to conduct
inspections who has obtained a food service sanitation manager certificate
issued by the Illinois department of public health.
   HEALTH OFFICER: The person employed by the village to make health
inspections and to enforce the health regulations of the village and the
Illinois department of public health and who has obtained a food service
sanitation manager certificate issued by the Illinois department of public
health.
   (C)   Inspection Of Food Service Establishments:
      1.   All establishments must pass an initial building and health
inspection prior to the issuance of a business license.
      2.   In addition to the initial inspection required under subsection (C)1
of this section, food service establishments will be required to have
additional annual inspections based on their relative risk for causing food
borne illnesses. Assignment of risk (high, medium or low) will be based on
criteria established by the Illinois department of public health program
standards (77 Illinois administrative code 615.310). The inspection schedule
will be as follows:
         (a)   High risk: Three (3) inspections per calendar year.
         (b)   Medium risk: Two (2) inspections per calendar year.
         (c)   Low risk: One inspection per calendar year.
   Risk level of each establishment will be reviewed and verified annually by
the health officer. The health officer is authorized to adopt reasonable
inspection procedures at least as stringent as those outlined in the Illinois
department of public health food service sanitation code (77 Illinois
administrative code 750) and the retail food store sanitation code (77 Illinois
administrative code 760).
      3.   In the event of a temporary food service establishment, it is
intended that all food be prepared on the premises of the food service
establishment and delivered to the place of service in an approved manner at
appropriate temperatures. All temporary food service establishments are subject
to inspection by the health officer or health inspector.
      4.   An inspection will also be conducted upon receipt of a complaint or
at such time as the health officer/health inspector has reason to believe a
health violation has occurred. If an establishment fails to remedy all
violations identified during the inspection at the time of the designated
reinspection, an additional fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) will be assessed. If
the establishment has rectified all problems identified by the first
reinspection, no fee will be assessed.
      5.   In the event further reinspections are required, an additional one
hundred dollar ($100.00) fee will be assessed for each reinspection. All
reinspection fees are payable before the next reinspection date. If critical
violations are found by the health officer/health inspector, a recommendation
may be made to the village president or president pro tempore to close the
establishment until such violations are corrected and the establishment
successfully passes a subsequent inspection and all fees are paid.
      6.   If the food service establishment fails to comply with the
regulations set forth in subsections (C)4 and (C)5 of this section, the health
officer/health inspector will advise the village president or president pro
tempore, who may then revoke or suspend said establishment's business license.
(Ord. 1510, 6-27-2001)
   (D)   Posting Of Inspection Report: One copy of the inspection report shall
be posted by the health officer upon an inside wall of the restaurant, and said
inspection report shall not be defaced or removed by any person except the
health officer. Another copy of the inspection report shall be filed with the
records of the health department and with the village clerk.
      The person operating the restaurant shall, upon request of the health
officer, permit access to all parts of the establishment and shall permit
copying any or all records of food purchased.
   (E)   Toilet Facilities: Every restaurant shall be provided with adequate
and conveniently located toilet facilities for its employees, conforming with
the ordinances of the municipality. In restaurants hereafter constructed,
toilet rooms shall not open directly into any room in which food, drink or
utensils are handled or stored. The doors of all toilet rooms shall be self-
closing. Toilet rooms shall be kept in a clean condition, in good repair and
well lighted and ventilated. Hand washing signs shall be posted in each toilet
room used by employees.
   (F)   Water Supply: Running water under pressure shall be easily accessible
to all rooms in which food is prepared or utensils are washed, and the water
supply shall be adequate, and of a safe, sanitary quality.
   (G)   Construction Of Utensils And Equipment: All multiuse utensils and all
show and display cases or windows, counters, shelves, tables, refrigerating
equipment, sinks and other equipment or utensils used in connection with the
operation of a restaurant shall be so constructed as to be easily cleaned and
shall be kept in good repair. Utensils containing or plated with cadmium or
lead shall not be used; provided that solder containing lead may be used for
jointing.
   (H)   Cleaning And Bactericidal Treatment Of Utensils And Equipment:
      1.   All equipment, including display cases or windows, counters,
shelves, tables, refrigerators, stove hoods and sinks, shall be kept clean and
free from dust, dirt, insects and other contaminating material. All cloths used
by waiters, chefs and other employees shall be clean. Single service containers
shall be used only once.
      2.   All multiuse eating and drinking utensils shall be thoroughly
cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal process after
each usage. All multiuse utensils used in the preparation or serving of food
and drink shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved
process immediately following the day's operation. Drying cloths, if used,
shall be clean and shall be used for no other purpose.
      3.   No article, polish or other substance containing any cyanide
preparation or other poisonous material shall be used for the cleaning or
polishing of utensils.
   (I)   Storage And Handling Of Utensils And Equipment: After bactericidal
treatment, utensils shall be stored in a clean, dry place protected from flies,
dust and other contamination, and shall be handled in such a manner as to
prevent contamination as far as practical. Single service utensils shall be
purchased only in containers, shall be stored therein in a clean, dry place
until used and shall be handled in a sanitary manner. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
   (J)   Refrigeration: All readily perishable food and drink shall be kept at
forty one degrees Fahrenheit (41°F) or below, except when being prepared or
served. Wastewater from refrigeration equipment shall be properly disposed of.
(Ord. 1439, 6-10-1998)
   (K)   Wholesomeness Of Food And Drink: All food and drink shall be clean,
wholesome, free from spoilage, and be prepared as to be safe for human
consumption. All milk, fluid milk products, ice cream and other frozen desserts
served shall be from approved sources. Milk and fluid milk products shall be
served in the individual containers which they were received from the
distributor or from a bulk container equipped with an approved dispensing
device; provided, that this requirement shall not apply to cream, which may be
served from the original bottle or from a dispenser approved for such service.
All oysters, clams and mussels shall be from approved sources, and if shucked
shall be kept until used in the containers in which they were placed at the
shucking plant.
   (L)   Storage, Display And Serving Of Food And Drink: All food and drink
shall be stored, displayed and served as to be protected from dust, flies,
vermin, depredation and pollution by rodents, unnecessary handling, droplet
infection, overhead leakage and other contamination. No animals or fowl shall
be kept or allowed in any room in which food or drink is prepared or stored.
All means necessary for the elimination of flies, roaches and rodents shall be
used. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-3-8: WHOLESALE PROVISION DEALER:
   (A)   Definition: A "wholesale provision dealer" is a person, firm or
corporation who or which engages in the business of buying and selling at
wholesale any meat, poultry, fish, butter, cheese, lard, vegetables, fruit,
flour, meal or other provisions in the municipality.
   (B)   Fee: The annual license fee shall be computed on a square footage
basis. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-3-9: GENERAL CONDITIONS:
   (A)   Premises: All premises and vehicles used by any licensee under this
chapter shall be maintained so as to comply with the following regulations:
(Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
      1.   Effective measures intended to minimize the presence of rodents,
flies, roaches and other insects on the premises shall be utilized. Copies of
pest control service records shall be available to the health officer upon
request. (Ord. 1510, 6-27-2001)
      2.   Be adequately lighted and ventilated to ensure a free circulation of
fresh air.
      3.   Be kept in a clean and sanitary condition.
      4.   Shall not have any living or sleeping quarters contained within the
area used for the business or occupation.
      5.   Shall have adequate toilet and lavatory facilities for employees.
Lavatory facilities shall have both hot and cold running water with approved
sanitary towels. The use of a common towel is prohibited.
      6.   All garbage and trash shall be kept in commercially manufactured
receptacles.
   (B)   Employees: Employees of licensees under this chapter shall comply with
the following regulations:
      1.   Keep themselves clean, both as to person and clothing.
      2.   Not be afflicted with or be a carrier of any infectious or
contagious disease. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
   (C)   State Statutes: All licensees under this chapter shall comply with
state statutes, regulations, orders, rules or codes, including, but not limited
to, food service sanitation code and retail food service sanitation code of the
Illinois department of public health regulating the licensee's business or
occupation or public health. If such state statutes, codes, rules, regulations
or orders are more restrictive than the provisions of this chapter, the
provisions of the state shall prevail. (Ord. 1439, 6-10-1998)
   (D)   Inspections: In addition to the information required on the business
license application, all food service establishments must be under the
supervision of a certified food sanitation manager as outlined in the Illinois
department of public health food sanitation code. The health officer shall be
provided with copies of all food service sanitation certificates issued by the
Illinois department of public health at the time of application for business
license and/or renewal. Failure to comply with this requirement may result in
the nonissuance of the business license.
Upon the loss of a certified food service manager, the food service
establishment must notify the health officer within three (3) days. Food
service establishments not in compliance because of employee turnover or other
loss of certified personnel shall comply with the terms and provisions as soon
as possible but no longer than three (3) months from the date of loss and shall
include a copy of the food service sanitation certificate for any new or
replacement employee, within seven (7) days of date of hire, if certified or
seven (7) days from date of certification if not certified. Failure to comply
with this requirement may result in revocation of said establishment's business
license. (Ord. 1510, 6-27-2001)
CHAPTER 4
OTHER BUSINESSES (EXCEPT ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES)
SECTION:
5-4-1: General Provisions
5-4-2: Barbershops And Beauty Shops

5-4-5: Pet Shops And Veterinary Hospitals
5-4-6: Lumberyards

5-4-10: Public Garage
5-4-11: Condition Of All Licensed Premises
5-4-12: Auctioneers
5-4-13: Auto Courts And Motels (Rep. by Ord. 1683, 3-11-2009)
5-4-14: Building Contractors
5-4-15: Expressmen, Draymen And Movers
5-4-16: Foreign Fire Insurance Companies
5-4-17: Handbills
5-4-18: Hospitals
5-4-19: Hotels, Motels, Hotel Clubs, Motel Clubs And Rooming Houses
5-4-20: House Movers
5-4-21: Fees, Standards
5-4-22: Insurance Brokers
5-4-23: Junk Dealers 1  (Rep. by Ord. 1861, 2-12-2014)
5-4-24: Itinerant Merchants; Peddlers And Hawkers
5-4-25: Nursing Homes
5-4-26: Outdoor Advertising
5-4-27: Pawnbrokers And Junk Dealers
5-4-28: Fuel Dealers And Bulk Storage Of Petroleum Products
5-4-29: Real Estate Brokers
5-4-30: Scavengers
5-4-31: Service Stations
5-4-32: Solicitors
5-4-33: Taxicabs
5-4-34: Tobacco Products, Retail Sale
5-4-35: Towing Vehicles
5-4-36: Vending Machines

5-4-2: BARBERSHOPS AND BEAUTY SHOPS:
   (A)   Sanitation: It shall be unlawful to use in any such establishment any
implements, tools or equipment upon any person after the same has been used
upon a person afflicted with any skin or scalp disease without first
sterilizing said tool, implement or equipment.
      It shall be unlawful to use any towel on any person after same has been
used, without first having such towel sterilized and cleaned.
   (B)   Inspections: It shall be the duty of the Health Officer to inspect
said establishments as often as necessary to ensure compliance with the above
provisions. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-4-3: DRY CLEANERS:
   (A)   Machines: Any machine used in a dry cleaning business shall be
completely enclosed by a cabinet and shall be vented with intake at the top and
the outlet at or near the bottom of such machine. Groups of machines may be
entirely enclosed or supported on all open sides by an enclosure topped with a
hood vented as provided for each individual machine.
   The exhaust system must maintain a minimum flow of one hundred (100) cubic
feet per minute face velocity through the loading door whenever the door is
open.
   The discharge stack for the machines and for the room in which the machines
are located shall extend at least two feet (2') above the level of any window
which can be opened located within fifty feet (50') of the outlet of the stack,
and shall be at least fifty feet (50') away from any fresh air intake leading
to any premises.
   The machines must be so constructed as to prevent the loading door from
being opened during the normal cycle of operation. Each machine shall be
equipped with a transparent door or port to allow visual examination of the
status of the cleaning cycle.
   Any connection of such machine with the water supply system must be equipped
with an air gap or vacuum breaker in the line upstream from the condenser; with
no control valves downstream from such gap or breaker. Wastewater shall be
discharged through an air gap.
   The room in which such machine is installed shall be ventilated so that
there shall be a minimum flow of air per machine from the area to which the
public is admitted, of at least five hundred (500) cubic feet per minute in a
room where there are no more than three (3) machines installed; four hundred
(400) cubic feet per minute where there are no more than eight (8) machines
installed; three hundred seventy five (375) cubic feet per minute where there
are no more than sixteen (16) machines installed; and three hundred sixty (360)
cubic feet per minute where there are more than seventeen (17) machines
installed. For this purpose, each cleaning cell shall be considered as one
machine.
   Each machine must be so designed and constructed as to prevent the leakage
of liquids, gas or vapors.
   (B)   Operation Regulations: No such automatic dry cleaning machine shall be
operated unless all the equipment described in the foregoing subsection is
properly installed and in good operating working condition.
   No establishment for which a license is required under this chapter shall be
open for business, and it shall be unlawful to admit the public or customers
into the room where such machines are located unless there is on duty in the
establishment at all times a competent person in charge of the establishment,
and in charge of the operation of such machines. There shall be warning signs
posted in places of easy observation warning of the dangers in the event
leakage of liquids, gas or vapor occurs. It shall be unlawful to permit any
residue containing solvent to flow into the sewer system of the municipality;
tightly covered metal containers may be used for temporary storage of such
waste outside the building. Such containers shall bear labels indicating the
contents and dangers involved in handling, and shall be locked if in an
unenclosed place.
   At least one legible sign shall be maintained in a place available to
customers giving the name, address and phone number of the owner of the
establishment, and the service department or agency responsible for the proper
maintenance of the machine.
   (C)   Inspections: It shall be the duty of the chief of police or other
official designated by the president and board of trustees to inspect or cause
to be inspected every establishment licensed under this section, at least once
every six (6) months. Any violations of this or other ordinances relating to
dry cleaners, premises and/or flammable liquids shall be reported to the
president and board of trustees.
   (D)   Fire Hazard: The chief of the fire department shall have the right to
enter any building or premises situated in the village and occupied by any dry
cleaning establishment, in order to examine the same and to determine whether
or not said building and premises, or any material, chemical or compound kept
therein, or used thereon, or any article or fabric dry cleaned, dyed, spotted
or finished, as received, used, kept, maintained or stored on said premises or
building conforms to the fire ordinances and regulations of the village or
constitutes a fire hazard within the village. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-4-4: ICE DEALERS:
All ice sold for human consumption shall be clean and packaged in such a manner
as to avoid contamination. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-4-5: PET SHOPS AND VETERINARY HOSPITALS:
   (A)   Definitions:
   PET SHOP: Shall be construed to include any establishment that offers to
sell, exchange, or offers for adoption with or without charge or donation dogs,
cats, birds, fish or other animals customarily obtained as pets.
   VETERINARY HOSPITAL: Any institution used for the harboring or reception for
care and treatment of dogs, cats or other animals operated by a licensed
veterinarian or veterinarians under the state of Illinois veterinary medicine
and surgery practice act of 2004.
   (B)   License Required: No person or persons shall engage in the business of
operating a pet shop or veterinary hospital without first obtaining a village
business license and complying with all applicable ordinances.
   (C)   Application For License: Application for license to operate a pet shop
or veterinary hospital shall be made in writing to the village clerk stating
the location of the premises and the number and types of animals proposed to be
kept on the premises. The building superintendent and/or village health officer
shall make all appropriate inspections of said premises to ascertain whether
they are fit and suitable for the housing and care of animals and to assure
that all ordinances are complied with.
   (D)   License Fee: The annual license fee for each pet shop or veterinary
hospital shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00).
   (E)   Veterinary Hospitals: The operation and staffing of all veterinary
hospitals shall be in accordance with the state of Illinois veterinary medicine
and surgery practice act of 2004.
   (F)   Running At Large Prohibited: No dogs or cats shall be permitted to
stray or be taken outside the limits of the pet shop or veterinary hospital
unless leashed in accordance with section 6-2-6 of this code relative to
animals.
   (G)   Inspection Of Premises: The village health officer and/or building
superintendent shall periodically inspect each such place of business to
determine compliance of the provisions of this chapter.
   (H)   Sanitation: All premises and equipment related to pet shops and
veterinary hospitals shall be kept clean and sanitary at all times. The
buildings and pens shall be washed and disinfected and kept in a sanitary
condition subject to inspection by the building superintendent and/or health
officer. All animals shall be humanely treated, with sufficient quantities of
wholesome food and water, and any animal having any disease shall be properly
isolated and treated.
   (I)   Compliance: All other requirements relative to the health, safety and
humane treatment of animals as outlined in title 6, chapter 2, of this code
relative to animals are hereby complied with. (Ord. 1585, 2-11-2004)
5-4-6: LUMBERYARDS:
   (A)   Fire Limits: No lumberyard shall be established or licensed within the
fire limits of the village 1 .
   (B)   Fire Apparatus: It shall be the duty of every person, firm or
corporation owning or operating a lumberyard to have the same equipped with
sufficient firefighting apparatus to handle any small fires which may start
therein and to prevent their spreading.
   (C)   Piling Lumber: It shall be unlawful to pile any lumber in a lumberyard
in such a way that the lumber is hanging over or in danger of falling onto any
adjoining property, street, alley or public way.
   (D)   Inspections: It shall be the duty of the fire chief to inspect every
lumberyard established in the municipality, to cause such inspections to be
made at least once every six (6) months to ensure compliance with this section.
(Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
