5-4-7: MACHINE SHOPS:
   (A)   Definition: The term "machine shop" as used in this section shall be
construed to mean and include every workshop in which machines are made or
metal parts thereof are repaired, or where parts of machines or tools,
implements, gears, dies, screws, or other metal articles are cut, filed, shaped
or repaired by means of a lathe or other machinery, or where machines are
issued in the process of the business.
   (B)   Sanitary Requirements: No building, structure or part thereof used for
or in connection with any machine shop shall be so used as to endanger the
health or property of the employees or of the public; the owner, lessee,
tenant, occupant or manager of any machine shop shall cause all floors and
other surfaces around or beneath any machine or workbench to be kept in good
order and repair and shall have suitable and convenient sanitary receptacles
for receiving waste and cloths used in and about machine shops for the purpose
of cleaning machines or parts of machines thereof or which are intended for any
other use. No person suffering from any contagious or infectious disease shall
be employed in or about any machine where cutting compound is used. All such
cutting compound or fluid shall be kept free from infectious or harmful matter.
   (C)   Inspections: It shall be the duty of the fire chief to make or cause
to be made such inspections of the premises as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this section. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-4-8: PAINT STORES:
It shall be the duty of the fire chief to inspect the premises of paint stores
to determine if combustible materials are being stored in accordance with the
fire regulations of the village. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-4-9: PARKING LOTS:
No parking space shall be provided for motor vehicles in a parking lot, where a
fee is charged for such parking, within ten feet (10') of any building or
structure used for housing accommodations unless the wall facing such parking
space is constructed of fireproof materials and unless the windows in such
wall, if any, are equipped with reinforced fire resistant glass. (Ord. 633B,
12-14-1966)
5-4-10: PUBLIC GARAGE:
   (A)   Applications: Applications shall state the location of the garage and
the number of cars which can be accommodated therein.
   (B)   License Fee: The annual license fee shall be computed on a square
footage basis.
   (C)   Smoking: It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke or light a
cigarette, cigar or pipe in any public garage.
   (D)   Premises; Building: It shall be unlawful to maintain or operate any
public garage in a frame building, or in any building or structure used for
school, church or theater purposes, or in any building which does not conform
to the requirements of the building ordinance. The premises of every garage
must be kept clean and free from flammable wastes.
   (E)   Location Restrictions: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate,
maintain or conduct a public garage within three hundred feet (300') of any
church, school or hospital in the municipality.
   (F)   Changing Identification Marks: It shall be unlawful for any person to
change the identification marks on the engine of any car or automobile in any
public garage. And, it shall be unlawful to change the license tags on such,
excepting in accordance with the register of motor vehicles kept by the
secretary of state of Illinois.
   (G)   Inspections: It shall be the duty of the fire chief to make or cause
to be made such inspections of public garages as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this section. Any police officer shall be
permitted at any reasonable time to view every car stored or kept in any public
garage, and it shall be unlawful to hinder any such inspection or to conceal
any motor car or motor vehicle from such inspection. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-4-11: CONDITION OF ALL LICENSED PREMISES:
   (A)   Fire Inspections: The premises of business licensed under the
provisions of subsection
5-4-1(A) of this chapter, shall be inspected periodically by the chief of the
fire department to ensure that premises are maintained so that fire exits and
other means of ingress and egress to the premises are not blocked so as to
hinder egress from the premises. The chief of the fire department shall also
determine that fire extinguishers and the general condition of the premises are
maintained in accordance with the fire regulations of the village.
   (B)   Building Inspections: The premises of business licensed under the
provisions of subsection
5-4-1(A) of this chapter shall be inspected periodically by the building
inspector to ensure that the premises have not become in an unsafe condition
for the public or employees of the licensee. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-4-12: AUCTIONEERS:
   (A)   Fees: The annual license fee shall be computed on a square footage
basis. A daily license fee shall be ten dollars ($10.00). (Ord. 912, 4-12-1978)
   (B)   Investigations: The chief of police, or any other officer designated
by the village president, shall investigate the character of every applicant
for an auctioneer's license, and no such license shall be issued to any person
who is not of good character.
   (C)   Employees: Every person, licensed as an auctioneer, may designate not
to exceed two (2) employees who may be authorized by him to conduct auctions.
The names of employees so designated must be given to the village clerk, and an
auctioneer to permit an auction to be conducted by an unlicensed employee.
   (D)   Auctions On Streets: No person shall sell or attempt to sell or offer
for sale at public auction, any goods, chattels, or personal or real property
of any kind upon the public streets or sidewalks of the municipality.
   (E)   Exemptions: Nothing in this section shall apply to any public auction
or sale made or conducted by a public officer by virtue of any judicial order
or process or by virtue of any power or authority contained in a mortgage or
trust deed. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-4-13: AUTO COURTS AND MOTELS:
(Rep. by Ord. 1683, 3-11-2009)
5-4-14: BUILDING CONTRACTORS:
   (A)   General Contractor: A general contractor is engaging in the business
of contracting with one or more trade contractors to perform the service of the
trade contractor. The general contractor's annual license fee shall be three
hundred dollars ($300.00).
   (B)   Trade Contractors: Any person doing business as a trade contractor
shall be construed as engaged in the business of a contractor. They shall not
be engaged with one or more other contractors. The annual license fee shall be
one hundred dollars ($100.00). (Ord. 1810, 11-14-2012)
   (C)   Regulations: It shall be the duty of all building contractors to
comply with all ordinances relating to the construction of building or other
structures, to the construction of streets or sidewalk pavements and all laws
or ordinances pertaining to or regulating the activities engaged in. (Ord.
633B, 12-14-1966)
   (D)   Bond: All contractors who are licensed under the provisions of this
section to do business must file and keep in force during the license period a
bond in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) with sureties to be
approved by the board of trustees. Said bond must require the principal and
surety to bind themselves firmly unto the village as obligee in the penal sum
of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). The condition of the obligation is to
indemnify the village and hold it harmless from any loss, damage, claim or
liability arising out of or resulting from the conduct or operation of such
business or the doing or failure to do any act in connection therewith. The
principal shall faithfully comply with the provisions of all laws or ordinances
regulating the business for which the license or permit is issued. (Ord. 1437,
6-10-1998)
   (E)   Insurance Required: All contractors shall furnish to the village an
insurance certificate issued by an insurance company authorized to do business
in the state providing for public liability coverage of not less than one
million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence. Demolition contractors are
required to carry a minimum of two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) worth of
coverage. Asbestos removal contractors are required to carry a minimum of two
million dollars ($2,000,000.00) worth of coverage. All insurance policies must
name the village of Midlothian, its agents, employees, officers and officials
as named insureds. (Ord. 1810, 11-14-2012)
5-4-15: EXPRESSMEN, DRAYMEN AND MOVERS:
The annual license fee for expressmen, draymen and movers shall be fifty
dollars ($50.00) plus thirty dollars ($30.00) for each truck used in said
business. (Ord. 912, 4-12-1978)
5-4-16: FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE COMPANIES:
   (A)   License Required: It shall be unlawful for any corporation or
association not incorporated under the laws of the state to engage in effecting
fire insurance in the municipality or to transact any business of fire
insurance in the municipality without fully complying with the provisions of
this section.
   (B)   Fee: Any such corporation or association shall pay to the treasurer of
the village, for the maintenance, use and benefit of the fire department
thereof, a sum of money equal to two percent (2%) of the gross receipts each
year received from premiums by any and all agents of any such corporation or
association or received as premiums in any way for fire insurance policies on
any property in the municipality. Such payments shall be made for the year
ending July 1 of each year.
   (C)   Reports: Each person acting as representative for or on behalf of any
such company or association shall, on or before July 15 of each year, render to
the village treasurer a full, true and just account, verified by oath, of all
premiums which have been received by him on behalf of the company or
association during the year ending the preceding July 1 on such fire insurance
policies.
   (D)   Time Of Payment: All payments under the provisions of this section
shall be made on or before July 15 following the termination of the year for
which such payments are due. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-4-17: HANDBILLS:
   (A)   Street Distribution Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person,
firm or corporation to distribute indiscriminately to the public, any cards,
circulars, handbills, samples of merchandise, or any advertising matter
whatsoever on any public street or sidewalk or other public place in the
municipality.
   (B)   House To House Distribution: It shall be unlawful to distribute
indiscriminately to the public by leaving at stores, offices, houses or
residences in the municipality, any cards, circulars, samples of merchandise,
handbills or any advertising matter whatsoever without first having secured a
permit therefor. Provided that this section shall not be construed to apply to
the sale of articles by licensed peddlers.
   (C)   License; Application: Applications for such licenses shall be made to
the village clerk, and shall contain a statement of the nature of the article,
cards or advertisements to be distributed and the name of the applicant and the
name of the manufacturer or distributor of such article or service advertised.
(Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
   (D)   Fee: The fee for such licenses shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per day.
No such license shall be issued to any but a person of good character. The
chief of police shall make or cause to be made an investigation into the
character of each applicant and shall report the results thereof to the village
clerk before any such license shall be issued.
The license so obtained shall not entitle the licensee to conduct any other
business without an additional license. (Ord. 912, 4-12-1978)
5-4-18: HOSPITALS:
   (A)   Hospital Defined: For the purpose of this section, a "hospital" is
hereby defined to mean any institution or place used for the harboring or the
reception, care and treatment (including treatments known as rest cure,
physical culture, hydropathic massage and all other forms of drugless
treatment) of two (2) or more persons suffering from or afflicted with any
mental or physical disease, ailment, sickness, bodily injury, alcohol or drug
addiction; or any institution or place for the reception and care, temporary or
continuous of one or more women during pregnancy while awaiting confinement,
during confinement or for one month or less after confinement, while recovering
therefrom. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
   (B)   License Fee: The annual license fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00)
plus two dollars ($2.00) per bed. (Ord. 912, 4-12-1978)
   (C)   Application: Any person, firm, association or corporation desiring
such license shall make written application to the president and board of
trustees in which application shall be stated the location or proposed location
of the hospital, the purpose for which it is or is intended to be built,
opened, conducted or maintained; the accommodations or proposed accommodations
for the inmates thereof; the nature and kind of treatment given or proposed to
be given therein; the name and address of the chief physician, surgeon or
attending chief physician or surgeon; or board of physicians or surgeons; and
the owners or proposed owners thereof.
   (D)   Location Of Contagious Disease Institutions: It shall be unlawful for
any person, firm, association or corporation to build, construct, maintain,
operate, conduct or manage any hospital, sanitarium, rest home or any other
institution, building or place for the reception, care and treatment of any
person or persons known to be afflicted with any disease of a contagious,
infectious, tuberculous, epidemic or communicable character whatsoever within a
distance of one-half (1/2) mile of any residence or other building within the
corporate limits of the municipality, used in part or as a whole for residence
purposes or human habitation, subject also to all the foregoing provisions of
this section.
   (E)   Inspection: Each hospital shall at all reasonable times be open to the
inspection of the health officer or the village president or any member of the
board of trustees or any person designated by the village president to make
such inspection. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-4-19: HOTELS, MOTELS, HOTEL CLUBS, MOTEL CLUBS AND ROOMING HOUSES:
   (A)   Definition Of Hotel, Motel, Hotel Club, Motel Club And Rooming House:
A place where a room or rooms are leased, rented, or furnished to the public
for any period of time and which charges a fee, rate, or other amount for the
provision of such room.
   (B)   License Fee: The annual license fee shall be as set forth in section
5-1-5 of this title.
   (C)   Condition Of Premises: All premises used for hotel, motel, hotel club,
motel club or rooming house purposes shall be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition, and all portions of such premises that are open for use by all
guests, patrons or by the public shall be kept lighted at all times they are
open. All such premises shall be kept heated between October 1 and May 1 to a
temperature of not less than sixty eight degrees (68o) between the hours of
seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and to a temperature of
not less than sixty degrees (60o) at all other hours.
   (D)   Sanitary Facilities: Water closets and lavatories shall be available
to all guests using any hotel, motel, hotel club, motel club or rooming house
and there shall be one bathroom equipped with water closets, shower or tub, and
lavatory facilities for each room on the premises.
   (E)   Exits: No building shall be used for a hotel, motel, hotel club, motel
club or rooming house unless there are at least two (2) exits to the outdoors
from such premises. It shall be unlawful to block or permit the blocking of any
exit from any premises used for a hotel, motel, hotel club, motel club or
rooming house.
   (F)   Compliance With Laws: Each hotel, motel, hotel club, motel club or
rooming house is required to comply with all village fire codes, health codes,
building codes, plumbing codes, electrical codes, and all other codes relating
to the health and safety of guests or patrons. Furthermore, each hotel, motel,
hotel club, motel club or rooming house shall comply with all state and federal
laws regarding the health and safety of such guests or patrons of such hotel,
motel, hotel club, motel club or rooming house.
   (G)   Other Regulations: It shall be unlawful to knowingly permit any
fugitive from justice to stay in any hotel, motel, hotel club, motel club or
rooming house. Each hotel, motel, hotel club, or motel club shall keep or cause
to be kept the register of guests as required by state law, and each operator
of a rooming house shall keep a list of all persons staying therein. Such
register or list shall be available for inspection by any member of the police
department at any time.
   (H)   Inspections: It shall be the duty of the fire chief to inspect or
cause to be inspected every hotel, motel, hotel club, motel club or rooming
house operated in the municipality as frequently as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this section. (Ord. 1683, 3-11-2009)
5-4-20: HOUSE MOVERS:
   (A)   Fee: The annual license fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). (Ord.
912, 4-12-1978)
   (B)   Bond: Every licensee under the provisions of this section shall file
with the clerk a bond in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) with
sureties to be approved by the president and board of trustees conditioned to
indemnify the municipality for any loss, damage or expense occasioned by it, by
any act or failure of the licensee, or by any failure of the licensee to comply
with the ordinances of the municipality relating to the business of house
moving or moving houses.
   (C)   Deposit; Insurance: In addition to compliance with the foregoing, no
permit shall be issued for moving a building until the mover deposits one
hundred dollars ($100.00) in cash with the clerk to cover the cost of repairing
any damage to village property in connection with such moving, and show
evidence of being covered by a public liability insurance policy in an amount
of not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00).
   (D)   Planking Street: The pavement of any street, alley or sidewalk on or
along which any house is moved shall be protected by two inch (2") planks along
the route. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-4-21: FEES, STANDARDS:
   (A)   Fees: The annual license fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for the
first location or vehicle and an additional thirty dollars ($30.00) for each
additional location or vehicle used. (Ord. 912, 4-12-1978)
   (B)   Standards: All ice sold or offered for sale in the municipality shall
be free from harmful materials, if such ice is sold or offered for sale for
domestic use. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-4-22: INSURANCE BROKERS:
The annual license fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). (Ord. 912, 4-12-1978)

(Rep. by Ord. 1861, 2-12-2014)
