5-4-24: ITINERANT MERCHANTS; PEDDLERS AND HAWKERS:
   (A)   Itinerant Merchants:
      1.   Definition: A vendor or merchant who sells commodities or goods from
private premises, but remains at one place for that purpose for temporary
periods only.
      2.   License Required: It shall be unlawful to do business in the village
as an itinerant merchant without first having secured a license therefor, as
hereinafter provided:
         (a)   The applicant must provide the village with a notarized
affidavit from the owner and business licensee of the premises he is requesting
to operate from. Said affidavit must give the applicant permission to operate
and state when and where he is to operate from and what products are to be
sold. The affidavit must acknowledge that the owner and business licensee shall
be held responsible along with the itinerant merchant for any violations of the
village or state statutes.
         (b)   The property to be used must be properly zoned for the use
requested.
         (c)   The applicant must operate and sell out of a permanent
structure, which structure must be approved by the village authorities. No
cars, trucks, vans or temporary stands are to be used.
         (d)   The applicant must fill out an application form, in duplicate,
to be furnished by the village clerk. The clerk shall retain the original of
the application, and, upon deposit by the applicant of the sum of fifteen
dollars ($15.00), plus the required license fees, shall forward the duplicate
to the police department. The police department shall conduct an investigation
to determine if the applicant is of good moral character. The police department
shall have a period of ten (10) days to conduct this investigation. If it is
determined by the police department that the applicant is of good moral
character, it shall approve the application. If the police department shall
determine that the applicant is not of good moral character, then the
application shall be refused and the license fee shall be returned to the
applicant. The fifteen dollars ($15.00) will be retained by the village. The
application shall set forth the product to be sold and the place intended to be
occupied or used for the business and the number of employees. The applicant
must provide the village with his sales tax number and must show that he issues
receipts showing his sales address in Midlothian, Illinois.
         (e)   The village shall issue an identity badge for the employees. The
identity badge shall be worn upon the person of the itinerant merchant in such
place as to be clearly visible to the public in general. Said badges are to be
returned immediately after use.
      3.   License Fee: The fee for said license shall be eighty five dollars
($85.00) for the first day and twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each
consecutive day thereafter with a maximum number of days to operate to be seven
(7) consecutive days. The times of operation shall be between the hours of nine
o'clock (9:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00) P.M. (Ord. 943A, 1-10-1979)
   (B)   Peddlers And Hawkers:
      1.   Definition: A peddler or a hawker is one who sells tangible
commodities from residence to residence or business to business, or any
combination of same. His sales are not made from one established spot. (Ord.
1419, 7-9-1997)
      2.   License Required: It shall be unlawful to do business in the village
as a peddler or hawker without having first secured a license therefor as
hereinafter provided.
         (a)   Applications for such licenses shall be made to the village
clerk and shall state thereon the description and number of vehicles, if any,
intended to be operated, the kind of merchandise to be peddled, the permanent
address of the peddler and the number of employees to be used.
         (b)   The applicant must fill out an application form, in duplicate,
to be furnished by the village clerk. The clerk shall retain the original of
the application, and, upon deposit by the applicant of the sum of fifteen
dollars ($15.00), plus the required license fee, shall forward the duplicate to
the police department. The police department shall conduct an investigation to
determine if the applicant is of good moral character. The police department
shall have a period of ten (10) days to conduct this investigation. If it is
determined by the police department that the applicant is of good moral
character, it shall approve the application. If the police department shall
determine that the applicant is not of good moral character, then the
application shall be refused and the license fee shall be returned to the
applicant. The fifteen dollars ($15.00) will be retained by the village. The
applicant must provide the village with their sales tax number and must show
that they issue receipts showing their sales address in Midlothian, Illinois.
         (c)   The village shall issue identity badges for the employees. The
identity badge shall be worn upon the person of the peddler or hawker in such
place as to be clearly visible to the public in general. Said badges are to be
returned immediately after use.
      3.   License Fee: The fee for said license shall be eighty five dollars
($85.00) for the first day and twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each
consecutive day thereafter with a maximum number of days to operate to be seven
(7) consecutive days. The times of operation shall be between the hours of nine
o'clock (9:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00) P.M.
   (C)   Fraud: Any licensed peddler, hawker or itinerant merchant who shall be
guilty of any fraud, cheating or misrepresentation, whether through himself, or
through an employee, while acting as a peddler, hawker or itinerant merchant in
the village, or who shall barter, sell or peddle any goods, merchandise or
wares other than those specified in his application for a license, shall be
determined guilty of a violation of this section. The owner and business
licensee where the itinerant merchant operates shall also be held accountable
for any violations. (Ord. 943A, 1-10-1979)
   (D)   Penalty: Any person violating any provision of this section shall be
fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than the penalty as
provided in section 1-4-1 of this code or the maximum allowed by state statutes
for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day
during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 943A, 1-10-1979; amd.
Ord. 1362, 9-13-1995)
5-4-25: NURSING HOMES:
   (A)   Definition: For the purpose of this section, a "nursing home" is
hereby defined to mean any institution, place or family used for the reception
or care, for a longer period than twenty four (24) hours, of three (3) or more
children or infants apart from their parents. A home is further defined to mean
any institution used for the reception or care of persons who are dependent or
not capable of properly caring for themselves, and shall be understood to
include homes for aged or infirm, orphan asylums, refuges and shelters and also
boarding homes caring for three (3) or more women with their children when such
children are less than fourteen (14) years of age. Such establishments shall be
classed as a commercial or business use.
   (B)   Application: The applications shall conform to the general provisions
of this code relating to applications for licenses and shall state the location
or proposed location of the home, the purpose for which it is to be opened,
conducted or maintained, the accommodations for the inmates thereof, the nature
and kind of care, instruction or benefits given or proposed to be given
therein, the names and addresses of the officials and/or board of officials
conducting, managing or maintaining said home, the name and address of the
chief physician, surgeon or attending physician or surgeon, or the names and
addresses of the board of physicians or surgeons attending therein if there is
such a board.
   (C)   Inspection: It shall be the duty of the health officer, upon
presentation of such application, to make or cause to be made strict inquiry
into the facts set out in such application and if upon inquiry and inspection
he shall find that such home complies with all ordinances and statutes relating
thereto, he shall recommend to the president and board of trustees that a
license be issued. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
   (D)   License Fee: The annual license fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00)
plus four dollars ($4.00) per bed. (Ord. 912, 4-12-1978)
   (E)   Accommodations For Inmates; Regulations As To Sanitation: In every
such home each room occupied or to be occupied by inmates shall be of such
dimensions as shall give each inmate not less than four hundred (400) cubic
feet of air space. Every such room shall have at least one window connecting
with the external air for each four (4) beds. Said windows shall be of such
dimensions as shall secure to each inmate at least one thousand five hundred
(1,500) cubic feet of fresh air per hour by natural ventilation, or in case
said window shall not secure one thousand five hundred (1,500) cubic feet of
fresh air per hour by natural ventilation, then each room shall, in addition
thereto, be fitted with such appliances for ventilation as shall secure to each
inmate in said room at least one thousand five hundred (1,500) cubic feet of
fresh air per hour. Each bed shall have at least forty (40) square feet of
floor space, and in every room or dormitory containing more than one bed, the
beds shall be so arranged as to leave a passageway of not less than two feet
(2') horizontally on all sides of each bed.
Each ward or wing in said home shall have running water furnished in one or
more places, either in said ward or convenient thereto so that the same be
adequate and convenient to the occupants thereof. The plumbing, water closets,
bathrooms and other sanitary appliances and equipment shall be constructed in
accordance with the village ordinance relating thereto. The floor of the cellar
or basement in the building used as a home shall be properly cemented so as to
be watertight.
The halls of each floor shall be open to the external air with suitable
windows, and shall have no room or other obstruction at either end thereof,
unless sufficient light and ventilation is otherwise provided for such halls,
and the building as a whole shall be provided with adequate and proper fire
escapes, stairways or inclines for exit.
All homes, including the culinary department, dining rooms, laundry,
laboratory, morgue and postmortem rooms connected with the same shall be
equipped from May 15 to November 15 with doors, screens and other appliances
necessary for the exclusion of flies. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-4-26: OUTDOOR ADVERTISING:
   (A)   Definition: The term "outdoor advertiser" as used in this section
shall mean and is hereby defined to mean any person, firm or corporation
engaged in the business of placing, posting or painting any sign,
advertisement, notice of display in one or more places for the purpose of
outdoor advertising so that the resultant display is visible from any street,
alley, sidewalk or other public place.
   (B)   Applications: Applications shall be accompanied by a list of all
places, including billboards or natural structures, on which it is intended to
place signs or advertisements. This list shall be added to from time to time by
the licensee as a right to post or place advertisements or signs on additional
places as required. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
   (C)   License Fee: The annual license fee shall be seventy dollars ($70.00)
for each billboard or poster panel maintained in the municipality. (Ord. 912,
4-12-1978)
   (D)   Consent Of Owner: It shall be unlawful to post any advertisements on
any premises in the municipality without the consent of the owner of such
premises. Such consents must be in writing, and must be filed with the clerk.
   (E)   Refuse: It shall be unlawful for any person, engaged in outdoor
advertising to permit any refuse resulting from this work to accumulate
anywhere in the municipality, excepting by placing it in properly established
refuse receptacles. It shall be unlawful to permit any loose or flapping or
combustible materials to hang from or to be attached to any billboard or
signboard or other place used for display or advertising purposes. All refuse
resulting from the operation of this business must be carefully gathered up and
properly disposed of.
   (F)   Weeds And Materials At Base Of Billboards: It shall be the duty of
every outdoor advertiser to keep all grass and weeds, and other growths, except
trees and ornamental shrubbery, cut down so that the same shall not grow to a
height greater than ten inches (10") within six feet (6') of any billboard or
signboard used by him; provided that this obligation shall extend only to
property controlled by the advertiser.
   (G)   Unlawful Advertising: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or
corporation to post or display any advertisement of an obscene or immoral
character, or any advertisement of any unlawful gathering, or advertisement of
unlawful sales.
   (H)   Disfiguring Signs: It shall be unlawful to mutilate or disfigure in
any way any lawful sign or advertisements in the municipality.
   (I)   Name Of Advertiser: It shall be unlawful for any outdoor advertiser to
carry on his business unless the name of such advertiser is attached, displayed
or printed on all billboards or signboards used by him, or on any notice,
placard, or advertisement posted by him, in such lettering as to be visible
from a distance of at least five feet (5') from the notice of advertisement.
   (J)   Exemptions: The provisions of this section shall not be construed to
apply to the posting of signs or notices by order of any court or by any public
officer in the performance of his duties. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-4-27: PAWNBROKERS AND JUNK DEALERS:
   (A)   Definitions: As used in this section, the following words and phrases
shall have the following meanings:
   INDIVIDUALLY IDENTIFIABLE ARTICLES: Articles that are individually
identifiable by a serial number or other applied numbers, letters,
characteristics or markings or other unique features that serve to distinguish
it from any other similar article and can be used to establish ownership of the
article.
   JUNK DEALER: Every owner, operator or employee engaged in the business of
the purchase, sale, trade or barter of secondhand articles, including, but not
limited to, recyclable materials, scrap metal, electronics, video game systems,
video games, video game accessories, jewelry, valuable and/or precious metals
and stones, or household goods, shall be deemed to be a junk dealer, whether
such dealer operates from a fixed storefront business or is conducting business
on a temporary, short term basis from a nonfixed location. Persons selling
personal property belonging to them or family members on a temporary basis from
their own residential property in the form of a properly permitted garage sale
or yard sale shall not be considered a precious metals dealer and are exempt
from reporting requirements required by this section. This definition shall
include "cash for gold" stores or consignment shops.
   JUNK/SCRAP COLLECTION VEHICLE: A motor vehicle used for the commercial pick
up or transportation of junk/scrap metal. A personal motor vehicle used to
transport junk/scrap belonging to the owner of that vehicle, which owner is not
in the business of junk/scrap collection, or family members, friends or
neighbors of the vehicle owner, to a junk/scrap yard is not considered to be a
junk/scrap collection vehicle, and does not need to be licensed as such.
   LEADSONLINE: A computerized records management system designed to record
transactions between pawnshops and precious metals dealers and their customers
and transmit said transactions electronically to law enforcement agencies.
   LICENSEE: The owner, operator and all volunteers or employees of a business
licensed under this section.
   PAWNBROKER: Every owner, operator, volunteer and/or employee engaged in the
business of receiving property in pledge or as security for money or other
things advanced to the pawner or pledger shall be deemed to be a pawnbroker.
Moreover, every owner, operator, volunteer and/or employee in a "pawnshop" as
defined by this code shall further be defined as a pawnbroker.
   PRECIOUS METALS: Articles consisting primarily of the elements of gold
(chemical symbol Au), silver (chemical symbol Ag), platinum (chemical symbol
Pt) or palladium (chemical symbol Pd) but not including articles merely plated
with these metals or articles similar in color to these metals but not actually
consisting of them.
   (B)   Exemptions: This section shall not apply to businesses or charitable
organizations that accept donated goods for resale and to precious metal
dealers that are purchasing precious metals solely at home sales nor shall it
apply to the sale or purchase of aluminum cans.
   (C)   Electronic Reporting Of Transactions: Every pawnbroker or junk dealer
shall operate and maintain a computer system with internet access and
photographic or video capability sufficient for the electronic reporting
requirement described in this section. Any failure or malfunction of such
equipment on the part of the licensee shall not exempt the licensee from the
recording/reporting requirements. The licensee shall immediately notify the
designated individual in the police department of any such failure or
malfunction, and shall have such resolved as soon as practicable. Failure by
the licensee to resolve any failure or malfunction of equipment in a reasonable
amount of time will lead to the license suspension or revocation proceedings as
defined in this section.
   (D)   Record Of Transactions: Every pawnbroker or junk dealer doing business
in the village shall report/upload to LeadsOnline, the below listed information
for each and every transaction conducted on a daily basis, by the end of each
business day. All information shall be recorded in the English language.
A transaction shall consist of all articles brought into a pawnbroker or junk
dealer for sale, barter, trade, pledge or pawn by a customer and includes the
sale of articles by a pawnbroker or junk dealer to another customer. Articles
brought into a pawnbroker or junk dealer for sale, barter, trade, pledge or
pawn at different times on the same date by the same customer shall be
considered as separate transactions. Each transaction is to be recorded
individually.
During each transaction, the pawnbroker or junk dealer shall require each
customer to show a valid form of identification which the pawnbroker or junk
dealer shall verify belongs to the customer. The identification must be a
passport, driver's license or identification card issued by a government entity
and must include a photograph of the customer. If, however, a customer does not
have a passport, driver's license or identification card issued by a
governmental entity with a photograph, then a pawnbroker or precious metals
dealer must require that two (2) forms of identification be shown and at least
one of these forms of identification must include the customer's home address.
In addition, if the customer does not have an identification form issued by a
governmental entity containing a photograph of the customer, the pawnbroker or
precious metals dealer shall photograph the customer in color and record the
customer's name, address, date of birth and social security number. The
licensee shall further keep a digital photograph or scanned image of the
identification which is provided by the customer.
Records of each transaction shall contain the name, address and date of birth
of each customer, a description of each item taken in or sold by the pawnbroker
or junk dealer, the date and time of the purchase and/or sale, as well as any
individual identifiable numbers such as model, brand, serial number, or applied
numbers or letters. A digital photograph or video of each item shall be taken
by the licensee of each item purchased, taken in barter, trade or pawned.
Licensees shall maintain records of all transactions for three (3) years
following the transaction.
   (E)   Issuance Of Signed Receipt: Every pawnbroker shall, at the time of
making any advancement or loan, deliver to the customer a receipt signed by him
containing an accurate account and description, in the English language, of all
the goods, articles or other things pawned or pledged, the amount of money,
value or thing thereon, the time of pledging the same, the rate of interest to
be paid on such loan and the name and residence address of the customer making
the pawn or pledge.
Every pawnbroker and/or junk dealer shall at the time of purchasing precious
metals from any customer, issue said customer a receipt containing the
description and weight of the items purchased and the amount of money paid for
said items.
   (F)   Employment Of Persons Under Sixteen: Pawnbrokers or junk dealers shall
not permit any person under the age of sixteen (16) years to make purchases or
take pledges in pawn for him.
   (G)   Junk Dealer Not To Act As Pawnbroker: Unless they have a pawnbroker
license, junk dealers shall neither receive any article nor thing by way of
pledge or pawn nor loan or advance any sum of money on the security of any
article or thing.
   (H)   Waiting Periods: No articles received on deposit or pledge by any
pawnbroker shall be permitted to be redeemed or removed from the place of
business for a time period of five (5) calendar days after the issuance of the
signed receipt. No articles pawned or pledged shall be sold or disposed of by
any pawnbroker within six (6) months from the time the customer defaulted on
the payment of interest on the money so advanced by the pawnbroker, unless
pursuant to the written consent of the customer.
No pawnbroker or junk dealer shall expose for sale, sell, trade, barter, melt,
crush/compact, destroy, alter or otherwise dispose of, any article that is
individually identifiable within fourteen (14) days of the time of purchasing
or receiving the same or until the same has been in or upon the premises where
the same are offered, exposed, traded, bartered or sold, for at least seven (7)
days, unless the article consists primarily of precious metal(s). Due to
fluctuations in the prices of precious metals and security concerns associated
with the accumulation of large amounts of precious metals, there shall be no
waiting period for such articles, even if they are individually identifiable.
There shall be no waiting period for coins, paper money or other
nonindividually identifiable articles.
   (I)   Prohibited Transactions: No pawnbroker or junk dealer, in the course
of conducting his business, shall receive any articles for pawn, pledge,
advancement of money, loan, resale, or personal use from customers who meet any
of the following criteria:
      1.   Are under eighteen (18) years of age;
      2.   Appear to be intoxicated or under the influence of drugs or alcohol;
      3.   Are known to the pawnbroker or junk dealer to have been convicted of
theft, residential burglary, burglary, home invasion, vehicular intrusion,
armed robbery, robbery or electronic fencing under the laws of the state of
Illinois or the equivalent of such laws of any other state. A peace officer may
provide such criminal conviction information to a pawnbroker or precious metals
dealer, and a pawnbroker or precious metals dealer shall also access the
LeadsOnline "no buy" list prior to making a transaction to ensure that the
prospective pawner/seller has not been convicted of any such crime;
      4.   Brings such articles to the premises in a shopping cart;
      5.   Presents a serial numbered article from which the serial number has
been removed or obliterated.
In the event that any of the above enumerated customers shall attempt to
conduct a prohibited transaction, a representative of that business shall
notify the police department of the incident while the customer is still
present in the business if safe to do so, or otherwise as soon as the customer
has left the business.
   (J)   Report Of False/Fictitious/Forged/Altered ID Card: In the event that a
person seeking to sell or pawn items to a licensed pawnbroker or junk dealer,
presents the licensee with what appears to be a false form of identification,
the licensee shall contact the police department as soon as it is safe to do so
and report the incident.
   (K)   Report Of Lost Or Stolen Articles To Police: Every pawnbroker or junk
dealer who shall receive or be in possession of any goods, articles or things
under circumstances which he or she believes have been lost or stolen, or which
have been alleged or supposed to have been lost or stolen shall immediately
notify the police department of such receipt and, forthwith on demand, exhibit
the same to any member of the police department.
   (L)   Return Of Stolen Property: When any person is found to be the owner of
stolen property which has been pawned or purchased by a pawnshop or junk
dealer, such property shall be returned to the owner thereof without the
payment of the money advanced by the pawnbroker or the junk dealer, which was
paid by the pawnshop or the precious metals dealer thereon or any costs or
charges of any kind which the pawnbroker or junk dealer may have placed upon
the same.
   (M)   Inspection Of Premises By Police: The chief of police or any officer
designated by him shall have general supervision over all pawnbrokers and junk
dealers, and shall also have power to inspect their respective places of
business and all articles or things kept therein, whenever he shall deem it
necessary to do so.
   (N)   Hours Of Operation: No business licensed under this section shall
purchase or accept goods, articles or things whatsoever, from any person
outside of posted business hours.
   (O)   Solicitation Of Articles: No person licensed under this section shall
be permitted to solicit business of any nature upon any street or public
highway in the village.
   (P)   License Requirement: In addition to any license which may be required
by the state of Illinois:
      1.   No person shall engage in, carry on or conduct the business of a
pawnbroker or junk dealer unless the business is licensed as such by the
village.
      2.   A pawnbroker license and junk dealer license are separate from each
other, and the license shall state for which it is.
      3.   A pawnbroker license shall entitle the licensee to engage in the
purchase, sale, trade or barter of secondhand articles in addition to the
business of receiving property in pledge or as security for money or other
things but shall not entitle the licensee to the use of a junk/scrap collection
vehicle.
      4.   A junk dealer license will entitle the licensee to engage in the
purchase, sale, trade or barter of secondhand articles and the use of one junk/
scrap collection vehicle, but shall not entitle the licensee to engage in the
business of a pawnbroker.
      5.   Neither a pawnbroker nor a junk dealer license is transferable.
      6.   A license shall only be issued to the actual owner, operator or
manager of the business for which the license is sought.
      7.   Should a pawnbroker or junk dealer own multiple businesses or have
multiple locations within the village where activities which are regulated by
this chapter take place, he must secure a separate license for each business
and/or location.
   (Q)   Fees: The annual fee for a pawnbroker's license and/or a junk dealer's
license shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00).
   (R)   Application: Any person desiring a license as a pawnbroker or junk
dealer shall make application in writing to the clerk, setting out in the
application the full name and residence of the applicant, if an individual, and
if a corporation, the name and residence of each of its officers. Such
application shall also set out the location at which it is intended or desired
to conduct such business, and such other information as the clerk or his
designee shall from time to time deem appropriate. The chief of police or his
designee shall investigate each applicant for these licenses. This person shall
report the findings to the clerk who shall determine whether the person has a
history of past criminal conduct or criminal associations that would make it
not in the best interests of the village of Midlothian to issue a license to
the applicant to engage in such business.
   (S)   Penalties: In addition to revocation and/or suspension of the business
license, any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any provision of
this section shall be subject to, at a minimum, a fine of not less than five
hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 1861, 2-12-2014)
5-4-28: FUEL DEALERS AND BULK STORAGE OF PETROLEUM PRODUCTS:
   (A)   Fees: The annual license fee for a fuel dealer or the bulk storage of
petroleum products shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first location and
vehicle and an additional thirty dollars ($30.00) for each additional location
or vehicle. (Ord. 912, 4-12-1978)
   (B)   Application: An application for said license shall be made in
conformity with the general requirements of this chapter relating to
applications for licenses. In addition such application shall state whether the
applicant uses or proposes to use storage facilities in connection with the
business of fuel dealer and if so, the location, place or premises where such
storage facilities are located or to be located, and capacity, and the number
of vehicles, if any, to be used in connection with said business.
The building inspector and inspector of the bureau of fire prevention shall
investigate such application and the matters and things therein stated.
   (C)   Emblems For Vehicles: Said licensee shall obtain from the village
clerk, at the time of the issuance and delivery of a license hereunder, as many
serial number license emblems or stickers as is required, allotting one such
emblem or sticker to each vehicle used by said licensee in connection with said
business, which emblems or stickers shall have plainly imprinted or stamped
thereon the words "Licensed Fuel Dealer's Vehicle, Village of Midlothian".
Similar additional emblems or stickers shall be issued and delivered to said
licensee upon the payment of the required license fee therefor for each vehicle
that may be added to said licensee's equipment and used in connection with said
business at any time during the current year for which said license was issued.
The licensee shall place or cause to be placed such emblem or sticker plainly
exposed to public view upon the inside of the windshield of such vehicle.
   (D)   Special Regulations: All places of business of fuel dealers or the
bulk storage of petroleum products shall be kept in a clean condition free from
accumulations of rags, wastepaper and other combustible waste materials.
Smoking shall be prohibited thereon. All such premises and all vehicles used in
connection with the business shall be inspected by an inspector of the bureau
of fire prevention at least once every year.
It shall be unlawful for any licensee to refuel any fuel storage container or
tank used in connection with an oil burning heater, boiler or furnace unless
such storage container or tank is equipped with an automatic or return vent
pipe or unless the fill pipe of such storage container or tank is equipped with
a screw or automatic cap. It shall be the duty of every licensee after filling
or refilling any fuel storage container or tank to replace the screw cap on
such fill tank, or if equipped with an automatic cap, to see to it that said
fill cap is properly closed. (Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-4-29: REAL ESTATE BROKERS:
   (A)   Definition: For the purpose of this chapter, a "real estate broker" is
defined as any person, association, copartnership or corporation, who, as an
agent, for a consideration, sells or offers for sale, buys or offers to buy, or
negotiates the purchase or sale or exchange of real estate, or who leases, or
offers to lease, or rents or offers for rent, any real estate or negotiates
leases, thereof, or of the improvement therein; for another or others; or who
employs any person as a real estate salesman to perform any of the above acts.
   (B)   Signs: It shall be unlawful for any "real estate broker" as defined in
subsection (A) of this section, to erect or maintain any sign on any real
estate without first having obtained a village real estate broker's license.
(Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
   (C)   Fee: The fee for a real estate broker's license shall be the sum of
fifty dollars ($50.00) per annum. No license shall be issued for a sum less
than the full amount of the annual license fee. (Ord. 912, 4-12-1978)
   (D)   Revocation: The president shall have the power to revoke a license
issued under this chapter, whenever a licensee, directly or indirectly, shall
in the president's judgment be guilty of:
      1.   Making any substantial misrepresentation, or engaging in untruthful
advertising, or
      2.   Making any false promises or other representations of a character
likely to influence, persuade, or induce action contrary to the best interest
of the village and preservation of property values in the village, or
      3.   Pursuing a continued and flagrant course of misrepresentation or the
making of false promises through agents or salesmen or advertising or
otherwise, or
      4.   Any misleading or untruthful advertising, or using any trade name or
insignia of membership in any real estate organization of which the licensee is
not a member, or
      5.   Acting for more than one part in a transaction without the knowledge
of all parties for whom he acts, or
      6.   Failure to furnish copies upon request of all documents relating to
a real estate transaction to all parties executing the same, or
      7.   Paying a commission or valuable consideration to any person for acts
or services performed in violation of this chapter, or
      8.   Having demonstrated unworthiness or incompetency to act as a real
estate broker in such manner as to endanger the interest of the public, or
      9.   Employing any person as a salesman on a purely temporary or single
deal basis as a means of evading the law regarding payment of commissions or
any of the provisions of this chapter, or
      10.   Of displaying a "for rent" or "for sale" sign on any property
without the written consent of an owner or his duly authorized agent, or
advertising that any property is for sale or for rent in a newspaper or other
publication without the consent of the owner or his authorized agent, or
      11.   Failing, within a reasonable time, to provide information requested
by the village president as a result of a protest or informal complaint to the
village, which would indicate a violation of this section, or
      12.   Disregarding or violating any provision of this section, or
      13.   Any other conduct, whether of the same or different character from
that hereinbefore specified which constitutes dishonest dealing. (Ord. 663B,
12-14-1966)
5-4-30: SCAVENGERS:
   (A)   License Fees: The annual license fee shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00), plus fifty dollars ($50.00) for each truck over one truck used in
the business. (Ord. 996, 3-11-1981)
   (B)   Vehicles: Any vehicle used by such scavenger in his business shall be
watertight, and equipped with airtight covers for such portions as are used for
the transportation of refuse. It shall be unlawful for any such vehicle to be
driven over or through any street in the municipality during or on a Sunday.
   (C)   Disposal: It shall be unlawful for any scavenger to dispose of or
store any refuse in any place in the municipality limits or within one mile
thereof, excepting with the permission of the president and board of trustees.
(Ord. 663B, 12-14-1966)
5-4-31: SERVICE STATIONS:
   (A)   Fees: The annual license fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) plus ten
dollars ($10.00) per nozzle. (Ord. 1107, 11-13-1985)
   (B)   Definition: A "service station" is any place of business where
gasoline or any highly volatile fuels for motor vehicles or internal combustion
engines are sold or offered for sale.
   (C)   Fire Extinguishers: Each service station shall be equipped with at
least one chemical fire extinguisher suitable for oil or gasoline fires, kept
in serviceable condition.
   (D)   Nonbusiness Filling Stations: Any person maintaining or operating any
storage tank for gasoline for the use of automobiles of the owner, lessee,
employees or agents of such person, shall comply with all of the provisions of
this section other than the requirement for the payment of a fee.
   (E)   Bulk Sales Prohibited: No motor fuels shall be dispensed at any
service station except into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles; provided,
however, that individual sales up to five (5) gallons may be made in metal
receptacles when painted red and labeled in full conformity with the Illinois
red can gasoline law.
   (F)   Safety Regulations:
      1.   No gasoline, naphtha or other flammable liquids shall be kept inside
a service station except in original sealed containers.
      2.   No person other than the service station owner or an authorized
employee shall use or operate any motor fuel dispensing equipment at any
service station.
      3.   No motor vehicle shall be serviced until the ignition has been
turned off.
      4.   No open lights or flames shall be permitted except within a stove in
the station building.
      5.   Premises must be kept clean and neat, free from rubbish or trash.
(Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-4-32: SOLICITORS:
   (A)   Definition And License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person
to engage in any commercial business as a solicitor without securing a license
as herein provided. Solicitor is defined as a person who enters upon
residential or business premises without the previous consent of the occupant
for the purpose of selling or taking orders to sell any goods, services or to
acquire information for any commercial business purpose.
   (B)   License Fee: There is hereby imposed a license fee of ten dollars
($10.00) per day per person soliciting in the Village.
   (C)   Application For License: All applicants for licenses required by this
section shall file a written application with the Village Clerk. The
application shall be signed by the applicant if an individual, by a partner if
a partnership or by a duly authorized signatory if a corporation. Applications
shall be made on forms available in the Office of the Village Clerk.
      1.   Investigation: Upon receipt of an application for a license required
by this section, the Village Clerk shall request the Chief of Police to
investigate the applicant. The Chief of Police is limited to ten (10) days to
conduct this investigation.
      2.   Reasons For Disapproval Of Applications: The Village Clerk shall
approve the application unless the investigation discloses tangible evidence
that the conduct of the applicant's business would pose a substantial threat to
the public health, safety, morals or general welfare. In particular, tangible
evidence of any of the following will constitute a valid reason for disapproval
of an application:
         (a)   The applicant has been convicted of a crime involving moral
turpitude;
         (b)   The applicant has made willful misstatements in the application;
         (c)   The applicant has committed prior violations of ordinances
pertaining to commercial business conduct and/or this section;
         (d)   The applicant has committed prior fraudulent acts; and/or
         (e)   The applicant has a record of continual breaches of solicited
contracts.
   (D)   Identification Badge: Upon issuance of a license under this section an
identification badge with the name of the authorized solicitor and the
expiration date of the license in large bold font shall be issued. The badge
shall be worn in such place as to be clearly visible to the public in general
and contain the words "Licensed Solicitor" and the number of the license.
   (E)   Six Month Limitation: In no case shall any license for soliciting be
valid for more than a six (6) month period.
   (F)   Exceptions To Section: The provisions of this section shall not apply
to officers or employees of the Village, County, State or Federal government or
any subdivision thereof when on official business or to political, religious or
other constitutionally protected speech.
   (G)   Revocation: Any permit may be revoked by the Village President or the
Chief of Police because of any violation by the solicitor of this section or of
any other provision of this Code, or any State or Federal law, or whenever the
applicant shall cease to possess the qualifications and character required in
this section for the original registration.
   (H)   Nonprofit Organizations; Blanket Permits And Waivers: Nonprofit
organizations may secure, by formal letter addressed to the Village Clerk, a
blanket permit approved by the Village Board upon a finding the non-profit
benefits the health, education, safety or quality of life of residents of the
Village. Having determined the eligibility of the non-profit under this
paragraph the Village Board may waive the requirements of this section or parts
thereof for the non-profit organization. If no waiver is granted, the nonprofit
organization must comply fully with this section. A nonprofit organization
shall be registered with the State Attorney General before any permit is
granted to the organization under this section.
   (I)   Prohibited Solicitation:
      1.   Hours Of Operation: No person, while conducting the activities of a
solicitor, whether licensed or unlicensed, shall enter upon any premises, knock
on doors or otherwise disturb persons in their premises between the hours of
seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M., except when having made
a prior appointment with the person being solicited.
      2.   Notice Regulating Soliciting: No person shall solicit at residences
or businesses within the Village if a "NO SOLICITORS" sign has been posted on
the residence or business in accordance with this section. Every person seeking
to secure the protection provided by this section shall post a notice, no
smaller than approximately three inches (3") by four inches (4") in size, on or
near the main entrance door to the residence or business, stating "NO
SOLICITORS". For purposes of uniformity, the notices shall be provided by the
Village Clerk's Office, at no cost, to persons requesting the notices. The
notice, so exhibited, shall constitute sufficient notice to any solicitor of
the determination by the occupant of the residence or business to prohibit
soliciting at that residence or business.
      3.   Duty To Abide: Every solicitor, entering upon residential or
business premises in the Village shall first examine the entrance area thereof
to determine if a notice as set forth in subsection (I)2 of this section is
posted. If so, he or she, whether licensed or not, shall immediately and
peacefully depart from the premises. Any solicitor who has gained entrance to
any residence or business, whether invited or not, shall immediately and
peacefully depart from the premises when requested to do so by the occupant
thereof. (Ord. 1962, 8-23-2017)
5-4-33: TAXICABS:
   (A)   Application And Fee: Applications shall specify the number of vehicles
owned and operated by the applicant. The annual fee is fifty dollars ($50.00)
per vehicle. (Ord. 912, 4-12-1978)
   (B)   Cab Stands: No vehicle of any kind shall stand upon or be parked upon
or make use of any public taxi or hack stand in the Municipality unless the
owner thereof has obtained a license as provided in the preceding subsection.
   (C)   Bond Required: No such license shall be issued to any person, firm or
corporation unless the applicant has secured the bond provided by statute.
   (D)   Age Of Applicant: No such vehicle license shall be issued to any
person under twenty one (21) years of age.
   (E)   Register: It shall be the duty of the Village Clerk to keep a register
of the names of persons to whom such license is granted or transferred, the
date when issued or transferred, the number of the license and the description
of the vehicle or vehicles licensed.
   (F)   Revocation Of License: The Village Board may revoke any license issued
hereunder for violation of or failure to comply with any of the provisions of
this section or for a violation of any State of Illinois or Village Traffic
Ordinance. In such an event the fee paid for the unexpired term of such license
shall not be refunded.
If any taxicab licensed hereunder shall become unsafe for the transportation of
passengers or unsightly in appearance, the license for said taxicab may be
suspended by the Chief of Police until said vehicle is put in fit condition for
public use.
It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to inspect every vehicle licensed
hereunder a sufficient number of times each year to ensure compliance with the
provisions of this section.
   (G)   Name Of Vehicle: Every vehicle licensed as aforesaid shall bear on the
outside thereof, in a conspicuous place, the name of the owner thereof, in
letters not less than two inches (2") high, which letters shall be of a color
in contrast to the color of the vehicle, and shall be properly proportioned and
legible.
   (H)   Rates Of Fare: The price or rates of fare to be asked or demanded by
the operator or owner of any such vehicle shall not exceed the maximum that may
be set by ordinance.
The distance to which the above rates apply shall be determined by the nearest
traveled route from the point where the passenger enters the vehicle to the
point where the passenger shall alight therefrom.
There shall be affixed on the inside of each vehicle in a conspicuous place and
in such manner that the same may be easily read by any person riding in such
vehicle, a card upon which shall be printed in plain, legible type, the rates
of fare provided for in this section.
Any passenger shall be allowed to have conveyed upon any of the vehicles
aforesaid, without charge, his ordinary traveling baggage; provided that
ordinary hand baggage shall not be construed to mean trunks or sample cases.
Upon request of any passenger the driver of such vehicle shall give the person
requesting the same a receipt for the amount of the fare demanded and paid.
   (I)   Penalty For Overcharge: The owner, driver or operator of any vehicle
licensed as aforesaid, who may have demanded and received any fare in excess of
what is provided for in this section shall return the excess received, and in
addition, be liable to a penalty of five dollars ($5.00) and may have his
license revoked.
   (J)   Advance Payment: Every such owner, operator or driver shall have the
right to demand in advance his fare of the person or persons so employing him
or entering his vehicle, and may refuse to convey any person who shall not
comply with said command.
   (K)   Refusal To Carry Passengers: No owner, operator or driver of any
vehicle licensed as aforesaid, shall refuse to convey in said municipality, any
person with or without hand baggage as aforesaid, when applied to for that
purpose; or having undertaken to convey such person, shall omit or neglect to
do so, under penalty of ten dollars ($10.00) for each offense.
   (L)   Parking On Streets: No person in charge of any public taxi or vehicle
carrying passengers for hire shall permit the same, except when receiving or
discharging passengers or when instructed by their passengers to do so, to
stand on any street, avenue or alley in said municipality for any period longer
than five (5) minutes, except as otherwise provided by ordinance.
   (M)   Soliciting Trade: It shall be unlawful for the owner, operator or
driver of any such vehicle licensed hereunder to solicit by word, gesture or
otherwise, the patronage of any person at any railroad station, or upon any
public street in the Municipality, and it shall be unlawful to stand or be upon
the platform of any railroad until the expiration of three (3) minutes after
the departure of such train, except to assist persons who have indicated a
desire to patronize the vehicle in his charge. Whoever shall be guilty of any
of the offenses mentioned in this section shall be fined not less than five
dollars ($5.00) nor more than twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-4-34: TOBACCO PRODUCTS, RETAIL SALE:
   (A)   Definition: Tobacco product(s) shall mean tobacco or any electronic
device used to consume tobacco or product that is made from or derived from
tobacco, or that contains nicotine, that is intended for human consumption
whether smoked, heated, chewed, absorbed, dissolved, inhaled or ingested by any
other means.
   (B)   Fee: The annual license fee for tobacco products shall be one hundred
dollars ($100.00). The license so obtained shall not entitle the licensee to
conduct any other business without an additional license.
   (C)   Age Restriction: It shall be unlawful to sell tobacco products to any
person under twenty one (21) years of age. (Ord. 2030, 6-26-2019)
5-4-35: TOWING VEHICLES:
   (A)   Fee: Applications shall specify the number of vehicles owned and
operated by the applicant. The annual fee is fifty dollars ($50.00) for the
first vehicle and thirty dollars ($30.00) for each additional vehicle. (Ord.
912, 4-12-1978)
   (B)   Location: No vehicle of any kind shall stand upon or be parked upon
any service station, garage, private or public property unless the owner has
obtained a license as provided in the preceding section.
   (C)   Bond Required: No such license shall be issued to any person, firm or
corporation unless the applicant has secured the bond provided by statute.
   (D)   Age Of Applicant: No such vehicle license shall be issued to any
person under twenty one (21) years of age.
   (E)   Village Clerk To Keep Record: It shall be the duty of the Village
Clerk to keep a register of the names of persons to whom such license is
granted or transferred, the date of issue or transfer, the number of the
license and the description of the vehicle or vehicles licensed.
   (F)   Revocation Of License: The Village Board may revoke any license issued
hereunder for violation of or failure to comply with any of the provisions of
this section or for a violation of any State of Illinois or Village Traffic
Ordinance. In such event the fee paid for the unexpired term of such license
shall not be refunded:
If any tow vehicle licensed hereunder becomes unsafe for towing or unsightly in
appearance, the license for said vehicle may be suspended by the Chief of
Police until said vehicle is put in safe condition for towing service.
It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to inspect every vehicle licensed
hereunder twice each year to ensure compliance with the provisions of this
section.
It shall be unlawful for any person to tow or allow to be towed any motor
vehicle into the corporate limits of the Village for the purpose of storage.
(Ord. 633B, 12-14-1966)
5-4-36: VENDING MACHINES:
   (A)   Application: Applications shall be made in writing to the Village
Clerk and shall state the full name of the applicant and the number of said
machines for which said applicant desires a license. Such application shall be
accompanied by evidence that the applicant, if an individual, or the person or
persons in charge of the business, if a firm or corporation, is or are
responsible persons of good character and reputation. The owner of the business
license is responsible for full compliance with this section.
   (B)   Fees: The annual fees for such licenses shall be:
 
Regular vending machines (food or articles) $ 50.00
Cigarette vending machines                  100.00
Nonprofit vending machines                  25.00
All other vending machines                  50.00
 
   (C)   License: The Village Clerk shall issue to the applicant a license for
the operation of such machines which shall be posted in a conspicuous place
upon each machine so licensed. Each license issued shall be for a period of one
calendar year.
   (D)   Inspection And Analysis: It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police
and the Village Health Officer, and they are hereby authorized and empowered to
inspect and examine all food or drink being offered for sale by means of said
automatic vending machines for the purpose of ascertaining whether the laws of
the State and of the Village in relation to sales from said vending machines
are complied with, and that said food and drink so offered for sale has been
kept fresh, clean and wholesome; and it shall be the duty of all persons, firms
or corporations operating said vending machines upon the demand of the Chief of
Police or of the Health Officer to furnish to him/her for his/her inspection
samples of all said food and drink, which samples may be analyzed by or under
the direction of said Chief of Police or the Health Officer; and a record of
such analysis shall be made and kept in his/her office for the inspection of
the public. (Ord. 1336, 11-9-1994)
   (E)   Cigarette Vending Machines: No person, firm, corporation or
association holding a business license under this section shall permit persons
under twenty one (21) years of age to operate any cigarette vending machine.
All machines shall have a sticker attached to the front which says:
      THE SALE OR THE POSSESSION OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS TO PERSONS UNDER TWENTY
ONE YEARS OF AGE IS PROHIBITED BY LAW.
      (Ord. 1390, 5-22-1996, eff. 7-1-1996; amd. Ord. 2030, 6-26-2019)
      The text of such signs shall be in red letters on a white background,
said letters to be at least one inch (1") high. (Ord. 1390, 5-22-1996, eff. 7-
1-1996)
   (F)   Penalty: Any person who shall violate the provisions of this section
shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than the
penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code or the maximum allowed by
State Statutes for each offense, and each day that the violation continues
shall be regarded as constituting a distinct and separate offense. (Ord. 1336,
11-9-1994; amd. Ord. 1362, 9-13-1995)
5-4-37: GARAGE SALES:
   (A)   Fees: No "garage sale" shall be held in the Village without obtaining
a permit from the Village Clerk. Each permit shall cost five dollars ($5.00).
   (B)   Defined: A "garage sale" shall consist of any sale of two (2) or more
items conducted on residential property, including, but not limited to, sales
from garages, decks, driveways, yards, basements or homes. This would not
include any sale of personal property which is included in a sale of real
estate.
   (C)   Time: Two permits may be issued in a calendar year to a family living
on the same residential property; and the length of any "garage sale" shall be
three (3) days and must be conducted only between the hours of eight o'clock
(8:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M.
   (D)   Display and sale of goods is permitted only between the hours of eight
o'clock (8:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. No sales may be conducted on a
sidewalk or public right-of- way nor shall any public sidewalk, street or
public right-of-way be obstructed as a result of a garage sale or other similar
sale.
   (E)   No garage sale signage shall be placed on public property. Signs and
banners advertising the garage sale or giving directions to the location of the
sale may not be attached to any utility pole, traffic control device, tree or
placed anywhere within the public right-of-way, including the sidewalk, berm,
parkway or street anywhere within the Village.
   (F)   The supervising resident owner or lease holder of the property where
the sale is located shall be presumed to be the person placing or causing the
placement of signs or advertising. Any signage which violates this rule may be
removed by any person and discarded in any lawful manner.
   (G)   Penalty: Anyone holding a garage sale without a permit or who violates
any provisions of this section shall be fined in a sum not to exceed the
penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code or the maximum allowed by State Statutes. (Ord. 773, 2-14-
1973; amd. Ord. 912, 4-12-1978; Ord. 1362, 9-13-1995; Ord. 2120, 4-12-2023)
5-4-38: DAYCARE CENTERS:
   (A)   Definition: "Daycare center" is any childcare facility receiving
children for daytime care during all or part of a day. The term "daycare
center" includes, but is not limited to, facilities commonly called "childcare
centers", "day nurseries", "nursery schools", "kindergartens", "play groups"
and "centers or workshops for the mentally or physically handicapped" with or
without State educational purposes. The term does not include: 1) kindergartens
or nursery schools or other daytime programs operated by public or private
elementary school systems or secondary level school units or institutions of
higher learning; 2) facilities operated in connection with a shopping center or
service, or other similar facility, where transient children are cared for
temporarily while parents or custodians of the children are occupied on the
premises, or are in the immediate vicinity and readily available; 3) any type
of daycare center that is conducted on Federal government premises; or 4)
special activities programs, including athletics, crafts instructions and
similar activities conducted on an organized and periodic basis by civic
charitable and governmental organizations.
   (B)   Plant And Equipment: The physical facilities provided both indoors and
outdoors shall protect the health and safety of children.
      1.   The building housing a center shall be approved prior to occupancy
and license renewal by the Illinois Department of Public Health and the Office
of the State Fire Marshal or local agencies authorized by those State agencies
to conduct inspections on their behalf. In addition, local licensing shall be
subject to inspection and approval in accordance with the regulations of the
Village building, health and fire authorities.
      2.   The building or portion of the building to which children from the
center have access shall be used only for a program of childcare during the
hours that the center is in operation. This shall not be construed to mean that
the space used for the program cannot be shared by other groups or persons when
the children enrolled are not present.
      3.   There shall be a posted emergency plan for evacuation, and monthly
fire drills shall be conducted at the center for the purpose of removing
children from the center as quickly as possible. Records shall be maintained of
the dates and times fire drills are conducted.
      4.   In facilities established after the effective date hereof, infants
and toddlers shall be housed and cared for at ground level. Travel distance
between any point in a room used for infants and toddlers and an exit
discharging directly outside shall not exceed one hundred fifty feet (150').
         (a)   The program shall be modified, as needed, when there are adverse
environmental conditions caused by weather, heating or cooling difficulties, or
other such problems.
   (C)   Indoor Space:
      1.   There shall be sufficient indoor space to conduct the program.
         (a)   There shall be a minimum of thirty five (35) square feet of
activity area per child in centers for normal children two (2) years of age and
older. This space is exclusive of exit passages and fire escapes, which must be
clear. This space is also exclusive of administrative space, storage areas,
bathrooms, kitchen, space required for equipment that is not used for direct
activities with children and gymnasiums or other areas used exclusively for
large muscle activity or active sports.
         (b)   During nap time, there shall be at least two feet (2') of space
on at least two (2) sides between cots.
         (c)   Storage space shall be provided for cots, bedding, and other
equipment.
         (d)   One room, no matter how large, shall accommodate only one group,
except that room dividers or program equipment at least three feet six inches
(3'6") in height may be used to define and separate the space for each group of
children up to age five (5).
      Gymnasiums and similar sized areas may accommodate two (2) groups,
without dividers, when used for large muscle activity and active sports.
            (1)   A group shall be as defined and set forth by Illinois
department of children and family services licensing standards.
         (e)   All rooms or spaces accommodating more than one group shall be
provided with an acoustical ceiling or its equivalent in carpeting or wall
covering. If carpeting is used to control noise, it shall not be required in
water play, painting, and similar areas.
      2.   Indoor space shall provide a safe, comfortable environment for the
children.
         (a)   Adjustable window shades, drapes, or venetian blinds shall be
provided.
         (b)   The floors and floor coverings shall be washable and free from
drafts, splinters, and dampness.
         (c)   Toxic paints or finishes shall not be used on walls, window
sills, beds, toys or any other equipment, materials or furnishings which may be
used by children or within their reach. Peeling or damaged paint or plaster
shall be repaired promptly to protect children from possible hazards.
         (d)   Any thermal hazards (radiators, hot water pipes, steam pipes,
heaters) in the space occupied by children shall be out of the reach of
children or be separated from the space by partitions, screens or other means.
         (e)   Sharp scissors, knives, matches, lighters, flammable liquids,
drugs, power tools, cleaning supplies and any other such items which might be
harmful to children shall be kept in areas inaccessible to children.
         (f)   The facility shall be well ventilated, and shall maintain a
temperature of not less than sixty eight degrees Fahrenheit (68°F) and not more
than seventy four degrees Fahrenheit (74°F) measured three feet (3') above the
floor. Relative humidity shall be maintained at between thirty five percent
(35%) and sixty percent (60%).
         (g)   Areas where children read, paint or participate in other
activities requiring close eye work shall be provided with a minimum of fifty
(50) foot-candles measured two feet (2') above the floor. Artificial light
sources shall be protected from hazards of breakage by installation of covers
or shields. Other areas may be provided with foot-candles of varying intensity,
depending on the usage; the average foot-candles for the entire classroom area
shall be at least thirty (30) foot-candles measured two feet (2') above the
floor.
   (D)   Outdoor Space: A safe outdoor space shall provide the following unless
the Illinois department of children and family services has approved
alternative facilities:
      1.   The outdoor play area shall accommodate twenty five percent (25%) of
the licensed capacity at any one time.
      2.   There shall be a minimum of seventy five (75) square feet of safe
outdoor play area per child for the total number of children using the area at
any one time.
      3.   Play space shall be safely enclosed or otherwise protected from
traffic and other hazards by a fence built in accordance with the village code.
      4.   Protective surface, such as, but not limited to, grass, pea gravel,
and mulching shall be provided in areas where climbing apparatus is used.
      5.   There shall be provided a surface that is suitable for children's
wheeled vehicles and pull toys.
      6.   Play areas shall be well drained and maintained in a safe, clean and
sanitary manner.
      7.   There shall be open and sheltered areas to permit children to enjoy
activities in either sun or shade and to protect them from excessive exposure.
      8.   If an area not connected with the facility, such as a public park or
playground, is used for play or recreation, the children shall be closely
supervised both during play and while traveling to and from the area.
   (E)   Toilets And Lavatories: Toilets and lavatories shall be readily
accessible to the children.
      1.   If toilets and lavatories are not child sized, safe steps shall be
provided, such as a platform.
      2.   Hot and cold running water shall be provided.
      3.   Mild soap and individual towels shall be available and used. Towels
may be disposable. Disposable towels and refuse shall be disposed of properly
in covered receptacles.
      4.   Hot water supplied to lavatories, bathing facilities, and other
plumbing fixtures used by children shall be tempered or thermostatically
controlled to less than one hundred twenty degrees Fahrenheit (120°F).
      5.   The following ratios of lavatories and toilet facilities shall be
provided:
Number Of Children In Daycare Facility Toilets Lavatories
Number Of Children In Daycare Facility Toilets Lavatories
1 to 10                                1       1
11 to 25                               2       2
26 to 50                               3       3
51 to 75                               4       4
76 to 100                              5       5
101 to 125                             6       6
126 to 150                             7       7
151 to 175                             8       8
 
      6.   Toilet and hand washing areas for school age children shall provide
for privacy.
      7.   Toilets shall be within close proximity to the children's activity
areas. If this is not possible in existing facilities, an adult shall accompany
children four (4) years of age and younger.
      8.   Toilet and lavatories shall be readily accessible to the staff.
      9.   Kitchen sinks used for food preparation shall neither be used as
hand washing lavatories, nor included in the total number of hand washing
lavatories.
   (F)   Ill Child: Space shall be provided for a child who becomes ill at the
center. Such space shall be ventilated and heated; equipped with a cot and
materials that can be easily sanitized; and shall be within sight and hearing
of an adult.
   (G)   Safe Water: A safe and sanitary water supply shall be maintained from
an approved public water supply.
   (H)   Pools: Swimming and wading pools shall be safety maintained and
supervised in accordance with the Illinois department of children and family
services licensing regulations.
   (I)   Food Service: Kitchen areas shall meet the following requirements:
      1.   All food service facilities in daycare centers must have personnel
certified in food service handling by the Illinois department of public health.
      2.   The center shall conform to all applicable food service rules and
regulations.
      3.   The kitchen facilities shall be adequately separated from other
daycare areas.
      4.   If children are in a kitchen, they should be under close
supervision. The stoves are to be equipped with safety devices on the burners
and all handles on pots and pans are to be turned so that a child cannot reach
them from the floor level.
      5.   Children should not be allowed to play or sleep in the kitchen.
      6.   Facilities serving meals must be provided with a refrigeration unit,
a commercial grade three (3) compartment sink with dual integral drain board or
portable dish table, or dish machine. If a dish machine is used, it must be
able to acquire sanitization.
      7.   A hand washing sink must be supplied with dispensed soap and
disposable towels. This sink should be used exclusively for hand washing.
      8.   All installations of plumbing must be in accordance with state and
village code for food service.
   (J)   Solid Waste Management:
      1.   All garbage and refuse within the center shall be collected daily
and stored in a manner that will not permit the transmission of disease, create
a nuisance or fire hazards, or provide harborage for insects, rodents or other
pests.
      2.   An adequate number of covered, durable, watertight, insect/
rodentproof garbage and refuse containers shall be provided for use.
      3.   Garbage and refuse containers used to discard diapering supplies,
food products or disposable meal service supplies shall be cleaned daily with a
germicidal solution unless plastic liners are used and disposed of daily.
   (K)   Insect And Rodent Control: Insect and rodent control shall be
maintained.
      1.   All outside doors, operable windows, and other openings shall be
screened. Doors with operable self-closing devices do not have to be screened.
      2.   Chemicals for insect and rodent control shall not be applied in
areas accessible to children when children are present in the facility.
   (L)   Housekeeping: The facility shall be cleaned daily and kept in a
sanitary condition at all times.
      1.   The facility shall provide necessary cleaning and maintenance
equipment.
      2.   Toys, table tops, furniture, and other similar equipment used by
children shall be washed when they become soiled or contaminated with matter
such as food, body secretions, or excrement.
      3.   Cleaning equipment, cleaning agents, aerosol cans, and other
hazardous chemical substances shall be stored in a space designated solely for
this purpose and shall be inaccessible to children.
      4.   Exit areas shall be kept clear of equipment and debris at all times.
      5.   There shall be no smoking in food preparation areas or in childcare
areas when children are present.
      6.   Major cleaning shall not be done while children are present.
      7.   Water tables and toys used in water tables shall be emptied daily
and cleaned with a mild germicidal solution before being air dried.
   (M)   Bedding: Facilities shall provide a separate crib, bed, or cot and
individual sheets and other bedding.
      1.   Cots, cribs, or beds used by children in a daycare facility may be
used for other children at night if separate sets of clean sheets and other
bedding are provided to each user.
      2.   Clean sheets and blankets shall be provided at least once a week or
as frequently as needed when wet or soiled.
      3.   Waterproof mattress covers or undersheets for cribs, beds, or canvas
cots shall be provided for all children who are bedwetters.
      4.   Each cot, bed, or crib shall be identified with the name of the
child.
      5.   Bed linens shall be tightly fitted and washable.
   (N)   Repair: Facilities and equipment shall be kept in safe repair so as
not to expose children to hazardous situations.
      1.   Any interior or exterior painted surface including walls, floors,
ceilings, equipment, toys, furnishings and cribs shall be maintained in good
order, free of lead paint.
      2.   Electrical outlets within the reach of children up to age five (5)
shall be covered or otherwise shockproof.
   (O)   Furnishings: Furnishings and equipment shall be durable, safe and
scaled to the size of the children.
      1.   Child size chairs shall be provided for preschool children.
      2.   Tables shall be of appropriate height and of a size to accommodate
comfortably a small group of not more than eight (8) to ten (10) children.
      3.   Individual lockers, cubicles, or separate hooks and shelves shall be
provided for the children's personal belongings.
      4.   Low, open shelves for play materials and books shall be provided and
within easy reach of the children.
      5.   Storage for surplus toys and supplies not currently in use shall be
provided.
      6.   A cot must be provided for each preschool age child in an all day
program. Floor pillows, sofas, carpet, beanbag chairs, or padded chairs shall
be provided for school age children for lounging or resting.
      7.   A first aid kit and a chart or handbook of first aid instructions
shall be available for staff use. The first aid kit shall consist of Band-Aids,
sterile bandages, sterile compresses, adhesive tape, scissors, mild soap,
magnifying glass with needles and tweezers for removing splinters.
      8.   Edges of all furnishings should be rounded and smooth.
      9.   All furnishings should be designed, constructed and maintained in
such a manner to be easily cleanable and/or sanitized.
      10.   An operable telephone shall be on the premises, easily accessible
for use in an emergency and other communications.
      11.   A list of emergency telephone numbers, such as the fire department,
police department, and emergency medical treatment shall be posted next to the
telephone.
      12.   Facilities operating on two (2) or more floors shall have intercom
service or other means of formal communications between floors.
   (P)   Night Care Centers Defined: "Night care center" means a facility in
which children are received for periodic care during the night when a single
parent, or both parents, are absent from home because of employment, emergency
or other reasonable circumstance, and the children are in need of supervision
during sleeping hours. A facility may be licensed for either daycare or
nighttime care, or both if circumstances permit, and whether the same children
are served according to the work shifts of their parents or other
circumstances.
      1.   A center receiving children for night care shall comply with
standards for all daycare centers except when inconsistent with the special
requirements prescribed in the Illinois department of children and family
services licensing standards.
   (Q)   License And Fees:
      1.   In addition to the usual application procedure provided by chapter 1
of this title, an applicant must provide proof that they have applied to the
state for a state license as a daycare center. The village inspection shall be
made after proper application is made and fees paid, but no village license
shall be issued until the applicant shall provide proof they have received the
appropriate state permit or license and until the applicant has been approved
by all appropriate village authorities.
      2.   The license fee shall be computed on the square footage area basis,
and the fees shall be computed as follows:
Square Feet License Fee
Square Feet     License Fee
1,500 or less   $ 75.00
1,500 to 3,000  105.00
3,000 to 4,500  145.00
4,500 to 6,000  185.00
6,000 to 8,000  225.00
8,000 to 10,000 275.00
10,000 and over 325.00
 
In computing square footage, there shall be included the entire building floor
area and any adjacent storage or display area.
   (R)   Inspection: Inspection of the daycare center will be made on a
semiannual basis by the village health officer. Inspections by other village
departments and/or officials will be made as deemed necessary for compliance
with fire, safety and building requirements of the village.
   (S)   Revocation Or Suspension Of Business License For Daycare Center: Any
business license for a daycare center may be revoked or suspended by the
village when the license holder fails to comply with this section, requirement
or any applicable state statute, village ordinance, county ordinance or
regulation or any rules, regulations or licensing standard of the Illinois
department of children and family services or any other appropriate state
agency, or in the event a permanent license is not issued by the Illinois
department of children and family services after a permit period of six (6)
months, or if the license from the Illinois department of children and family
services is revoked or suspended at any time. Prior to such suspension or
revocation by the village, the holder of said license shall be given the
opportunity for a hearing before the village board of health. (Ord. 1059, 1-25-
1984)
5-4-39: BILLBOARDS:
Any individual, company or other entity which owns, manages and/or maintains a
billboard, as that term is defined under the Midlothian village zoning
ordinance, shall obtain a business license on an annual basis to operate any
such billboards within the village. Such fee shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00) each year due on or before January 1 of each calendar year. (Ord.
1714, 12-23-2009)
5-4-40: MEDICAL CANNABIS DISPENSING ORGANIZATION:
   (A)   Definition: A "medical cannabis dispensing organization" is a facility
operated by an organization or business that is registered by the department of
financial and professional regulation to acquire medical cannabis from a
registered cultivation center for the purpose of dispensing cannabis,
paraphernalia or related supplies and educational material to registered
qualifying patients.
   (B)   License Fee: The license fee for a medical cannabis dispensing
organization shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) annually.
   (C)   Requirements: Each medical cannabis dispensing organization shall be
required to maintain its proper licensure through the state of Illinois to
operate and shall otherwise follow all applicable state laws and local
ordinances.
   (D)   Limitations:
      1.   A medical cannabis dispensing organization may not be located within
one thousand feet (1,000') of the property line of a preexisting public or
private preschool or elementary or secondary school or daycare center, daycare
home, group daycare home, part day childcare facility or park. A registered
dispensing organization may not be located in a house, apartment, condominium,
or an area zoned for residential use.
      2.   Each medical cannabis dispensing organization shall adopt all
necessary security measures as required by state law and regulation.
      3.   No medical cannabis dispensing organization shall be located in the
same building, office complex or structure as any medical physician.
      4.   No medical cannabis dispensing organization shall erect or place any
signage on its premises or in the lot surrounding its premises: a) depicting a
marijuana leaf and/or plant or b) that use the words cannabis, marijuana, pot,
dope or any other slang term for cannabis.
      5.   Any medical cannabis dispensing organization is only authorized to
be open for business to the public and to fill prescriptions during the hours
of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. through nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. Monday through
Sunday. (Ord. 1859, 1-22-2014)
5-4-41: ADULT USE CANNABIS BUSINESSES:
   (A)   Definitions:
