CHAPTER 1
MILK
(Rep. by Ord. 798, 1-9-1974)
CHAPTER 2
GARBAGE
SECTION:
8-2-1: Definition
8-2-2: License Required And Limitations On Number
8-2-3: License Application
8-2-4: License Fees
8-2-5: Use Of Public Dump Restricted
8-2-6: Garbage Vehicles; Requirements
8-2-7: Receptacle Required
8-2-8: Specifications; Garbage Containers
8-2-9: Location Of Residential Garbage Containers And Temporary Construction
Dumpsters
8-2-10: Containers; Deposit Of Refuse
8-2-11: Burning Of Combustible Materials
8-2-12: Collection Charges
8-2-13: Garbage Bills
8-2-14: Collection Regulations
8-2-15: Branch Pick Up
8-2-16: Dumping In Lakes And The Like Prohibited
8-2-17: Violations
8-2-1: DEFINITION:
The term "private scavenger" shall mean any person engaged in the removal and
disposal of table refuse or animal and vegetable matter usually known as
garbage from restaurants, cafes, stores, business establishments and residences
or the removal and disposal of ashes and cinders. (Ord. 1817, 12-12-2012)
8-2-2: LICENSE REQUIRED AND LIMITATIONS ON NUMBER:
   (A)   No person shall engage in the business of private scavenger without
first having obtained a license so to do.
   (B)   No more than nine (9) persons shall be issued licenses to engage in
the business of private scavenger within the corporate boundaries of the
village at any time.
   (C)   No garbage pick up by any scavenger service shall be made between
seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. (Ord. 1817, 12-12-2012)
8-2-3: LICENSE APPLICATION:
An application for a private scavenger license shall be made in writing to the
clerk and shall contain the name and address of the applicant, the number of
vehicles intended to be used in the business, the type of vehicles and the
method of disposal and the place thereof as proposed by the applicant.
Applications for new licenses shall be approved by the committee on public
works and services of the village board. All private scavengers shall be
required to use equipment of a type acceptable to the superintendent of public
works and shall be required to replace old or unsuitable equipment. (Ord. 1817,
12-12-2012)
8-2-4: LICENSE FEES:
The annual license fee shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00), plus
seventy five dollars ($75.00) for each truck over one truck used in the
business. (Ord. 1817, 12-12-2012)
8-2-5: USE OF PUBLIC DUMP RESTRICTED:
Garbage shall under no circumstances be disposed of in any public dump or
public place within the village. (Ord. 1817, 12-12-2012)
8-2-6: GARBAGE VEHICLES; REQUIREMENTS:
   (A)   Any person owning or controlling any vehicle in the village, used for
the collection and removal of refuse or garbage shall cause all such vehicles,
and all implements used in connection with the loading and unloading hereof,
when not in use, to be stored and kept in such place or places and in such
manner as not to create a nuisance; and shall cause all such vehicles and
implements to be thoroughly disinfected and put in an inoffensive condition
when so stored and not in use.
   (B)   Vehicles used for the collection of refuse or garbage must be of the
all metal and totally enclosed type.
   (C)   Such vehicles and implements shall be thoroughly disinfected at least
once each week, whether in use or not, unless the same shall not have been used
since the last disinfection thereof.
   (D)   No person owning or controlling any vehicle used for the collection
and removal of refuse or garbage in the village shall cause or permit any such
vehicle to be so loaded; to be in such defective condition; to be so out of
repair; to be of such faulty construction; or to be so improperly driven or
managed that any refuse or garbage (with which such vehicle is loaded) shall
drop or fall out on any public way or other place in the village. Such vehicle,
and any box, can or other receptacle carried therein or thereon, shall be so
constructed as to be strong and virtually air and water tight so as to prevent
any such refuse or garbage from emitting any odor and so as to prevent any part
of the contents or load thereof from falling, leaking or spilling therefrom. It
shall be the duty of every person in possession or control of any such vehicle
to replace at once on or in such vehicle any part of the contents thereof which
shall or may have fallen, dropped or spilled from such vehicle, or from any box
or receptacle conveyed thereon, upon any public way or other place whatever.
(Ord. 1817, 12-12-2012)
8-2-7: RECEPTACLE REQUIRED:
   (A)   It shall be the duty of every owner, agent, occupant or lessee of any
house, building, flat, apartment, business, school, library, church, lodge hall
or any other premises to maintain in good order and repair, a container for
garbage and to keep their property clean and free from any accumulation of
garbage, refuse or ashes at all times.
   (B)   No person shall burn refuse or garbage of any kind in the village,
except that controlled fires are permitted if they are specifically authorized
by the mayor and village board. (Ord. 1817, 12-12-2012)
8-2-8: SPECIFICATIONS; GARBAGE CONTAINERS:
   (A)   Residential Garbage Or Refuse Containers For Single-Family Or Two-
Family Dwellings: The garbage container shall be a commercially manufactured
ninety six (96) gallon toter for trash, which is watertight, has a close
fitting cover and is provided with handles. Residents are required to place all
trash (other than bulk items) in the ninety six (96) gallon toter.
   (B)   Recycling Containers: Commercially manufactured sixty five (65) gallon
toters for recycling of glass, aluminum and paper shall be used for such
recyclable materials. Such recycling toters will be picked up every week or
every other week as determined by the village board.
   (C)   Commercial And Apartment Garbage Or Refuse Containers:
      1.   All apartments, businesses, schools, libraries, churches, lodge
halls, institutional, commercial and industrial garbage and refuse shall be
stored in rust resistant, nonabsorbent, watertight metal containers with
tightfitting covers (covers must be used at all times) and adequate handles for
collection purposes. All containers must be designed for use with collection
vehicles.
      2.   All containers must be a minimum size of one and one-half (11/2)
cubic yards and must be contracted to be emptied a minimum of once per week or
more often if garbage overflows the containers. Apartment buildings shall be
required to maintain a one and one-half (11/2) cubic yard container for each
two (2) dwelling units.
      3.   No person other than a private scavenger licensed by the village
shall collect or remove garbage or refuse from any site in the village.
      4.   Storage of all containers shall be at the rear of the building in
such a manner as to be concealed from view from the street or public way of
such building. If it is impractical to store containers from public view, the
village will require a fenced in area so as to hide such containers from public
view. All areas surrounding the containers must be clean and free of garbage or
refuse at all times. The responsibility for this is entirely with the owner,
manager or agent.
   (D)   Use Of Containers Of Another: No person, business or corporation shall
deposit or cause to be deposited any garbage, refuse or any substance in a
garbage or refuse container or in a recycling toter or recycling container
referred to in subsections (A), (B) and (C) of this section, unless said items
belong to the person, business or corporation who owns or leases the toter/
container, or unless said person, business or corporation has written
permission of the owner or lessee of the toter/container.
   (E)   Exemptions: The requirements of this section shall not apply to:
      1.   Village owned refuse containers placed and maintained by the village
for use by the village or by the general public.
      2.   Dumpsters which have been issued a temporary permit for a limited
duration of use. (Ord. 1817, 12-12-2012)
8-2-9: LOCATION OF RESIDENTIAL GARBAGE CONTAINERS AND TEMPORARY CONSTRUCTION
DUMPSTERS:
   (A)   For single- or two-family residential dwellings all refuse, recycling
and landscape toters, as well as all refuse, recycling and landscape containers
("garbage containers") shall be kept in the rear of the principal building on
the lot, except when it is necessary to place the same in the parkway for
purposes of garbage collection. On the day preceding the collection of refuse,
recycling or landscape materials, residents shall be permitted to place garbage
containers in the parkway no earlier than nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. Any and all
garbage containers shall be removed from the parkway no later than nine o'clock
(9:00) A.M. on the day immediately following the collection of refuse,
recycling or landscape materials. (Ord. 1869, 5-14-2014)
   (B)   Any drop-off/roll-off construction dumpster used on a temporary basis
for construction, roofing, concrete removal, remodeling, cleanup, landscaping
or other uses shall be placed on private property only. If such placement is
impossible or impractical, placement of the construction dumpster on the street
will be allowed by a special permit that must be obtained from the building
department. Permits will be granted only when it is determined by the building
department that the placement of the construction dumpster on private property
is impossible or impractical. The term of the special permit to place a
construction dumpster on the street shall be one week. Extensions of the
permitted term may be made by the building department. Any construction
dumpster that has been positioned on the street must be protected by at least
two (2) barricades which have been equipped with a flashing warning light and
placed in a manner that is conspicuous to traffic approaching from either
direction. The barricades shall be made available at the department of public
works for a nominal fee and a refundable deposit that is equal to the cost of
replacement. It is the obligation of the owner of the property, any contractor
using the construction dumpster and the owner of the construction dumpster to
make sure this section is complied with. (Ord. 1817, 12-12-2012)
8-2-10: CONTAINERS; DEPOSIT OF REFUSE:
No person shall deposit garbage or refuse of any kind in any street, alley,
parkway or public way, except as provided in this chapter. Refuse which is too
large to be placed in a toter or container may be placed alongside the toter or
container, but in such a way that it cannot be blown about or scattered by the
wind. The size and type of refuse being discarded is governed by a disposal
service contract. (Ord. 1817, 12-12-2012)
8-2-11: BURNING OF COMBUSTIBLE MATERIALS:
It shall be illegal to burn any garbage, waste or refuse in any fashion not
permitted by section 6-8-15 of this code. (Ord. 1872, 6-11-2014)
8-2-12: COLLECTION CHARGES:
The mayor and the village board shall establish, by resolution or ordinance,
the charges for single-family, residential garbage collection, landscape (yard)
waste and recyclable materials collection and disposal service within the
village. Such collection and disposal service shall not be furnished to
buildings containing multiple dwellings over two (2) units, and any commercial,
industrial or business establishments and the owners of such buildings shall
make private arrangements for the collection and disposal of garbage, refuse
and waste in a sanitary manner. (Ord. 1817, 12-12-2012)
8-2-13: GARBAGE BILLS:
The charges shall be monthly, but at the discretion of the village board shall
be billed quarterly and may be included as a separate item on each water bill
rendered by the village. In the case of such billing the holder of each water
account shall be billed for the number of family units being serviced through
that account. (Ord. 1817, 12-12-2012)
8-2-14: COLLECTION REGULATIONS:
The following rules relating to garbage collections are hereby adopted:
   (A)   Proper Disposal: Garbage shall be drained of liquid and securely
wrapped before being placed in containers. It is not necessary to separate.
   (B)   Excess Waste: Waste over and above the quantities noted herein will be
picked up on request at a reasonable additional charge.
   (C)   Holidays: When the pick up day falls on a holiday, the waste will be
picked up on the next scheduled working day.
   (D)   Electronic Waste: Electronic waste will not be picked up and shall not
be placed for pick up in any refuse, landscape, or recycling toter or any
refuse, landscape, or recycling container or otherwise placed for pick up.
   (E)   Recyclables; Illegal Pick Up:
      1.   Recyclable materials (glass, aluminum and paper) shall be placed in
commercially manufactured sixty five (65) gallon toters for pick up every week
or every other week as determined by the village board.
      2.   It shall be illegal for anyone but the designated licensed scavenger
to pick up any recyclable items which are placed at the curb in appropriate
recycling containers. Anyone seen illegally picking up said recyclables or
having said recyclables in their possession shall be issued a citation unless
said person can prove that the recyclables are theirs.
   (F)   Landscape Waste: Approved containers for landscape waste may include
either a thirty three (33) gallon or equivalent reusable container (with an
affixed adhesive label which reads "Yard Waste") or kraft type paper bags.
Toters may also be leased from the village's contracted waste/landscape hauler.
(Ord. 1817, 12-12-2012)
8-2-15: BRANCH PICK UP:
   (A)   No branches may be placed on the parkway nor will any branches be
picked up from the parkway except when authorized by the village board because
of acts of nature. Special pick ups may be paid for by the village residents by
calling the village scavenger authorized for residential pick up.
   (B)   Any person who places branches on the village parkway other than at
the times designated by the village board or without complying with the
regulations for a special pick up shall be in violation of this section. Any
person convicted of violating this section shall be fined not less than twenty
five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each
day the branches are on the parkway shall be considered a separate violation of
this section. (Ord. 1817, 12-12-2012)
8-2-16: DUMPING IN LAKES AND THE LIKE PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful to deposit or throw any refuse or garbage or other
material of any kind in any lake, creek, stream, pond, or other body of water
within the village. (Ord. 1817, 12-12-2012)
8-2-17: VIOLATIONS:
   (A)   Upon discovery of a violation of this chapter regarding excess garbage
or refuse, the village, by any duly authorized agent, shall serve or cause to
be served a notice of violation upon the owner or occupant of any premises on
which garbage is overflowing or the surrounding areas are not clean and free of
garbage, and shall demand the abatement of the nuisance within twenty four (24)
hours.
   (B)   In the event the nuisance referred to in subsection (A) of this
section is not abated within twenty four (24) hours, the village may proceed to
abate the nuisance by removal of the garbage. The owner or occupant shall be
responsible for all costs of such abatement including all legal and
administrative fees. The minimum charge for such abatement shall be two hundred
dollars ($200.00).
   (C)   Upon discovery of any other violations of this chapter, the village,
by any duly authorized agent, shall serve or cause to be served a notice of
violation upon the violator.
   (D)   Any person convicted of violating this section shall be fined not less
than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00). Each day the violation continues shall be considered a separate
violation of this section.
   (E)   Neither the village or any of its agents shall be liable for any
damage to property occasioned in the enforcement of this section. (Ord. 1817,
12-12-2012)
CHAPTER 3
SEPTIC TANKS; SURFACE DRAINAGE
SECTION:
8-3-1: Use Of Septic Tanks Prohibited
8-3-2: Obstructing Surface Drainage
8-3-1: USE OF SEPTIC TANKS PROHIBITED:
The use of septic tanks or any similar method of sewerage treatment in the
village is hereby prohibited; provided, that the provisions of this chapter
shall have no application in any portion of the village where connections
cannot be made to the sewer system of the village. (Ord. 192, 8-27-1940)
8-3-2: OBSTRUCTING SURFACE DRAINAGE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect any building, structure, or
retaining wall, or to deposit any filling of earth, ashes, rubbish, rubble,
concrete, masonry or any kind of dump in a natural or artificially created
drainage course so as to interfere with, block, divert or hinder the drainage
of surface waters. (Ord. 508, 10-11-1961)
CHAPTER 4
NUISANCES
SECTION:
8-4-1: Definition; Prohibition
8-4-2: Nonsummary Abatement; Notice
8-4-3: Nonsummary Abatement
8-4-4: Summary Abatement
8-4-5: Cost Of Abatement; Lien
8-4-6: Penalty
8-4-7: Reward
8-4-1: DEFINITION; PROHIBITION:
The following acts, conduct and conditions are hereby declared and defined to
be "nuisances", and when committed, performed or permitted to exist by any
individual, firm, association or corporation within the territorial limits of
the village are hereby declared to be unlawful and prohibited:
   (A)   Nuisance Defined: Any act or offense which is a nuisance according to
the common law of the state of Illinois, or declared or defined to be a
nuisance by the ordinances of the village. In addition, the officials of the
municipality shall be authorized to abate any nuisance which, while not
specifically defined within this chapter, shall constitute the unreasonable,
unwarrantable or unlawful use by a person of property, real or personal, or
from his own improper, indecent or unlawful personal conduct which works an
obstruction or injury to a right of another, or of the public, and produces
such material annoyance, inconvenience, discomfort or hurt that the law will
presume an actionable nuisance. Nuisances may be abated which are public or
which are both public and private in nature.
   (B)   Dead Animals: To cause or suffer the carcass of any animal or any
offal, filth or noisome substance to be collected, deposited or to remain in
any place under his ownership or control to the prejudice of others.
   (C)   Offal: To throw or deposit any offal or other offensive matter, or the
carcass of any dead animal in any watercourse, lake, pond, spring, well or
common sewer, street or public highway.
   (D)   Water Pollution: To corrupt or render unwholesome or impure the water
of any spring, river, stream, pond or lake, to the injury or prejudice of
others.
   (E)   Obstruction Of Public Places: To obstruct or encroach upon public
highways, private ways, streets, alleys, commons, landing places and ways to
burying places.
   (F)   Noxious Smells: To erect, continue or use any building or other place
for the exercise of any trade, employment or manufacture, which, by occasioning
noxious exhalations, offensive smells or otherwise, is offensive or dangerous
to the health of individuals, or of the public.
   (G)   Billposting: To advertise wares or occupation by painting notices of
the same on, or affixing them to fences, walls, windows, building exteriors,
utility poles or on hydrants, other public or private property, or on rocks or
other natural objects, without the consent of the owner, or if in the highway
or other public place, without permission of the proper authorities.
   (H)   Garbage And Waste: To dump, abandon, deposit, dismantle or burn upon
any public property or right of way, highway, park, street or parkway anywhere
in the village, any trash, garbage, ashes, junk, junked or wrecked motor
vehicles or parts thereof, or miscellaneous waste.
   (I)   Outside Storage: To store, keep or maintain outside of a closed
building, any junk, parts, machinery or equipment not in an operable condition,
or motor vehicle not in an operable condition, where such inoperable motor
vehicle is an actual danger or detriment to life, safety, health or peaceful
enjoyment of the property of surrounding landowners; provided, however, that
this provision shall not apply to a properly licensed junkyard or other
permitted outdoor storage use which is in full compliance with all of the
ordinances of the village governing the same.
   (J)   Unfit Dwellings: To own, maintain or keep a dwelling unit unfit for
human habitation or dangerous or detrimental to life, safety or health because
of lack of repair, defects in the plumbing system, lighting or ventilation, the
existence of contagious diseases or unsanitary conditions likely to cause
sickness among persons residing in said premises or residing in proximity
thereof.
   (K)   Rat Harborage: To store or place any materials in a manner which may
harbor rats.
   (L)   Noise: To produce or permit to be produced, whether on public or
private property, any offensive noise to the disturbance of the peace or quiet
of any person residing in the vicinity.
   (M)   Diseased Animals: All diseased animals running at large.
   (N)   Stagnant Water: To obstruct any gutter or watercourse so as to cause
water to stagnate therein, or to permit foul or stagnant water to stand upon
any premises.
   (O)   Offensive Substances: To cause, permit or suffer any garbage or
offensive substance of any kind to be collected, deposited or remain in any
place in the village other than as prescribed in the garbage refuse and debris
regulations contained in this code.
   (P)   Dust Prevention: Dust and other types of air pollution borne by the
wind from such sources as storage areas, yards, roads and the like, shall be
kept to a minimum by landscaping, paving, oiling, fencing, cutting of weeds or
other appropriate means.
   (Q)   Pest Infestations: All infestations of flies, fleas, roaches, lice,
ticks, rats, mice, fly maggots, mosquito larvae, rodents, insects, vermin and
pest birds.
   (R)   Noxious Plants: To permit the growth upon any premises of any noxious
plants.
   (S)   Unsafe Buildings: To construct or maintain any building or structure
which is in an unsanitary, unsafe or dangerous condition, or to maintain or
permit any building or part thereof to be or remain in an unsanitary condition
by reason of the basement or cellar being damp or wet or the floor of such
basement or cellar being covered with stagnant water, or by reason of the
presence of sewer gas, or which by reason of any other unsanitary, unsafe or
dangerous condition endangers the health or safety of any person.
   (T)   Barbed Wire: The use of "barbed wire" for fencing or screening of any
type in a residentially zoned district.
   (U)   Bathtub Barbecuing: Barbecuing or cooking of any type in indoor
bathtub.
   (V)   Abandoned Refrigerators: It shall be unlawful for any person to leave
or permit to remain outside of any dwelling, building or other structure, or
within any occupied or abandoned building, dwelling or other structure under
his or its control, in a place accessible to children, any abandoned,
unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or other container which has an
airtight door or lid, snap lock or other locking device which has not been
removed from said icebox, refrigerator or container.
   (W)   Open Excavations: It shall constitute a nuisance to allow any building
foundation or excavation to remain open and unclosed for a period in excess of
thirty (30) days. Such an excavation or foundation may be filled in by order of
the board of trustees after said thirty (30) day period.
   (X)   Potable Water: It shall constitute a public nuisance if any building
used for residential purposes does not have a clean, potable and adequate
supply of running water. (Ord. 999, 5-27-1981)
   (Y)   Weeds:
      1.   Duty Of Property Owners To Cut Weeds: It is the duty of each owner
of real property located within the village not to permit weeds, whether
growing or not, to stand on his property at a height greater than eight inches
(8") from the ground. Any real estate containing weeds having attained a height
of eight inches (8") or more is hereby declared a nuisance. Each property owner
shall take such action as is lawful and as often as is necessary to cut weeds
and remove them, such that they will not exceed the maximum permitted height.
      2.   Notice To Owner To Cut Weeds: In the event that a property owner
permits weeds on his property to exceed the maximum height, the village clerk
shall serve written notice upon him to comply with the provisions of subsection
(Y)1 of this section within five (5) days from the date of such notice.
      3.   Action By Village Upon Failure Of Owner To Cut Weeds: If a property
owner fails to comply with the provisions of subsection (Y)1 of this section,
and the village clerk has given the notice provided for in subsection (Y)2 of
this section, at the expiration of the five (5) day period set forth in such
notice the village may enter upon the property and cut the weeds. The village
clerk shall keep accurate records of the cost incurred by the village in so
doing, whether such cost arises out of a contract entered into by the village
with others to cut the weeds, or whether the cost arises out of the assignment
of village employees to cut the weeds. As soon as reasonably may be after weeds
are cut by the village and the cost thereof is determined, the village clerk
shall send a written demand to the property owner to reimburse the village for
such cost.
      4.   Lien Upon Real Property: The cost to the village of cutting weeds on
the property of an owner who has failed to comply with subsection (Y)1 of this
section is a lien in favor of the village against such property. If, after the
demand for payment provided for in subsection (Y)3 of this section has been
sent by the village, the property owner does not pay to the village the amount
demanded, the village clerk shall cause the notice of such lien to be recorded
in the office of the Cook County recorder (or, if the property is subject to
the Torrens registration system, then in the office of the Cook County
registrar of titles) not later than sixty (60) days after such cost is
incurred. The notice shall contain a sworn statement setting out: a) a
description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof; b) the
amount of money representing the cost and expenses incurred or payable; and c)
the date or dates when such cost and expenses were incurred by the village.
      5.   Release Of Lien Upon Payment: Upon payment to the village of the
amount demanded in the notice provided for in subsection (Y)3 of this section,
if the village has recorded or registered a notice of lien as provided in
subsection (Y)4 of this section, the village clerk shall execute and deliver to
the property owner a release of such lien, which release may be recorded or
registered by the property owner. (Ord. 1142, 10-14-1987)
   (Z)   Inoperable Motor Vehicles:
      1.   The village does hereby declare all inoperable motor vehicles,
whether on public or private property and in view of the general public, to be
a nuisance and fines may be levied for the failure of any person to obey a
notice received from the village which states that such person is to dispose of
any inoperable motor vehicles under his control, and the village hereby
authorizes the police department to have the inoperable motor vehicle or parts
thereof removed after seven (7) days from the issuance of a village notice. The
owner of the vehicle shall be responsible for all towing and storage charges.
However, nothing in this section shall apply to any motor vehicle that is kept
within a building when not in use, to operable historic vehicles over twenty
five (25) years of age, or to a motor vehicle on the premises of a place of
business engaged in the wrecking or junking of motor vehicles.
      2.   As used in this section, "inoperable motor vehicle" means any motor
vehicle from which, for a period of at least seven (7) days, the engine, wheels
or other parts have been removed, or on which the engine, wheels or other parts
have been altered, damaged or otherwise so treated that the vehicle is
incapable of being driven under its own motor power. "Inoperable motor vehicle"
shall not include a motor vehicle which has been rendered temporarily incapable
of being driven under its own motor power in order to perform ordinary service
or repair operations. (Ord. 1150, 3-9-1988)
8-4-2: NONSUMMARY ABATEMENT; NOTICE:
Except where otherwise provided by the ordinances of the village, any officer
of the village possessing police powers may serve or cause to be served a
notice, in writing, upon the owner, agent, occupant or person in possession,
charge or control of any lot, building or premises or item of personalty in or
upon which any nuisance, requiring them or either or both of them to abate the
same within a specified reasonable time. It shall not be necessary in any case
for the notice to specify the manner in which any nuisance shall be abated
unless he shall deem it advisable so to do. Such notice may be served or given
by any officer who is so directed. (Ord. 999, 5-27-1981)
8-4-3: NONSUMMARY ABATEMENT:
If the person so served and notified does not abate the nuisance within the
specified reasonable time, the corporate authorities may proceed to abate the
nuisance in any or all manner allowable by law, including, without limiting the
generality thereof, the following:
   (A)   Seeking to impose a monetary penalty as defined by section 8-4-6 of
this chapter by instituting an ordinance enforcement action.
   (B)   Seeking to enjoin the continuation of the nuisance by the filing of a
lawsuit in a court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 999, 5-27-1981)
8-4-4: SUMMARY ABATEMENT:
Whenever, in the opinion of an officer of the village possessing police powers,
the maintenance or continuation of a nuisance creates an imminent threat of
serious injury to persons or serious damage to personal or real property, or if
the nuisance can be abated summarily without or with only minor damage to the
items or premises which are creating the nuisance, and the continuation of the
nuisance poses a substantial threat of injury to persons or property or a
substantial interference with the quiet enjoyment of the life normally present
in the community, such officer shall proceed to abate such nuisance; provided,
further, that whenever the owner, occupant, agent or person in possession,
charge or control of the real or personal property which has become a nuisance
is unknown or cannot readily be found, the municipal officer with police power
may proceed to abate such nuisance without notice. Where the abatement of the
nuisance requires continuing acts by the corporate authorities beyond the
initial summary abatement and any other additional emergency abatements, it
shall seek abatement of such nuisance on a permanent basis through judicial
process as soon as reasonably possible. (Ord. 999, 5-27-1981)
8-4-5: COST OF ABATEMENT; LIEN:
In either case provided by the two (2) previous sections, the expense of such
abatement shall be collected from the person who may have created, continued or
suffered such nuisance to exist. The village may file a lien for the cost
against any real estate whereupon the nuisance existed. (Ord. 999, 5-27-1981)
8-4-6: PENALTY:
Any individual, firm or association or corporation violating any of the
provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be fined not more than the
penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code or the maximum allowed by
state statutes for each offense. Each day that a violation is allowed to exist
shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 999, 5-27-1981; amd. Ord. 1362, 9-
13-1995)
8-4-7: REWARD:
   (A)   The village board recognizes that it is in the best interests of the
village to help abate nuisance or trespass on village property or property of
others within the village. To further this goal, the village will provide a
reward to anyone supplying information leading to the conviction of any person
involved in creating a nuisance or trespass on property of the village or of
any private person or business.
   (B)   The village board offers a reward of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for
anyone providing information or evidence leading to the conviction in a court
of law of any individual who causes a nuisance or trespass on the property of
the village or a private person or business. In the instance of one or more
individuals providing the evidence or testimony, the reward will be shared.
   (C)   A nuisance is any action as set forth in this chapter, and includes,
but is not limited to, dumping or depositing anything of an offensive nature on
a public way or on private property. (Ord. 1551, 7-24-2002)
CHAPTER 5
CLEAN INDOOR AIR
SECTION:
8-5-1: Findings
8-5-2: Definitions
8-5-3: Smoking Prohibitions
8-5-4: Posting Of Signs; Removal Of Ashtrays
8-5-5: Designation Of Other Nonsmoking Areas
8-5-6: Exemptions
8-5-7: Enforcement; Complaints
8-5-8: Violations
8-5-9: Injunctions
8-5-10: Discrimination Prohibited
8-5-11: Entrances, Exits, Windows And Ventilation Intakes
8-5-1: FINDINGS:
The village board makes the following findings:
   (A)   That the Illinois general assembly has passed the smoke free Illinois
act 1  which prohibits smoking in all public places, government buildings,
government owned vehicles and places of employment, with certain specified
exceptions.
   (B)   That section 65 of the smoke free Illinois act 2  allows any nonhome
rule municipality to regulate smoking, as long as such regulations or ordinance
is not less restrictive than the smoke free Illinois act.
   (C)   That the village board adopts the findings of the Illinois general
assembly as annunciated in the smoke free Illinois act as follows:
      The General Assembly finds that tobacco smoke is a harmful and dangerous
carcinogen to human beings and a hazard to public health. Secondhand tobacco
smoke causes at least 65,000 deaths each year from heart disease and lung
cancer according to the National Cancer Institute. Secondhand tobacco smoke
causes heart disease, stroke, cancer, sudden infant death syndrome, low birth
weight in infants, asthma and exacerbation of asthma, bronchitis and pneumonia
in children and adults. Secondhand tobacco smoke is the third leading cause of
preventable death in the United States. Illinois workers exposed to secondhand
tobacco smoke are at increased risk of premature death. An estimated 2,900
Illinois citizens die each year from exposure to secondhand tobacco smoke.
      The General Assembly also finds that the United States Surgeon General's
2006 report has determined that there is no risk-free level of exposure to
secondhand smoke; the scientific evidence that secondhand smoke causes serious
diseases, including lung cancer, heart disease, and respiratory illnesses such
as bronchitis and asthma, is massive and conclusive; separating smokers from
nonsmokers, cleaning the air, and ventilating buildings cannot eliminate
secondhand smoke exposure; smoke free workplace policies are effective in
reducing secondhand smoke exposure; and smoke free workplace policies do not
have an adverse economic impact on the hospitality industry.
      The General Assembly also finds that the Environmental Protection Agency
has determined that secondhand smoke cannot be reduced to safe levels in
businesses by high rates of ventilation. Air cleaners, which are capable only
of filtering the particulate matter and odors in smoke, do not eliminate the
known toxins in secondhand smoke. The American Society of Heating,
Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE) bases its ventilation
standards on totally smoke free environments because it cannot determine a safe
level of exposure to secondhand smoke, which contains cancer causing chemicals,
and ASHRAE acknowledges that technology does not exist that can remove
chemicals that cause cancer from the air. A June 30, 2005 ASHRAE position
document on secondhand smoke concludes that, at present, the only means of
eliminating health risks associated with indoor exposure is to eliminate all
smoking activity indoors.
(Ord. 1660, 1-23-2008)
 
Notes
1 1. 410 ILCS 82/1 et seq.
2 2. 440 ILCS 82/65.
8-5-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms shall mean:
BAR: An establishment that is devoted to the serving of alcoholic beverages for
consumption by guests on the premises and that derives no more than ten percent
(10%) of its gross revenue from the sale of food consumed on the premises.
"Bar" includes, but is not limited to, taverns, nightclubs, cocktail lounges,
adult entertainment facilities, and cabarets.
EMPLOYEE: A person who is employed by an employer in consideration for direct
or indirect monetary wages or profits or a person who volunteers his or her
services for a nonprofit entity.
EMPLOYER: A person, business, partnership, association, or corporation,
including a municipal corporation, trust, or nonprofit entity that employs the
services of one or more individual persons.
ENCLOSED AREA: All space between a floor and a ceiling that is enclosed or
partially enclosed with: a) solid walls or windows, exclusive of doorways; or
b) solid walls with partitions and no windows, exclusive of doorways, that
extend from the floor to the ceiling, including, without limitation, lobbies
and corridors.
ENCLOSED OR PARTIALLY ENCLOSED SPORTS ARENA: Any sports pavilion, stadium,
gymnasium, health spa, boxing arena, swimming pool, roller rink, ice rink,
bowling alley, or other similar place where members of the general public
assemble to engage in physical exercise or participate in athletic competitions
or recreational activities or to witness sports, cultural, recreational, or
other events.
GAMING EQUIPMENT OR SUPPLIES: Gaming equipment/supplies as defined in the
Illinois gaming board rules of the Illinois administrative code.
GAMING FACILITY: An establishment utilized primarily for the purpose of gaming
and where gaming equipment or supplies are operated for the purpose of accruing
business revenue.
HEALTHCARE FACILITY: An office or institution providing care or treatment of
diseases, whether physical, mental, or emotional, or other medical,
physiological, or psychological conditions, including, but not limited to,
hospitals, rehabilitation hospitals, weight control clinics, nursing homes,
homes for the aging or chronically ill, laboratories, and offices of surgeons,
chiropractors, physical therapists, physicians, dentists, and all specialists
within these professions. "Healthcare facility" includes all waiting rooms,
hallways, private rooms, semiprivate rooms, and wards within healthcare
facilities.
PLACE OF EMPLOYMENT: Any area under the control of a public or private employer
that employees are required to enter, leave, or pass through during the course
of employment, including, but not limited to, entrances and exits to places of
employment, including a minimum distance, as set forth in section 8-5-11 of
this chapter, of fifteen feet (15') from entrances, exits, windows that open,
and ventilation intakes that serve an enclosed area where smoking is
prohibited; offices and work areas; restrooms; conference and class rooms;
break rooms and cafeterias; and other common areas. A private residence or home
based business, unless used to provide licensed childcare, foster care, adult
care, or other similar social service care on the premises, is not a "place of
employment".
PRIVATE CLUB: A not for profit association that: a) has been in active and
continuous existence for at least three (3) years prior to the effective date
of the smoke free Illinois act, whether incorporated or not; b) is the owner,
lessee, or occupant of a building or portion thereof used exclusively for club
purposes at all times; c) is operated solely for a recreational, fraternal,
social, patriotic, political, benevolent, or athletic purpose, but not for
pecuniary gain; and d) only sells alcoholic beverages incidental to its
operation. For purposes of this definition, "private club" means an
organization that is managed by a board of directors, executive committee, or
similar body chosen by the members at an annual meeting, has established
bylaws, a constitution, or both, to govern its activities, and has been granted
an exemption from the payment of federal income tax as a club under 26 USC 501.
PRIVATE RESIDENCE: The part of a structure used as a dwelling, including,
without limitation: a private home, townhouse, condominium, apartment, mobile
home, vacation home, cabin, or cottage. For the purposes of this definition, a
hotel, motel, inn, resort, lodge, bed and breakfast or other similar public
accommodation, hospital, nursing home, or assisted living facility shall not be
considered a private residence.
PUBLIC PLACE: That portion of any building or vehicle used by and open to the
public, regardless of whether the building or vehicle is owned in whole or in
part by private persons or entities, the state of Illinois, or any other public
entity and regardless of whether a fee is charged for admission, including a
minimum distance, as set forth in section 8-5-11 of this chapter, of fifteen
feet (15') from entrances, exits, windows that open, and ventilation intakes
that serve an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited. A "public place" does
not include a private residence unless the private residence is used to provide
licensed childcare, foster care, or other similar social service care on the
premises. A "public place" includes, but is not limited to, hospitals,
restaurants, retail stores, offices, commercial establishments, elevators,
indoor theaters, libraries, museums, concert halls, public conveyances,
educational facilities, nursing homes, auditoriums, enclosed or partially
enclosed sports arenas, meeting rooms, schools, exhibition halls, convention
facilities, polling places, private clubs, gaming facilities, all government
owned vehicles and facilities, including buildings and vehicles owned, leased,
or operated by the state or state subcontract, healthcare facilities or
clinics, enclosed shopping centers, retail service establishments, financial
institutions, educational facilities, ticket areas, public hearing facilities,
public restrooms, waiting areas, lobbies, bars, taverns, bowling alleys,
skating rinks, reception areas, and no less than seventy five percent (75%) of
the sleeping quarters within a hotel, motel, resort, inn, lodge, bed and
breakfast, or other similar public accommodation that are rented to guests, but
excludes private residences.
RESTAURANT:
   (A)   An eating establishment, including, but not limited to, coffee shops,
cafeterias, sandwich stands, and private and public school cafeterias, that
gives or offers for sale food to the public, guests, or employees; and
   (B)   A kitchen or catering facility in which food is prepared on the
premises for serving elsewhere. "Restaurant" includes a bar area within the
restaurant.
SMOKE OR SMOKING: The carrying, smoking, burning, inhaling, or exhaling of any
kind of lighted pipe, cigar, cigarette, hookah, weed, herbs, or any other
lighted smoking equipment. (Ord. 1660, 1-23-2008)
8-5-3: SMOKING PROHIBITIONS:
No person shall smoke in a public place or in any place of employment or within
fifteen feet (15') of any entrance to a public place or place of employment. No
person may smoke in any vehicle owned, leased, or operated by the state or a
political subdivision of the state. Smoking is prohibited in indoor public
places and workplaces unless specifically exempted by section 8-5-6 of this
chapter. (Ord. 1660, 1-23-2008)
8-5-4: POSTING OF SIGNS; REMOVAL OF ASHTRAYS:
   (A)   "No Smoking" signs or the international "no smoking" symbol,
consisting of a pictorial representation of a burning cigarette enclosed in a
red circle with a red bar across it, shall be clearly and conspicuously posted
in each public place and place of employment where smoking is prohibited by
this chapter by the owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of
that place.
   (B)   Each public place and place of employment where smoking is prohibited
by this chapter shall have posted at every entrance a conspicuous sign clearly
stating that smoking is prohibited.
   (C)   All ashtrays shall be removed from any area where smoking is
prohibited by this chapter by the owner, operator, manager, or other person
having control of the area. (Ord. 1660, 1-23-2008)
8-5-5: DESIGNATION OF OTHER NONSMOKING AREAS:
Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, any employer, owner,
occupant, lessee, operator, manager, or other person in control of any public
place or place of employment may designate a nonenclosed area of a public place
or place of employment, including outdoor areas, as an area where smoking is
also prohibited provided that such employer, owner, lessee or occupant shall
conspicuously post signs prohibiting smoking in the manner described in
subsections 8-5-4(A) and (B) of this chapter. (Ord. 1660, 1-23-2008)
8-5-6: EXEMPTIONS:
Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, smoking is allowed in the
following areas:
   (A)   Private residences or dwelling places, except when used as a
childcare, adult daycare, or healthcare facility or any other home based
business open to the public.
   (B)   Private and semiprivate rooms in nursing homes and long term care
facilities that are occupied by one or more persons, all of whom are smokers
and have requested in writing to be placed or to remain in a room where smoking
is permitted and the smoke shall not infiltrate other areas of the nursing
home.
   (C)   Hotel and motel sleeping rooms that are rented to guests and are
designated as smoking rooms, provided that all smoking rooms on the same floor
must be contiguous and smoke from these rooms must not infiltrate into
nonsmoking rooms or other areas where smoking is prohibited. Not more than
twenty five percent (25%) of the rooms rented to guests in a hotel or motel may
be designated as rooms where smoking is allowed. The status of rooms as smoking
or nonsmoking may not be changed, except to permanently add additional
nonsmoking rooms. (Ord. 1660, 1-23-2008)
8-5-7: ENFORCEMENT; COMPLAINTS:
   (A)   The village health department and police department shall enforce the
provisions of this chapter and may assess fines pursuant to section 8-5-8 of
this chapter.
   (B)   Any person may register a complaint with the village health department
and/or police department for a violation of this chapter.
   (C)   Violations of this chapter shall be administered pursuant to title 6,
chapter 11 of this code. (Ord. 1660, 1-23-2008)
8-5-8: VIOLATIONS:
   (A)   A person, corporation, partnership, association or other entity who
violates section 8-5-3 of this chapter shall be fined pursuant to this section.
Each day that a violation occurs is a separate violation.
   (B)   A person who smokes in an area where smoking is prohibited under
section 8-5-3 of this chapter shall be fined in an amount that is not less than
one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00).
   (C)   A person who owns, operates, or otherwise controls a public place or
place of employment that violates section 8-5-3 of this chapter shall be fined:
1) not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for the first violation;
2) not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the second violation within
one year after the first violation; and 3) not less than two thousand five
hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for each additional violation within one year after
the first violation.
   (D)   A fine imposed under this section shall be allocated as follows:
      1.   One-half (1/2) of the fine shall be distributed to the Illinois
department of public health; and
      2.   One-half (1/2) of the fine shall be distributed to the village.
(Ord. 1660, 1-23-2008)
8-5-9: INJUNCTIONS:
Nothing contained in this chapter shall be deemed to prohibit, modify, prevent
or otherwise affect the ability of the Illinois department of public health,
any state certified local public health department, the village police
department or any individual personally affected by repeat violations to
institute, in a circuit court, an action to enjoin violations of the smoke free
Illinois act or this chapter. (Ord. 1660, 1-23-2008)
8-5-10: DISCRIMINATION PROHIBITED:
No individual may be discriminated against in any manner because of the
exercise of any rights afforded by this chapter. (Ord. 1660, 1-23-2008)
8-5-11: ENTRANCES, EXITS, WINDOWS AND VENTILATION INTAKES:
Smoking is prohibited within a minimum distance of fifteen feet (15') from
entrances, exits, windows that open, and ventilation intakes that serve an
enclosed area where smoking is prohibited under this chapter so as to ensure
that tobacco smoke does not enter the area through entrances, exits, open
windows, or other means. (Ord. 1660, 1-23-2008)

CHAPTER 1
SIDEWALKS
SECTION:
9-1-1: Sidewalk Construction; Permit; Fee
9-1-2: Construction Requirements
9-1-3: One-Course Sidewalks
9-1-4: Two-Course Sidewalks
9-1-5: Cement; Type
9-1-6: Sidewalk Widths
9-1-7: Installation Required
9-1-1: SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION; PERMIT; FEE:
Any person desiring to install any Portland cement concrete sidewalk on any
public street or place in the village shall, before beginning such work, obtain
a permit to install the same from the clerk, and before such permit shall be
issued, the person shall pay for such permit a sum equal to forty cents ($0.40)
per linear foot of sidewalk to be installed; provided, however, that the
minimum fee for such permit shall be fifty dollars ($50.00).
It shall be unlawful to construct or install any sidewalk during any period
beginning October 1 and ending April 30. (Ord. 929, 5-24-1978)
9-1-2: CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
All sidewalks hereafter constructed in the village shall be either one-course
or two-course Portland cement concrete sidewalks which shall conform in all
respects to the specifications hereinafter set forth for one-course sidewalks
or two-course sidewalks. Sidewalks shall be built to the grade established
therefor by the engineer, and such grade shall be given by means of stakes set
by the engineer. (Ord. 27, 1928)
9-1-3: ONE-COURSE SIDEWALKS:
One-course sidewalks shall be constructed as follows: A subgrade shall be
prepared by cutting down or filling up the surface of the ground to an
elevation which, after being thoroughly compacted, shall be five inches (5")
below the sidewalk grade. Wherever filling is necessary, it shall be done with
earth, or other material equally as good for filling purposes, free from animal
or vegetable matter, thoroughly compacted, and placed in layers not more than
twelve inches (12") in thickness.
Upon the subgrade shall be placed a layer of Portland cement concrete five
inches (5") in thickness. The concrete shall consist of one part Portland
cement, two (2) parts torpedo sand and three (3) parts crushed stone or gravel
measuring not less than one-fourth inch (1/4") nor more than one and one-half
inches (11/2") in any dimension, all of which shall be free from dust, loam and
dirt or other foreign substance. The materials shall be thoroughly mixed with
water in a batch mixer or mixed by hand, in which event the cement and sand
shall be thoroughly mixed dry, into which shall be incorporated the three (3)
parts of stone as specified herein, after which the mixture shall be moistened
with water and the whole mass thoroughly mixed and placed on the foundation and
rammed until solid. The concrete shall be struck off and finished in such a
manner as to ensure a smooth and even surface. (Ord. 27, 1928)
9-1-4: TWO-COURSE SIDEWALKS:
Two-course sidewalks shall be constructed as follows: A subgrade shall be
prepared by cutting down or filling up the surface of the ground to an
elevation which, after being thoroughly compacted, shall be five inches (5")
below the sidewalk grade. Wherever filling is necessary, it shall be done with
earth or other material equally as good for filling purposes, free from animal
or vegetable matter, thoroughly compacted, and placed in layers not more than
twelve inches (12") in thickness.
Upon the subgrade shall be placed a layer of Portland cement concrete four and
one-fourth inches (41/4") in thickness. The concrete shall consist of one part
Portland cement, two and one- half (21/2) parts torpedo sand and four (4) parts
crushed stone or gravel, measuring not less than one-fourth inch (1/4") nor
more than one and one-half inches (11/2") in any dimension, all of which shall
be free from dust, loam and dirt or other foreign substances. The materials
shall be thoroughly mixed with water in a batch mixer, or mixed by hand, in
which event the cement and sand shall be thoroughly mixed dry, into which shall
be incorporated the four (4) parts of stone as specified herein, after which
the mixture shall be moistened with water and the whole mass thoroughly mixed
and placed on the foundation and rammed until solid. Before the layer last
described has set, a finishing layer of Portland cement concrete three-fourths
inch (3/4") in thickness shall be placed thereon. The layer shall consist of
two (2) parts Portland cement and three (3) parts torpedo sand, thoroughly
mixed dry, then moistened with water and mixed again to form a mortar which
shall be spread in such a manner as to ensure a smooth and even surface after
being thoroughly troweled. (Ord. 27, 1928)
9-1-5: CEMENT; TYPE:
The Portland cement to be used shall be so ground that ninety two percent (92%)
will pass through a standard number 100 sieve having ten thousand (10,000)
meshes per square inch. Briquettes made from a mortar composed of one part
Portland cement and two (2) parts torpedo sand, exposed to the air for one day
and immersed in water for six (6) days, shall develop an ultimate strength of
two hundred (200) pounds per square inch. (Ord. 27, 1928)
9-1-6: SIDEWALK WIDTHS:
All sidewalks hereafter constructed shall be constructed with the following
widths:
   (A)   Eight feet (8') when fronting on property which is zoned for business
purposes.
   (B)   Five feet (5') when fronting on property which is zoned for other than
business purposes 1 . (Ord. 288, 7-14-1948)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-84-1 et seq.
9-1-7: INSTALLATION REQUIRED:
Sidewalks will be required to be installed on all new construction of homes,
apartments, businesses, industrial or recreational use. Sidewalks shall also be
required where they do not exist on any remodeling projects where in the
determination of the building superintendent, the interest of the village would
require installation of the sidewalk. The construction of the cement sidewalk
would be on the full street frontage of the lot or lots to be improved and on
the side lots frontage on corner lots. Sidewalks shall be built and located in
accordance with the regulations and ordinances of this code. (Ord. 874, 2-23-
1977)
CHAPTER 2
CULVERTS
SECTION:
9-2-1: Obstructing Ditches
9-2-2: Installation Of Culverts; Permit
9-2-3: Application For Permit
9-2-4: Culverts; Dimension Requirements
9-2-5: Investigation Of Application
9-2-1: OBSTRUCTING DITCHES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to fill, partially fill or obstruct any
highway drainage ditch in the village. (Ord. 446, 11-12-1958)
9-2-2: INSTALLATION OF CULVERTS; PERMIT:
It shall be unlawful for any person to install any culvert in or driveway over
any highway drainage ditch in the village without securing a permit therefor in
accordance with this chapter. (Ord. 446, 11-12-1958)
9-2-3: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
Any person desiring to install a driveway over or to install a culvert in any
highway drainage ditch shall make application for a permit therefor to the
clerk. The application for permit shall describe the location of the property
and the location of the driveway or culvert to be installed. The application
shall be referred to the superintendent of public works, who shall inspect the
premises and determine the proper size, type and depth of the culvert. (Ord.
446, 11-12-1958)
9-2-4: CULVERTS; DIMENSION REQUIREMENTS:
Culverts in highway ditches shall be not less than twelve inches (12") in
diameter and such greater diameter as may be determined necessary for the
location by the superintendent of public works.
Culverts under driveways shall be constructed of reinforced concrete or
corrugated steel. Culverts shall be at least twelve feet (12') in length. (Ord.
446, 11-12-1958)
9-2-5: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICATION:
The superintendent of public works shall make a report on each application and
shall issue a permit in accordance with his findings. No charge shall be made
for permits issued under the provisions of this chapter 1 . (Ord. 446, 11-12-
1958)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-80-11.
CHAPTER 3
NUMBERING BUILDINGS
SECTION:
9-3-1: Numbering Required
9-3-2: Numbering Base Designated
9-3-3: Number Spaces; Designation
9-3-4: Street Prefixes Designated
9-3-5: Assignment Of Numbers
9-3-6: Size Of Numbers
9-3-7: Alteration Of Number Without Consent Prohibited
9-3-8: Reassignment Of Numbers
9-3-1: NUMBERING REQUIRED:
It shall be the duty of the owner, agent or person in possession of every
building in the village to number it in the manner hereinafter provided. (Ord.
198, 1-28-1941)
9-3-2: NUMBERING BASE DESIGNATED:
All lots or houses located on the north and south streets or on streets running
in a northerly or southerly direction shall be numbered from 147th Street as a
base, beginning with number 14700 at the north line of 147th Street, and
decreasing towards the north, and beginning with number 14701 at the south line
of 147th Street and increasing towards the south.
All lots or houses located on east and west streets running in an easterly or
westerly direction shall be numbered from Crawford Avenue (40th Avenue) as a
base, beginning with number 4000 at the east line of Crawford Avenue and
decreasing towards the east, and beginning with 4001 at the west line of
Crawford Avenue and increasing towards the west. (Ord. 198, 1-28-1941)
9-3-3: NUMBER SPACES; DESIGNATION:
There shall be assigned to each mile eight hundred (800) numbers, or one
hundred (100) numbers to each one-eighth (1/8) of a mile on all streets, and
such numbers shall change from any one hundred (100) to the succeeding one
hundred (100) at the intersecting street nearest to the one-eighth (1/8) mile
lines. The even numbers on north and south streets, or streets running in a
northerly or southerly direction shall be on the west side of the streets. The
even numbers on east and west streets, or streets running in an easterly or
westerly direction, shall be on the north side of the streets. (Ord. 198, 1-28-
1941)
9-3-4: STREET PREFIXES DESIGNATED:
All north and south streets, or streets running in a northerly or southerly
direction, shall bear the prefix "South".
All east and west streets, or streets running in an easterly or westerly
direction, shall bear the prefix "West". (Ord. 198, 1-28-1941)
9-3-5: ASSIGNMENT OF NUMBERS:
The clerk shall assign or cause to be assigned to each lot or part of lot,
residence, apartment or place of business, its legal number.
The clerk shall inform the owner, agent, or person in possession of such
premises, as to the number thereof at any reasonable time upon request. (Ord.
198, 1-28-1941)
9-3-6: SIZE OF NUMBERS:
Each of the figures of every number on any residence or apartment building
shall be not less than three inches (3") in length, and on any store or place
of business not less than five inches (5") in length. All numbers shall be
placed in a conspicuous place on or near the entrance to the building to which
the same are attached. (Ord. 198, 1-28-1941)
9-3-7: ALTERATION OF NUMBER WITHOUT CONSENT PROHIBITED:
Whenever any house or building shall have been numbered or renumbered in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter, the number shall not be changed
or altered without the consent of the clerk. (Ord. 198, 1-28-1941)
9-3-8: REASSIGNMENT OF NUMBERS:
In all cases where house numbers have been assigned on any street in pursuance
of this chapter, it shall be the duty of the clerk to adjust and reassign such
numbers as the same may be required from time to time; and in all cases where
there is a mistake or conflict in numbers, the clerk shall direct and make the
proper adjustment of the same 1 . (Ord. 198, 1-28-1941)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-80-18.
CHAPTER 4
WEEDS
(Rep. by Ord. 800, 1-23-1974)
CHAPTER 5
REMOVAL OF SNOW AND ICE
SECTION:
9-5-1: Removal Required
9-5-2: Removal Time Limited
9-5-3: When Removal Impossible; Use Of Sand
9-5-1: REMOVAL REQUIRED:
Every owner, occupant or other person having charge of any building or lot of
ground in the village abutting upon any street or public place, shall remove
the snow and ice from the sidewalk in front of the building or lot of ground.
If the sidewalk is of greater width than five feet (5'), it shall not be
necessary for the owner, occupant or other person having charge of the building
or lot to remove snow and ice from the same for a space wider than five feet
(5'). (Ord. 122, 12-12-1933)
9-5-2: REMOVAL TIME LIMITED:
The snow which falls or accumulates during the day, except Sunday, before four
o'clock (4:00) P.M. shall be removed within three (3) hours after the same has
fallen or accumulated. Snow which falls or accumulates on Sunday and after four
o'clock (4:00) P.M. and during the night on other days shall be removed before
ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. on the following morning. (Ord. 122, 12-12-1933)
9-5-3: WHEN REMOVAL IMPOSSIBLE; USE OF SAND:
In case the snow and ice on the sidewalk shall be frozen so hard that it cannot
be removed without injury to the pavement, the owner, or occupant or other
person having charge of any building or lot of ground as aforesaid, shall
within the time specified in the last section, cause the sidewalk abutting on
the premises to be strewed with ashes, sand, sawdust or some similar suitable
material and shall as soon thereafter as the weather will permit, thoroughly
clean the sidewalk 1 . (Ord. 122, 12-12-1933)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-80-13.
CHAPTER 6
EXCAVATIONS
SECTION:
9-6-1: Excavations; Estimate Of Expense; Permit
9-6-2: Bond Required
9-6-3: Applications For Permit
9-6-4: Supervision Of Excavations
9-6-5: Costs
9-6-6: Refund Of Surplus Deposit
9-6-7: Unlawful Injury To Streets
9-6-1: EXCAVATIONS; ESTIMATE OF EXPENSE; PERMIT:
Before a permit shall be granted to any person to open any street, sidewalk,
alley or public place in the village for any purpose, a permit fee as set forth
in section 4-3-12 of this code shall be paid, but for anything not covered by
said section, an estimate of the cost of inspection as hereinafter provided and
of restoring the pavement or the surface of the street, sidewalk, alley or
public place to a condition equally as good as before having been opened, to
the satisfaction of the superintendent of streets, with a fair additional sum
as margin for contingent damages to be determined by the superintendent of
streets, shall be made by the clerk, who, before issuing the same, shall
collect the amount of the estimate and the fee for the permit, which fee is
hereby fixed at the sum of fifteen dollars ($15.00). (Ord. 931, 5-24-1978)
9-6-2: BOND REQUIRED:
No permit shall be issued to any person, permitting the obstruction of any
street or sidewalk or the tearing up, removing or repairing of any street or
sidewalk, or any part thereof, until the person, making application for such
permit shall first have executed to the village a good and sufficient bond in
an amount as set forth in section 4-3-12 of this code. Said bond is conditioned
to indemnify, save and keep harmless the village from any loss, cost, damage,
expense or liability of any kind whatsoever, which it may suffer, or which it
may be put to, or which may be recovered from it from or on account of the
issuance of the permit, or because of any act done by virtue of the authority
given in the permit, or for any damage, loss or expense to any person caused by
or because of the obstruction of any street or sidewalk, or by the tearing up,
removing or repairing of such street or sidewalk, or any part thereof. (Ord.
931, 5-24-1978)
9-6-3: APPLICATIONS FOR PERMIT:
The superintendent of streets shall not issue any permit for the opening of any
street, alley or public way by any person until he shall have been fully
advised of the time, place and character of the opening and the purpose thereof
and until the permit has been ordered to be issued by the president and board
of trustees; and all applications for permits shall be in writing and shall be
accompanied by a plat or pencil tracing or sketch, showing the location,
character and dimensions of the proposed opening. (Ord. 96, 3-24-1932)
9-6-4: SUPERVISION OF EXCAVATIONS:
All work done under the authority of the permit shall be supervised and
inspected by the superintendent of streets, and immediately after the
completion of the work done under such authority shall, with village workmen,
immediately put back, restore and replace in proper place and condition any
pavement displaced by reason of such work, and shall restore and replace the
surface of any street, alley or public way which may be opened or otherwise
disturbed; all of the work to be done in such manner as shall be satisfactory
to the superintendent of streets and subject at all times to the approval of
the board of trustees. (Ord. 96, 3-24-1932)
9-6-5: COSTS:
The costs of the supervision and inspection and of restoring the pavement or
street as hereinabove provided shall be determined by the superintendent of
streets and approved by the board of trustees and shall be deducted from the
amount deposited with the clerk as hereinabove provided. (Ord. 96, 3-24-1932)
9-6-6: REFUND OF SURPLUS DEPOSIT:
After completion of the work to the satisfaction of the superintendent of
streets and the board of trustees, the superintendent shall certify to the
clerk and to the board of trustees the amount of any surplus remaining from the
amount deposited in such case and such surplus shall thereupon be paid to the
proper claimant. (Ord. 96, 3-24-1932)
9-6-7: UNLAWFUL INJURY TO STREETS:
No person shall injure or tear up any pavement, sidewalk or crosswalk, or any
part thereof, dig any hole, ditch, drain, or dig or remove any sod, stone,
earth, sand or gravel from any street, alley or public ground in the village
without having first obtained written permission from the superintendent of
streets given in accordance with the provisions of this chapter 1 . (Ord. 96,
3-24-1932)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-80-7.
CHAPTER 7
PUBLIC WEIGHMASTERS
SECTION:
9-7-1: Appointment
9-7-2: Application; Bond; License
9-7-3: Deputy Weighmaster
9-7-4: Scales
9-7-5: Change Of Location Of Scales
9-7-6: Weigh All Commodities
9-7-7: Charges For Weighing
9-7-8: Seal
9-7-9: Weight Certificates
9-7-10: Records
9-7-11: Street Scales Prohibited
9-7-12: False Weights
9-7-13: Certificate To Be Delivered Or Posted
9-7-14: Alteration Of Certificate Prohibited
9-7-15: Reweighing Commodities Owned By Weighmaster
9-7-16: Reweighing Commodities Not Owned By Weighmaster
9-7-17: Obstructing Reweighing Operation
9-7-18: Net Weight
9-7-19: Weighmaster May Weigh Own Commodities
9-7-20: Commodities Sold In Load Lots
9-7-1: APPOINTMENT:
Any person owning a scale suitable for weighing any commodity, produce or
article of merchandise in load lots, when contained in any wagon truck or other
vehicle, or in any quantity less than load lots when not contained in any
wagon, truck or other vehicle, shall be eligible for appointment as a public
weighmaster in the village after complying with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 170, 11-22-1938)
9-7-2: APPLICATION; BOND; LICENSE:
Every applicant for a license as public weighmaster shall file with the clerk
an application in writing signed by the applicant, and setting forth the
location of his place of business, and such other information as may be
required by the clerk. The application shall also contain the following
agreement:
   The applicant hereby agrees and consents as a condition of the issuance of a
license hereunder, that in case the applicant as a public weighmaster weighs
any load lot of any commodity, produce or article of merchandise sold in load
lots by weight, sold or delivered by the applicant or by any person directly or
indirectly interested with the applicant, in the operation of the public scale
of the applicant, the Chief of Police, or his agent, or the purchaser or
consignee shall have the right to reweigh or cause to be reweighed as provided
in this Chapter, any such load lot. This condition is accepted by the applicant
with the understanding that the same shall, upon the issuance of a license
hereunder at once become binding upon him.
The applicant shall also execute and present with his application a bond to the
village in the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00), with such surety as may
be approved by the board of trustees, conditioned upon the performance of the
duties as public weighmaster, and for the payment of any fines which may be
imposed upon him for violations of any such duties. Upon compliance with these
conditions and upon payment of the sum of twenty dollars ($20.00) as an annual
license fee, the clerk shall issue a license authorizing the applicant to act
as a public weighmaster.
The license so issued shall contain apt words indicating that the same is
issued subject to the conditions and agreements herein set forth, and any
person violating any of these conditions shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor. (Ord. 913, 4-12-1978)
9-7-3: DEPUTY WEIGHMASTER:
Each public weighmaster shall have the power to appoint all necessary deputies
to attend such weights and scales, the deputies to furnish a bond in the same
amount as the public weighmaster and conditioned in the same manner. Each
deputy weighmaster must pay an annual fee of ten dollars ($10.00). Each public
weighmaster shall be answerable for all acts of the deputy weighmaster; but the
weighmaster's responsibilities hereunder shall not relieve the deputy's
liability for his own acts. The weighmaster may cancel such appointment at any
time but he must notify the chief of police of such cancellations. (Ord. 913,
4-12-1978)
9-7-4: SCALES:
Every public weighmaster licensed hereunder shall provide his own scale, which
shall be approved by the chief of police, and the weighmaster shall keep them
adjusted and repaired at his own expense. They shall be inspected by the chief
of police every six (6) months or more often if necessary. (Ord. 170, 11-22-
1938)
9-7-5: CHANGE OF LOCATION OF SCALES:
Weighmasters or deputies are entitled to weigh only over scales mentioned in
the application, and for each new scale a new entry must be made on the
application, and the chief of police notified. If the location of any scale is
changed, the clerk shall issue a transfer upon payment of a transfer fee of two
dollars ($2.00). (Ord. 913, 4-12-1978)
9-7-6: WEIGH ALL COMMODITIES:
The public weighmaster or his deputy shall weigh all commodities tendered for
weighing at any reasonable time except holidays and Sundays. (Ord. 170, 11-22-
1938)
9-7-7: CHARGES FOR WEIGHING:
Public weighmasters when not the owner of the commodities being weighed by them
shall be entitled to charge a sum not in excess of ten cents ($0.10) for each
load or part of load when contained in any vehicle, or any commodity or article
weighed by them over such scales. (Ord. 170, 11-22-1938)
9-7-8: SEAL:
Every weighmaster shall procure a seal, in form to be approved by the clerk,
which shall show his name, and shall stamp each certificate issued by him with
such seal. (Ord. 170, 11-22-1938)
9-7-9: WEIGHT CERTIFICATES:
Each public weighmaster shall make out in triplicate a weight certificate on
each load weighed by him or his deputy, containing the following information:
   (A)   The commodity or article weighed.
   (B)   Name of weighmaster or deputy.
   (C)   Name of person for whom weighing was done.
   (D)   Name of driver of vehicle, or name of person bringing material to be
weighed to scales.
   (E)   Kind of vehicle.
   (F)   Address of cosignee.
   (G)   Gross weight of vehicle and driver.
   (H)   Tare weight of vehicle and driver.
   (I)   Net weight of article.
Any weighmaster shall not in any case state the tare weight of a vehicle until
he has ascertained it himself; except in cases of a divided load. (Ord. 170,
11-22-1938)
9-7-10: RECORDS:
Each weighmaster must keep a copy of every certificate which shall be numbered,
and shall constitute the record of his business. Each certificate must be
accounted for and kept for a period of at least two (2) years, and be open to
the inspection of the chief of police. (Ord. 170, 11-22-1938)
9-7-11: STREET SCALES PROHIBITED:
No one except public weighmasters licensed hereunder shall weigh any commodity
or article for a fee or reward, and no one shall use or keep a scale in any
public place, street, or alley without permission to do so from the board of
trustees. (Ord. 170, 11-22-1938)
9-7-12: FALSE WEIGHTS:
No public weighmaster shall issue a certificate giving a false weight for the
article weighed and upon conviction of a false weight certificate issuance, he
shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and the board of trustees may in its
discretion cancel his license.
Any person requesting a false certificate from any public weighmaster shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. 170, 11-22-1938)
9-7-13: CERTIFICATE TO BE DELIVERED OR POSTED:
A copy of the weight certificate shall be delivered to the purchaser, or if
there is no one at the place of delivery to receive the delivery, shall be
posted in a conspicuous place at the place of delivery before the article or
commodity so weighed and described in the certificate shall be unloaded. The
remaining copy shall be retained by the seller. (Ord. 170, 11-22-1938)
9-7-14: ALTERATION OF CERTIFICATE PROHIBITED:
No person shall alter any certificate or attempt to use it for any load other
than that for which it was issued. (Ord. 170, 11-22-1938)
9-7-15: REWEIGHING COMMODITIES OWNED BY WEIGHMASTER:
Upon request to the chief of police, any purchaser of any goods owned or sold
by the public weighmaster and weighed by him, may take the goods under the
supervision of the public weighmaster to another scale approved by the chief of
police and there reweigh the same. (Ord. 170, 11-22-1938)
9-7-16: REWEIGHING COMMODITIES NOT OWNED BY WEIGHMASTER:
Any person upon request to the chief of police shall be permitted to take his
load to another scale for the purpose of reweighing his load, but on the
following conditions: gross load to be weighed immediately and tare weight to
be ascertained immediately after delivery of load; the reweighing must take
place on a scale approved by the chief of police. (Ord. 170, 11-22-1938)
9-7-17: OBSTRUCTING REWEIGHING OPERATION:
Any person having his goods reweighed who does not follow the foregoing
provisions or who in any way obstructs the chief of police shall be deemed
guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. 170, 11-22-1938)
9-7-18: NET WEIGHT:
When any commodity, produce or article is sold subject to the public
weighmaster's weights, the net weight shown in the weight certificate issued by
the weighmaster shall be taken to be the true net weight of the same, subject
to the right of reweighing as herein provided. Net weight within the meaning of
this chapter shall be the actual weight of the commodity, produce or article
excluding the weight of the vehicle, if any, in which it is loaded, and
excluding the weight of the horse and driver of such vehicle, as the case may
be, if such horses and driver or either of them are weighed as part of the tare
weight. (Ord. 170, 11-22-1938)
9-7-19: WEIGHMASTER MAY WEIGH OWN COMMODITIES:
Nothing in this chapter shall prevent a public weighmaster from engaging in the
business of selling any article, commodity or produce which is ordinarily
delivered by vehicle or from weighing the same. (Ord. 170, 11-22-1938)
9-7-20: COMMODITIES SOLD IN LOAD LOTS:
Every load of any commodity, produce or other article of merchandise sold in
load lots by weight, delivered by wagon, truck or other vehicle, shall be
weighed by a public weighmaster. (Ord. 170, 11-22-1938)
CHAPTER 8
REMOVAL OF SHOPPING CARTS
SECTION:
9-8-1: Abandoned Carts
9-8-2: Removal Of Carts
9-8-3: Posting Of Ordinance
9-8-4: Penalty
9-8-1: ABANDONED CARTS:
No person shall abandon or leave unattended any grocery cart or shopping cart
upon any public street, sidewalk, or public way within the village or upon the
private property of any person adjoining or abutting any public way or sidewalk
within the village other than on premises where said carts were originally
obtained. (Ord. 714, 1-27-1971)
9-8-2: REMOVAL OF CARTS:
No person shall remove or license or permit the removal of grocery carts or
shopping carts from the premises and parking lots from the establishments which
furnished said carts. (Ord. 714, 1-27-1971)
9-8-3: POSTING OF ORDINANCE:
A copy of this chapter shall be posted in a conspicuous place in every place of
business or establishment which provides grocery carts or shopping carts for
use by its customers or patrons. (Ord. 714, 1-27-1971)
9-8-4: PENALTY:
Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall
be subject to a fine not exceeding the penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of
this code or the maximum allowed by state statutes for such offense. (Ord. 822,
10-9-1974; amd. Ord. 1362, 9-13-1995)
CHAPTER 9
DISTRIBUTION OF PRINTED MATTER
SECTION:
9-9-1: Prohibited Conduct
9-9-2: Responsibility For Prohibited Distribution
9-9-3: Penalty
9-9-1: PROHIBITED CONDUCT:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to hand any circular, pamphlet,
handbill, folder, advertising material or other printed matter whatsoever to
the occupant of any vehicle operated or standing in the public way, or to place
or thrust such circular, pamphlet, handbill, folder, advertising material or
other printed matter whatsoever into, upon or under the windshield wiper of an
unoccupied vehicle standing in the public way without village permission.
   (B)   It shall also be unlawful for any person to do the above on private
property without obtaining in advance the written permission of the owner of
the property.
   (C)   Any materials which are discarded or which litter the area shall be
the responsibility of those doing the distribution and/or the sponsors of the
material.
   (D)   1. The owners and/or advertisers who use newsracks, newspaper vending
machines, vending machines, display racks or holders (hereinafter referred to
as "dispensing device"), for distribution of flyers, pamphlets, brochures,
papers, handbills, folders, advertising materials or any printed materials or
products that can be removed from the dispensing device must provide cleanup of
their materials which may be discarded by anyone.
The owners of the dispensing device and/or the person or company whose name or
names appear on the material or product shall be responsible for any littering
or discarded material from their dispensing device.
      2.   Any dispensing device placed in the village must have the name,
address and phone number of the owner permanently affixed to the dispensing
device or it may be removed from its location by the village.
      3.   No dispensing device described in subsection (D)1 of this section
may be attached or secured to any other dispensing device or to any tree,
utility pole, light pole, telephone, traffic control device, sign, bus shelter,
