12-1-2A: MINOR PIN CONSOLIDATIONS AND PIN DIVISIONS:
As an alternative to the subdivision requirements of this title 12, if in the
determination of the village a pin consolidation or pin division is a minor pin
consolidation or pin division, the following shall apply.
(A)   An applicant for a minor pin division or consolidation may, at the
applicant's own risk, apply for such division or consolidation pursuant to this
section 12-1-2A. Applicants for a minor pin division or pin consolidation shall
provide a plat of division or plat of consolidation for review, prepared by a
state of Illinois licensed professional land surveyor, that accurately depicts
the existing and proposed lot configurations; the legal description(s) of the
resulting division or consolidation; the name and address of the applicant; a
brief statement describing the name of the division or consolidation and the
number of lots proposed; and the locations of any existing structures.
(B)   In addition, the applicant shall submit to the village a pin
consolidation or pin division application form as provided by the village, and
a pin division/consolidation form as provided by Cook County. These forms shall
be completed by the applicant and approved by the village.
(C)   Along with the survey and application forms, the applicant shall also pay
to the village a non-refundable deposit as determined by the village.
(D)   Once the application and any additional materials are approved by the
village, a hearing shall be held before the village plan commission pursuant to
village code sections 2-1-5 (Plan Commission Powers), and
12-1-2A and
11-2-9 (Public Hearings and Public Notices). At this hearing, the plan
commission shall afford all persons interested an opportunity to be heard on
the proposed division or consolidation. The public hearing may be adjourned and
reconvened from time to time.
(E)   Lands subject to flooding and land deemed to be topographically
unsuitable should not be divided or consolidated for any uses that may increase
danger to health, life or property, or aggravate erosion or flood hazard.
(F)   In determining whether to grant a division or consolidation, the village
shall consider the following:
   1.   Compliance with the Illinois plat act;
   2.   Proposed use of the property in relation to surrounding properties, and
the village's comprehensive plan, zoning map, and building and zoning codes;
   3.   Access to utilities, drainage, and motor vehicles, including easements
and rights-of-way;
   4.   Parking, traffic flow and street congestion;
   5.   Any other condition of the resulting division/consolidation which may
be of concern to the health, safety, and welfare of the village and its
residents.
Following public hearing on the application, the plan commission shall make
recommendations to the village board whether to approve or deny the application
pursuant to village code section 2-1-5 (Powers of Commission). The plan
commission shall make a final report within thirty (30) days after the final
adjournment of the public hearing, and submit the proposed ordinance for the
entire village to the board of trustees, to be enacted with or without change,
or to be referred back to the commission for further consideration. (Ord. 2170,
5-14-2025)
12-1-3: COMMENCEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION:
No grading, building or construction of any kind relating to development of
land within the definition of "subdivision" shall be started except in
accordance with these regulations. Construction of improvements shall be in
accordance with subsection 12-1-7(G) of this chapter. Construction of buildings
and dwellings shall be started only after issuance of building permits and no
building permit shall be issued prior to recording of the final plat. (Ord.
1136, 6-24-1987)
12-1-4: INFORMAL CONSIDERATION:
While the subdivision plan is still in sketch form, the subdivider may consult
with the plan commission to determine conformity to the official comprehensive
plan, including the major street plan, the zoning title, and compliance with
these regulations and with other village laws not in conflict with these
regulations. (Ord. 1136, 6-24-1987)
12-1-5: PRELIMINARY PLAT:
Prior to the completion of the final survey of streets and lots of any
subdivision and before any map of the subdivision is made in form suitable for
recording, a preliminary plat, prepared in accordance with the regulations set
forth herein, shall be submitted to the plan commission for its review and
recommendations. In the event a proposed subdivision is one acre or less in
area, the subdivider shall have the right to dispense with preparation of the
preliminary plat and to proceed directly with submission of the final plat. In
such case, the fee of subsection (F) of this section shall be payable upon
submission of the final plat.
   (A)   Submission Of Preliminary Plat: An application in writing in sextuplet
(6 copies) for the conditional approval of the subdivision, together with ten
(10) prints of the preliminary plat shall be filed with the plan commission at
least ten (10) days prior to the regular monthly meeting of the commission to
receive action at such meeting. The plan commission may forward copies of the
application with prints to the engineer, the park board and the school boards.
The plan commission shall determine whether the preliminary plat is in proper
form and shall not receive or consider the application as filed until all
documents are in accordance with the requirements set forth herein.
The application is to be accompanied by a statement from the clerk, collector,
ex officio, that the filing fee has been paid as specified in subsection (F) of
this section.
   (B)   Consideration Of Preliminary Plat: The plan commission will study the
preliminary plat in connection with the official comprehensive plan including
the major street plan, the zoning title and the topography of the area, and
will take into consideration the general requirements of the community, the
particular requirements of the neighborhood, and the best use of the land to be
subdivided. Particular attention will be given to specific requirements for
parks, playgrounds, school sites, major streets, the adequacy of street
connections and the suitability of the land for development. The preliminary
plat may also be subject to check by the engineer, the park board and school
boards.
   (C)   Action On Preliminary Plat: The plan commission will communicate its
conditional approval or its disapproval, in writing to the subdivider within
sixty (60) days of the time at which application for conditional approval is
made, giving, in cases of conditional approval:
      1.   The specific changes which will be required in the preliminary plat.
      2.   The character and extent of the required public improvements.
      3.   The nature and extent of the percentage surety which it will require
to guarantee completion of the improvements.
   (D)   Conditional Approval Of Preliminary Layout: Conditional approval by
the plan commission of the preliminary layout does not constitute acceptance of
the plat of the proposed subdivision, acceptance of proposed improvements or
final agreement as to improvement specifications or cost. It is to be
considered only as approval of general layout design.
   (E)   Effective Period Of Conditional Approval: Conditional approval of the
preliminary plat shall be effective for a maximum period of twelve (12) months
except that submission within this period of a final plat applying to a portion
of the area covered by the preliminary plat shall extend the effective period
of conditional approval to a maximum of twenty four (24) months from the date
of submission of the preliminary plat. If a final plat has not been submitted
to the plan commission within these time limits, the preliminary plat shall
again be submitted to the plan commission for conditional approval.
   (F)   Fees:
      1.   Conditions: In order to cover the costs of examining the plat,
advertising and holding public hearings, legal fees, copying fees, tax search
fees, recording fees and other expenses incidental to the approval of the
subdivision and recording of same, the subdivider shall pay a fee at the time
of application for conditional approval of the preliminary plat. There will be
no refund of any portion of the fee if the subdivider fails to apply for final
approval of the subdivision. If, because of the failure of the subdivider to
submit a final plat within twelve (12) months after receiving conditional
approval of a preliminary plat, it is necessary to resubmit a preliminary plat
for conditional approval, the subdivider shall be required to pay the fee
currently in effect at the time of resubmission. (Ord. 1136, 6-24-1987)
      2.   Amount: The fees for submission of a subdivision shall be five
hundred dollars ($500.00), plus one hundred dollars ($100.00) per dwelling
unit, existing and proposed. If the subdivision is not approved by the village
board, no refund will be given. (Ord. 1540, 6-12-2002)
      3.   Place Of Payment: Fees shall be paid to the clerk, collector, ex
officio, at the village hall.
      4.   Use: All fees collected for the submission and approval of
subdivisions shall be credited to the general fund of the village.
      5.   Separate Charge: All fees established by this section are in
addition to any sums paid to cover costs of preparation of improvement plan and
field inspection of construction as required under the provisions of section
12-1-7 of this chapter. (Ord. 1136, 6-24-1987)
12-1-6: SUBMISSION OF FINAL PLAT:
After approval of the preliminary layout by the plan commission and fulfillment
of the required conditions, the subdivider shall apply in writing to the
chairman of the plan commission for approval of a final plat. The final plat
shall conform substantially to the preliminary layout as given conditional
approval. The application shall be in duplicate and shall be accompanied by the
original inked plat on material approved by Cook County records office and ten
(10) prints. Specifications for the plat and for other documents to accompany
the application are given in section 12-1-8 of this chapter. The final plat
will not be considered as submitted unless it is in agreement with
specification and accompanied by the required documents.
   (A)   Hearing: The chairman of the plan commission will notify the
subdivider or his representative of the time and place at which he will be
heard publicly on behalf of his application.
   (B)   Action On Final Plat: The plan commission will communicate in writing
to the subdivider its disapproval or recommendation for approval of the final
plat, together with the reasons therefor within sixty (60) days after the date
on which application for such approval is made. If the plan commission approved
the final plat, such approval will be entered upon the tracings by signature of
the chairman. The tracings shall then be transmitted to the village board by
the plan commission with recommendation for its approval. Upon approval by
village board action the tracings shall be signed by the president. Approval by
the village board may be by resolution setting forth all conditions upon which
approval is predicated. The original tracing shall be recorded with the Cook
County recorder of deeds after all signatures and seals are affixed.
Appropriate notifications shall be given the plan commission and the subdivider
advising village board approval or disapproval and advising document numbers
after recording. If the plat is disapproved, the tracings are to be returned to
the plan commission with statement of reasons. A copy of the reasons for
disapproval may be filed in the office of the village clerk and the applicant
may be notified of this action in writing.
   (C)   Approval Not Acceptance Of Improvements: Approval of the final plat
shall not be deemed to constitute or effect any acceptance by the village of
any improvement shown on the plat.
   (D)   Effectiveness Of Final Approval: Approval of the final plat by the
plan commission and the board shall be null and void if the plat is not
acceptable for recording in the office of the recorder of deeds of Cook County.
   (E)   Documents: Attendant documents accompanying the final plat are to be
forwarded to the board with the tracings and are to be filed by the clerk.
(Ord. 1136, 6-24-1987)
12-1-7: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
   (A)   General Principles Of Acceptability:
      1.   Conformance To Official Comprehensive Plan: The subdivision shall
conform to the official comprehensive plan or the portions thereof then
existing, and shall not encroach upon areas designated in the official
comprehensive plan for future public facilities.
      2.   Provision For Future Subdivision: If a tract is subdivided into
larger parcels than ordinary building lots, such parcels shall be arranged to
allow the opening of future streets and logical further subdivision.
      3.   Reserve Strips Prohibited: There shall be no reservation of strips
of land that prevent or limit access to land dedicated or intended to be
dedicated to public use.
      4.   Buffer Strips: Where a residential subdivision adjoins a railroad
right of way, an industrial area, a business area, a major street or other land
use which would have a depreciating effect on the residential use of the
property, a buffer strip ten feet (10') in width, to form a screen, may be
required by the village.
      5.   Building Sites: Every lot must contain a suitable building site.
      6.   Trees: Valuable large trees shall be preserved whenever possible.
Where planting strips are provided with trees, trees or shrubs within a forty
foot (40') radius from intersecting property lines at a street intersection
shall not have branches closer than eight feet (8') to the ground over
sidewalks and fifteen feet (15') over roadways. The subdivider shall provide
two (2) trees per lot, spaced uniformly in the right of way, of uniform size no
less than two and one-half inches (21/2") in diameter, and of species approved
by the superintendent of public works.
These trees shall not be planted directly over water mains, sanitary sewer
lines, or underground gas or electric lines. The village also recommends that
the following trees not be allowed for planting in parkways: elms, willows,
poplars, box elders, soft maples, ornamental trees (crab trees, flowering
shrubs, fruit trees), and upright evergreens.
      7.   Neighborhood Plan: If a suggested plan for the neighborhood or area
in which the tract to be subdivided is located has been made by the village,
the street layout of the subdivision shall be in general conformance thereto.
      8.   Variations: Variations from the design and dimensional standards and
improvement requirements of these regulations may be made by the village in
cases where, owing to exceptional conditions, there are extreme difficulties or
hardships in the way of carrying out the strict letter of these regulations.
Resubdivision of a single lot of a platted block of an old subdivision shall be
considered as an exceptional condition meriting departure from the strict
letter of these regulations. No variation shall be made that will be
detrimental to the public welfare or that will affect adversely the official
comprehensive plan.
   (B)   Streets; Layout And Design:
      1.   Major Streets: Whenever a subdivision embraces a major street, as
shown on the major street plan, such major street shall be platted in the
location and of the width indicated on the major street plan.
      2.   Secondary Streets: Secondary streets shall be included when it is
apparent that sufficient traffic will flow from the minor streets within the
subdivision and that such traffic will need to be channeled to control the
number of access points to the major street. There is a requirement of a sixty
six foot (66') right of way.
      3.   Street Layout: The street layout shall be devised for the most
advantageous development of the entire neighborhood area. Where necessary to
the neighborhood pattern, existing principal streets in adjoining subdivisions
shall be continued and shall be at least as wide as the existing streets and in
alignment with them. The street layout shall provide for the future extension
of the principal streets into unsubdivided lands adjoining.
      4.   Minor Streets: Minor streets shall be so laid out so that their use
by through traffic will be discouraged. There is also a sixty six foot (66')
right of way requirement.
      5.   Intersections: There shall be a minimum number of intersections of
minor streets with major streets.
      6.   Marginal Access Streets: Where a subdivision has frontage on a major
street, as shown on the major street plan, or on a super highway or other high
volume trafficway and where it is not feasible to have the lots back to such
high volume streets, provision shall be made for marginal access streets. These
marginal access streets shall be approximately parallel to and on each side of
the major street right of way and separated from such right of way by a strip
of land at least forty feet (40') wide. Separation strips may be provided with
screen planting, but such planting shall be so placed that it does not obstruct
vision at intersections.
      7.   Streets For Uses Adjacent To Railroads Or Major Streets: Where a
subdivision borders on or contains a railroad right of way or major street, the
village may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such
right of way or major street, at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of
the intervening land. The distances shall also be determined with due regard
for the requirements of approach grades and future grade separations.
      8.   Streets At Business Centers: In front of areas zoned or designed for
commercial use, the street width and the roadway width shall be increased on
the side on which the property for commercial use is located by a merging lane
at least fifteen feet (15') wide. This is to ensure the free flow of traffic
without interference by vehicles entering or leaving parking areas. This is not
a parking space requirement and shall in no way affect or diminish requirements
by the zoning title or otherwise for off street parking facilities; neither
shall fulfillment of this requirement and its acceptance by the village be
deemed approval or endorsement of any change in zoning necessary for such
commercial use.
      9.   Alleys: Paved rear alleys not less than twenty feet (20') wide will
be required in all business and industrial districts of subdivisions, except
where special conditions make alleys impracticable; in such cases adequate off
street loading space, suitably surfaced, shall be provided. Dead end alleys
shall be avoided, or, if provided, shall include a turnaround. In general,
alleys will not be approved for residential districts of a subdivision, except
where topographic or other conditions may necessitate their use.
      10.   Half Streets: Half streets shall be prohibited, except where
essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision in conformity with
the other requirements of these regulations; and where the village president
and the board of trustees finds it will be practicable to require the
dedication of the other half when the adjoining property is subdivided.
Wherever a half street is adjacent to a tract to be subdivided, the other half
of the street shall be placed within such tract. No strip or area shall be
reserved along any portion of a street, or alley which will prevent adjacent
property owners access thereto except by consent of the village board.
      11.   Street Grades: Street grades shall conform in general to the
terrain and shall be not less than one-half of one percent (0.5%) nor more than
five percent (5%). Street grades shall be such as to provide natural surface
drainage of stormwater regardless of the presence or absence of storm sewers.
The intent is to avoid depressions or inverts that will flood in flash storms
for which storm sewers are inadequate.
      12.   Cul-De-Sacs: Cul-de-sacs shall not exceed five hundred feet (500')
in length including turnaround and shall have a turnaround not less than one
hundred twenty five feet (125') in diameter of right of way and pavement
diameter of one hundred feet (100') back of curb to back of curb at the closed
end.
      13.   Right Of Way Widths: The minimum right of way widths for streets,
alleys and crosswalkways shall be as provided in title 1, chapter 15 of this
code.
      14.   Roadway Widths: Roadway widths shall be as provided for in title 1,
chapter 15 of this code.
      15.   Curvature Of Streets: The minimum radius of curvature of streets on
the centerline shall be:
 
Major street     600 feet
Secondary street 300 feet
Minor street     100 feet
Cul-de-sac       100 feet
 
      16.   Reversed Curves: Between reversed curves on major and secondary
streets there shall be a tangent at least one hundred feet (100') long.
      17.   Intersections: Street intersections shall be at right angles or
nearly so. Where, because of topographic or other reasons an intersection
cannot be at right angles, such intersection shall be so designed as to ensure
safety. Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one hundred twenty
five feet (125') shall be prohibited.
      18.   Curb Radii: Curb radii shall not be less than twenty feet (20').
Where an angle of intersection less than sixty degrees (60°) is permitted, curb
radii shall be increased as necessary for safety.
      19.   Street Names: No street names may be used which will duplicate or
be confused with the names of existing streets in the Midlothian postal
district. Existing street names must be projected wherever possible. Street
names shall be subject to the approval of the village board.
      20.   Access To State Highways: If the tract of land proposed to be
subdivided or any part thereof lies adjacent to a highway over which the
department of transportation of the state of Illinois has jurisdiction with
respect to maintenance and upkeep thereof, and an entrance or entrances are
desired from such highway to lots, streets, roadways, or alleys in such
proposed subdivision, the subdivider shall submit prior to subdivision approval
to the village a written permit from the said department of transportation,
granting his permission to obtain and construct such an entrance or entrances.
   (C)   Blocks:
      1.   Lengths Of Blocks: Blocks shall not exceed one thousand five hundred
feet (1,500') in length; blocks longer than eight hundred feet (800') in length
may be required to have crosswalkways. Crosswalk easements not less than ten
feet (10') in width shall be provided where deemed necessary by the plan
commission at the approximate centers of the blocks. The use of additional
crosswalkways in any instance to provide safe and convenient access to schools,
parks, or other similar destinations may be recommended by the plan commission.
      2.   Blocks For Industrial Or Commercial Use: Blocks intended for
industrial or commercial use shall be designed specifically for such purpose,
with adequate space set aside for off street parking and loading.
      3.   Blocks On Major Streets: It is preferred that blocks adjacent to
major streets be so arranged that the long dimension of the block be parallel
to the major street and that lots do not front on or have access to the major
street. Where this arrangement is not feasible, marginal access streets may be
required.
   (D)   Lots:
      1.   Minimum Width And Area: Lots for residential use shall be at least
sixty feet (60') wide at the building setback line and shall be at least eight
thousand one hundred (8,100) square feet in area. Septic systems are not
allowed if sewers are reasonably accessible. Residential lots, served by septic
systems shall be a minimum of one hundred feet (100') wide at the building line
and shall have a minimum area and depth as determined by specifications for
seepage systems recommended by the county department of public health; provided
further; that no such lot shall have an area less than twenty thousand (20,000)
square feet.
         (a)   Lots for residential use in a subdivision of two (2) acres or
less may be at least fifty feet (50') wide at the building setback line and
shall be at least six thousand two hundred fifty (6,250) square feet in area
when after review of the plan commission the village board feels that a new
subdivision is in an area composed of lots of compatible lot size and the
village board approves said subdivision.
         (b)   A subdivision of two (2) acres or less will not be approved for
fifty foot (50') lots if the owner and/or subdivider has made the subdivision
two (2) acres or less by dividing, selling or subdividing a larger parcel of
land he has a beneficial interest in or which he owns or has under contract.
      2.   Maximum Depth: The maximum depth of any lot, exclusive of unusable
land shall be three and one-half (31/2) times the width of the lot.
      3.   Lot To Abut On Street: Every lot shall abut on a dedicated and
improved street for at least twenty five feet (25').
      4.   Building Setback Lines: Minimum setback lines from property lines in
residential zone shall conform with the zoning regulations.
      5.   Corner Lots: Corner lots in residential zones shall conform to the
corner side yard and front yard setbacks in the applicable zoning district.
      6.   Property Lines At Corners: Property lines at street intersection
corners shall be arcs having a radii of at least ten feet (10') or shall be
chords of such arcs.
      7.   Side Line Of Lots: Side lines of lots shall be approximately at
right angles or radial to the street line.
      8.   Shape Of Lots: The shape of lots and their orientation shall be
appropriate to the location of the proposed subdivision and to the type of
development contemplated.
      9.   Double Frontage Lots: Double frontage lots, other than corner lots,
will be permitted only under unusual circumstances.
   (E)   Public Places:
      1.   Parks And Playgrounds: Not less than seven percent (7%) of the area
of every subdivision, exclusive of streets, alleys and unusable land shall be
set aside for public recreational, school or other public purposes, other than
of streets and alleys, unless the village shall find that the proposed
subdivision is adequately served by such facilities. In small subdivisions,
such reservation of land shall be so located as to permit combining it with
similar reservations in adjoining tracts. Reservations of land for park and
recreational use shall be located to conform as nearly as possible, with the
parks section of the official plan. Whenever a final plat of subdivision, or
part thereof, has been approved by the corporate authorities as complying with
the official map and there is designated therein a school site, park site, or
other public land, the corporate authorities having jurisdiction of such use,
be it school board, park board or other authority, such authority shall acquire
the land so designated by purchase or commence proceedings to acquire such land
by condemnation within one year from the date of approval of such plat; and if
it does not do so within such period of one year, the land so designated may
then be used by the owners thereof in any other manner consistent with this
chapter including the official map and the zoning title.
      2.   Natural And Cultural Features: Outstanding natural and cultural
features, such as scenic spots and watercourses shall be preserved insofar as
possible.
      3.   Easements:
         (a)   Regulations: All aboveground utilities shall be placed on rear
or side property lines. Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, an
appropriate easement shall be provided for the watercourse in either an open
cut or in an underground conduit, depending upon the density of development.
Where water mains, sanitary sewers, storm sewers, gas mains, telephone lines,
power lines or other utilities are located on or adjacent to property lines,
adequate easements together with right of ingress or egress thereto and
therefrom shall be provided and platted. Easements shall not be less than ten
feet (10') in width and shall be centered upon the centerline of the utility.
Where more than one utility is to occupy the easement, the easement shall be of
such width as to extend five feet (5') at each side beyond the centerlines of
the outermost utilities. Additional width shall be provided where necessary to
accommodate utility pole bracing. The village may require evidence of approval
by the public utility company of easement width. Where side lot easements occur
adjacent to a driveway, there shall not be less than ten feet (10') clearance
between the easement line and the extreme projection of the building structure.
(Ord. 1136, 6-24-1987)
         (b)   Drainage Easements: Drainage easements are deemed to be for the
mutual benefit of the lands connected or protected by said drainage easement
and shall constitute a perpetual easement on such lands and shall not be
filled, extracted, breached or impaired in any way without the written consent
of the owners of such lands benefited. Their consent must provide that they
have read and agree with the engineering report referred to below. Lands
benefited shall be determined by a qualified engineering report paid for by the
landowner who wishes to do any work in an easement area. The engineering report
must show why the drainage easement is not needed or to what extent it can be
reduced. It must show what property is currently affected by the drainage
easement and what property would be affected by any change in the drainage
easement. A detailed plan must be provided for any work required in the
drainage easement area. The village engineer will review the report and plan at
the landowner's expense and must give his approval before a permit will be
issued by the village or before any work can be done or change made to the
easement area.
         (c)   Utility Easements: Utility easements shall have no structure or
building (except a division fence) placed upon it unless the owner of the land
obtains written permission from all the utilities who have a right to use said
easement. The written permission must describe the land, the easement, their
right to use the easement and what type of an encroachment structure or
building they would allow and where it would be allowed on the easement area.
         (d)   Proof Of Compliance: Any improvement or structure requiring a
village permit will require that the applicant provide satisfactory proof of
compliance with this subsection (E)3 before any application or a variation will
be considered. (Ord. 1441, 6-24-1998)
   (F)   Monuments And Markers:
      1.   Monuments shall be of concrete with a diameter of not less than six
inches (6") and thirty six inches (36") long, cast in place, with a copper
dowel three-eighths inch (3/8") in diameter, at least two and one-half inches
(21/2") in length imbedded so that the top of the dowel shall be not more than
one-fourth inch (1/4") above the surface and at the center of the monument.
      2.   Monuments shall be set so that the top is level with the established
grade adjoining it and placed so that the marked point on the metal center
shall coincide exactly with the intersection of street property lines, the
intersection of all angles in the boundary line and at the beginning and ending
of all curves along streets on the inside street lines.
      3.   Lot corners not marked by concrete monuments as required herein,
shall be marked by galvanized or wrought iron pipe, or iron or steel bars at
least three feet (3') in length and not less than five-eighths inch (5/8") in
diameter, the top of the pipe or bar to be set level with the established grade
of the ground adjoining it.
   (G)   Improvements:
      1.   Working Drawings And Specifications Required: Before considering the
approval of the final plat for any subdivision, the village will require that
complete working drawings and specifications be submitted for those
improvements requested at the time of conditional approval of the preliminary
layout. Improvements required may include one or more of the items listed in
subsection (G)5 of this section.
      2.   Source Of Drawings And Specifications: The subdivider shall have the
option of having working drawings and specifications for improvements prepared
by a registered professional engineer, retained by the subdivider or of having
such drawings and specifications prepared by the village.
Under either option, all working drawings, specifications and cost estimates
shall be checked by the engineer or by a consulting firm duly retained by the
village. The subdivider shall reimburse the village for preparation and for
checking of working drawings, specifications and cost estimates in accordance
with subsection (G)16 of this section. Working drawings and specifications
shall be in strict accordance with village standards and requirements and shall
be subject to approval by the village engineer.
      3.   Permission Required: Specific permission of the board shall be
secured before commencement of construction of any improvement. Approval of the
final plat by the board shall constitute permission to proceed with
construction, provided the plat is accepted for recording by the county
recorder. If the subdivider elects, as provided in subsection (G)14 of this
section, to construct an improvement prior to approval of the final plat, the
board may extend permission to proceed upon recommendation of the plan
commission together with certification by the engineer that working drawings
and specifications have been prepared and that engineering fees have been paid
and that suitable inspection bonds have been posted.
      4.   Other Permission: The subdivider shall also secure any permission
required by law of the state and county officials and permission extended by
the village shall not relieve the subdivider of responsibility to secure state
and county approval.
      5.   Types Of Improvements: The village shall have the power to require
one or more of the following improvements depending upon the nature and scope
of the subdivision. Particular attention shall be given to means for
disposition of stormwater and to the desirability of curb and gutter or other
provision to prevent breakdown of pavement edges. The design, layout and
carrying capacities of stormwater, sanitary sewer, and water facilities shall
recognize the future requirements of adjacent undeveloped areas.
         (a)   Street and alley grading and surfacing.
         (b)   Grading and surfacing of off street parking space.
         (c)   Curb and gutter.
         (d)   Sidewalks.
         (e)   Crosswalks.
         (f)   Sanitary sewage facilities.
         (g)   Water mains and hydrant.
         (h)   Stormwater drainage facilities.
         (i)   Street signs.
         (j)   Streetlights.
         (k)   Driveways.
         (l)   Street trees.
         (m)   Seeding or sodding.
         (n)   Compacted fill.
         (o)   Topsoil where appropriate.
         (p)   Retention ponds.
      6.   Village Standards: All improvements shall be in accordance with
village standards and requirements and regulations in effect at the time of
submission of the final plat. Maintenance of retention ponds shall be the
responsibility of the owner and subdivider and they must provide proof of a
plan to provide proper maintenance. They may not deed the property to others
unless the grantee has a plan of maintenance approved by the village.
      7.   Qualification Of Contractors: The developer shall make available to
the engineer and superintendent of public works a list of all contractors and
subcontractors who are to participate in construction of public improvements.
Such contractors and subcontractors shall be subject to the licensing
provisions of this code and shall be subject to disqualification by reason of
faulty performance upon past construction work done.
      8.   Inspection Required: All improvements shall be subject to inspection
by a duly authorized and qualified village inspector both during the course of
construction and after construction is complete. The inspector shall have
authority over materials of construction, methods of construction and
workmanship to ensure compliance with working drawings and specifications. The
contractor shall provide for reasonable tests and proof of quality of materials
as requested by the inspector, and upon due cause shall include weather
conditions, questionable materials of construction, workmanship or nonadherence
to specifications and drawings.
      9.   Inspection Reports: The inspector may be required to prepare and to
submit to the superintendent of public works each day a report stating progress
of work and giving his findings as to quality and quantity of materials used
and quality of methods and workmanship. He shall in particular call attention
to any circumstances that entail departures from working drawings and
specifications such as unforeseen difficulties of drainage, groundwater, poor
subsoil, unstable fill material, unconventional or faulty practices of
contractors or other circumstances. Whenever, in his opinion, such departures
are likely to cause either a lower ultimate standard of performance or a higher
construction cost than could reasonably be anticipated, he shall immediately
notify the engineer. When an improvement has been completed he shall prepare a
summary report.
      10.   Subdivider Responsible: Approval by the inspector or absence of
inspection shall in no way relieve the subdivider of full responsibility for
adherence by his contractors to specifications and working drawings nor for
high standards of materials, methods and workmanship.
      11.   Approval Not Acceptance: Approval by the inspector shall not be
deemed acceptance of the improvement by the village. Acceptance shall be only
by action of the board and acceptance shall be contingent upon a favorable
inspection report.
      12.   Notification: It shall be the responsibility of the subdivider or
his contractor to notify the engineer and superintendent of public works when
work is to be started and to request assignment of an inspector. The initial
notification that a particular improvement is to be started shall be in writing
and shall reach the engineer and superintendent of public works seven (7) days
in advance of the date that inspection is to begin. The notice shall be
accompanied by an inspection bond in accordance with subsection (G)16 of this
section.
      13.   Responsibility For Maintenance: As further assurance of serviceable
construction and to provide for repair of damage resulting from subsequent
construction operations of the subdivider or his contractors, the subdivider
shall be responsible for all maintenance of an improvement for a period of not
less than fifteen (15) months following completion of construction of that
improvement; providing, in addition, that the subdivider shall be responsible
for all maintenance of roadways, curbs and gutters, sidewalks, parkway strips
and extension boxes and hydrants of water facilities until all construction
work has been completed upon other improvements, and fill adjacent to the
improvements under consideration. The guarantee of completion and maintenance
shall recognize the possibility of maintenance costs and the terms of the
guarantee shall provide for reimbursement to the village for any maintenance
expenses incurred by the village in performing maintenance work after failure
of the subdivider to perform such work upon due notice. An improvement shall
not be accepted by the village sooner than fifteen (15) months after completion
of construction nor before all construction work has been completed upon
adjacent improvements, and fill until all maintenance work is complete.
      14.   Guarantee Of Completion And Maintenance: The board shall not
consider approval of the final plat unless and until the subdivider has
guaranteed the completion of all required improvements within a reasonable
period and in compliance with working drawings and specifications and has
guaranteed to maintain the improvements until they are accepted by the board.
This guarantee shall be by one or a combination of one or more of three (3)
methods. Only one method shall be applied to one specific improvement.
         (a)   The subdivider may post a performance bond prepared in a form
approved by the attorney and underwritten by a surety company listed as
approved by the village. The amount of the bond shall be not less than one
hundred twenty five percent (125%) of the final estimate of cost of the
improvement as estimated by the engineer under subsection (G)16 of this
section. There shall be no reduction in the amount of that portion of the bond
applying to a particular improvement unless and until that improvement is
complete and accepted or approved by the board. The subgrade, base course and
surface course of a street, alley, or parking area shall be considered as a
single improvement from the standpoint of acceptance. A subdivider may post a
letter of credit from a bank approved by the village. Said letter of credit
must be in a form approved by the village attorney. The letter of credit would
be accepted upon the same terms as set out above for a performance bond.
         (b)   The subdivider may deposit a cash bond with the village in
accordance with a specific escrow agreement approved by the attorney and board
and in an amount not less than one hundred twenty five percent (125%) of the
final estimate of cost of the improvements as estimated by the engineer under
subsection (G)16 of this section. The deposit shall be held in a special
account by the village and the agreement may provide for partial payouts as
work progresses in amounts recommended by the engineer and approved by the
board as corresponding to the original estimate of unit costs. Partial payouts
shall be contingent upon favorable inspection reports and the sum of partial
payouts for a single improvement shall not exceed eighty percent (80%) of the
original deposit for the improvement until and unless the improvement is
complete and accepted or approved by the village. The subgrade, base course and
surface course of a street, alley or parking area shall be considered a single
improvement from the standpoint of acceptance.
         (c)   Upon specific permission of the board, as recommended by the
engineer, the subdivider may elect to complete one or more improvements prior
to approval of the final plat. Where the subdivider elects to guarantee
completion of an improvement by this method, approval of the final plat shall
be contingent upon certification by the superintendent of public works and
engineer that the improvement has been completed in accordance with drawings
and specifications, that the inspection reports are favorable, and that
guarantee has been provided to cover costs of maintenance of the improvement in
accordance with subsection (G)13 of this section.
      15.   Acceptance: Acceptance of an improvement for the village shall be
only by resolution of the board upon recommendation of the engineer. Acceptance
shall be contingent upon:
         (a)   The fulfillment of the requirements of subsection (G)13 of this
section.
         (b)   An opinion by the attorney that satisfactory and proper
conveyances have been made by the subdivider to the village or to the
appropriate school or park districts.
         (c)   The improvement being complete and in good repair in accordance
with village standards and requirements.
         (d)   Inspection reports indicating compliance with working drawings
and specifications.
         (e)   A single improvement shall not be accepted in part; it shall be
complete throughout the subdivision as indicated in the final plat and working
drawings. The subgrade, base course and surface course of a street, alley or
parking area shall be considered as a single improvement.
         (f)   Acceptance of an improvement shall constitute release of the
applicable portion of the performance bond or of the applicable portion of the
balance of cash deposit.
      16.   Fees: To defray the engineering and inspection expenses incurred by
the village in preparation or checking of preliminary and final cost estimates,
working drawings, specifications, in checking the final plat (prepared by
others), and in executing inspection responsibilities, the subdivider shall be
required to reimburse the village as follows. These are separate and distinct
charges from the fee paid at the time of submission of the preliminary layout.
         (a)   If the subdivider elects to have working drawings and
specifications prepared by the village, he shall make a request for preparation
of a preliminary estimate of construction costs for improvements. This request
shall be in writing to the clerk and shall be accompanied by a certified check
in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to be receipted for the clerk.
This bond is to guarantee the expenses of preparation of the preliminary
estimate by the engineer.
         (b)   When notified of the amount of the preliminary estimate of
construction costs the subdivider shall make a further written request to the
clerk an engineering fee equal to one hundred percent (100%) of the engineer's
quoted charge to the village as based upon the practices recommended in the
"Schedule Of Recommended Fees For Engineering Services", latest edition and
revisions, as published by the Illinois Society of Professional Engineers.
         (c)   Upon payment of the engineering fee, the one hundred dollar
($100.00) bond shall be refunded. The one hundred dollar ($100.00) bond shall
be forfeited if the engineer's fee is not paid within twelve (12) months after
notification of the amount of the preliminary estimate of construction costs
and a new bond shall be posted with a new request for preliminary estimate.
There shall be no refund of the engineering fees if the project is abandoned or
if approval of the final plat is denied. Any revision of working drawings, for
whatever reason, shall be subject to an additional engineering fee, paid in
advance, in an amount quoted by the engineer.
         (d)   If the subdivider elects to have working drawings,
specifications and cost estimates for improvements prepared by an engineer
retained by himself, he shall apply in writing to the clerk making a request
that such drawings, specifications and estimates be checked by the engineer.
The application shall be accompanied by two (2) sets of construction prints,
specifications and estimates. The clerk shall inform the subdivider of the
amount of the charge for this service and the charge shall be based upon the
"Schedule Of Recommended Fees For Engineering Services", latest edition and
revisions, as published by the Illinois Society of Professional Engineers.
Checking shall proceed after the subdivider has paid over this fee to the
clerk. Additional fees shall be paid for rechecking of drawings, specifications
and estimates arising from revisions made by or required of the subdivider.
There shall be no refund of engineering fees if the project is abandoned for
any reason whatsoever.
         (e)   The engineering fee is intended to include preparation or
checking of preliminary and final cost estimates, working drawings,
specifications and staking, but it is not intended to include inspection.
         (f)   Before final approval of any plans for grading or construction
of improvements the subdivider, owner or contractor seeking approval of
improvements shall post with the clerk a cash inspection bond in an amount
agreed upon among the engineer, the superintendent of public works, and
subdivider or contractor as being sufficient to provide for review and
inspection charges at the current per diem rates. From this bond shall be
deducted each day the inspection expense incurred by the village at the rates
set forth below. Any excess of the bond over total inspection charges will be
refunded to the depositor and any overdraft on the bond shall be provided for
immediately by the subdivider or contractor to ensure continuity of inspection
and to prevent stoppage of construction by the superintendent of public works.
         (g)   It shall be the responsibility of the subdivider, owner, or
contractor to notify the engineer seven (7) days in advance as to dates that
construction work will commence and be completed for purposes of determining
the number of days of inspection charge. In event of dispute, only notification
in writing shall be considered as proof of notice.
         (h)   Per diem inspection rates for review and inspection shall be
equal to one hundred percent (100%) of the engineer's quoted charge to the
board as based upon the "Schedule Of Recommended Fees For Engineering
Services", latest edition and revisions, as published by the Illinois Society
of Professional Engineers. If inspection is performed by an inspector on the
village payroll the charge shall be two hundred percent (200%) of the regular
salary paid to the inspector computed to an hourly basis. There shall be not
less than a four (4) hour charge for time spent in any one day. For time spent
outside of the regular working hours of the inspector, the hourly charge shall
be three hundred percent (300%) of the regular salary paid to the inspector
computed to an hourly basis.
   (H)   Protection And Repair Of Existing Improvements: The subdivider, his
contractors and suppliers shall be jointly and severally responsible that
existing improvements and the property of the village are not damaged or
rendered less useful or unsightly by the operations of the subdivider, his
contractors or suppliers. This provision is intended to include damage or
nuisance with respect to the land, improvements or landscaping of the village;
damage to existing streets, sidewalks, curbs and gutters, parkways by passage
thereover of equipment or trucks or by excavation for the any purpose; the
spillage or tracking of earth, sand or rock onto existing streets, sidewalks,
curbs and gutters or parkways; the washing by stormwater of earth or sand onto
streets, sidewalks, curbs and gutters or parkways or into catch basins; damage
to water mains, sanitary sewers, culverts or storm sewers. To reduce or
localize the possibility of damage to streets to be used for access to the
subdivision by equipment and trucks and the subdivider shall be responsible for
enforcement of this instruction upon his contractors and their suppliers. The
subdivider shall make provisions to prevent washing of earth or sand onto
sidewalks, streets, curb and gutter and into catch basins by stormwater. Where
deemed advisable, the board shall have the power to require, either prior to
commencement of construction or after construction is in process, that the
subdivider post a surety to guarantee repair of damages or abatement of
nuisance. Where need for surety becomes apparent after construction is in
process, the board shall have the power to order construction discontinued
until surety becomes apparent after construction is in process. The board shall
have the power to order construction discontinued until surety has been posted.
Expenses incurred by the village in repairing damages, cleaning streets, catch
basins and sewers shall be deducted from the surety.
   (I)   Other Regulations Prevail: None of the provisions of these regulations
pertaining to permission, surety, fees, acceptance and approval shall be
constructed as exempting subdividers, general contractors, sidewalk
contractors, cement contractors, building contractors, plumbing contractors or
plumbers, sewer contractors, drain layers, electrical contractors, electricians
or any other contractor or craftsman from any other provision or regulation of
this code with respect to licenses, fees, surety, inspection or other control.
(Ord. 1136, 6-24-1987)
12-1-8: DOCUMENTS:
   (A)   Preliminary Plat: The preliminary plat tracings and prints shall have
dimensions that are multiples of eight and one-half inches (81/2") along one
side and multiples of eleven inches (11") along the adjacent side. Tracings
shall be submitted rolled in a mailing tube, and prints shall be submitted
folded eight and one-half inches by eleven inches (81/2" x 11"). The drawing
shall be to a scale of one inch equals one hundred feet (1" = 100'). The
preliminary plat shall contain the following information:
      1.   Name of the subdivision.
      2.   Legal description of location.
      3.   Scale of the layout or plat.
      4.   Date.
      5.   Statement of whether the north point is true or magnetic, and
whether bearings shown on the plat are true or magnetic.
      6.   Boundary lines of the subdivision with length and bearing of lines.
      7.   Relationship of the subdivision to section and half section lines
and to any hearings to nearest official monuments.
      8.   The location, widths and names of streets or other public ways,
easements, railroad and utility right of way; both within the subdivision and
those adjacent to or leading into the subdivision.
      9.   Proposed methods of providing for stormwater, sanitary sewage and
water.
      10.   Location of land intended to be dedicated to public use or reserved
in the deeds for the use of all property owners in the subdivision.
      11.   Numbers and dimensions of lots and blocks.
      12.   Minimum front, side and rear yard setback lines.
      13.   Location of watercourses and other important features. Indicate
flood levels of watercourses.
      14.   Contours, with one foot (1') intervals, referred to sea level
datum.
      15.   Name and address of owner and subdivider and name of designer of
preliminary layout.
      16.   The names of subdivisions immediately adjacent and the names of
owners of record of adjacent unsubdivided tracts.
      17.   Existing permanent buildings or structures within or adjacent to
the tract.
      18.   Where the preliminary plat covers only part of the subdivider's
entire holding, a sketch of the prospective street system of the unsubmitted
part shall be furnished, and the street system of the submitted part will be
considered in the light of adjustments and connections with the street system
of the part not submitted.
      19.   If the informal consideration indicates that the subdivision is a
portion of a unit area for development of the official plan, the preliminary
layout shall include a small scale study of the unit area.
   (B)   Final Plat: The final plat shall conform to the dimensional and scale
standards of the preliminary plat and shall contain all the information of
subsections (A)1 through (A)8 and (A)10 through (A)13 of this section of the
preliminary plat requirements of this section, and in addition, shall contain
the following information as listed in subsections (B)1 through and (B)6 of
this section. The certification required in subsections (B)7, (B)8, and (B)9 of
this section may be required from time to time. Accurate location and reference
of all monuments which shall be in conformance with subsection 12-1-7(F) of
this chapter.
      1.   Certification by a registered land surveyor to the effect that the
plat represents a survey made by him and that the monuments shown thereon
actually exist as located and that all dimensional and other details, such as
curve data, are correct. (Form (D)1 of this section.)
      2.   Notarized certification by the owner of the land and any lien holder
or other persons having an interest therein of the adoption of the plat and the
dedication of streets and other public areas. (Form (D)2 of this section.)
      3.   Certification by signature of proper officials of the county that
there are no tax delinquencies. (County clerk form.)
      4.   Certification by signature of the village clerk or treasurer that
there are no special assessment delinquencies. (Form (D)4 of this section.)
      5.   Space for approval of the plan commission by date and signature of
the chairman of the commission. (Form (D)5 of this section.)
      6.   Space for approval of the board by date and signature of the
president. (Form (D)6 of this section.)
      7.   Certification by signature of the attorney that satisfactory
conveyances to the village have been provided applying to rights of way for
streets, alleys and easements, and for land for parks, playgrounds and other
public use. (Form (D)7 of this section.)
      8.   Approval by signature of the clerk and engineer indicating that the
plat has been checked, that all working drawings and specifications for
improvements have been prepared in conformance with village standards and
requirements and that engineering fees have been paid. (Form (D)8 of this
section.)
      9.   Certification by signatures of the clerk and attorney that
satisfactory provisions have been made for guarantee of performance for
construction of required improvements. On items where construction has already
been completed, there shall be certification by the superintendent of public
works and engineer that construction has been completed and inspected and found
to be in accordance with village standards and requirements and that surety has
been posted to provide for repair of damage done while the subdivision is being
completed. (Form (D)9 of this section.)
      10.   Subsections (B)1 through (B)9 of this section may be executed in
order of listing and may be in the forms set forth in subsection (D) of this
section. (Ord. 1136, 6-24-1987)
      11.   The plat must indicate if the resubdivision or subdivision is
located within a special flood hazard area as identified by the federal
emergency management agency. (Ord. 1164, 10-26-1988)
      12.   Topographical and profile studies shall be submitted with the
subdivision plat and shall have on their face the signed statement of a
registered professional engineer and the owner of the land or his duly
authorized attorney, to the effect that to the best of their knowledge and
belief the drainage of surface waters will not be changed by the construction
of such subdivision or any part thereof, or that, if such surface water
drainage will be changed, reasonable provision has been made for collection and
diversion of such surface waters into public areas, or drains which the
subdivider has a right to use, and that such surface waters will be planned for
in accordance with generally accepted engineering practices so as to reduce the
likelihood of damage to the adjoining property because of the construction of
the subdivision. These topographical and profile studies shall not be recorded,
but shall be retained by the village as permanent public documents.
      13.   If the property being subdivided has any liens against it, the
holders of the liens must consent to subdivision and release their interest in
the land dedicated by the plat.
   (C)   Attendant Items: The final plat shall be accompanied by documents
including the following:
      1.   Two (2) copies of working drawings and specifications for
improvements.
      2.   Two (2) copies of restrictions to be incorporated into deeds or
covenants to be recorded with the plat.

12-1-9: APPEALS:
   (A)   Procedure For Appeal: The recommendations of the plan commission to
the village board are advisory only and are not binding on the village board.
Therefore, the decision of the plan commission cannot be appealed.
   (B)   Transcript Of Proceedings: Any party aggrieved by the decision of the
village board may, within thirty (30) days of written notice, ask the village
board for a rehearing on their decision. Said request must be in writing and
must state specific reasons why the village board should allow the rehearing.
The decision to grant or deny a request for a rehearing shall be up to the
village board. If a rehearing is granted by the village board, they shall set
an appropriate fee and notify the petitioner of the fee for the rehearing. Upon
payment of said fee by the petitioner, the village board shall set a hearing
date. The hearing shall be public and notice of said hearing shall be given by
the village. This notice shall be by publication, by mail, or by posting in the
village hall.
   (C)   Rehearing: At any rehearing, the village board shall obtain all
exhibits from the plan commission and shall allow the petitioner to present any
evidence which is reasonably relevant to the issues. Anyone present at the
public hearing may express their views on the subject matter of the hearing.
The decision of the village board shall be made after the rehearing and shall
be given to the petitioner in writing. (Ord. 1136, 6-24-1987)
12-1-10: CONDITIONS OF SALE OR LEASE:
After the adoption of these rules and regulations it shall be unlawful to sell
or offer for sale or to lease for any time exceeding five (5) years any lot or
block within the village or contiguous unincorporated territory not more than
one and one- half (11/2) miles beyond the corporate limits thereof and not
included in any other municipality, unless a plat has:
   (A)   Been recorded with the office of the appropriate county recorder prior
to the adoption of these regulations.
   (B)   Been approved by the plan commission and been recorded in compliance
with these regulations. (Ord. 1136, 6-24-1987)
12-1-11: CONDITIONS OF RECORDING:
No recorder shall record any map, plat or subdivision of land situated in the
village, nor within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits
thereof and not included in any other municipality, unless such map, plat or
subdivision is entitled to record by reason of official approval by the plan
commission as required by these regulations and unless the subdivision shown
thereon provides for streets, alleys and public grounds in conformity with the
applicable requirements of these regulations and all other parts of the
official plan of the village.
The subdivider shall submit an original and six (6) copies of the final plat to
the Cook County recorder of deeds. Such plats shall be at least eight and one-
half inches by fourteen inches (81/2" x 14") but not more than thirty inches by
thirty six inches (30" x 36"). Subdivider shall furnish the village clerk with
a copy of the recorded final plat. (Ord. 1136, 6-24-1987)
12-1-12: AMENDMENTS:
   (A)   Agent And Purpose: The plan commission may, from time to time, adopt
and amend rules and instructions for the administration of these subdivision
regulations, to the end that approval of plats will be expedited, or where such
amendments are deemed necessary.
   (B)   Public Hearings: These subdivision regulations can be changed or
amended by the village board after a public hearing, due notice of which shall
have been given in a newspaper of general circulation in the village at least
fifteen (15) days nor more than thirty (30) days before the date of such
hearing. The village board may waive the public hearing requirement. (Ord.
1136, 6-24-1987)
12-1-13: STATUS OF SUBDIVISIONS IN PROCESS:
   (A)   Any proposed subdivision that has not received conditional approval of
the preliminary plat shall be subject to all of the requirements of these
regulations.
   (B)   Any proposed subdivision that has received conditional approval of the
preliminary plat within the twelve (12) months preceding adoption of these
regulations, but which has not received approval of the final plat shall be
subject to all of the requirements of these regulations.
   (C)   Any subdivision that has received approval of the final plat but which
is still in process of completion with respect to improvements or construction
of service connections shall be subject to either the old ordinance or the new
ordinance as determined by the village board. (Ord. 1136, 6-24-1987)
12-1-14: VACATION OF PLATS:
   (A)   Process: Any plat may be vacated by the owner of the premises at any
time before the sale of any lot therein, by a written instrument to which a
copy of the plat is attached, declaring it to be vacated. If there are public
service facilities in the highways, streets, alleys and other public ways and
in easements shown on the plat, the instrument shall reserve to the public body
or utility owning such facilities, the property, rights of way, and easements
necessary for continuing public service by means of those facilities and for
the maintenance, renewal and reconstruction of the same. The instrument shall
be approved by the village board in the same manner as plats of subdivisions.
The instrument shall also be submitted for approval to the highway commissioner
and to the county superintendent of highways and to the district engineer of
the department of transportation of this state and to the public utility or
utilities involved if the plat affects them. The board, highway commissioner,
county superintendent of highways or district engineer of the department of
transportation of this state, as the case may be, may reject any instrument
that abridges or destroys any public rights in any of its streets and alleys.
The instrument shall be executed, acknowledged or proved and recorded or filed
in the same manner as plats of subdivisions. Once recorded or filed the
instrument operates to destroy the effect of the recording of the plat vacated
and to divest all public rights in the streets, alleys and public grounds and
all dedications laid out or described in the plat and to render effective any
reservation set forth in the instrument. When lots have been sold, the plat may
be vacated in the manner provided in this section by all owners of lots in the
plat joining in the execution of the writing.
   (B)   Vacation Of Part Of Plat: Any part of a plat may be vacated in the
manner provided in the preceding section, and subject to the conditions therein
prescribed. Provided, such vacation shall not abridge or destroy any of the
rights or privileges of other proprietors in such plat; and, provided further,
that nothing contained in this section shall authorize the closing or
obstructing of any public highway laid out according to law. (Ord. 1136, 6-24-
1987)
12-1-15: ABROGATION AND GREATER RESTRICTIONS:
This chapter repeals and replaces the previous chapter 1 of this title.
However, this chapter does not repeal, abrogate or impair any existing
subdivision easements, roadway dedications or deed restrictions of any
subdivisions previously approved and recorded. (Ord. 1136, 6-24-1987)
12-1-16: SEPARABILITY:
The provisions and sections of this chapter shall be deemed separable and the
invalidity of any portion of this chapter shall not affect the validity of the
remainder. (Ord. 1136, 6-24-1987)
12-1-17: EFFECTIVE DATE:
This chapter shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage and
approval and publication in pamphlet form as required by law. (Ord. 1136, 6-24-
1987)
CHAPTER 2
FLOODING AND STORMWATER
ARTICLE A. GENERAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES
SECTION:
12-2A-1: Authority And Purpose
12-2A-2: Organization
12-2A-3: Definitions
12-2A-4: Permit Procedures
12-2A-5: Permit Materials
12-2A-6: General Provisions
12-2A-1: AUTHORITY AND PURPOSE:
   (A)   Authority: This chapter is enacted pursuant to the police powers
granted to the village by 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2-1, 5/11-12-12, 5/
11-30-2, 5/11-30-8, and 5/11-31-2.
   (B)   Purpose: The purpose of this chapter is to:
      1.   Protect buildings and other property from damage due to flooding.
      2.   Protect the life, health and safety of the residents of the village.
      3.   Minimize disruption of commerce and governmental services and the
impairment of the tax base caused by flooding.
      4.   Prevent new development from increasing the flood or drainage hazard
to others.
      5.   Prevent future public expenditures for repairs and recovery
activities following a flood and for drainage improvements and flood protection
projects.
      6.   Preserve and enhance the quality of surface water.
      7.   Preserve the natural characteristics and functions of watercourses
and floodplains to moderate flood and stormwater impacts, improve water
quality, and preserve aquatic/riparian habitat.
      8.   Reduce the sedimentation in the watercourses of the village.
      9.   Meet the requirements of 615 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/18g, the
rivers, lakes and streams act.
      10.   Meet the requirements of 44 CFR section 60.3.
      11.   Make federally subsidized flood insurance available for property in
the village by fulfilling the requirements of the national flood insurance
program. (Ord. 1671, 8-13-2008)
12-2A-2: ORGANIZATION:
To protect people and property from flooding, development of land must be
managed both in the watershed (where the water comes from) and in the
floodplain (where it accumulates). Therefore, this chapter has three (3)
articles.
   (A)   General And Administrative Procedures: This article includes the
definitions, permit procedures and similar administrative matters that apply to
all development projects
   (B)   Site Development Requirements: Article B of this chapter contains the
land development requirements that manage the runoff of stormwater that leaves
the development site. It includes criteria for the amount of water that can
leave a site and measures that must be taken to improve the quality of the
water.
   (C)   Floodplain Development Requirements: Article C of this chapter
contains requirements for developments that will be located in the floodplain.
It includes criteria to protect the new development, to minimize the impact of
the development on flooding to other properties, and to protect the flood
conveyance channel.
   (D)   Overlapping Requirements:
      1.   Floodplains are part of the watershed. All floodplain developments
must also meet the site development requirements of article B of this chapter,
where applicable.
      2.   The definitions in section 12-2A-3 of this article and the
administrative procedures in sections 12-2A-4, 12-2A-5, and 12-2A-6 of this
article apply to both articles B and C of this chapter.
   (E)   Development: This chapter regulates all "development" as defined in
section 12-2A-3, "Definitions", of this article.
      1.   The regulatory criteria are different for three (3) different sizes
of development: level 1, level 2 and level 3, which are also defined in section
12-2A-3 of this article.
      2.   When the term "development" is used alone, it includes all three (3)
levels. (Ord. 1671, 8-13-2008)
12-2A-3: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions are adopted:
BASE FLOOD: The flood having a one percent (1%) probability of being equaled or
exceeded in any given year. The "base flood" is also known as the 100-year
frequency flood event. Application of the base flood elevation at any location
is as defined in section 12-12C-1 of this chapter.
BASE FLOOD ELEVATION (BFE): The height in relation to the North American
Vertical Datum (NAVD) of 1988(or other datum, where specified of the crest of
the Base Flood. Application of the BFE at any location is as defined in Section
12-2C of this chapter.
BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICE (BMP): A measure used to control the adverse impacts
of a stormwater discharge on water quality downstream. BMPs include structural
devices (e.g., grassed swales, filter strips and detention basins) designed to
remove pollutants and reduce runoff volumes and nonstructural measures such as
public information on proper disposal and use of pesticides and herbicides.
BUFFER: An area of natural vegetation adjacent to channels, wetlands, lakes,
ponds or other surface waters to be left open for the purpose of eliminating or
minimizing adverse impacts to such areas.
BUILDING: A building that is principally aboveground and is enclosed by walls
and a roof. The term includes a gas or liquid storage tank, a manufactured
home, mobile home or a prefabricated building. This term also includes
recreational vehicles and travel trailers to be installed on a site for more
than one hundred eighty (180) days, unless fully licensed and ready for highway
use.
BYPASS FLOW: An approach that routes tributary drainage area runoff around and
not through a stormwater control structure.
CLOMR: Conditional letter of map revision.
CHANNEL: Any river, stream, creek, brook, branch, natural or artificial
depression, ponded area, flowage, slough, ditch, culvert, gully, ravine, wash,
or natural or open manmade drainageway, which has a definite bed and banks or
shoreline, in or into which surface or ground water flows, either perennially
or intermittently.
CHANNEL MODIFICATION: Alteration of a channel by changing the physical
dimensions or materials of its bed or banks. Channel modification includes
damming, riprapping (or other armoring), widening, deepening, straightening,
relocating, lining and significant removal of native vegetation from the bottom
or banks. Channel modification does not include the clearing of dead or dying
vegetation, debris, or trash from the channel.
COMPENSATORY STORAGE: An artificially excavated, hydraulically equivalent
volume of storage within the SFHA used to balance the loss of natural flood
storage capacity when artificial fill or buildings are placed within the
floodplain. The uncompensated loss of natural floodplain storage can increase
off site floodwater elevations and flows.
CONDITIONAL LETTER OF MAP REVISION: A letter providing FEMA's comment on a
proposed project that would, upon construction, affect the hydrologic or
hydraulic characteristics of a flooding source and thus result in the
modification of the existing floodway, the effective BFEs, or the SFHA.
DESIGNATED FLOODWAY:
   (A)   The Floodways designated on the countywide FIRM of Cook County
prepared by FEMA panel numbers 17031C0638J, 17031C0639J, 17031C0726J and
17031C0727J of the countywide FIRM for Cook County dated August 19, 2008 and
panel numbers 17031C0619K and 17031C0707K of the countywide FIRM for Cook
County dated November 1, 2019. When two Floodway maps exist for a waterway, the
more recent effective Floodway limit shall prevail.
   (B)   The Designated Floodway boundary should be scaled off the FIRM map and
located on a site plan, using reference marks common to both maps on any site.
Where interpretation is needed to determine the exact location of the
Designated Floodway boundary, IDNR/OWR should be contacted for the
interpretation.
DETENTION BASIN: A manmade structure for the temporary storage of stormwater
runoff with controlled release during and immediately following a storm.
DEVELOPMENT:
   (A)   "Development" means any manmade change to real estate, including:
      1.   Construction, reconstruction, repair, or placement of a building or
any addition to a building;
      2.   Installing a manufactured home on a site, preparing a site for a
manufactured home, or installing a travel trailer or recreational vehicle on a
site for more than one hundred eighty (180) days. Parking a travel trailer or
recreational vehicle on site for less than one hundred eighty (180) days is not
considered "development", provided it is fully licensed, not connected to any
utilities, and ready for highway use;
      3.   Drilling, mining, installing utilities, construction of roads,
bridges, or similar projects;
      4.   Demolition of a building or redevelopment of a site;
      5.   Clearing of land as an adjunct of construction;
      6.   Construction or erection of levees, walls, fences, dams, or
culverts; channel modification; filling, dredging, grading, excavating, paving,
or other nonagricultural alterations of the ground surface; storage of
materials; deposit of solid or liquid waste;
      7.   Subdivision of land, annexation agreements, and finalization of a
plat, replat, planned unit development or manufactured home park; and
      8.   Any other human development project that might change the direction,
height, or velocity of flood or surface water, including extensive vegetation
removal.
   (B)   "Development" does not include:
      1.   Maintenance of or resurfacing of roads when there is no increase in
the ground or road surface elevation;
      2.   Gardening, plowing, and similar agricultural practices that do not
involve filling, grading, or construction of levees;
      3.   Erection of a storage shed, accessory building, fence and playground
equipment, that:
         (a)   Has a footprint of less than fifty (50) square feet,
         (b)   Is not located in a floodway or within ten feet (10') of a
property line, and
         (c)   Is properly anchored to withstand surface water flows.
ELEVATION CERTIFICATE: A form published by FEMA that is used to certify the
elevation to which a building has been elevated.
EMERGENCY OVERFLOW: The structure in a detention or retention basin designed to
protect the basin in the event of a malfunction of the primary outlet or a
storm event greater than the basin design storm.
EXCAVATION: Any act by which organic matter, earth, sand, gravel, rock or any
other similar material is cut into, dug, quarried, uncovered, removed,
displaced, relocated or bulldozed. The term shall include the conditions
resulting therefrom.
EXCEPTIONAL FUNCTIONAL VALUE WETLAND: Any wetland that either: a) meets the
Illinois natural area inventory's definition for determining exceptional
functional value; or b) is located in an Illinois natural area inventory site.
EXISTING GRADE: The vertical location of the existing ground surface prior to
excavation or filling.
EXISTING MANUFACTURED HOME PARK OR SUBDIVISION: A manufactured home park or
subdivision for which the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on
which the manufactured homes are to be affixed or buildings to be constructed
(including, at a minimum, the installation of utilities, the construction of
streets, and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads) is
completed before the effective date of the Village's initial floodplain
management regulations.
FEMA: The federal emergency management agency, the agency responsible for
administering the national flood insurance program.
FIRM OR FLOOD INSURANCE RATE MAP: A map prepared by the federal emergency
management agency that delineates the special flood hazard area of the village.
The FIRM includes flood insurance rate zones and may or may not include
floodways.
FPE OR FLOOD PROTECTION ELEVATION: The elevation above sea level (NGVD) to
which new buildings must be protected from flood damage.
FLOOD: A general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of
normally dry land areas from overflow of inland or tidal waves, or the unusual
and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source.
FLOOD FRINGE: That portion of riverine floodplains outside of the designated
floodway.
FLOOD INSURANCE STUDY: An examination, evaluation and determination of Flood
hazards and if appropriate, corresponding water surface elevations.
FLOODPLAIN: Any land area susceptible to being inundated by floodwaters from
any source.
FLOODPLAIN OR SPECIAL FLOOD HAZARD AREA (SFHA): For purpose of this chapter,
these two terms are synonymous and shall means any land area susceptible to
being inundated by water from any source. Floodplain also includes those areas
of known flooding as identified by the community. The Floodplains are those
lands within the jurisdiction of the village and unincorporated Cook County
that are within the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the village or that may be
